Book 1

50 Walks Around Hereford

 

The start points for all the walks from the given locations in Hereford, (Whitecross roundabout, Fire station, Belmont and Tescos roundabouts) should take about half an hour by car to reach.

*

All of these 50 Walks have been covered many times and they have been constantly edited to ensure most people, (if not everyone) will be able to follow the instructions given. Walks last covered in 2017.

*

The measurements for most walks have been taken off ordnance survey maps, therefore hilly walks may be of a greater distance than stated.

*

 

Index

 

Name

Distance

Description

Walk 1 Holme Lacy Riverside Walk.

8 km (5 mile).

Flat walk mostly along the river Wye. There are many stiles along this walk.

Walk 2 Woonton to Almeley.

8 km (5 mile).

Easy walk with no hills.

Walk 3 Sutton Walls & Marden.

8 km (5 mile).

Fairly easy walk with no big hills as you walk across farm land and fields.

Walk 4 The Spectre of Glyndwr.

7 km (4.3 mile).

Hilly walk across field, paths, lanes, woods and common.

Walk 5 On Offas Dyke.

9 km (5.6 mile).

Strenuous walk. There are beautiful scenic views as you walk up to the top of Rushock hill.

Walk 6 Hergest Ridge.

9 km (5.6 mile).

Strenuous walk along the Hergest ridge. Scenic views.

Walk 7 Breinton.

9 km (5.6 mile).

Easy walk along a lot of minor road.

Walk 8 Abbey Dore

9 km (5.6 mile).

Walk across common land and fields. Many stiles.

Walk 9 Bodenham.

7 km (4.3 mile).

Easy walk with no hills, you walk across farm land and fields.

Walk 10 Kings Caple.

7 km (4.3 mile).

Walk along road, river and across country, with a pub in Hoarwithy. A couple of small hills to climb.

Walk 11 Stretton Grandison.

6 km (3.7 mile).

Easy walk across farm land.

Walk 12 Harewood End.

6 km (3.7 mile).

Hilly walk along straight bridleways and up a little valley with some nice views along good terrain. Dont go when its to wet.

Walk 13 Monnington Walk.

6 km (3.7 mile).

Easy pleasant walk along small roads, grassy lanes and through Bulmers apple orchards.

Walk 14 Garway Hill.

5 km (3.1 mile).

Walk over common land with magnificent panoramic viewpoints. Underfoot the paths are firm and grassy.

Walk 15 The Marcle Ridge.

7 km (4.3 mile).

Walk over farm and woodland paths and tracks, of which 1 miles is along the Marcle Ridge with its spectacular panoramas.

Walk 16 Athelstans Wood.

8 km (5 mile).

Strenuous walk over undulating farmland and woodland. Athelstan's Wood is an ancient wood named after a Bishop of Hereford in 1056.

 

Walk 17 Vowchurch Common.

10 km (6.2 mile).

Strenuous walk over farm and woodland tracks with delightful views and constantly changing scenery.

Walk 18 Kington and Lower Hergest.

7 km (4.3 mile).

Strenuous walk with one or two small mountains to climb. Very good views as you walk along a river, go across common land and walk through Park Wood.

Walk 19 Fownhope & Common Hill.

6 km (3.7 mile).

Moderate walk with three short sharp climbs. Scenic viewpoints and through a nature reserve.

Walk 20 Stoke Lacy & Ullingswick.

8 km (5 mile).

Walk over farmland, through woods and along the alder tree lined banks of the River Loddon. There are some gentle rolling hills but it is an easy walk.

Walk 21 Backbury Hill & Pentaloe.

8 km (5 mile).

Walk over rolling country through woods and farmland.

Walk 22 Brockhampton & River vWye.

7 km (4.3 mile).

Walk over varied terrain of woodland, farmland and along a lovely stretch of the River Wye. The walk involves one short steep down and another steep uphill section.

Walk 23 Orleton and Bircher.

6 km (3 mile).

Easy winter walk, four stiles. 90 per cent country lanes and open common.

Walk 24 Aconbury Hill.

6 km (3.7 mile).

A moderate walk along good woodland paths, roads and across open land. Only a couple of stiles to climb.

Walk 25 Weobley.

8 km (4.9 mile).

An easy walk around one of the most attractive and best kept villages in the UK.

Walk 26 Oyster Hill.

8 km (4.9 mile).

A lovely fields and lanes walk with wide views from the top of Oyster Hill. A lot of stiles to cross.

Walk 27 Kilpeck, Coles Tump, Orcop

Hill and Mynde Park.

10 km (6 mile).

Hilly, energetic walk along quiet lanes, field paths with fine views and parkland.

Walk 28 Pengethley, River Wye &

Sellack.

9 km (5.6 mile).

An easy walk on good firm tracks. The route is over varied terrain, through farmland woods and a 1 km stretch along the Wye.


 

Walk 29 The Vale of Eywas.

8 km (4.9 mile).

A strenuous walk around a circuit of the Vale of Ewyas. An ascent up the attractive valley of Cwm Bwchel leads to a cairn at Bal-Bach, marking the summit of a mountain pass.

Walk 30 Skenfrith and Garway.

8 km (4.9 mile).

Most of this route is along quiet, narrow, roughish country lanes, little more than farm tracks, amidst the beautiful scenery of the Monnow Valley on the border between Wales and England.

Walk 31 Worcester Beacon.

8 km (4.9 mile).

A strenuous walk which should be carried out in clear weather.

Walk 32 Pembridge and Eardisland.

8 km (4.9 mile).

Herefordshire is famed for its black and white villages of which Pembridge and Eardisland are among the finest.

Walk 33 Around Twyn-Y-Gaer.

9 km (5.5

mile).

This is a strenuous walk but has much historical interest. An Iron Age fort caps the summit of Twyn-y-Gaer with panoramic views over three valleys.

Walk 34 Ledbury to Frith Wood.

8 km (4.9 mile).

A delightful all-seasons walk. The outward walk is along tracks and footpaths which - even if the grass dampens your trousers - do not usually get muddy.

Walk 35 Hay-on-Wye, Mouse Castle

Wood and Cusop.

10 km (6.2 mile).

Starting from Hay-on-Wye, this pleasant and easy paced walk goes across fields, through woods and by riverside meadows in the gentle rolling countryside of the Wye Valley.

Walk 36 Hereford and Dinedor Hill.

10 km (6.2 mile).

Dinedor Hill is the prominent hill (600ft) lying to the south east of Hereford.

Walk 37 Hill and Lake Around

Boddingham.

5 km (3.1 mile).

A moderate walk with some steep slopes through wooded area, along a lake and across country.

Walk 38 Ledbury.

7.5 km (4.6 mile).

Walking from the centre of the delightful historic market town of Ledbury takes us past the church into Coneygrove Wood and over the hill to the tiny village of Eastnor, with its beautiful early 19th-century castle.

Walk 39 The Central Ridge Beacon.

9 km (5.6 mile).

Views from the ridge are hardly less inspiring than those from greater heights, and the approach from Colwall and the return have sufficient twists and turns to maintain interest.

Walk 40 Dorstone.

10 km (6 mile).

From the old village of Dorstone set in the beautiful Golden Valley, this walk crosses farmland and rises to the edge of the open hilltop of Merbach Hill.

Walk 41 Bishops Frome.

7 km (4.3 mile).

Climb a small hill, where spectacular views open up, and continue through farmland with orchards, hop fields, crops and pasture.

Walk 42 The Cradley Brook.

7 km (4.3 mile).

An easy and pleasant stroll for a summer's evening or a winter's afternoon.

Walk 43 Ragged Stone and Chase End Hills.

7 km (4.3 mile).

The final undulations of the Malvern Hills manifest themselves as

Ragged Stone and Chase End Hills. Lower than, and detached from, the main ridge, they tend to be less well trodden, and this adds to their quiet charms.

Walk 44 Hoarwithy and Carey.

7 km (4.3 mile).

An excellent easy walk along well defined tracks and along the river Wye.

Walk 45 Vagar Hill.

10 km (6.2 mile).

Very good scenery. Very strenuous hilly walk.

Walk 46 Ballingham.

8 km (5 mile).

A moderate ramble with a steep descent. Sloping fields, view from Carey Bank and along Wye Riverbank.

Walk 47 Putley and Aylton.

7 km (4.3 mile).

An easy walk with one climb into some woods. Going through orchards, wood, field paths, country lanes and two churches.

Walk 48 Bredwardine.

 

8 km (4.8 miles)

Hilly strenuous walk along fields, lanes and roads. Beautiful views across the Wye Valley.

Walk 49 Winforton.

 

8 km (4.9 miles)

A steady easy walk across farmland and along small roads.

Walk 50 Staunton-on-Wye.

 

7 km (4.3 miles)

Dont do it when its wet underfoot as it crosses a number of arable fields. Pleasant walk with no hills.

 

 

 

Starting Points Hereford

 

Whitecross Roundabout.

 

 

Fire Station.

 

 

Asda. Belmont Road.

 

 

Tescos Roundabout

 

 

 

 

 

 

Walk 1 Holme Lacy Riverside Walk

Last walked in January 2019

 

Description. An 8 km (5 mile) flat walk mostly along the river Wye. There are many stiles along this walk.

Start. Park the car by the old railway bridge in Holme Lacy. Explorer Map 189 Grid 554357.

Direction from Belmont roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A49 to Ross-on-Wye and at 3 of a mile, (528 yds), TL at traffic lights and head towards Holme Lacy on the B4399. Continue straight on to reach Holme Lacy. As you go thru Holme Lacy, and just past the Primary School on your R, the road goes over a former railway line, (4.4 miles). Immediately over the former railway line, on the L hand side is a gap in the roadside big enough to park the car.

 

1. Holm Lacy. In the Doomsday Book, Holme Lacy was recorded as Hamme which was an estate of the Bishop of Hereford and held by Roger de Lacy, which is where the "Lacy" affix comes from. In 1354 substantial estates in the west of England were granted by William the Conqueror to Walter de Lacy, including the lands of Hamme, and just along the road is Holme Lacy House, a magical Grade 1-listed mansion where King Charles I rested his still-intact head in 1645. The mansion is now a hotel. Walk a few paces further along the L hand side of the road to reach the first house, and a footpath signpost. TL, (the house is now on your R), and a little further on you go thru a metal gate into F1. Walk along the L hand edge of this field, above the railway cutting, and when you reach the field end you will see the River Wye directly in front of you. Continue to follow the field edge as it bends around to the R, the river is now way down there on your L.

 

2. The River Wye. Keep the river on your L. Proceed on thru a small gate and stile into F2. Walk on thru a small field and over a stile into F3. At the end of the next field you cross over a stile into F4. At the field end you cross over a stile and continue straight on thru a wooded area to reach its edge, where you cross over another stile by a metal gate into F5. Continue walking along the river bank (the river is on your L): and go over a stile into F6. The next stile you cross over is by a small hut, which is used by fishermen, (it looks more like a portable toilet), you are now in F7. Continue along the riverbank for about 1 km, (passing the Confluence of the river Wye & Lugg), crossing a stile into F8. Continue on to the end of the field to climb some concrete steps to reach the B4399 Holme Lacy road, on the L is Holme Lacy Bridge that crosses the river Wye.

 

3. Holme Lacy Bridge. Cross the road with care. Go down concrete steps, follow path to stile and cross over into F9. Continue by the river for about 1 km and go thru F10, then its over three wooden plank bridge and thru a kissing gate into F11 to pass a small tin hut on wheels (R). Continue along the river and as you reach the end of this field, (with St Cuthbert's tower in view), bend R, to go thru a small metal swinging gate in the corner of the field and onto a road.

4. Church Lane. TL and walk up the lane to the Church of St Cuthbert, Holme Lacy. St Cuthberts, Holme Lacy church is largely 13th and 14th century work, with the addition of a 16th century north transept and south porch. There is a solid 14th century tower, rising in three stages at the west end of the church. The original village of Holme Lacy lay much closer to the church but was moved when Holme Lacy House was rebuilt in the 17th century.

3
 

3
 
 


4
 

2
 

5
 

1
 
5. St Cuthbert Church. When ready retrace your steps to the start of 4 and go back thru the small swinging gate and into F11. This time bear L over this very large field and head diagonally across it to the far corner. If you are heading in the R direction (Westerly) you will pass about midway between two poles, and then between two lone trees in the field to get to the corner. Once at the corner, go thru a small swinging gate and out onto the road where you TR. Follow the road around to the R as you head towards Hereford. Continue along this road and about 80 meters past Wilsley House, which is on your L, you TR and go thru a small metal swinging gate and into F12. Walk Half L and at the end of the field you go thru a small wooden gate into what at the moment is a building site. TR, and follow the fence(R) down to the bottom where you TL. You go thru a k-gate and walk along an enclosed grassing path, (a fence is on your L and trees are on your R). At the end of the path is the Holme Lacy road, which goes over the old railway bridge. TR and walk a few paces along the road to meet up with your motor thats parked on the opposite side. Holme Lacy railway opened in 1855 and was located on the Great Western Railway line linking Ross-on-Wye and Hereford. Under the Beeching plan the station was closed in 1964, the platform remains but the station building has been demolished.

 

 

 

Walk 2 Woonton to Almeley

Last walked in January 2019

 

Description. An 8 km (5 mile) easy walk with no hills.

Start. By telephone box in Woonton. Explorer Map 201 Grid 353523.

Directions from Whitecross roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A438 to Brecon and after 1 miles TR onto the A480 to Creden Hill. Cross over a roundabout then traffic lights at Creden Hill and on towards Kington. At approximately 10.9 miles stop at the Leominster/Brecon road junction where you TL, and immediately TR signed Kington 7. At 12.6 miles you reach Woonton. TL sign for Almeley 1, take the first right and park up near to the telephone box.

 

1. Woonton. Woonton is a hamlet about 1 mile from the disused railway station at Almeley, this station was on the Kington and Eardisley line. The name of Woonton is Anglo Saxon and means, the dweller at the farm by the wood (Wod-tun). The Religious Society of Friends have a meeting house in this village. Go back up the road from the telephone box and cross the main road ahead onto a Public Footpath, Friends Meeting House 1888, (Chapel Stile Cottage) is on your R. Walk to the end of the wide footpath and go thru a kissing gate (R) into F1. Keep to the R edge of this large field. Go thru a gap in the hedge into F2 and continue along the R field edge. At the field end you TR and go thru a kissing gate and continue along an enclosed track. Pass stables and house on your R and follow a wide track/drive to meet a road where you TL. As the road bends L you continue straight on down a No Thru Road.

 

2. No Thru Road. Continue along the No Thru Road and when the road bends L, by a footpath sign, TR, go thru a gate and along an enclosed track, (the track may be a little overgrown the further along you go). When the lane peters out, continue in the same direction by walking a short distance along the edge of the field on your L. At the end of the field you TL and continue along the field edge for about 25 paces, then TR into the tree line and go down some hidden steps. Cross over a footbridge and continue up F3, passing a lone oak tree to reach a stile by gates. Cross over the stile into F4 and continue along the L edge to go thru gates and along an enclosed track. Go thru a gate into F5 and continue along the top R edge. At the end of the field TR and cross over a couple of stiles, into F6. Continue on up, keeping a hedge on your L to cross over a styled footbridge into F7. Keep to L field edge and go over a stile/metal gate onto a road.

 

3. St Marys Church. TL and walk along the road to a road junction, (straight in front of you is Alemely Church, St Mary). Cross the road ahead, go thru the small church gates and follow the path that goes past the main entrance and around the L hand side of the church. It is not known how long there has been a Christian church on this site, apart from some re-used arch stones above the doors, which are of an earlier date, the oldest part of the church is the base of the West Tower, which was built about 1200. Beside the church of Almeley is a grass-grown mound upon the keep of a medieval castle once stood. The whole site of the ancient castle is now under pasture. Neither the Doomsday Survey nor the earliest list of border fortifications make any mention of an ancient castle on this site and no evidence exists as to when Almeley Castle was built. Continue on the path to a small metal gate and onto a road where you TL. Continue down the road to reach a stone track/drive on your R, going to The Batch Cottage, this track/drive appears just before the road goes over a stream.

 

4. Batch Cottage Drive. TR, walk along the R hand side of the stream along Batch Cottage Drive, which is a Public Footpath. On reaching a garage yard, take a couple of steps to the R and continue in the same direction, walking along an enclosed path thats to the R of a garage, and after a short distance goes thru a kissing gate and across a concrete footbridge. Follow the woodland path, the stream is now on your R. 60m further on, just before reaching a wooden seat, bear R onto the lower path. Upper path gets overgrown. Cross a wooden footbridge and continue on the main path, keeping the stream on your R and ignoring any bridges that cross the stream. Pass a black and white cottage, then pass House at Pooh Corner and continue on up until you reach a main road. TR onto a road and go thru Almeley Wootton, ignore the road going off to the L. Go passed a red phone box (L) to reach a road junction where you TR, (The Friends Meeting House is on your R).

6
 

5
 

4
 

3
 

2
 

1
 
5. Almeley. Continue along the road towards Almeley. Almeley is mentioned as a small village in the Doomsday Book of 1086. Almeley had a railway station on the line from Kington to Eardisley, the station building, (which is used as a cattle shed), and the platform still exist. Pass a Public Footpath sign on the R, and a few meters further along, on the L is another Public Footpath sign, (about 100m from a house) where you TL and cross over a stile into F8. Bear slightly L as you cross this field to cross over a stile by a metal gate into F9. Follow the overhead cables to cross a stile thats near to the corner of a wood into F10. Follow the overhead cables; the wood is on your R, to cross another stile into F11. Continue across the next field and in the field corner you cross over one stile, then immediately TR to cross over another stile and onto a tarmac lane, where you TL.

6. Brick House Farm. Continue along the lane to reach Brick House Farm on the R. The lane veers L, you keep straight ahead and cross over some grassland to join a narrow road where you TR. Continue along the road for about 1 km to reach the main road where you TR. A short distance further on you TR to reach the start point at red phone box.

 

 


Walk 3 Sutton Walls & Marden

Last walked in March 2019

 

Description. An 8 km (5 mile) walk, fairly easy with no big hills as you walk across farmland and fields.

Start. From a lay-by opposite, and a little way up from Sutton-St-Nicholas church. Explorer Map 202 Grid 535455

Directions from Whitecross roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A4110 Canon Pyon (Three Elms road) for 1 mile and TR at the traffic lights onto the A4103 Worcester (Roman road). Continue on the A4103 towards Worcester and at the second roundabout, at 3.2 miles, TL, signposted Bodenham and Sutton-St-Nicholas. At 5.6 miles, TR at the cross roads, (just past a red telephone box and The Golden Cross Bar and Restaurant). Travel along the road a short distance and park on the L hand side just past the church, which is on your R (total 5.7 miles).

 

1. Sutton St Nicholas Church. The church is on your L as you walk back down to the cross roads by The Golden Cross Bar and Restaurant. Go straight across the crossroads and walk along the road ahead. After about km, (just past a black and white house on the L called Ordis Cottage) you TR and walk up a wide enclosed bridleway, signposted To Ordis Court. Continue up the enclosed bridleway. A few hundred metres further on the track bends to the R, you carry straight on and go thru a gap in the hedge into F1. Keep to the L hand edge of the field as you climb up to reach a copse, where you TL into the copse. After about 20 meters in, you meet a track that goes around the bottom of the ramparts.

 

2. Sutton Walls Hill Fort. TR, after a short distance, by a way marker post, the track goes around to the L and follows the foot of the northern ramparts. Keep along the inside edge of the wooded area below the ramparts which are on your L and an orchard field is on your R. Travel around for about km to reach a way marker post (R). If you want to go to the top of the ramparts continue on for a short distance and take the first track on the L, else TR by the way marker and go down the track to cross a stile into F2. Sutton Walls hill-fort was occupied from about 400 BC until the Roman Conquest. At Sutton Walls the average height of the adult males was 5 ft 8 inches - this was actually taller than the average height of adult British males in the 1950s, when the site was excavated. Archaeological digs have revealed that around AD 48, 24 people were killed in the fort (probably by Romans) and thrown into the ditch. The skeletons show the wounds received, and some were decapitated. This did not end occupation, however, and the fort remained in use until around the 3rd century.

 

3. Sutton Walls Hill Fort. Continue down the R hand edge of F2, cross over another stile into F3. Continue on down the R field edge and at the bottom corner, (by a metal gate and stile), you TL and walk along the R field edge. Go thru two metal gates into F4 and walk along the L field edge, along a farm track, to go thru a gate onto a road. TR, walk along a short distance to a road junction on the L, Church Lane, and cross over to the war memorial. Continue down Church Lane to have a look around Marden Church, St Mary. St Marys church in Marden is made up of Kent ragstone, sandstone and a little crowstone, the oldest part of the building, the Chancel, dates from around 1200. The Tower dates back to the thirteenth century, and the reason for its unusual shape is that when the first six bells were hung, the original battlements and steeple were removed. The belfry was then enclosed with the white weatherboarding seen today which is known as a snuffer. The oldest of these six bells was dated 1693. There are two war memorials in the church, which can be found at the western end of the south aisle. They remember those villagers who lost their lives in the two World Wars.

 

4. War Memorial. Return back up the lane to the war memorial. Opposite the war memorial you TR over a stile in a fence and into F5. Go across F5 (a small field) to cross over another stile into F6. Cross over F6, keeping parallel with the dyke, which runs along the L hand field boundary, to cross a concrete footbridge in the top L corner, and thru a metal gate into F7. Walk across this field to cross over another stile by a metal gate into F8 Go slightly R as you cross this field to cross over a stile, which is to the R of a loan tree, into F9. Cross this field and bear R to follow the river to the end of the field where you cross a stile onto a road. TR.

3
 

4
 
5. Moreton Bridge. Walk along the road for 20 paces and TL over a stile by a gate into F10. Continue across a large field and cross over a stile into F11. Continue in the same direction across this field, and when approaching the field end, bear L to cross a way marked wooden footbridge thats nearest to the copse corner, into F12, (ignore the bridge on your L and the bridge thats on your R). TR and continue up the L field edge, (the copse is on your L). Cross a stile by a gate, (the stile/gate is to the R of Freens Court Farm), into F13.

 

5
 

2
 

6
 

1
 
6. St Michaels Church. This next path across a large field was poorly defined but may now be better trodden? Bear slightly R and aim for a T pole in the next field, the third T-pole from the R of a red bricked house. As you come over the brow you will see a stile in the hedge. Cross over the stile into F14 and continue in the same direction to go thru a small/large metal gate into F15 (field is adjacent to Sutton St Michael Church). The church dates back to the 12th century and has been little altered since it was first built situated above the watermeadows of the river Lugg. The Knights Hospitallers of the Order of St. John reserved the R to bury pilgrims who died in their care in the churchyard; the same churchyard is the only burial ground for the united parish today. Continue to the opposite side of this field and go thru a large/small metal gate onto a lane, TL and continue a short way to the road where you TR. Continue along this road to the start point.

 

 


Walk 4 The Spectre of Glyndwr

Last walked in March 2019

 

Description. A 7 km (4.3 mile) hilly walk across field paths, lanes, woods and common.

Start. Near Westhope Bus Shelter. Explorer Map 202 Grid 464510.

Directions from Whitecross roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A4110 Canon Pyon (Three Elms road). At 6.4 miles, after just passing thru Canon Pyon, you TR onto a minor road to Westhope. At 7 miles at a T‑junction you TL, the road bends to the R then goes thru Westhope and just before a red post box and a bus shelter [7.3m] you turn sharp L. After 200 meters you can park on the R hand side of the road.

 

The Spectre of Owain Glyndwr. Glyndŵr was born in 1359. On 16 September 1400, Glyndŵr instigated the Welsh Revolt against the rule of Henry IV of England. Although initially successful, the uprising was eventually put down. Glyndŵr was never captured nor tempted by royal pardons and never betrayed. His final years are a mystery. Owains wife Margaret along with two of his daughters were taken prisoner and incarcerated in the Tower of London. They were all to die in the Tower before 1415. The Great Welsh Rebel was in fear for his life, not expecting a pardon from the new king, Henry V, and living out an existence in deserted places and caves. Tradition has it that he died and was buried possibly in Corwen church of SS Mael & Sulien close to his home, or possibly at his estate in Sycharth or on the estates of his daughters' husbands Kentchurch in south Herefordshire or Monnington in west Herefordshire. Glyndŵr has remained a notable figure in the popular culture of both Wales and England, portrayed in Shakespeare's play Henry IV, Part 1 (as Owen Glendower). In 2000, celebrations were held all over Wales to commemorate the 600th anniversary of the Glyndŵr rising.

 

1. The Hamlet of Westhope. Return back down the road to Westhope and bearing L at the T-junction you pass the bus shelter and red post box on your L. 30 meters further on, opposite a house called Speedwell, you TR, cross the road and go a short way along a drive, then fork R off the drive and along a public footpath and thru a metal gate/stile and into an open field F1. Turn half R, and half way up the field you go thru a small wooden gate into F2. Walk slightly L to cross over another stile/metal gate into F3. About 50m along the R hand edge TR thru a metal gate into F4. TL to walk along the L hand edge of this field and thru a metal gate into F5. Keep to the L hand edge of this field and go thru a gate, down steps, across a sunken path, up steps, across a stile into F6. Keep to the L field edge to cross over a stile into F7. Continue along the R hand edge of this field to go thru a metal rusty gate on your R and into F8. Immediately TL and go thru a newer metal gate into F9. Go to the end of this field, keeping the hedge on your L, to cross a metal gate onto a wide stone and concrete farm drive.

 

2. Lawtons Hope Wood. TL, walk up the drive for about 40m and then TL thru a metal gate and walk up a stony pathway to go thru another gate into a wood. Walk along the stony pathway for about 100m, when the pathway starts bending R, you continue straight on, along a not so well defined, unmarked dirt track, (if you reach a T-junction on the stony pathway you have gone to far). 100m further on you go thru a metal gate into F10. On the same line but bearing slightly R, slope down the field, and not far from the bottom you TR thru a metal gate into F11. With the tree line on your L, continue along the L hand edge of this field for about 80m and TL, to cross over a two-plank footbridge into F12. Climb a steep bank, keeping near to the fence/hedge on your L. Ignore the small wooden gate(L) and continue on up the L field edge to reach the top, where you go thru a small wooden gate onto a farm track. TL, after a few paces TR to climb five steps and continue up an enclosed track. You then climb 16 more steps onto cross paths, where you TR and continue up an enclosed public footpath, (Holly Hall Cottage is on your R and Stone Cottage is on your L side). After about 80m TR at cross tracks and continue up hill along a public footpath to reach Backwoods House gateway on your R, the gateway consists of two metal gates with stone statues of lions on each post.

 

3. Lion Statue. Continue in the same direction up an enclosed track to go thru a small wooden gate into F13. TL, follow the edge of the field that bends R and a little further on it turns sharp L (by a way mark sign). At this point dont TL but go straight on up across the field, passing a concrete water trough, to cross a stile onto a well defined stony track. TL and go along the track, after passing Rose Cottage on your R the track gets wider. Continue along this wide stony track to a triangle and onto a tarmaced road.

4
 

1
 

5
 

3
 
4. Beech Farm. TR, go along the road for a few paces and just before a cattle grid you TL and go along an enclosed public footpath, then between buildings and onto the end of a tarmac road. TR then after a few paces you TL and go thru a small wooden gate that is next to a metal gate. Keep to the L hand fence/hedge and continue on in the same direct until you reach a metal gate. Go thru the gate and continue along an enclosed track to reach a small wooden gate on your L. TL thru the gate and into into Westhope Wood. Go downhill for about 130 meters to a track T-junction by a marker post and TL. Continue down for about 35 meters and TR at another marker post. Bear L at the next marker post, and continue along the inside edge of the wood to go thru a small wooden gate, out of the wood and into an open field.

 


2
 
5. Westhope Wood. TR and continue along the field edge keeping the fence/wood on your R. When you get to the field corner TL, and with the fence on your R continue down to the next corner but before you reach it bear L and head for the rusty looking gate with a way mark sign and a tall wooded pole attached to one side. Go thru the gate and continue down to the L of farm buildings and on to a road. TL and three quarters of a mile along road you arrive at the start point.

 

 

Walk 5 On Offas Dyke

Last walked in April 2019

 

Description. A 9 km (5.6 mile) strenuous walk. There are beautiful scenic views as you walk up to the top of Rushock hill.

Start. Kington car park (off Mill Street). Explorer Map 201 Grid 295565.

Directions from Whitecross roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A4111 to Kington. At 18.2 miles you TL at a roundabout heading for Kington Town Centre. Go thru the town centre and near the end you TL at the clock tower (18.8 miles) and along Mill Street into the car park (total 18.9 miles).

 

You follow the Offas Dyke path (acorn sign) to the end of number 3.

 

1. Kington. Kington is an historic market town on the English/Welsh border, and though on the western side of Offa's Dyke, it has been an English town for a thousand years. The town is in the shadow of Hergest Ridge, and on the River Arrow. The west end of Kington is dominated by the tall clock tower commemorating Queen Victoria's Golden Jubilee in 1887. Kington has a long history of cider making, going back to even before Roman Times. Leave the car park and TR, continue to the end of Mill Street, TL at the clock tower and proceed up Church Street. TR by the war memorial into The Square, and continue up the road as it curves L, then R before dropping down to reach a No though Road directly in front of you, (Crooked Well road). Carry on down to cross over Back Brook, and thence across the busy by-pass.

 

2. Kington By-Pass. Continue up the lane opposite, (ignore the stile on your R). Once the road has bent L you TR and go thru a small metal gate, and head up towards a metal gate on the R hand side of a house. Continue past the house and along an enclosed track. Go thru a wooden gate and continue on up, to go thru a kissing gate and out into F1. Keeping to the R field edge, head up hill towards another house. Go thru kissing gate and up an enclosed track, which ends at a small wooden gate. Go thru the gate and a little further up you cross a stone track. From this point on you will be following the acorn, the Offas Dyke way marker. Continue up hill, staying to the L of the houses in front, you then go across a golf link of Kington Golf Course. Kington Golf Club's 18-hole course on Bradnor Hill is said to be the highest in England, over 390 metres above sea level. You pass a small yellow post and cross over a tarmac lane and on across a cattle grid. Continue on down the lane/drive. Just before reaching a wooden gate you bear L to go thru a metal gate into F2. Cross the field, heading to the L hand corner of a belt of woodland to go thru a small/large metal gate. Continue in the same direction, keeping the wood on your R and a fence on your L. At the end of the fence bear slightly L; further on you go thru a small metal gate, down two steps and into F3. Cross over F3 and over another stile into F4. Continue in the same direction, down a dip to go thru a small/large metal gate by a big old tree into F5. Continue in the same direction to go thru a small/large metal gate in the corner of a field into F6. The direction will now change slightly to the R as height is gained to reach a fence/tree line.

 

3. The Bower. Continue in the same direction, a tree line/fence is on your R. When you are getting near to the end of the field you bear L, to go thru a metal k/gate into F7 (the stile is about 80m to the L of a metal gate). Continue in the same direction, across F7 and arrive at Offa's Dyke itself, where you TL and walk on the R hand side of the mound but on the L hand side of a fence. Offa was the King of Mercia from 757 until his death in July 796, many historians regard Offa as the most powerful Anglo-Saxon king before Alfred the Great. Offa built an earthwork, (Offas Dyke) that covers about two-thirds of the length of the English-Welsh border. Go over a stile into F8; keep to the fence (R). When you reach a clump of trees, you follow the mound as in bends to the L. Keep fence on your R. Cross a stile into F9, and 80m further on the track drops slightly to the L, still keeps in the same direction. Height is lost as our route curves past woodland on our R, to reach a stile/metal gate. Go thru the gate into F10, and a few paces further on the track bears L; 100m further on you TL. This is where you leave the Offas Dyke path.

4
 

3
 
4. End of Offas Dyke. Go straight downhill to the corner of a fence by a track junction, TL over a stile into F11. Bear slightly R and 80m further on you cross another stile into F12. Bear R and head downhill along the gully to cross a small stream, (there are some ruins on your R that used to be Holywell Farm, it is now almost non existent). The route now parallels the stream, which is on your R. It continues on for over a kilometer, keeping to the R edge of a number of fields, to get near to farm buildings of Dunfield, the first buildings on your R. Do not follow the track as it bends R and goes over the stream, but continue in the same direction, keeping to the L of the stream. Cross over a stile onto a track and bear slightly R, continue forward, with a fence/stream on your R, to cross a medal gate/stile into F13. Cross over the field to reach a metal gate, which you go thru to enter Bradnor Wood. Take the track to the L, uphill, then 30m further on it veers R and continues on level ground. The track now follows the edge of the wood for about a kilometer and leads out of the wood to a tarmac road, by Dingle Cottage (ignore the first cottage you pass).

 

5
 

2
 
5. Dingle Cottage. Turn R for a few yards, and at the gable of the cottage go L, and continue along a fence on your R (no path). At the end of the fence continue in the same direction heading towards an off white house. A little further on you bear L, and walk alongside a hedgerow/fence that is on your L. You pass a new house on your L, and then you cross over two stiles. Keep to the fence on your R, and after a short distance turn sharp R and go thru a metal gate onto a driveway. TL and walk along the drive. When the driveway bends to the R, TL and crossover a stile into F14. Bear R to go thru a metal gate and into F15. Cross this field, passing between two barns to get to F16. Bear R and drop down to the far R corner to go thru a gate onto the bypass. Cross the by-pass and up the road to Kington Town Centre. Continue almost to the top of the hill, and if you want to visit the church you TL at a road junction, which is just past the turning for Hergest Ridge on your R, else continue on along the road to the town centre and back to the car.


 

1
 
 


Walk 6 Hergest Ridge

Last walked in May 2019

 

Description. A 9 km (5.6 mile) strenuous walk along the Hergest ridge. Scenic views.

Start. Ridgebourne Road, park on grass verge at end of road. Explorer Map 201 Grid 279568

Directions from Whitecross roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A4111 to Kington. At 18.3 miles cross over the first roundabout and head for Rhayader on the A44, then at 18.6 miles you cross over another roundabout, heading in the same direction. At 19.6 miles you take the first turning on the L signposted Kington Town Centre. At 19.9 miles you take the first turning on the R signposted for Ridgebourne and Hergest Croft. Carry on up the single track road to reach the end where there is a green signpost, Thank You for Visiting Kington (total 20.5 miles).

 

Hergest Ridge

 

Hergest Ridge is a large hill on the border between England and Wales (the highest point being in England) near the town of Kington, the Offa's Dyke path runs the length of this ridge. During the Second World War the hill was cultivated, but has now reverted to rough sheep grazing and moorland, and is partly covered by bracken and gorse.

 

The Vaughan family features a lot in Hergest, Kington history, Thomas Vaughan being the first to reside here. He lived at a place called Hergest Court and was the archetypal wicked squire. He was killed, decapitated actually, at the Battle of Banbury (part of the Wars Of The Roses series) in 1469. No sooner had his head hit the ground than his faithful and fearsome black bloodhound came howling across the battlefield and scooped up the head in its massive jaws and set off full pelt back to Hergest Court. Thomas was buried in the eerie family vault at Kington Church, but his ghost, in the form of a black bull, and accompanied by the ubiquitous black hound, rampaged thru the area scaring the populace to such a degree that the people simply refused to go outside and the whole economy of the area was seriously compromised.

 

A disused Victorian circular country racecourse is sited on the hill and is clearly marked on Ordnance Survey maps and still visible today on the ground. The racecourse was popular between 1825 and 1846 replacing an earlier racecourse on nearby Bradnor Hill just to the north of Kington town. Horse races continued here until around 1880 in summer with panoramic views on all sides and popular with the local gentry.

 

Mike Oldfield Hergest Ridge (the place behind the album name) - Hergest Ridge is a hilly ridge which Mike Oldfield was able to see from his house at the time of writing the album. He moved there after the success of Tubular Bells to escape the attention.

 

1. Car Parking. Walk up the path and pass thru a gate, we now come upon the open hillside. You are now walking along a wide stony/grass track, following the fence and tree line on your L.

 

2. Fence/tree Line. After a short distance you follow a narrower grass track that bears off to the L, keeping next to the fence/tree line. A little further along, at the fence corner, you TL to following the fence/tree line. Continue on until the fence/tree line turns L towards a farm. Continue straight on, past a tall sign post, down and up a gully to again join the fence/tree line on the other side of the gully, carry on in the same direction keeping the fence/tree line on your L.

 

3. Fence Corner. At the next corner the fence/tree line dips L then R, you continue straight on to follow around the edge of the gorse bushes which will be on your R hand side, then you meet up with the corner of the fence/tree line ahead. Continue on in the same direction and the fence/tree line again dips off to the L, you carry straight on to reach a tall wooden signpost. Bear slightly R and head for the tallest lone tree, passing another way marker post before meeting up again with the corner of the fence/tree line.

 

2
 

1
 
4. Fence Corner. 50m further on the track veers away from the fence/tree line, off to the R, and goes down a gully and up the other side to meet up with the corner of the fence/tree line further on. Continue in the same direction, following the track as it bears slightly R of the fence/tree line on your L, (the fence/tree line drops down L then comes back up). Continue on to reach the fence/tree line corner, at this point the track heads away from the fence/tree line and towards the brow of the hill of Hergest Ridge. You go past another fence corner before reaching the brow of the hill.

3
 
 


5
 

4
 

3
 
5. Hergest Ridge. TR. Take the wide track thats on the L side and travel up and along the ridge that has signposts along it, indicating that you are on the Offas Dyke Path. You now walk along the top of the ridge, the Offas Dyke, to the car, which is about 4 km away. About half way along you will pass a small group of monkey puzzle trees with a bench to sit down on. You may see a number of wild horses and foals and can imagine the horses racing around the 1 mile track that surrounds you.

 

 

Walk 7 Breinton

Last walked in April 2019

 

Description. A 9 km (5.6 mile) easy walk along a lot of minor road.

Start. National Trust Car Park at Breinton. Explorer Map 189 Grid Ref: 472396.

Directions from Whitecross roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A438 to Brecon and at 1.8 miles TL into Breighton Lane, signposted Breighton 2. Continue on and at 2.8 miles at a T‑junction you TL for Hereford. At 3.2 miles you TR, signpost for Breighton Church, and continue along a road which is Unsuitable for Long Vehicles. At the bottom of the slight hill the road bends sharply to the L, a few meters further on you TR and a short way down this lane is a car park near to the church (total 3.6 miles).

 

1. St Michael Church. The country church of St Michael at Lower Breinton overlooks the River Wye and is just a few miles west of Hereford city centre. The first church here was built in the Norman period, but this was extensively restored in the Victorian period to produce the church we see today. It gets quite a few visitors because it is located directly beside the popular Wye Valley Walk, which follows the course of the river. The interior is largely Victorian, with a number of 18th and 19th century memorials. The parish register begins in 1625. The earthworks around are the remains of Breinton Camp, a moated house which was the country residence of the Treasurer of the Cathedral in the middle ages. Leave the car park thru the kissing gate and follow the track straight ahead down to the river. If you wish to see the Breinton spring, do not go thru the gate at the bottom of this track, but turn R and follow the riverbank for 50 meters. You will see the spring water coming out of the hillside at eye level. To continue the walk, return to the gate and then follow the riverbank downstream towards Hereford. Continue for one and a half kilometers, going over a small-gated wooden footbridge, and further on you see a large redbrick building on your L, (Warham House).

 

2. Warham House. As the track reaches the end of the field opposite the house, and just before another small gated wooden footbridge, TL, go thru a small metal into F1. Keeping to the R field edge, continue up towards the house, going thru a kissing gate into F2 continue up the R side of the field, passing the house (L), to go thru another kissing gate onto a road, passing a notice board that says Welcome to Green Bank. TL, following the road to a T‑junction (ignore the drive on the L into Warham House). TR, almost immediately TL, to continue along another minor road. Stay on this road to the next T-Junction. TL and proceed along this road for a kilometer, reaching an old cider press and a cattle grid on your L. Cider Press Little Breinton Farm. This cider press, presumably it was a two-stage process is by the roadside adjacent to the farm entrance. The farm is surrounded by cider orchards. A little further on, you TR and proceed up a lane, which is a Private Road.

 

3. Wyevale Wood. The tarmac ends as you pass Upper Hill farm on the R, and is replaced by chippings, dirt etc. Shortly afterwards the lane bends L, and you go past a large pond on your L. The lane narrows down to a dirt track, and you continue on along the inside edge of a wood. Carry on along this track until you come out of the trees to a crossroads of paths and bridleways. Carry straight on along the enclosed bridleway. or TR and after a few paces TR into Wyevale Wood, the nature reserve, bear R to go into the small wooden hut where you can watch the many

4
 
different types of bird feeding. Wyevale Wood Nature Reserve is secondary woodland on an ancient woodland site. A small stream runs along the southern boundary, parallel to the public footpath. Inside the wood is a hut from where the birds can be observed. The bridleway

3
 
eventually comes out onto a tarmac road that is Green Lane. Follow the lane to the T-junction, cross the road

5
 
ahead and go though a small wooden gate into F3.

 

1
 
4. Green Lane. Continue straight ahead, keeping the R field edge, to reach the top corner of the field. TL and continue along the R field edge to reach the field corner. TR, a few paces further on you go thru a small wooden gate and along the inside of a wooded area. Follow the track and climb over a stile into an orchard. Climb over this stile, bear L and walk around the edge of the orchard. The path rises gently. You walk up a small bank and go over a stile into F4. Keep to the L field edge and continue on to the end of the field, where you cross over another stile into F5.

2
 
Go straight ahead, enjoying the views over the Wye Valley that stretches out on your R hand side. As you approach another small wood, cross over the stile in the L corner, where it can sometimes be muddy. Carry on thru the wood on this footpath before climbing 4 steps (L), going over a stile onto a track. TR and continue down the track, past some houses to reach the road at Breinton village.

 

5. Breinton Village. TL and follow the road thru the village for 2 kilometers taking care in traffic. After 2 kilometers, you pass a large complex of renovated buildings on the R. The road here turns sharply R, a little further down hill it turns sharply L. At this turn there is a well-hidden footpath sign on the R that leads over a wooden footbridge, up 11 steps and over a stile into F6. Bear R across this field, and go thru a kissing gate in the far R hand corner, into F7. Bear R and follow the edge of field to the far R hand corner where you go thru a kissing gate and onto a track. TR and you will shortly reach a road/drive. Cross the lane and go thru a small metal gate into a small orchard. Go across the meadow and along a footpath, passing a tennis court on your L, to go thru a small metal gate onto a road/rough lane. TR and follow the lane down to the car park just around the corner.

 

Walk 8 Abbey Dore

Last walked in April 2019

 

Description. An 9 km (5.6 mile) walk across common land and fields. Many stiles.

Start. Dore Abbey, Explorer Map OL13 Grid 386303.

Directions from Tescos roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A465 to Abergavenny. At 6.9 miles TR sign posted Abbey Dore 3. At 9.1 miles at a road junction TL to Dore Abbey. Continue into Abbey Dore and at 9.8 miles, at a road junction you TL for Dore Abbey. At 10.2 miles, (150 metres past Dore Abbey) park on the L hand side of the road, in a lay-by oposite a pub called Neville Arms.

 

1. Abbey Dore. Abbey Dore is a village and parish in Herefordshire, the place is famous for its 12th century Cistercian Abbey, Dore Abbey. Dore Abbey was founded in 1147 by French Cistercian Monks who were not academic recluses but were skilled at managing their agricultural lands in Dores case breeding sheep with fine wool. The Abbey was suppressed (dissolved) by Henry VIII in 1537 and the buildings sold to Lord John Scudamore who dismantled all the monastic buildings and sold the stone, all that remained (i.e. the present Abbey) was L as a roofless ruin until 1630. Restoring the ruins into a Parish Church was deemed an appropriate penance for John Scudamores great-great-grandson and the rebuilt church was re-consecrated in 1634. The Church you see today enjoys regular Church services, has a fine organ and is the venue for many concerts. From the lay-by you face the main road and TR to walk along the road towards the Abbey, after a few hundred metres on the R is the archway into Dore Abbey which was founded in 1147. TL and cross the road, go up a few steps to cross over a stile into a field F1. Climb up the steep hill to the top L hand corner to cross over another stile into F2. Cross the field diagonally, aiming for a white cottage. There is a stile beside the cottage but do not cross it, instead you continue up the field and go thru the gap into {F3}. Continue on up the L field edge, and near the top corner you TL to cross a stile and follow along an enclosed track. After a few metres the track bends to the R, and a bit further on it ends at another stile. Cross the stile onto Ewyas Harold Common. Bear R and continue uphill along a concrete path that gently ascends, you pass under power lines and continue along the path until it levels off and eventually brings you to the cattle grid leading off the common. Cross the cattle grid to join the tarmac lane and continue on the same line, passing farm buildings, (the first building on your L is called Meadow Croft). After about km you emerge onto a minor road. Continue in the same direction along this minor road for just over km, and TR thru a metal gate into F4 (ignore the first metal gate you pass). There is a way mark sign post attached to this gate, which is about 400m past Cwm Hill Cottage (L). Bear L across the field and cross over a double stile into F5. TR and follow the hedge on your R, cutting off the field corner, to go thru a small metal gate into F6. Cross this field to cross over a double stile, and continue walking in the same direction to go into F7.

 

2. {F7}. Drop downhill; follow the power lines to cross over a stile into F8. Keep in the same direction as you continue down hill, bear slightly L, to cross over a ford at the bottom of the field. TR to follow the stream until a stile appears in the fence on your L. Cross the stile into F9 and walk up the hill to cross over a stile by Pen-Twyn Farm. Continue in the same direction to cross another stile a little way ahead, into F10. Go straight down this field to cross over another stile and down a short enclosed track into F11. Keeping the fence/tree line on your L, go down to the bottom of the hill and cross over a stile/wooden gate, then go over a stony track with a cattle grid on your L and continue in the same direction to cross over a wooden footbridge, up some steps and over a stile into a field with newly planted trees. Head diagonally L thru the trees to go thru a wooden gate and out onto the B4347 road.

 

4
 

3
 

2
 
3. The B4347. TL, carry on along this road, which bends to the R going towards Hay, for about 1 km. Turn into the next road on your R, sign posted Kerrys Gate, and continue along this road until it turns sharp L. At this point you TR and continue straight on down the drive to a property called Riverdale, which was a Victorian workhouse. It is now private dwellings, so keep to the drive. An Act of Parliament of 1834 led to the building of workhouses such as that at Abbey Dore on the site that is now Riverdale. Instead of each parish being responsible for its own poor and needy, a system dating from the reign of Elizabeth I, parishes were to be grouped into Poor Law Unions, each run by a Board of Guardians and each bound to build a workhouse to serve the linked parishes. As workhouses went, the Dore one was small, built for eighty to a hundred people that might "farm out" their poor for a set sum, if they wished. At the end of the drive keep walking in the same direction to cross over a stile into an orchard. Go straight thru the orchard. Cross a double stile into F12. Continue in the same direction, (keeping the river on your R) to cross a stile into F13. Cross this field, aiming for bottom L corner, and go thru a small metal gate, then over a wooden footbridge and through another small metal gate into F14. TR, walk a few paces and TR to go thru a metal gate gap, then bear L and walk along an enclosed track, (the river is on your R). At the end of the enclosed track you go thru another metal gate and back into F14. Walk a few paces and go thru another metal gate and continue along an enclosed track. At the end of the enclosed track go thru another metal gate into a field, and continue along the R field boundary, a fence and the river is on your R. You then go thru a kissing gate and along an enclosed track to go thru a small wooden gate and then a kissing gate and onto a main road, with Abbey Dore Court on the opposite side.

 

1
 
4. Abbey Dore Court. TL, 100 metres along the road you TR and walk along a footpath, the large building on the corner is the old Magistrates Court. Follow the footpath to a kissing gate to the R of some large metal gates and continue round to the R, to rejoin the River Dore. Follow the river to reach a concrete gated footbridge, and cross over the river into F15. Head for the L side of the Abbey as you cross this field. Cross a small wooden footbridge then go thru a kissing gate. Walk towards the abbey; go thru another couple of kissing gates to enter the grounds of Dore Abbey. Continue in the same direction to leave the Abbey along the main path onto the main road, TL and return to the start.


 

Walk 9 Bodenham

Last walked in April 2019

 

Description A 7 km (4.3 mile) easy walk with no hills, you walk across farm land and fields.

Start Parking area in Bodenham. Explorer Map 202 Grid 530509.

Directions from Whitecross roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A4110 Canon Pyon (Three Elms road) for 1 mile and TR at the traffic lights onto the A4103 Worcester (Roman road). TL at the second roundabout sign posted for Bodenham (3.2 miles). At 9.4 miles, just beyond Bodenham and before Englands Gate Inn, TL, sign posted to Bodenham Church. At 10.3 miles you TL by the memorial cross and park on the R hand side just before getting to the church (total 10.4 miles).

 

1. St Michaels Church. Bodenham, St Michaels Church. The parish church of St Michael and All Angels at Bodenham is set in a beautiful location beside the peaceful River Lugg. The church is primarily 14th century, in the Decorated Gothic style and consists of a chancel, a 3-bay nave with clerestory, south and north aisles, and a solid west tower on a square plan topped by a truncated lantern spire. Within the church are several intriguing historical monuments and a 13th century carved stone font. With your back to the car parking area TR, following the sign to the church the road bends to the R and then to the L, into the churchyard. The other side of the church you go thru the gate in the far R hand corner of the churchyard, and cross two foot bridges, the second one spans the River Lugg. TR, follow the sign to The Vern. Stay close to the riverbank until you reach a footbridge with a stile at each end. Negotiate this and bear slightly R to cross over F1, heading for the far corner, to cross another footbridge with a stile at each end. TR, and after a few paces bear L to climb a small bank to cross over a double stile. TL, and continue up the bank and into a F2. Bear diagonally R across this field, head for the L hand side of a small wood, and on reaching it you continue thru a gap and along an enclosed green lane. After a short distance you go thru a small metal gate to emerge onto a road, with the Vern being on your R.

 

2. Roadway. TL and follow this road for about 130m, just before two poplar trees either side of the road you TL and cross over three planks and a stile into the same field as before {F2}. Walk straight ahead, keeping close to the edge of the garden on your R. At the end of the garden TR and follow the field boundary, that soon bends L. Continue on, and when you reach the far R hand corner of the large field, go thru a wide gap on your R and into F3. Continue in the same direction as you make your way to the woods (Ashgrove Wood), keep to the fence on your L. At the end of the field (after about 80m) TL, go over a stile/metal gate into F4, TR and continue along the R field boundary. After about 130m, (near the end of the field), you TR and cross over a footbridge with a stile at each end, into F5. Head half L across the field to reach the bridge behind the church, back to the junction of paths.

 

3. River Bridge. Dont go over the bridge but head off to the R, and follow the sign for Bodenham Moor (1 mile). Follow the river (L), and at the end of the field you cross a stile into F6. At the end of this field you cross a stile into F7. You leave the river and head diagonally R across this field, to cross a stile thats in a fence corner, underneath a big oak tree, and go into F8. Continue straight across this arable field, passing underneath power lines to cross a stile onto a narrow road. Cross the road, climb over a stile/metal gate into F9, continue in the same direction across this field, to meet a tree line/small stream on the L. Continue along the L field edge to cross over a stile into F10. Continue along the L field edge for about 50m then TL, cross over a concrete footbridge and turn immediately R thru a small metal gate into F11. Go diagonally L across this field, heading towards two tall popular trees and the back gardens of some houses. On reaching the two popular trees you go thru a gate gap onto the road called Orchard Close. TR and then follow the close to its T-junction where you TL onto the main road. Continue on thru the village, ignoring any side turnings, to reach the Englands Gate Inn.

 

4
 

3
 

2
 

1
 
4. Englands Gate Inn. Pass the pub on your L to reach the T-Junction where you TL onto the main A49/A417 road. Walk along the main road, taking great care as the traffic is often heavy and fast. Take the first yellow waymark sign on the L (opposite Calderwell Farm, the last in a line of houses on the other side of the road) and go thru a small wooden gate into F12. Keep to the R field edge and go round the field boundary. TR when you reach a small gap in the hedge thats underneath a public footpath sign, onto a narrow road. TL and continue along to the end of the road and TR at the T-Junction. Carry on along this road, ignoring any turnings, crossing over Bodenham Bridge, (the river Lugg flows underneath). Carry on along this road and take the first Public Footpath sign on the L, passing thru a kissing gate. Follow the footpath signs, keeping the hedge on your L, and pass thru two more kissing gates to reach F13. Cross this small field and go thru a gap in the hedge/tree line, thats underneath the R hand popular tree, into F14. Continue in the same direction across this field and along the R field edge, to go thru a metal kissing gate into the churchyard. Follow the path thru to the lichgate on your R, to leave the churchyard and walk back to your car.


 

Walk 10 Kings Caple

Last walked in May 2019

 

Description. A 7 km (4.3 mile) walk along road, river and across country, with a pub in Hoarwithy. A couple of small hills to climb.

Start. Park the car outside St John the Baptist Church, Kings Caple. Explorer Map 189 Grid Ref: 559288.

Direction from Belmont roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A49 to Ross-on-Wye and after .4 of a mile, at traffic lights, you TL and head towards Holme Lacy on the B4399. At the first mini roundabout (.6 of a mile) TR to Hoarwithy. At 7.2 miles, just before entering Hoarwithy, TL to Kings Caple. About mile further on, at 7.6 miles you TR, signed to Ruxton, and drive along a single lane road to the church. Total distance is 8.5 miles.

 

1. St John the Baptist Church, Kings Caple. The churchyard stands on the bailey of a Norman castle, whose motte, known as Caple Tump, stands across the road. This road was part of a Roman road called Caple Street. In the gallery stands the Benefactions Board from 1796; this shows the six charities established for the Poor by local landowners and their tenants. An unusual one is called Cake Money by which Pax Cakes are still distributed every Palm Sunday to the congregations of this church. The church has six bells, the oldest dating from 1632. Park on the grass by the tump opposite the 13th century St John the Baptist Church, (a tump is a small rounded hill or mound). From the road go around the R hand side of the tump to a stile in the fence on your R. Climb over the stile and cross a track to climb over another stile into a field F1. Walk straight across the field to go thru a metal gate/kissing gate onto the Sellack Boat Road, and TR. Continue on, passing a house called Shieldbrook, which is on your L, and keep on until the road turns sharp L. Continue straight on, thru the middle field gate onto the enclosed mud track to cross a footbridge over the river Wye.

 

2. Bridge over the River Wye. Before continuing, turn R and go under the bridge to read the memorial commemorating this link between Kings Caple and Sellack. The bridge, put up in 1895, brought to an end the centuries old ferry between the parishes. From the footbridge continue straight across the fields, heading towards the church at Sellack. You cross over a small wooden footbridge, and continue on to cross over a stile into F2. Cross the field to reach a stile by a metal gate. If you want to visit the 13th century church then cross over the stile in front of you, else cross over the stile on your R, into F3. Sellack church is dedicated to St. Tysilio and claims to be the only English church dedicated to a Celtic saint. Head diagonally across the field towards the river, and on reaching the river you TL and continue along the riverbank. Cross over a stile, which is on the R of a double metal gate, and continue along the river bank, passing a smart looking fishing hut by the edge of the woods on your L. Keep to the edge of the wood on your L as it veers away from the river, at the end of the wood you continue on, to cross over a stile thats in the middle of metal gates and onto a road.

 

3. Kynaston, Hentland. Take the road opposite, signposted Kynaston, Hentland, and continue uphill for a kilometer until it turns sharp L. TR and walk along the enclosed Public Footpath. Continue along this track for 200 meters, then ignore the track as it bends around to the L and walk straight on down another enclosed track, to go underneath electric cables. The enclosed track descends a little as it bends to the R and after 150 metres you go thru a metal kissing gate into F4. Continue along the L field edge; keep to the fence/hedge on your L and go thru a metal kissing gate into F5. Continue along the L field edge to go thru another metal kissing gate, to cross over a farm track and into F6. Keep to the L field edge, there are power cables above that you can follow. Walk along the edge of this large field that eventually descends to its far corner, where you climb over a stile into a wooded area. Walk straight on to climb over another stile/metal gate onto a concrete drive. Continue in the same direction to walk down an enclosed track thats to the L of a double garage and a house called Quarry Bank. Walk down the track that descends thru trees to reach a main road.

 

5
 
4. Road to Hoarwithy. Bear slightly L and walk with care along the road into Hoarwithy. Walk past the New Harp Inn on your R and take the first R turn signposted Kings Caple 1, (the church of St Catherine is on your L). The church is not always open but there are splendid views from the terrace. The original chapel was built in 1840. The interiors are sumptuous, modelled after the Cathedral at Le Puy, in France. The centrepoints are the white marble altar studded with precious stones and a similar white marble pulpit with panels of green porphyry. Continue along the road passing the tollhouse on the bridge over the Wye. After crossing the river bridge you walk towards the Kings Caple sign (R), and just before the sign, TR, to walk along a dirt track that runs parallel to the river.

 

4
 

1
 
5. Ancient road. Walk along this track, which widens to the ancient road it once was, gradually getting closer to the river. Ignore the stile and footpath sign on your L. The track bears L away from the river to join the road. Turn L and walk past the entrance to Lower Ruxton Farm on the L. Just before the white cottage on your R, TR onto a stone track. Keep to the L of the black corrugated barn, and go into F7. Walk straight across F7 to cross over a stile into F8. Go straight across F8 to cross another stile onto the road. TL, and walk up the winding road, as you pass the large house on the R called The Green, the road bears L. Follow this to the next junction and bear L. Ahead is Kings Caple church.

2
 

3
 
 

 


Walk 11 Stretton Grandison

Last walked in December 2018

 

Distance. A 6 km (3.7 miles) easy walk across farm land.

Start. St Lawrences church. Explorer Map 202 Grid 633441.

Directions from Whitecross Roundabout. [Turn milometer to zero]. Take the A4110 Canon Pyon (Three Elms road). After 1 mile, at traffic lights, TR onto the Roman Road and the A4103 to Worcester. After 10.1 miles, at traffic lights, TR onto the A417 to Gloucester. At 11.3 miles you TL, and 100m further on TL again to park by Stretton Grandison church.

 

1. Church of St Lawrence. St Lawrence Church dates back to the 13th Century and over the centurys  the parishioners have strived to maintain the Church and its Traditions. Inside the church are beautiful stained glass windows; the only hexagonal font in Herefordshire that has a sunken quatrefoil on each face, the font has been painted a reddish colour. There is also a monument to Sir Edward Hopton, died in 1668 and his wife Deborah, died in 1702. Figures of Hope and Charity grace the pediment, and a genuine gauntlet from the Civil War hangs from beneath it. Walk into the churchyard and TL in front of church spire, then carry on up the straight path and over a stile into a field F1. Bear R and go up the field to go thru a small wooden gate into a strip of trees. Continue in the same direction to back out of the trees into F2 going thru a second small wooden gate. TR and walk along the edge of the field, (the wood is on your R), at the end of F2 you go thru a small wooden gate into F3, and continue along the field edge keeping the wood on your R. Continue on, and at the end of this field you go thru a metal gate that stands between two cottages. Continue on along a gravel drive to cross over a cattle grid onto a road.

 

2. Cattle Grid. TR, go down the road, about 100m beyond a black and white cottage on the L you TL and walk along the signed surfaced bridle path/road. At the cross roads (the New House private road is in front), you TR and continue on for about 80m. TL off the surfaced path and go thru a small, way marked metal gate and into F4, walk along the L edge of this large arable field. In the bottom L hand corner you go thru a small metal gate and into F5. Heading in the same direction, towards a pylon, go along the L edge of this field and thru a gap in a hedge into F6. Continue along the L edge of this field, towards the pylon, to cross a footbridge into F7. Bearing R (one o'clock) you go across this field to walk over the second footbridge into F8. Favour the L edge of this arable field as you head for the trees. At the end of the field you follow the edge around to the R, and 30m on you TL into the trees and continue along a small dirt track to cross the river Frome via the third footbridge. Exit the trees by crossing a plank bridge and small wooden gate into F9. Walk along the L edge of this large field. Continue around this field to go thru a metal gate in top R corner and onto the main road, (Mill Cottage sign is displayed).

 

2
 

1
 
3. Mill Cottage. TR and walk along the road for about a kilometre, passing Rochester House (former vicarage then club), Forge Courtyard and then The Staples. Further on, at the beginning of a small wood (R), you TR and cross over a stile into F10. Bear half R and cut across this large field, onto a tarmac lane that goes to Canon Frome:St James church, (ignore a concrete path if you happen to cross over it). A Roman auxiliary fort, (look at map) lay to the west of Canon Frome and covered an area of just over 5 acres, the area available for occupation was about 4 acres, the fort was protected by a rampart and double ditch system. The encampment would have been large enough to have been garrisoned by a mixed auxiliary unit of both foot soldiers and cavalry troopers with a nominal complement of five hundred men. The unit was probably stationed during the early campaigns of governor Publius Ostorius Scapula, sometime around A.D.47/8. TR and walk along the lane to reach the gate into Canon Frome Court and the church. Dont go thru the gate, but TL and walk along the R edge of F11, to go thru a metal gate in the far R hand corner.

 

4
 

3
 
4. Field Corner. Now go ahead thru gap and continue on along the L edge of F12. Cross over a ditch into F13 and continue along the R hand edge, to cross over a concreted double gated bridge and into F14. Very slightly L you then continue on for about 80m and go thru a kissing gate into F15. Bear L to go straight across this field and thru a gated gap, which is about 130m in from the R hand corner (or follow the R edge of the field around) to cross over a low concrete bridge into F16. Go straight across this field to go thru a kissing gate into common ground. Carry on in the same direction to reach an unfenced road. TL and head back to the start point.

 

Walk 12 Harewood End

Last walked in December 2015

 

Description. A 6 km (3.7 mile), hilly walk along straight bridleways, up a little valley with some nice views along good terrain. Dont go when its to wet.

Start. Park the parking area across the road from Harewood End Inn. Explorer Map 189 Grid 529269

Direction from Belmont roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A49 to Ross-on-Wye, and after 8.8 miles TR and park in the parking area opposite houses.

 

Harewood Park, situated in a quiet valley between Hereford and Ross on Wye, is a 900 acre estate which the Duchy of Cornwall, (owned by Prince Charles and Camilla) bought as part of the Prudential purchase in 2000. When the Duchy of Cornwall acquired the estate in May 2000 they made plans to breathe new life into what had become an abandoned group of farmsteads within Herefordshire, (The Duchy of Cornwall is a private estate which funds the public, charitable and private activities of The Prince of Wales and his family). The Duchy has been the driving force behind plans to revitalise the cottages and buildings on the estate and this positive rural regeneration project has already created jobs and homes in the area. In 2003 plans were prepared for the estates rural regeneration project that would take an estimated eight years to complete at a cost of approximately 8-9 million. The scheme was designed by consultant architect Craig Hamilton and dealt with the sympathetic and sustainable restoration of three groups of buildings at Home Farm, Grange Farm and Harewood Park itself. The scheme, which received considerable support from the local Planning Authority and the surrounding inhabitants of the area, was designed to provide an inspirational place for people to live and work but also to save the structures from the plight of decay and collapse.

 

1. Harewood End Inn. A Traditional country pub and restaurant, 5 letting bedrooms all en-suite facility in the beautiful Herefordshire countryside. Large home cooked menu available daily. Go back to the main road and cut straight across it, to walk along the tarmac Bridleway thats to the R hand side of Harewood End Inn. Pass a garage on your R and for over km you go along a narrow enclosed dirt track that will widen out into a tree-lined avenue, you then go thru a way marked metal gate and onto a wide stony farm track. Go straight ahead along the farm track for well over km to reach Woodlands Farm.

 

2. Woodlands Farm. Continue ahead between farm buildings to exit by a wooden gate on the L, (in front of silos), onto a grassy avenue. Walk along the avenue for about 100m to go thru a wooden gate into {F1} and continue along the L hand edge of this field. Keeping the fence on your L you continue on for another km, going under power lines and passing trees on your L, to reach the corner of the field where you cross over a stile by a metal gate into {F2}. TR and walk along the top of the field for about 100 metres, then TL and descend the field, straight down past stables and a house on your L to go thru a metal gate and onto the tarmac road.

 

3. Tarmac Drive. TL, a little way along the drive you go thru a wooden gate onto a grassy track. Carry on in the same direction passing a pond on your R, and then go thru a wooden gate below the start of a wood on your L. Carry on for about a kilometre up the valley, passing underneath power lines, going thru a metal gate and then passing a wooded area on your L. Near the end of the field, on the L hand side, go thru a metal gate and on up an enclosed avenue, to go past a restored old farmhouse on your L.

 

3
 
4. Grange Farm. Bear R across a stony drive onto tarmac drive/lane and continue along lane. Ignore drive into St Denis Chapel, which is on your R, and ignore the drive further along the lane on your L, which goes to Grange Farm. St Deniss Chapel is part of a comprehensive regeneration project of Harewood Park. Originally the private chapel to the estate, this is the third chapel on the site and dates from 1864. Follow the lane to a road junction and TR at a small pond, (if its still there) in front of Home Farm. Immediately passed the farm, (now on your L), you TL and go up 7 wooden steps and thru a small wooden gate into {F3}. Keep to the fence and the L hand edge of the field until the fence turns sharp L, at this point you go straight across the field, going up the steep hill to cross over a stile at the top into {F4}. Walk on in the same direction and then follow the R edge of this field. As you pass a house on your R the field edge will bend L, and after about 100m you TR to cross over a stile in a hedge to get onto the main road.

 

4
 

2
 
5. Harewood End. TR and walk along pavement for 35 metres and cross over the A49 to cross over a stile opposite and into {F5}. Go straight across and down the field to cross over a hidden stile which is just R of the bottom field corner, then go down steps and onto a road, (if the stile is to overgrown then go thru the metal gate in the corner, turn sharp R and go thru another metal gate and onto the road). TL to snake down the road to the first house on the L which is Netherton Farm.

 

6
 

1
 

5
 
6. Netherton Farm. TL towards the house and walk about 30 metres up the L most drive and just before the metal gate TL up a grassy channel. Cross the stile, which is on the L of the metal gate, into {F6} and follow the R edge of the field, hedge is on your R. Carry on to the end of the field and cross a stile/metal gate and continue along the R edge of {F7} to cross another stile in the top R hand corner into {F8}. TL, follow the L edge of this field to cross another stile on the L and go along an enclosed track between fences to a telephone kiosk which is opposite Harewood End Inn.

 

 

 

Walk 13 Monnington Walk

Last walked in May 2019

 

Description. A 6 km (3.7 mile) easy pleasant walk along small roads, grassy lanes and thru Bulmers apple orchards.

Start. Monnington Village by a red telephone box. Explorer Map OL13 Grid 372435.

Directions from Whitecross roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A438 to Brecon and at 7.4 miles TL to Monnington-on-Wye. At 8.2 miles TL toward Monnington Court and park on the verge near to the red telephone box.

 

Monnington Walk is no doubt grateful for being off the beaten track, away from the busy A438, and close by the River Wye. If apple orchards are much in evidence, then discovery that this is part of the Bulmer estates will not be a surprise. Visitors are made to feel welcome rather than an intrusion, and a further bonus is that this walk involves the minimum of ascent - ideal after Sunday lunch!

 

1. Monnington Court. Walk along the road towards Monnington Court and take the first turning on your R, a bridleway that leads you past Albert House (R) and onto Monnington Walk, a 1km long avenue with a line of fir trees on either side. Monnington Court, a building largely of the seventeenth century, but with a fifteenth-century wing closest to the church. The avenue, lined with fir trees was probably planted in 1628 to mark the election of William Tomkins as MP for nearby Weobley. The firs are interspersed with yews, and some replacement planting has taken place. There are orchards on your L, at there best in mid or late May when in full blossom. Continue to the end of Monnington Walk, initially walking along a tarmac lane and when the lane bends L towards a house you carry straight on thru a metal gate and onto the grassy avenue that has a line of trees either side. At the end of the avenue, after about 1km and just before reaching a metal gate into woods, TR and go thru a gate into F1.

 

2. Gate. Carry on straight across the field, keeping to the fence/hedge on your R. At the end of the field you go thru a metal gate and TR to continue along an unmettled road/track. Walk along this road/track for almost a kilometer, ignoring any way marked footpaths L or R, the road/track then bends L.
