A little further on, by a hydrant 76/6, the road/track bends R and transforms into a narrow tarmac road.

 

3. Monnington House. Continue along this road for about 1.3 km, ignoring the road on your R (where the telephone box is) that goes to Monnington Court. Continue along this road, (which ends at the main A438 road to Hereford), and not far from the main A438 a big oak tree, a footpath sign and a metal gate on the R hand side is reached, at this point you TR and go thru the metal gate into Bulmers orchard fields.

 

4. Bulmers Orchard Fields. The history of Bulmers began in 1887, when H P (Percy) Bulmer, youngest son of the Rector of Credenhill, first pressed apples from his father's orchard. Bulmers cider can be found worldwide and Strongbow is sold across Europe, Scandinavia, USA, Australasia and the Far East. The company is now owned by Heineken. Walk along the L field edge, (after a few meters the hedge turns L, and further on it turns R). Keep to the hedge on your L and follow the field boundary around for about 1.3 km, till you reach the end of various orchard fields, which is just in front of a brook and a wooded area. Before reaching the field end the hedge turns sharp L, then it bears R and continues on to the end of the field. At the field end you TR and continue along the edge of the field, keeping the brook/wooded area on your L. After a couple of hundred meters you TL and cross over a wooden bridge into another orchard field. Go straight across, going between sets of orchards and heading for the River Wye.

 

2
 

1
 

4
 

3
 
5. River Wye. TR when you get to the river. When the river bends L you follow the fence on you L, the fence heads off R towards the church. Follow the way marks to the church. Uvedale and Mary Tomkins of Monnington Court rebuilt the church in 1679 and there is a carved Royal Stuart Arms of Charles II on the South wall. The 17th Century fittings are virtually all intact and typically almost everything has twisted legs or balustrades including the altar table, chancel screen and two-decker pulpit. The famous Heroes Grave of William Williams, who fought under the Duke of Wellington at Waterloo, is in the churchyard. You have a stream on your R as you pass under the church archway that has seats L and R. The path bears L away from the stream to the road, the start point.

 

5
 
 

 


Walk 14 Garway Hill

Last walked in May 2019

 

Description. A 5 km (3.1 mile) walk over common land with magnificent panoramic viewpoints. Underfoot the paths are firm and grassy.

Start. From Garway Hill telephone box, 10 miles south west of Hereford. Explorer Map 189 Grid 448250.

Directions from Tescos roundabout. (Turn milometer to zero). Follow the A465 to Abergavenny for a 7.2 miles and TL onto a minor road signed Garway Hill. At 8.2 miles TR at the T-Junction. At 9.3 miles TL at the next T-junction. At 10.4 miles at the hamlet of Bagwyllydiart, ignore the turning to the left and continue for 40 meters to TR signed Garway Hill. Continue along main road to park on the grass verge just before the red telephone box, total distance of 11.8 miles.

 

1. The Sun. Walk down the road for 50 meters. TR onto a concrete track with a house on your right displaying a weathered pub sign of 'The Sun'. Continue up the track, passing the rebuilt cottage on your right to a metal gate at the end of the track leading onto Garway Hill Common.

 

2. Garway Hill Common. Go through the gate onto the common. TR, and follow a fence line for the first 100 meters, then continue on a wide grassy track towards the top of the hill. As you ascend you will see ahead of you, to the left of the top of the hill, the Sugar Loaf, a triangular shaped mountain, on the southern end of the Black Mountains. It will disappear as you climb to be replaced by Ysgyryd Fawr, or Holy Mountain, as it gradually comes into view. Its geological slip can be clearly seen, which according to local Welsh folklore is where Noahs Ark finally rested! Three quarters of the way to the top of the hill you will come to a pond on your right. It provides water for the ponies that roam the hill. TR here and follow the path to the Radio Mast at the common boundary fence.

 

3. Radio Mast. To got the best of the panoramic views, move to a small mound 40 meters to the left of the mast to see, from right to left Hereford City, the Clee Hills, Wye Valley, Radnor Forrest, Hay Bluff, Hatterall Ridge, the entire eastern ridge of the Black Mountains, the Sugar Loaf, Yr Skirrid and Blorenge. Now with your back to the Radio Mast take the narrow grassy path to the structure on the top of the hill, a world war two observation tower and a trig point. You are now at 1200 ft.

 

4. Top of Garway Hill. The building is the remains of an Observation Tower built in World War2 but almost immediately redundant due to the arrival of Radar. Alongside it is the Ordnance Survey Tri-angulation Point, once used for map making but now also redundant in an age of aerial photography and satellite surveying. To the West below you is Kentchurch Court, the home of the Scudnmore family who still occupy it. This is a 14thC castle, restored as an Edwardian house by Nash around 1800. Between you and the house is the deer park with its herd of fallow deer. The house was used by the BBC TV in 2004 for a series about life in an Edwardian country house. Continue on in the same direction, taking the left hand fork in the path after about 100 metres as you start travelling down hill. Keep along the ridge as you go down hill, heading in roughly the same direction, although you do veer off slightly left, and head towards a wooded area in front. This brings you out onto a stony track at the fenced boundary of the common, (and next to a wooden gate at the entrance to a house in front). TL along the stony track to join a surfaced road by a little red post box and Garway Parish notice board.

 

2
 

4
 

3
 

1
 
5. Chantry Cottage. TL along the road and pass White Rocks Farm building on your right to reach a cattle grid. TL immediately before the cattle grid to ascend a concrete/rocky drive for about 200 meters to the corner of a low stone garden wall on the right. Turn sharp right here to follow the garden wall to pass Chantry Cottage. Built in 1904 and with a plaque in memory of Rev. Jones who provided it, in 1929, as a place of rest and retreat for clergy. Follow the garden wall/fence uphill to the corner and just passed the wooden lodge in the garden, then slightly right as you continue straight on, in a north easterly direction, along a narrow grassy path between bracken, which after a short distance will gradually ascend. Continue up hill in the same direction and pass under some power lines as you head for the gate in the right hand corner of the common. You are now back at point 2. Retrace your stops to the start paint.

5
 
 

 


Walk 15 The Marcle Ridge

Last walked in July 2019

 

Description. A 7 km (4.3 mile) walk over farm and woodland paths and tracks, of which 1 miles is along the Marcle Ridge with its spectacular panoramas.

Start. The Marcle Ridge car park and picnic site, 8 miles south east of Hereford. Explorer Map 189 Grid 630346

Directions from the Fire Station. (Turn milometer to zero). 200 yards passed the Fire Station TR signed 'Fownhope B4224'. After 3.9 miles, (in Mordiford) TL signed Woolhope 3. After 6.8 miles, (in Woolhope) TL at a T junction and continue on main road signed for Ledbury 8. Keep R thru the next village and at a road junction, after 7.7 miles, TR signed Much Marcle 4. Go up the hill and along the ridge and at 8.8 miles TR at the next junction on the R and park in the layby on the L. (2 blue sign posts at this site: Unsuitable for HGVs and Unsuitable for LGVs).

 

The route along Marcle Ridge has been an important line of communication for many millennia. The long, gentle slope of its eastern side offers well drained, easily worked agricultural land and this is reflected in the huge number of prehistoric, Roman and medieval sites recorded. During the Bronze Age and Iron Age farmsteads would have been scattered over this slope with the ridge itself used as a vantage point

 

1. Lay By. From the lay by you go back up to the Much Marcle road and go up the public footpath steps on your R, over a stile and into F1, (you will now be following the R hand edge of the fields with woods on your R for the whole length of the ridge, heading towards the TV and Radio Mast). Continue along the ridge and thru a number of fields(7), passing the radio mast(L) thats in field 6. Continue along the R hand edge of F7, and at the end you go down some wooden steps and thru a kissing gate onto an enclosed track.

 

2. Enclosed Track. TR and continue down hill along the enclosed track. Ignore all paths off this track until you reach the bottom. Before you get to the old farm house (Grey Hill Barn) thats on the R hand side, and by a public footpath sign, you TR and go thru the metal gate into a field. Walk straight ahead (going north), under the double power lines and along the R side of a line of trees to reach a farm track where you TL and follow the track around the R hand edge of large fields. The stony track crosses a very small stream and goes uphill, bends to the R, and then joins a narrow road. TL and walk uphill along the narrow road that soon goes downhill to join a main road at a T-junction. TR a few metres before the T-junction to go over a cattle grid, thru double wooden gates onto a tree lined grassy track. With a fence on your L, follow this level track thru a metal gate and on towards farm buildings. As you approach the farmyard, keeping to the field edge, you pass a pond on your R and then go thru a metal gate into a farmyard.

4
 

3
 

1
 
3. Duck Pond. Follow the farm track uphill and to the L, after about 50 metres, (at the end of an open barn), turn sharp R and continue up a track into the woods. Follow the track along the edge of the wood, (ignore a track going off to the L) and when the track you are on turns L, you carry straight on and cross a stile into an arable field. There is no clearly defined path but you go straight across the large arable field, to reach the corner of the woods. Continue in the same direction along the top edge of the field, (the wood is on your L), until you reach a metal gate/stile in the far top L hand corner of the field. Cross over the stile to go into the wood, (if in any doubt look at your map). Walk along the track thru the wood and when the track turns L you carry straight on to cross a metal gate/stile into a meadow. Cross the meadow keeping parallel to the wood on your R to reach a mound ahead that used to be a lime kilns. Pause to take in the panorama to your L of the Black Mountains with Hay Bluff on the northern end. The village of Woolhope is below you. The foreground is part of the Woolhope Dome an area of limestone surrounded by the more typical red soil of Herefordshire and its underlying Old Red Sandstone. It explains the mound which turns out to be lime kilns. At the lime kilns you TR and make for a metal gate/stile at the end of the wood.

 

4. Lime Kilns. Cross the metal gate/stile and go downhill along the L edge of the wood. Leave the wood thru a metal gate and continue on in the same direction, keep to the L field edge as you go up a large field. When you reach the top L hand corner of the field you go thru a metal gate into a short length of enclosed track to join a minor road. You are now at Hoopers Oak. In 1575, about half a mile from here, a landslip buried buildings. A house near the sight is called The Wonder, In memory of this catastrophic event. TR here and follow the road for half-a-mile back to the picnic area.

2
 
 

 


Walk 16 Athelstans Wood

Last walked in July 2019

 

Description. An 8 km (5 mile) strenuous walk over undulating farmland and woodland. Athelstan's Wood is an ancient wood named after a Bishop of Hereford in 1056.

Start. From St David's church, Little Dewchurch, 5 miles south east of Hereford. Explorer Map 189 Grid 529317

Directions from Belmont roundabout. (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A49 to Ross-on-Wye and at 3 of a mile, (528 yds), TL at traffic lights and head towards Holme Lacy on the B4399. At 6 of a mile, (500 yds), TR at mini roundabout signed Dewchurch 5. In Little Dewchurch, after 54 miles TR signed St Davids Church. After 58 miles park in the lay-by at the church.

 

1. St Davids Church. St David's, Little Dewchurch, is a small village church set in the beautiful countryside of South Herefordshire on the edge of the Wye Valley. It has a medieval tower (14th century) housing six bells that are rung regularly. The rest of the church was designed and rebuilt by the architect and artist Frederick Preedy in 1869-70. With your back to the church take the road to your R, after 30 metres the road bends L, follow the road gently uphill for a while, and just before the road bends to the R you TL and cross over a stile into F1. Walk 40 metres downhill, keeping to the fence on your R, to TR over a stile/gate and into F2. Follow the pylons and the delightful stream on your L, to cross over a stile into F3, and continue along the bank of the stream. At the bottom L hand corner of F3 you dog-leg L then R to reach the track that crosses the stream. Do not cross the stream but turn R into F4, and follow the track uphill, with a hedge on your R, to join a short enclosed muddy lane into the farmyard. Go straight ahead thru the yard, with one or more gates, to rejoin the road thats coming from the church.

 

2. Church lane. Go straight ahead, down the road to the bottom of the hill and TR onto a track that has a metal gate and stile 40 metres ahead. Cross the stile and continue on for 30 metres then TL at the first footpath, to go uphill along the edge of the wood and thru a small wooden gate into F5. Go straight ahead and to the L of three oak trees. Near the oak trees, on your L hand side, you meet up with a hedge, keep it on your L and follow it to a gate and stile in the corner of the field. Cross the stile onto a road. Turn sharp R onto an enclosed stony track, which becomes an enclosed green lane, and follow it for about 1 km, ignoring all other paths or tracks to R and L. The track may narrow in places if the grass and weeds on either side have grown, but eventually the track becomes more defined and will turn into a lane/road as you continue on to reach St Marys church of Little Birch, which is on your L.

 

3. St Marys Church. Immediately after the church TR down a track to reach Higgins Well at the bottom. The well was restored for Queen Victorias Diamond Jubilee in 1897. Legend has it that the landowner tried to stop local people drawing water from it but after his own house was flooded he relented and the well has never run dry since! Now TL to take the uphill track behind the well. A short stretch of this can be muddy, though some stepping stones are provided. Carry on to the main road and TR, walk a few paces and TR to follow the No Thru road/Unsuitable for HGVs uphill. The road bears L and continues uphill for about 1km to the T junction where you TR.

 

4. T Junction. TR here. Continue along this road, (passing a house on your R called Green Lea Cottage, or Bwthyn Tir Glas in Welsh), and go

straight ahead thru a metal gate thats across a grassy track. Follow this track gently down hill to reach its end, at a metal gate. Go thru two metal gates

and continue in the same direction, with newly planted trees on your L and sawed down trees on your R. Follow the path into the trees to a T-junction of tracks, where you TL and walk along a wider forest track. Follow the track downhill, the track swings to the R and runs parallel with a stream on your L. Continue downhill for about km to a track junction where a track to the L crosses the stream by a culvert.

 

5
 

4
 

3
 

2
 

1
 

4
 
5. Culvert. A culvert is a device used to channel water. It may be used to allow water to pass underneath a road, railway, or embankment. In forestry, proper use of cross-drainage culverts can improve water quality while allowing forest operations to continue. Cross the stream and turn sharp L to follow the track uphill, the stream is now below you on your L. Continue on for about km to reach a clearing in the track, a sort of car parking area. Go to the far end of the clearing and just before reaching a gate turn sharp R to go up a way marked path that goes thru the woods. Go thru the wood to reach the other side and cross a stile into F6. Head slightly R to cross this field, heading toward the R side of an electric pylon. At the end of the field go thru a gap into F7 and walk along the R field edge, with the hedge on your R. In the Field corner you go thru hedge gaps into F8, a hedge and 2 sets of stiles are on your L as you continue down hill to a tarmac lane. Go down hill to the road junction and TL to the car park.

 

Walk 17 Vowchurch Common

Last walked in July 2019

 

Description. A 10 km (6.2 mile) strenuous walk over farm and woodland tracks with delightful views and constantly changing scenery.

Start. Lay-by opposite Vowchurch church. Explorer Map OL13 Grid 362365.

Direction from Tescos roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A465 Abergavenny road. At –8 of a mile you TR and take the B4348 to Hay on Wye. At 2–8 miles, in Clehonger, TL onto the B4349 to Hay on Wye. At 5–2 miles TR onto the B4348 to Vowchurch. At 8–6 miles, and in a hidden dip you TL for Vowchurch. 200 yards further on park opposite the church.

 

1. St Bartholomews Church. Was consecrated in 1348, the bell turret is 1522 and inside, the 17th Century roof covers chancel and nave and is supported by huge carved oak pillars, the Jacobean screen has dragon carvings and the font is Norman. Walk back up to the B4348 and cross the main road. TR and immediate L to go uphill on a minor road signed Vowchurch Common (Private Land). Turn off the road onto a public footpath immediately before the first house on the L. Keep on the footpath for almost a kilometre as it changes to a green lane and then to a muddy track until you reach a way marked path on the L, which is just past a derelict brick building on the L. Continue in the same direction for 10 metres then TR up a steep unmarked narrow track, this soon goes between gardens and reaches a drive that goes to Frogs Hollow house on your L. Cross the drive and continue in the same direction uphill and around a lone stile to join a road. TL and go uphill for about 200 metres, (passing a house on your L called Mount View), to the first house on the R, Juniper Cottage

 

 

2. Vowchurch Common. TR immediately after the cottage to go along a footpath to a stile onto Vowchurch Common. Bear L and walk along the top of the common and follow the footpath thru scrub. After crossing a couple of stiles you reach a small wooden gate and an enclosed track that goes L. Dont go thru the gate, ignore any waymark signs, TL and follow the enclosed track to go thru a metal gate onto a road. TR, go down the road and after about 80 metres you go thru a wooden gate, a few metres further on you cross over a stile on your L into a field, (beware of the long drop down some steps on the far side of the stile). TR and go downhill with the hedge on your R to a (hidden) stile in front of a white house. TL onto a track and go downhill and thru a metal gate into a green field, a derelict building is on your L. Continue downhill with the hedge on your R until the field becomes a wide enclosed track, then after 30 metres TL onto a concrete plank and over a ditch and thru a small metal gate into a green field. Now follow the hedge on your L. As you near the end of the field, and in the bottom corner you cross a footbridge that is 50 metres to the L of a half-timbered farmhouse. TL along the track leading to Monnington Court farm buildings. Go thru a metal gate and across a cattle grid to continue along a drive to a road where you bear R, after 100 metres TL thru a small metal gate into a field.

 

3. Guys Estate. Go uphill to enter the wood ahead by a gate (Guys Estate). Keep on a muddy track, generally going uphill. After about 4 hundred metres, by a way marked post, the track bends R and continues uphill to a T junction with a very wide gravelled forest track. TL, go along the wide track until you come to the first main intersection where the track bends R, (ignore the first footpath on your R). Follow the track as it bends R, (ignore the track that goes straight ahead) and after half a dozen paces you TL and follow the grassy track, gently ascending, to go thru a gate gap into a field. Now follow the edge of the wood for almost a kilometre. 100 metres before the field ends, near a white house, you turn into the wood and continue in the same direction and walk along the inside edge of the wood, to emerge onto the drive. Go straight ahead and follow the drive to where it turns sharp R.

 

4. Hill Farm. Turn off the drive here, (ignore the gate on your L to Hill Farm), continue in the same direction for a good 1 km, stay along an enclosed farm track that keeps to the inside edge of the wood. You will pass thru a gate, you then continue on, keeping to the R inside edge of the wood until you reach a track junction where you bend R (ignore the track ahead that has a chipped stone path), and continue on past a large wooden building(L) to reach Poston Lodge Farm. Immediately past a tennis court (L) you TL, and with the farm buildings on your R you continue on to go thru a small metal gate and into a meadow.

 

5
 

4
 
5. Cwm Du. Go straight across the narrowest part of the meadow, keeping just to the L of the start of a valley Cwm Du to cross a stile by some mature oaks into a patch of scrub. Go steeply down thru it for a few yards to cross a stile into another meadow. Go down the valley; aim to pass by the R hand side of a big lone oak tree thats to the R of buildings Cwm Cottage. Make your way up to the wood on your R and continue along the outside edge. At the corner of the wood, you turn half R, and head across and up to the top corner of the field by the wood. Cross a stile thats to the L of the wood and go thru an orchard and onto a tarmac road. Cross the road and go downhill across the narrowest part of the meadow to join a hedgerow on your R. Follow the field boundary, keeping the wood on your R. Ignore the first stile on your R and continue around the boundary for a further two hundred metres, going down then uphill to cross another stile on your R into the wood and thru to the main road.

 

1
 

6
 

3
 

2
 
6. Poston Mill Park. Cross the busy road with caution and TL. After 50 metres turn into the Caravan Park (ignore the first turning), go straight down and ahead, passing reception to cross the River Dore by a footbridge. TL and go thru a metal gate and into a field, follow the river, which is on your L until you reach a gate, then cross a small field to a gate to the L of Turnastone Church onto the road. Tradition has it that several centuries ago two pious ladies disagreed where to build a church to serve the two local parishes. I vow I will build my church before you turn a stone of yours: hence the neighbouring churches of Vowchurch and Turnastone. Turn L and follow the road back to the start, crossing over Vowchurch Bridge.


 

Walk 18 Views to the Urals

 

 

Description. A 7 km (4.6 mile) hilly, moderate ramble. The walk goes thu a park, along roads and along an open hill. If you stand on the top of the Malvern Hills and look east the next highest hills are the Urals in Russia. Hereford Times July 2019.

Start. Malvern Priory Road Car Park. Opposite the swimming pool. Explorer Map OS 190 Grid 778459.

Direction from Whitecross Roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). CHECK MILAGE Take the A4110 Canon Pyon (Three Elms road). After 1 mile at traffic lights TR. Continue on the A4103 towards Worcester and at 19.3 miles TR onto the A4219 Malvern/Cowleigh Road. Continue straight on to the end of the road (21.4 miles), and at traffic Lights you TR. On reaching Great Malvern you TL and go down Church Street (????miles). Go straight over the first set of traffic lights (theatre is on the R) ignore the next R turn, and TR at cross roads (parking signs displayed) and go down Victoria Road. Straight across the cross roads and along Priory Road, to park in the car parks (L) that are opposite the swimming pool.

 

1. Priory Road Car Park (opposite Splash Pool). Emerge and TL along Priory Road. TO BE WRITTEN

 

At the L bend, cross and go up a walled footpath next to No4 Priors End. At the end, TL past Lindsay Arts Centre and TL into College Road to Malvern College. During World War II, the college premises were requisitioned by the Admiralty and the school temporarily relocated to Blenheim Palace. Continue. Bend R at Headmasters House, past Ashfield. Swing up L along Abbey Road, short distance to Wells Road, cross and, at 1860 fountain, TR as if for Colwall.

 

2. Upper Wyche Road. TL along near pavement, past Chalet No. 24 and Earnslaw Quarry, with views across Seven Plain, for one mile, to the Wyche Inn. TR, into Herefordshire, to find toilets, bus stop and bench area. But TR up Beacon Road, at Gundys Meadow. Follow obvious surfaced path, perhaps favouring Hensbys right, eastern approach for gradual ascent one mile to

 

3. Worcestershire Beacon. Celebrating the Queens first sixty years, the topography will tell you that (RAF Defford) at Croome Park was 7 miles due east, but can you see the Ural Mountains? When ready, carry on due north quite steeply down over rougher ground, 550m, to an indicator stone. At the path junction look for the way to St Anns Well. Go forward five paces and TR, at the time of writing, thru a wooden gate. (Not back on yourself.) After about 75 paces, fork L down the broader path. Curve right down narrowing path, thru gorse, until you reach broad cross path. Turn sharp L. Go under trees, thru gate towards clearing and viewing area, but TR to St Anns Well.

 

4. St Anns Well. Continue down twisty surface to the road. TR for town centre via 99 steps (actually 95) and Rose Bank Gardens (Walenty Pytels Buzzards),to R of mount Pleasant. TL then fork lower R, signed Malvern Theatres. After 50m, TL in Abbey Road. TR down Church Street. Pass Priory. TR for Theatres (old Winter Gardens.) TL into Priory Park. Pass L of bandstand, across Swan Pool, by Splash to park.

 

 

3
 

4
 

2
 

1
 
 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 


Walk 19 Fownhope and Common Hill

Last walked in August 2019

 

Description. A 6 km (3.7 mile) moderate walk with three short sharp climbs. Scenic viewpoints and thru a nature reserve.

Start. Fownhope recreation field off Capler Lane. Explorer Map 189 Grid 579343.

Directions from the Fire Station. (Turn milometer to zero). 200 yards passed the Fire Station TR signed 'Fownhope B4224'. Continue on to the end of Fownhope and at 6.1 miles you TR at St Marys Church and go along Capler Lane. After a couple of hundred yards, (6.2 miles) a small white road sign points to the Recreation Field and Parking River Wye, TR here and go along a narrow lane to the car parking area at the Recreation Field.

 

1. Car Park. Return to Capler Lane and TL, go back along Capler Lane to the road junction by St Marys Church. Go straight across the main road into Common Hill Lane. Proceed along the lane and on your L you pass Canon House, Church Croft road and then Fownhope Medical Centre. Continue on for 150 metres and when the road bends to the R, you TL and go thru a small wooden gate into an arable field F1. TR, follow the field edge (hedge on your R) which, at about 60m bends L. Continue along the field edge for about 100 meters and TR at the hedge corner, into F2. Walk up to the top of the field (fence/tree line is on your R) and cross over a stile onto a gravel driveway. Go across the driveway and continue up hill, to go thru a stile gap and onto a dirt lane (Green Lane), where you TL. Walk along the green lane and after about 40 meters fork R up hill. Continue up the track to TR at a T junction thats by a telegraph pole (ignore any small tracks off to the R). Continue up a steeper track to another T Junction by a way marked post. TL to go along a well defined track which is part of the Wye Valley Walk.

 

2. Wye Valley Walk. Continue along the track, passing a cottage on your R. The track is now wide and stony as you continue downhill to a main road (Woolhope road). Cross the road, and then walk on to cross a concrete bridge over a stream. TR and veer to the L as you go thru a gate and up an enclosed track into F3. Continue up the track to reach the end of the wooded area on your R, just by a marker post. Keeping in the same direction go straight across this field to reach a metal gate at the end of the field. Do not go thru the gate but TR and follow the L edge of the field down, to cross a stiled footbridge over a stream and into F4. Go slightly L up this field to cross a stile onto a well defined track/bridleway, (the track goes around the perimeter of Haugh Woods).

 

3. Haugh Wood. TR, follow the excellent bridleway for about 1km back to a main road. If you want to make a slight detour to visit Tom Springs Memorial, TR and go along the road for about 30 meters then TL thru a gate and the memorial is about 100 metres in front of you. Return to continue the walk. Tom Spring would become the champion bare knuckle fighter of all England. Perhaps his most famous fight was against John Langan, the Irish champion, who he beat after 77 rounds. TL and walk along the road for about 20 meters to TR and go thru a small metal gate into F5, opposite a black and cream cottage called Rudge End. Go straight across the field to go thru a field gap and over a brook into F6. Go straight up this field to go thru a small wooden gate at the top, (the gate is to the R of a house on the hill). Bear R and after a few paces go thru another small wooden gate, then TL to go up a track to emerge at Five Ways, (five tracks, one of which is a tarmaced).

3
 
 


4. Five Ways. There are two enclosed tracks directly in front of you, take the track on the L which starts going up hill. Continue climbing for 200 metres to cross a bridleway gate/stile on your R to pass into Common Hill Nature Reserve. Turn half R and climb the hill, then climb some steps to sit at the viewpoint on Monument Hill, (not that you can see anything). Go thru the gate on your L and TL, continue up and along the ridge to go thru the next small wooden gate. Continue along the track for a short while, and opposite a house on your L you veer R, up a slope to go thru a small wooden gate and onto a track. TL to follow the track down to the main road, (Hawkers Lane).

 

5
 

4
 

2
 

1
 
5. Hawkers Lane. TR to follow the quiet lane downwards for about 1 km, (ignore a R fork into Common Hill Lane) and reach a main road. Cross the road diagonally R and go thru a metal gate, following public footpath as it bends L and goes thru a farmyard, and continues along the side of a bricked wall (L), to find a detached stile which is near the end of the wall. Continue in the same direction i.e. TL walk 10 paces then TR, and follow the upper R edge of the field, and after about 70 metres you cross a stile into F7, there are solar panels in this field. Continue in the same direction, along the R field edge, and in the field corner you cross over a stile into F8, (ignore the first stile thats on your R). Continue in the same direction, keeping to the R field edge to cross over a stile onto the main road (Capler Lane) opposite Tump Farm. TR, walk along the lane past the 30mph signs and for a few hundred meters when you TL for the recreation field and the car park.

 

Walk 20 Stoke Lacy & Ullingswick

Last walked in March 2016

 

Description. An 8 km (5 mile) walk over farmland, thru woods and along the alder tree lined banks of the River Loddon. There are some gentle rolling hills but it is an easy walk.

Start. From the car park opposite Stoke Lacy church 9 miles north east of Hereford. Explorer Map 202 Grid 621494.

Directions from Whitecross roundabout. (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A4110 Canon Pyne (Three Elms road) for 1 mile and TR at the traffic lights onto the A4103 Worcester (Roman road). Continue on the A4103 towards Worcester, crossing over two roundabouts, then TL on the A465 to Bromyard[3.8m]. At 11.5 miles you reach Stoke Lacy church where you TR, sign posted Hopton 1, the car park is on the R.

 

1. Stoke Lacy. To Start the walk go back to cross over the main road. TL for 40 metres then R onto an access track between houses and follow it until it ends at a double garage to the L of a house. Go thru a small wooden gate to the L of the garage into a field {F1}. Continue in the same direction across the field to cross a stile and foot-bridge into {F2}. Bear L across {F2} and go towards a line of trees which hide the River Loddon. Follow the river along until the remains of a red brick building (Huddle Mill) can be seen behind the hedge in the bottom L corner of the field.

 

2. Footbridge. TL across a footbridge into the bottom of {F3} and then go straight ahead to cross another footbridge over the River Loddon and into {F4}. TR and follow the river thru three fields {F5}{F6}{F7}. At the end of {F7}, where the river bears away to the R, go straight ahead with a fence and house on your R. After passing the house TR thru a gap in the fence (where a gate used to be) and into a small paddock, TL and go to the far corner of the paddock and cross a stile onto a stony drive to the house. TL down the drive to join a minor road. TR for 5 metres then L up some steps then 20 metres to a stile into a short green lane (overgrown in 2004 and, if still so, walk to the R of it) leading to cross a stile into {F8}. Continue ahead, to walk along a wide grassy strip, passing between a copse on your L and a hedge on your R and a cider orchard, until you come to a gate. Go thru the gate to pass to the R of a cottage, continue straight on to the main road and TR, ignore the tarmac road immediately to your R that passes thru double gates.

 

3. Double Gates. Follow the road until you reach the Three Horseshoes Inn on your L. TL immediately after it up a track until you come to a track junction. Ignore all gates, tracks to houses and another into a wood, to continue straight ahead on the on1y track that goes downhill to go thru a metal gate into {F9}, a wood is on you R. Continue down and along the edge of the wood and thru a gate into {F10}. Walk along the inside edge of Boxash Wood and into {F11}. Follow the hedge on your L thru a gate and onto an enclosed fenced track, carry on to a track junction; a corrugated shelter is on your R. Ignore the track to your L and go straight ahead into {F12} and follow a hedge on your L, to reach a gate at the end of a field.

 

3
 
4. Gate. Go thru this gate into the corner of a field, and a few metres ahead you go thru another gate into the garden of a house, with barns (Sheepcoutts Court). Go towards the buildings the R of way passes immediately to their R. Then follow the garden wall on your L to join a tarmac drive, where you TL. After 300 metres you reach the main road and TL. Walk along the road to arrive at the church in the attractive village of Ullingswick. The church has 12C origins but had major restoration in the 19th C. It is well worth a visit and the building next to it Upper Court is an interesting 16th C house. Follow the road round the church yard and onto where the wooden building ends, then after a further 5 metres, on the R by a finger post, TR over a stile (this stile may be over grown with weeds) and into {F13}. Keep to the fence on your R and continue on thru a metal gate into {F14}. Continue on to go thru a metal gate into {F15}. Go straight across this field to cross a stile onto a main road.

 

5
 

4
 

2
 

1
 
5. Minor Road. TL and walk along the road for about 1 km to reach double metal gates and an overgrown footpath post (R), (the house opposite used to be the Three Crowns Inn). TR into {F15} and go diagonally uphill to an electricity pole in the middle of the field. Carry on down the field and on thru the wood, to reach a gate at the other end. Dont cross over the gate but TL and walk along the inside edge of wood where there is no clear path - to a stile in the R corner of the wood, cross the stile into {F16}. Walk diagonally R up this large field, aiming for the top R corner and the end of a tall hedgerow (R). Near the top you bend R and walk along a narrow part of the field and thru a metal gate onto a minor road. TR and follow the road to its junction with the A465. TL to go downhill to Stoke Lacy village and the start.

 

 

Walk 21 Backbury Hill & Pentaloe Glen

Last walked in March 2016

 

Description. An 8 km (5 mile) walk over rolling country thru woods and farmland.

Start. From Swardon Quarry car park and picnic site 5 miles south east of Hereford. Map Explorer 189 Grid reference SO 578386.

Directions from the Fire Station. (Turn milometer to zero). With the Fire Station on your L. 200 yards passed the Fire Station TR signed 'Fownhope B4224'. After 3.9 miles, (in Mordiford) TL signed Dormington. After 4.8 miles TR signed for Checkley and a picnic site. After 200 yards the road continues on around to the L, a little further on you keep R and head on uphill for a further mile to Swardon Quarry picnic site and car park, which is on your R. [5.5 miles]

 

1. Quarry Car Park. With your back to the quarry/car park TR, walk 10m up the road to TR onto a track thats off to the R. Walk a few metres and TL (by a sign post for Mordiford Loop), and walk up hill, going thru a belt of wood-land. After 140m you reach another Mordiford Loop sign post where you TR and go thru a small metal gate and along a wide grassy path. Walk along this path for almost 1 km, going thru a gate, crossing a track and thru another gate, to continue on until you go thru a metal gate into a field {F1}. Keep to the fence on your R for about 70m, and then continue on thru a wide gateway gap into {F2}. Go downhill, keeping the fence/hedge on your L, to go thru a small metal gate at the bottom, into a wood. Follow the path thru the wood and downhill, (ignore a cross track that appears 15m down). Near the end of the wood you go down some wooden steps onto a metalled track. TR and go downhill to the main road.

 

2. Mordiford. TL and after 200 m, just past a wooden bench, TL at a Mordiford Loop Walk finger post and follow a narrow path to join a residential road. Mordiford is a village and a parish in the district and county of Hereford; the village stands on the river Lug, near its influx to the Wye, and is under Backbury hill. The village has a post office, (if still functional), a bridge over the river Lug, a pub (The Moon Inn), and a church. The church has Norman portions; is chiefly later English; has a transept rebuilt in 1852, and a tower rebuilt in 1814; has also a memorial window to the eldest daughter of R. Hereford, Esq.; and contains a piscina, an ancient monument, an effigies with a very ancient inscription, and a memorial of a very remarkable storm which passed over the village in 1811. The parish contains also the hamlets of Checkley, Checkley-Green, Sufton, and the Rock. After the third bungalow on the L, TL down a narrow fenced path to go thru a kissing gate into {F3}. Keep the Brook on your L as you walk along this long field, then along a stone chippings drive to reach a metal bridge at the end of {F3} where you TR and walk up to the top field corner thats by a derelict cottage, to go thru a small wooden gate into Bear's Wood. After 50m into the wood you reach a wide track where you TL. Walk along the wide track until you emerge onto an open area at the end, (there is a metal bridge on your L that crosses the stream). Ignore the small track ahead thats to the R of the stream and bear R to go uphill on the main forest road. After km, when the road bends sharp R back on itself, in the far L corner of the bend you go into the woods and down a narrow path that leads to a stile into {F4}. Cross the stile, walk a few paces into the field and TR, now aim for the lowest corner of the wood ahead to cross another stile. Go into Limburies Wood and follow the footpath, keeping to the edge of the wood on your L until it emerges onto a main track. TL, cross the brook and walk along the track for about 30m to cross a stile on your R into {F5}.

 

4
 

3
 

1
 
3. Stile. Follow the brook and cross a stile into {F6}. Follow the brook and cross a stile into {F7}. Follow the brook and go thru a small metal gate and along an enclosed track, to reach a minor road. TR and walk along the minor road that bends L, until you reach St Nicholas Checkley Chapel (L). 150m further up the road you TL (The FIRS house is opposite).

1
 

5
 
Go thru a gate on the L and follow the enclosed track to go thru a gate and across a bridge over the brook. Follow a footpath between hedges into a wood. Once in the wood ignore all paths and tracks to both R and L and keep on the main track that converts into a stone chipping drive as it goes gently uphill, to emerge onto a wider track at a T-junction. TL and walk along the wide enclosed track for 30m to TR where the track forks before a cottage.

 

2
 
4. Track Fork. Go uphill on the track, after 150 m TR off the track onto a footpath signed 'Loop Walk' to continue uphill with a fence on the L. Stay on this main path for l km until you reach a track junction by a marker post and TL, (dont go up the steps in front of you). Continue down hill to reach a minor road. TR for 50 m then TL off the road onto a grassy path into a belt of trees and follow this path back to the quarry.

 

Walk 22 Brockhampton and The River Wye

Last walked in April 2016

 

Description. A 7 km (4.3 mile) walk over varied terrain of woodland, farmland and along a lovely stretch of the River Wye. The full walk involves one short steep down and another steep uphill section.

Start. Brockhampton church 8 miles South East of Hereford. Map 189 Grid 594321.

Direction from the Fire Station. (Turn milometer to zero) 200 yards passed the Fire Station TR signed 'Fownhope B4224'. Continue on thru Fownhope and at 6.2 miles you TR at the cross roads immediately before St Marys Church, signed 'Capler and Brockhampton Church and go along Capler Lane. Follow for 1.8 miles [8m] to turn L at -the cross roads and go downhill for 300 yards to park on the road by the church [8.1m]

 

1. |Brockhampton Church. Brockhampton church was built in 1902 and described by the architectural authority, Nicholaus Pevsner, as One of the most convincing and most impressive of churches of its date in any country. The architect and builder was Lethaby, a disciple of William Morris and the Arts & Crafts movement. Indeed there are two tapestries one each side of the altar made in the William Morris Workshop from designs by Edward Burne-Jones. The church is lovingly maintained by its parishioners even to the hand embroidered prayer book covers, each with a different wild flower. It is a must for a visit. With your back to the Lych Gate, cross the road and TR, walk for 20 metres and TL to go thru a gate into {F1}. Go down the valley to cross two fields {F1} & {F2} that are separated by a small wire fence, you can cross the fence going over wooden steps or by going thru a wooden gate. As you descend and near to the end of the fields Brockhampton Court will be on your L. Brockhampton Court was rebuilt in 1893 from an 18century rectory, it was the home of Alice Foster and her husband of the Yorkshire milling family, who had the church built in memory of her parents. It is now a Residental Home. At the end of the fields go over a stile/wooden gate onto a minor road and TR. Follow uphill to a road junction. Cross the junction to walk up an enclosed track leading uphill, to enter {F3}. Now follow the track with a hedge on your R thru two fields {F3} & {F4}. At the end of the second field go thru a wooden gate and then immediately R over a stile and into {F5}, follow the hedge on your R to join a grassy green lane. TL and follow the enclosed grassy green lane until it ends at an arable field. TR into {F6} and follow the track with the hedge on your L until you reach a minor road.

 

2. Minor Road. TL along the road for 700 metres, going thru a group of cottages, and just past the Welcome to Brockhampton road sign (L) reach a Picnic Site on your R. TR and take the track in the R corner of the site, going downhill thru the trees - mainly Sweet Chestnut. If it is wet be careful, especially on a short steep section, as the track is metalled and the stones can be slippery. On reaching the River Wye TR and walk along the river bank. Continue along the bank for about 1 km and follow the track as it swings away from the river, going gently uphill, follow the track up to a minor road. TR and go uphill for 700 metres, involving a short steep section of 1 in 6, to a Viewing Point on your R.

 

1
 

2
 

3
 
3. Viewing Point. Pause here for the spectacular view down the Wye Valley. Now with your back to the Viewing Point cross the road and TR for a few metres to TL onto a very short length of track into {F7}. Continue in the same direction keeping the hedge on your R. Uphill on the L hand side is Capler Camp, an Iron Age Hill Fort occupied between 500BC and 200/300AD. To the east, (half R) is Marcle Ridge and the Mast, Mary Hill with its distinctive crown of trees is to the south east and the Forest of' Dean along the skyline from south to south west. Continue thru two fields {F7} & {F8} and over two stiles. A few metres after the second, TR over another stile/metal gate into {F9}. Turn half R and cross this diagonally, cutting off the corner, to cross a stile in the hedge ahead into {F10}. Continue across {F10} to a gate on the R of a house. Go thru the gate and down a short lane to a minor road. TR and go 150 metres downhill back to the start.

 

 

 

 

Walk 23 Orleton and Bircher

Last walked in Jan 2016

 

Description. A 6 km (3 miles) easy winter walk, four stiles. 90 per cent country lanes and open common.

Start. Orleton village hall. Explorer Map 203. Grid 487674.

Directions from Whitecross Roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A4110 Canon Pyon (Three Elms road) for 1 mile and TR at the traffic lights onto the A4103 to Worcester (Roman road). TL at the first roundabout (2 miles), onto the A49 to Leominster. Go straight across the next two roundabouts (9.5 miles then 12.5 miles) on the A49 heading towards Shrewsbury. TL at the next roundabout (13.3 miles) onto the A44 to Leominster. At 13.8 miles TR onto the B4361 towards Richards Castle. Go thru Luston and at 18 miles you TR at the T-junction for Ludlow. At 19 miles you TR for Orleton Village. A little further on (L) is the village hall.

 

1. Orleton Village Hall. Leave the hall car park and TR, walk on for 75m to reach the B4361. Go straight across the cross-roads (Bakers Arms pub is on the L) and walk on up Green Lane, a narrow road thats going towards Orleton Rise. Go past some houses and continue on to pass Rose Cottage (L) and then Broad Green Farm (R) to reach a road junction where you TL, the Caravan Park is on your R hand side. Gently climb this narrow lane, passing Barn Hall (L). At the next junction the road bends L, (ignore the No Through Road ahead).

 

2. Holly Lane. Go past Rise Hill cottage (L) and some intermediate holly trees. Descend for 500m, go round L bend to reach the next T-junction. TR and go up a No Through Road, after 200m you go thru a wooden gate. Walk on another 75m and look for a narrow footpath on your L.

 

3. Bircher Coppice. TL and climb up thru the trees, swinging around to the L as you continue quite stiffly up to the stony edge of the coppice. Emerge and keep ahead on the (now) grassy track thru the bracken, with a cottage and barn down to the L. The track widens to an aggregate drive (to the cottage), dropping L and R, passing a small parking area and leveling to a high marker post.

 

4. Farm drive. Turn sharp L down the farm drive to a shorter marker post, which is to the L of Woodend Farm. From the marker post you continue in the same direction and descend the dingle, ford trickle of a stream and pass Lower Woodend Cottage (R) to continue in the same direction and over a stile into a field {F1}. Continue along the R field edge, over a stile thats next to a cottage and into {F2}, continue along R field edge. Cross over another stile into {F3} and head straight for the house (with three windows) and stile in front. Cross over the stile and TR, walk down a drive. Go past Pennyfarthing Cottage (R) to reach a lane.

 

5. Lane. TR and go down the lane for just over a kilometer, passing Asley Moor Hall and Temple House, to reach the B4361 cross roads. Go straight across and up the narrow lane opposite thats between high banks, to reach the next T-junction.

 


6. Kitchen Hill Road. TL, walk on past Little Furlongs, (L, no through road) to reach Orelton Post Office. TL down Millbrook Way, to get back to the village hall.

 

 

 


Walk 24 Aconbury Hill

Last walked in Apr 2016

 

Description. A 6 km (3.7 mile) moderate walk along good woodland paths, roads and across open land. Only a couple of stiles to climb.

Start. Park by Little Birch Village Hall. Explorer Map 189 Grid 506324.

Directions from Belmont Roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A49 to Ross-on-Wye and after 4 miles, (at the top of the long hill) TL, sign posted Kings Thorn and Little Birch. After 4.7 miles, (just past the 30mph speed limits) TL signposted for Little Birch. Continue along the main road, ignore any turning L or R, to reach the village hall and a red telephone box on your R, total mileage is 5.4 miles.

 

1. Village Hall. With your back to Little Birch Village Hall, TR and walk past the red telephone box (L). TL at the Methodist chapel (L) and walk up the Public Footpath that behind the chapel. After 120m along a wide track TR thru a kissing gate/gate and walk straight up another wide track into Aconbury wood. Carry straight on up, ignore any turn offs, (you pass two way marker posts on your way up) until you get very near the top, where there is a L and R way-marker post by cross tracks. TR and walk about 150m to the next marker post beneath hill fort ramparts. Aconbury Hill Fort was inhabited from about 200BC to after the Romans arrived, though it seems that it's known locally to be a 'Roman Camp'. The interior of the camp is wooded and a path leads up to its highest point where there is a triangulation point rather redundant given the density of the trees. When Hereford was under siege during the Civil War, there werent many trees on Aconbury Hill and the old Roman fort on the top was in a commanding position. The oval-shaped entrenchments enjoyed unimpeded views over the road coming from Monmouth, across to the Mynde and Much Dewchurch and the approaches to Hereford Castle. In the autumn of 1642, the Royalist forces of Lord Herbert had pushed their way from Raglan Castle via Monmouth on to Aconbury Hill. Thus ensconced, they could reconnoitre a means of recapturing Hereford from the Earl of Stamfords small Parliamentary army. The roles were reversed in August 1645 when an army of Parliaments Scottish allies deployed detachments on both Dinedor and Aconbury Hills. Their disciplinary commander, the Earl of Leven, orchestrated the operations of his siege from a tent on the very summit of Aconbury Hill. Immediately past the way marker post you bear R and head off east, to walk along a well defined track, (ignore the track going down hill). The track drops gently down and follows marker posts until you reach the edge of the wood. Near the edge of the wood the track forks L, (on your R hand side you will see a wooden gate and stile).

 

2. Lower Woodland Edge. Bear L and walk along a broad woodland path, keeping to the L upper path at a fork by a bend, then carry on thru conifers to reach a gravel track in a clearing, at an obvious path junction, by three chopped down tree trunks laying next to each other. From this viewpoint you can see out of the woods and into the walking wild world.

 

3. Three Tree Trunks. From the view point you continue on the same line but down the lower R grassy track thats way marked. Follow this waymarked track for 380m to a marker post on your L, then continue on for another 30 paces to find another marker post on your R, and TR down thru a kissing gate into field 1{F1}. Carry straight on down along the L edge of {F1}, (keeping the hedge on your L), to go thru a metal gate and onto Aconbury road.

 

4. Aconbury Road. TR along a quiet lane towards Aconbury. Crest the lane and at a bend in the road just beyond a cottage, climb the L hand bank and go thru a gap in the hedge, which is a Public Footpath, and into {F2}. Head straight across a vast open field, bearing slightly R, to reach a gap in the hedgerow in front that is near to the R hand field corner. Go thru the gap into {F3} and TR. Keep to the hedge on your R and go down hill and into {F4}. Continue down hill and in the same direction, this time with a tree line and ditch on your R, to pass thru a metal gate onto a road.

5
 
 


3
 

2
 

4
 

1
 
5. Aconbury Church. TR and proceed along the road to Aconbury Church on your L. Saint John the Baptist Church, Aconbury. A Priory for sisters of the Order of St John of Jerusalam and was founded in the reign of King John, and was still recorded as such in 1237, a hospital being attached to it. It probably became an Augustinian monastery soon after this date. The priory church, now the parish church of St John, was built circa 1230-40 and probably extended to the East of the present building. Continue along the bend in the road to pass Aconbury Court, farm buildings and then Aconbury Lodge, to leave the road on the L at the next bend that is just beyond the pond. Go thru the gap and up the field {F5}, keeping L of the tree line. At the end of the tree line the trail goes steeply up hill to an unsigned gap, (direction is roughly 11oclock) and into a wood. You pass an oil drum and continue thru the trees up to a gravel track. TR for 30 paces then sharp L, walk up the bank to where the track starts levelling out and look for the first stile on your R. Cross the stile into {F6} and climb up the R field edge, the woods are on your R, near the top of the field you have to cross over another stile on your R and back into Aconbury Wood. TL and head on down a bridle path to the road at Priory Stone. TR for Little Birch Village Hall.

 

Walk 25 Weobley

Last walked in Apr 2016

 

Description. An easy 8 km (4.9 mile) walk around one of the most attractive and best kept villages in the UK.

Start. In Bell Square, Weobley, 10 miles north west of Hereford. Map Explorer 202 Grid reference 402517.

Directions from Whitecross Roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A438 to Brecon and after 1.4 miles TR immediately after the Wyevale Garden Centre onto A480 and follow this till you reach 8.6 miles to TR at the sign for Weobley on the B4230. At 11 miles you enter Weobley, TR at the second junction, 11.3 miles, and park on the L in Bell Square adjacent to the Telephone Exchange [11.3m].

 

1. Weobley. The Domesday Book called it Wibelai - Wibba's ley or forest clearing, Wibba having been a 6th-century Saxon chief. In Weobley many aspects of 1500 years of British history are represented, from its Saxon origins, thru the Norman Conquest to the medieval period, the Civil War, and the agricultural revolution. Here you will discover the remains of an 11th Century castle, a 12th Century Church and many houses from the14th Century onwards. Its not difficult to understand why Weobley won the National Village of the Year in 1999. Out of the car park and TL to walk uphill turning R at the Red Lion into the centre of the village. As you go up the main street keep L at the bus shelter. At the T junction at the top of the road cross the road and take the track opposite between two cottages to a gate into the grounds of the site of a 11th century castle. Follow the path thru the ramparts to a kissing gate/gate into a field {F1}. Bearing slightly R, cross {F1} to go thru a kissing gate/gate into {F2}. Continue straight across this field, along a well defined track to the fields end, then cross over a stone track and thru a kissing gate into {F3}.

 

2. Wooded Area. With a fence on your L, continue up this field and go thu a kissing gate into {F4}. At the end of {F4} you TR, and follow the edge of the wood (L) to pass thru a metal gate/stile and walk along an enclosed lane. Shortly after passing a house and stone walls on your L, TL thru a kissing gate, over a small wooden footbridge and into {F5}. Go diagonally L up this field and then cross over a way marked stile/metal gate that is in the L hand fence corner. You now walk along a well defined farm track. Continue along this enclosed track to pass thru a kissing gate, a belt of woodland and onto a road. TL down the road for 30m, then TR and walk along a minor road sign posted for Ledgemoor (also Marshpools Inn). Follow this road to the first junction and TR. After 50m TL thru a gate into {F6} and follow the hedge on the R to the end of the field where you go thru a metal gate onto a road. TL, after 80m TR and walk along a road/drive signed as a public footpath. When you reach the end of the road, by Rose Tree Cottage, you TR and walk an enclosed fenced footpath between New Street Stone House and a brick wall, to cross over a stile and two wooden planks into {F7}. TL, after 30m cross over stile (L) into {F8}. Cross the field diagonally R to cross a stile, to the L of a house, onto a road. Cross the road and over another stile into {F9}, then go half R and head off diagonally across this field. Go thru a metal kissing gate and over three planks of wood into {F10}.

 

3. Three Planks. Cross this field and go thru a gap in the hedge into {F11}. Cross this field and go thru a metal kissing gate into {F12}. Keep to the hedge on your L and continuing in the same direction to go thru another metal kissing gate into {F13}. Continue in the same direction to cross over a stile/metal gate onto an enclosed track, a short distance further on you reach a minor road. Cross over the road to pass thru a kissing gate into {F14}, and then cross this field diagonally L to pass thru a kissing gate into {F15}. Continue on, diagonally R, to a wide gap in the hedge ahead, then bear L and make for the far R corner of the field, with houses beyond, to a kissing gate into an enclosed green lane. Follow this lane, ignoring a way marked footpath off to the L, until it becomes an asphalt path and joins a road.

 

5
 

4
 

3
 

2
 

1
 
4. Residential Area. Cross the road, TL along the pavement for 40m then TR between houses. Follow this path, keeping to the L thru a residential area, passing along cycle paths and public footpaths until the path emerges to go between the fenced edge of a field and a handrail above a ditch. Continue to where it ends at a gate onto a track. TL and head towards the church and reach a bend in a road. Continue straight on, and TR off the road and thru a kissing gate into a horses paddock. This magnificent church, St Peter & St Paul, stands as a monument to the past importance of the village of Weobley. Its recently restored spire is 185 tall and most of the building dates from the 14th century, though some earlier parts remain. This Norman church holds an unnerving legend and that is the legend of old Nick. It is believed by many that if anybody says the Lords prayer backwards whilst walking around the large cross in the churchyard they will call upon the devil, whether there is any truth in this story or whether it is just down to folklore is unknown and nobody as ever been brave enough to try it!

 

5. Horses Paddocks. Keep to the hedge on your L, and then go across a small wooden gated concrete bridge into another paddock. Continue on to go thru a kissing gate and along an enclosed track to reach the main road. TR along the pavement passing a half timbered red house and the Roman Catholic church. Then after another 100m cross over the road to go up a track for 50m to cross a stile on your L and into {F16}. Go up the hill with a hedge on your L to pass thru a kissing gate into {F17}. Straight up this field to pass thru a small metal gate into {F18}. With the hedge on your L, go under power lines and climb to the top of' the hill where there is a seat to enjoy the 360 degree panorama. Now continue downhill, ignoring the first stile on the L to pass thru a kissing gate on your L into {F19}. Cross the field diagonally R towards a kissing gate, cross that gate and head straight on to pass thru another kissing gate. Continue down to a farmyard; go thru the farmyard gate and on to the road. TL along the road for 200 yards, then TR back to the start.

 

Walk 26 Oyster Hill

Last walked in May 2016

 

Description. A 8 km (4.9 mile) walk. A lovely fields and lanes walk with wide views from the top of Oyster Hill. A lot of stiles to cross.

Start. By Colwall Church. Explorer Map 190. Grid 739423

Directions from Whitecross Roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A4110 Canon Pyne (Three Elms road) for 1 mile and TR at the traffic lights onto the A4103 Worcester (Roman road). After 7.7 miles TR, signposted to Stoke Edith. After 9 miles TL at T junction (not sign posted) onto main road to Ledbury. Reach roundabout at 15.9 miles and go straight across heading for the Town Centre. Go thru the town centre and near the end, at 16.9 miles, TL at the traffic lights to Malvern on the A449. Stay on the A449 and at 19.8 miles TL onto the B4218 to Colwall. After 20.2 miles, at a bend in the road, TL for Wellington Heath. Just underneath the railway bridge at 20.4 miles you TR for Coddington. About mile further on you pass the church on the L, TL and the car park is around the other side of the church, 21.3 miles in total.

 

1. Colwall Church. Leave the car park by the path running thru the churchyard, keeping the church on your L. At the far side you TR along the road. After 200 metres (passing a new burial ground on your R), there is a footpath at an angle on your L. The footpath goes thru a few trees, then you go half R across the field{F1}, to cross a stile into {F2}. The path may not be obvious here, but it continues straight ahead along the line of trees ahead of you, to cross a stile fence in the far corner, into {F3}. Continue along the edge of the field (with a fence on your R) for about 100 metres; go over a stile on your R into {F4}, and turn immediately L (so you are now walking with the fence on your L). In the L corner of this field, you cross over another stile into {F5}. Continue straight thru the middle of this field to a stile on the far side.

 

2. Railway Line. The path then goes up and crosses the railway line on an embankment, and then drops down again on the other side. Take care trains run regularly on this line. This railway is part of the Cotswold Line serving the village of Colwall in Herefordshire. The railway station in Colwall has one platform and seating but no ticket office or self-service machine (tickets being available to purchase once on board the train). The station was opened in 1861, the same year as the Hereford and Worcester Railway Line. Continue ahead thru a small copse and over a wooden bridge to {F6}. As you enter the field you fork R (one o'clock), and cross diagonally to reach a small copse, where you TR and cross a stile/metal gate into {F7}, (the copse is now on your L side). Cross the field diagonally to a stile in the far R corner (next to the railway line) and follow the track down to the road, where you TR and go under the railway bridge. TL and continue along the road signed to Ledbury and Wellington Heath.

 

3. T Junction. After kilometre, at the T-junction, go thru a metal gate immediately ahead of you and along a short enclosed footpath, you then go thru another metal gate and thru some trees. You then enter open fields {F8}. Continue in the same direction, keeping the stream and fence to your R. Continue on to go over a stile into and thru a small copse to cross over another stile into {F9}. Keep the fence/stream on your R as you cross the field to cross over a stile onto a well defined track. Go straight across the track and over another stile into {F10}. Keeping the fence/trees on your L, continue up a short but steep incline, to cross a stile onto a road where you TR. After 250 metres the road bends L, and you TR at the private road to Hope End Farm. Take the footpath and cross over a stile to the L of this private road into {F11}. This grassy track goes across a field, initially keeping closer to the fence on the R, and then bearing slightly L as you climb the field and look to your R, and get a view down to what is a walled Garden at Hope End.

 

5
 

1
 
4. Stile. Go thru a small metal gate and walk up an enclosed track, keeping to the fence on your R. You then go thru a gate and out into open land {F12), where you continue on up to the top of Oyster Hill, stopping at the park bench to sit and look at the view . Continue on past a trig point (R), and bear L, follow the path down hill to continue down an enclosed track, passing thru two stiles/metal gates, to reach a road. TR and follow the road (going downhill) for almost km, then take the road on youre R and continue down this road to meet up with the first buildings on your L, Pithouse Farm.

 

4
 

3
 

2
 
5. Path. At this point you take the path forking off the road on your R, over a stile/metal gate and into {F13}. Continue on in the same direction, keeping the tree line/fence on your L as you cross a stile into {F14}. Following the power cables above, you cross the next three fields {F15}{F16}{F17}. After a few paces in this field, thats an orchard; you will go passed a metal gate and concrete slab on your L, ignore this and continue on along the field. A little further on you TL over a stile, two wooden planks and over another stile, then you TR into {F18} and continue in the same direction as before, but with the fence now on your R. Continue to the road. TL along the road and after about 40 metres you take the public footpath on the R and cross over a stile/metal gate into {F19}. The path goes straight ahead thru the middle of the field to a stile and bridge on the far side. After the bridge, the path (usually well marked) slants slightly to the R across a field to a metal gate. Go thru the gate, walk a few paces and TR along a gravel track, thru a metal gate and continue on to the road next to the church where you TR and walk along the road to the car park and your start point

 

 

Walk 27 Kilpeck, Coles Tump, Orcop Hill and Mynde Park

Last walked in August 2016

 

Description. A 10 km (6 mile) hilly, energetic walk along quiet lanes, field paths with fine views and parkland. (The original route was displayed in the Hereford Times on January 2011).

Start. By Kilpeck Church. Explorer Map 189. Grid 445305

Directions from Tescos Roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A465 to Abergavenny. At 5.9 miles turn L for Kilpeck. At 6.7 miles turn R for Kilpeck Church. At 6.9 miles you arrive at the church, follow the road as it bends around to the L and park up on the R hand side.

 

1. Kilpeck Castle and Church. With youre back to the church; continue along the road directly in front of you to reach a T-junction, in front of The Kilpeck Inn, and TR. Continue along the road and after a short distance the road bends L, then R, as it bends R you go straight on, along the road sign posted to, Village Hall. Continue along this road, passing the Village Hall which is on your L, then pass a driveway to Dippersmoor which is on your R, then climb up to the top of the hill, where the road bends to the L, a road junction is on your R. TR, and walk along a scenic No Thru Road to (what is) New House Farm.

 

2. New House Farm. Go straight ahead thru the farmyard and exit via a metal gate/stile into a field {F1}. Go along the R field edge. In the R corner you go thru a metal gate into {F2} and TR. Go along the R field edge, which swings around to the L, and after about 300m you go thru a gate gap thats in front of you, into {F3}. Continue around the L field edge and after 100m, at the edge of the woods, you TL thru a gate gap into {F4}. Keep to the L field edge and at the top L corner you go thru an unmarked metal gate into an overgrown enclosed tree-lined grassy track. Walk up the track, passing to the L hand side of a barn, to bear slightly L and continue on up a driveway. The driveway, that is now tarmacked, goes over a mini-grid and on up to reach a road junction at Primrose Cottage. Go straight ahead up a minor road and then TL at the next T-junction.

 

3. Butts Bungalow. A little further on and just past the first house (L) (Butts Bungalow), you TL and go thru two metal gates/stiles. Continue in the same direction, walking along a prominent track that a little further along follows power lines. Go thru a metal gate and pass a stone cottage on your R, continue on to cross a way marked metal gate/stile into Mynde Wood (with its fallow deer). 40m further on you bear R and follow way marked path, along the gradually climbing track. After about 250m the track splits in two, ignore the one that turns R and goes up hill, you take the L track and carry on in the same direction for about 15m, where you TR up steps and over double stile to exit Mynde Wood into {F5}. Go straight across and over a stile into {F6}. Go straight ahead, bearing a little R up and over the top (with Coles Tump clump of trees over to the R). On the far edge of the same field you will find a stile in the hedge.

 

4. Green Lane, Orcop Hill. Cross the stile, a few paces further on you TL and continue along an enclosed track, passing a dwelling (below to the R). Continue along the track that drops down to meet a surfaced road by Springfield. TL, continue along the road to cross over a grid, then after dropping down 150m to cross over another grid, cross a stile (on the R) into {F7}. (Ignore the way marker) TL and maintain original line with the fence/road on your L, skirting elbow of Bettws Court Farm, then go up the hill and over a stile. 30m further on you cross over another stile and go back into Mynde Wood. Now, keep descending, ignoring turns, straight ahead and down a couple of wooden steps, and further on past a marker post and across a track and onto a broader path. Continue ahead and out of Mynde Wood via a gate and into a paddock. Go straight ahead, thru a metal gate, (stables are now on your L), on thru a wooden gate to a tarmac drive where you bear R and head towards The Mynde.

6
 

5
 

2
 

1
 
5. The Mynde (Royalist stronghold in the Civil War). You reach a T-junction and TL to go over the cattle grid and on towards The Mynde. A little further on the drive forks, take the L fork and then go over another cattle grid to follow the tarmac drive as it bends to the R, (the old mansion and clock tower are on the R and the ponds are on the L). At the end of the pond you TL off the tarmac drive and onto a well defined track, which goes down and across a gully and up. Carry on up the track, pass a corregated iron barn (R), and go thru a small metal gate onto a track that leads to a house (L). TR and walk down the track to meet the road. TL, 120m further up you TR and go thru metal gate gap into {F8}. Head towards the way marked elbow, (corner of wood) on the L. TL, go down and across footbridge into {F9}. Turn half R and go up thru a small metal gate in hedge into {F10}. Continue ahead and go thru gap in hedge in top L corner, into {F11}. Bearing R you head for the lone tree near the bottom of this field, and just beyond that you cross over a footbridge and into {F12}. Climb this field to the R of a cottage.

3
 
 


4
 
6. Nash Hill Cottage. Cross stile, go down some steps and onto a road. TL, 20m and TR thru double gate into {F13}. Bear L to reach the hedge corner, then TR and go down the field towards a pylon, going over three planks/stile into {F14}. Straight across this field to cross a gated footbridge into {F15}. TL and go around the field edge to TL thru metal gate onto road. TL and head for The Kilpeck Inn where you TR and head for the car.

 

 

Walk 28 Pengethley, River Wye & Sellack

Last walked in May 2016

 

Description. An easy walk of 9 km (5.6 miles). If the River Wye is in flood then shorter walk must be taken, but apart from this situation, the walk is on good firm tracks. The route is over varied terrain, thru farmland woods and a 1 km stretch along the Wye.

Start. From the lay-by 10 miles South of Hereford on the A49. Grid reference Explorer Map 189. Grid 548253.

Directions from Belmont roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A49 to Ross-on-Wye. At 10.3 miles, 500 yards passed the Pengethley Garden Centre, park in the lay-by on the L.

 

1. Pengethley Garden Centre. Walk back up the road for about 300 yards and TR to walk along a tarmac lane to Upper Pengethley Farm. When the lane bends to the L, (there is a pond on the L and farm buildings on the R) you continue ahead, going thru three metal gates and into a field {F1}. Walk along a farm track on the L for about 100m and where several tracks and fields converge you TL into {F2}. Keep to the farm track as you walk along the R field edge, to go thru a fence gap into {F3} and continue along the R edge. At the end of {F3} the route becomes an enclosed farm track, and you pass some farm buildings (L). Continue along the track until you reach a minor road junction, (straight ahead is a private road to Selleck Church). This track provides some fine. Look half L for the tall red sandstone spire of Kings Caple church 2 km away across the Wye valley and beyond it Blackbury Hill. Ahead is the Marcle Ridge with its radio mast and beyond are the Malvern Hills. Then R is May Hill, the distinctive rounded hill crowned with a cluster of trees some 11 km away. Although only 971 feet high it is a familiar landmark for many miles around.

 

2. Caradoc Hill. TL and go down the road. When you eventually reach the bottom of the hill, at the junction of a minor road, TR and cross over a stile into a meadow {F4}. Cross the field to reach the river, where you TR and walk along the river bank and along this beautiful stretch of the Wye for 1 km to Sellack suspension footbridge. This section of the Wye is a favourite for fishermen and you will soon pass a Fishing lodge. Salmon catches of over 50 lbs have been caught in the past front this part of the river. The suspension footbridge of Selleck was built in 1895 and until then there was a ferry. Look at the memorial plinth on the bridge recording the good will between the two parishes either side of the river. At the bridge TR and make for Sellack church two fields away.

 

3. Sellack Church. The church has 12th C origins. There is a most unusual gravestone in the churchyard near the east end of the north aisle, it simply reads GONE with a finger pointing to the heavens! Leaving the church TL along the road to just before the first cottage on the R. TR here and cross over a stile into {F5}. TR and follow the fence on your R gently uphill to cross a stile/wooden gates into a wood. Continue on for a few yards and the path divides, ignore a track going uphill and take the level one on the R.

3
 
After a few more yards, ignore a track on the R going down hill to the stream and continue on the level track thru the wood on what soon becomes a narrow path, to go thru a small wooden gate into {F6}. Go straight ahead keeping to the lowest part of the valley to a stile at the far side of meadow. Cross the stile to walk along a fenced path, at the end you cross another stile onto a minor road. Cross the road and continue in the same direction up a smaller road towards Upper Grove Common.

 

4
 

2
 
4. Upper Grove Common. Continue for nearly a kilometre, keeping R at the first road junction, then at the second, immediately after a large ornamental pond, TR onto a track signed for the Grove Cattery. Continue to where the track divides, (just by two old terraced cottages on your L, the last one being called Tally Ho Cottage) and TR, go to the end of a short enclosed track, (passing a house on the R called Quabbs Cottages) and go thru a small wooden gate on the L into {F7}. Go uphill with a hedge on the R to go thru a small wooden gate into {F8} and TL. Keep to the L field edge and follow it around to the R to reach the second corner where you go thru a gap in the hedge into {F9}, and then TL. Follow the field edge as it goes downhill, around to the R, and uphill until it reaches the A49 road, under the pylon power lines, (the passageway onto the road is in the corner of the field). TR and walk 50 yards up the road back to the start point.

 

1
 
 

 

 

 


Walk 29 The Vale of Eywas

Last walked in June 2016

 

Description. A strenuous walk of 8 km (4.9 miles) around a circuit of the Vale of Ewyas. An ascent up the attractive valley of Cwm Bwchel leads to a cairn at Bal-Bach, marking the summit of a mountain pass.

Start. Llanthony Priory. Explorer Map OL13. Grid 289278.

Direction from Tescos Roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A465 to Abergavenny. After 16.6 miles turn R, signposted to Llanthony 6. After a few hundred yards turn R, signposted Llanthony 6, continue along the minor road for just over 6 miles, [22.9m] and turn R into the Llanthony Priory free car park.

 

1. Llanthony Priory. Llanthony Priory lies in a wild and beautiful setting, cocooned among the trees and hedgerows of the Vale o f Eywas, immediately below the steep bracken clad ridge, which rises up to the English border, less than a mile away. Christian worship first took place here over 1400 years ago when St David himself founded a chapel. The present remains date from the Norman period, when William de Lacy established a priory in about 1118. Later that century, Gerald of Wales visited Llanthony as part of his tour of Wales, recruiting soldiers for the Crusades. He commented it was situated among barbarous people. The priory never really flourished. By the time of the dissolution of the monasteries in 1536, there were just four monks and the site was sold for less than 200. It certainly occupies a classic position, and was inevitably painted by Turner on a visit in the nineteenth century. Follow the priory access lane back to the road along the valley. TL and walk along the road for about 30 metres, and before the phone box on the R hand side you TR, go in the direction of the footpath sign to Bal-Bach 2km, which goes just in front of Mill House. Cross the River Honddu on a footbridge. On the far side of the bridge, turn R and go thru a small metal gate and head for Bal-Bach. Soon another small metal gate leads you into a muddy green lane. Thankfully cross over this, passing thru a wooden gate on the opposite side, to follow the signpost for Cwm Bwchel. Marker posts now lead you up thru fields, crossing a stile, thru a strip of trees and across a wooden footbridge over a small stream. Go thru a small metal gate, bear L and go thru another gate, the route then follows the R hand side of the stream. Go thru a small metal gate, the route continues on, passing farm building on your L, to gain the open mountainside by crossing a stile. Follow the way marker signs for The Beacon Way as you climb steadily up the R hand side of the valley.
