After a short distance you cross a stile, a little further on you cross a track junction with a wooden signpost, continue in the same direction up to Bal-Bach, which is an area at the very top of the valley. The track continues to climb thru wilder, open country, it is now less steep and an engineered route spares you the bracken and squelchy peat. Near the top, the route tends to bend to the L to reach cairn Bal-Bach.

 

2. Bal-Bach. At the cairn at Bal-Bach TR to follow a broad track. After about 150 metres you leave this track (at the first turning not the second) and fork R, to walk along a grassy track that contours around the side of the hill. The path is levelish for about 11/2 km then it bends to the R and descends more steeply. Eventually you come to a metal gate, pass thru this and continue along the track to pass an old ruined building down to the R. Just beyond this, (dont continue on thru another gate), TR into the field and go down hill, keeping to the wire fence on your L as you head towards farm buildings. Go thru a metal gate that is to the R of the farm buildings, onto the farm access road. This access road/track leads gently and directly to the main valley road.

 

2
 

1
 
3. Valley Road. TL and follow it for about 300 yards. Then TR along a no thru road, signposted to a trekking centre. Cross the bridge over the river. Soon after the bridge the lane curves to the L but you turn sharp R and go thru a wooden gate onto an enclosed track (ignore the first wooden gate on your R and go thru the second gate, which is a little further up the hill). After almost a kilometre you go thru a wooden gate onto a single-track road. Continue on in the same direction for about another kilometre to a T-junction where you TL onto the main road to Llanthony. A little further along the road, on your R, you pass the Half Moon Hotel, a white building that I think is now closed as a hotel. A little further on from the hotel, when the road bends to the R, you go straight on and up thru a small wooden gate into a field, cross the field and go thru wooden gates and on to the car park.

 

 


Walk 30 Skenfrith and Garway

Last walked in June 2016

 

Description. 8 km (4.9 miles). Most of this route is along quiet, narrow, roughish country lanes, little more than farm tracks, amidst the beautiful scenery of the Monnow Valley on the border between Wales and England.

Start. Parking area in front of Skenfrith Castle. Explorer Map 189. Grid 458202.

Directions from Belmont Roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A49 to Ross-on-Wye. After 4.5 miles TR onto A466 towards Monmouth. When milometer is on 11.2 miles TR onto the B4521 to Abergavenny/Skenfrith 3. At Skenfrith when the milometer is on 14.1 miles TR to park by Skenfrith the castle.

 

1. Skenfrith. Skenfrith is a typical border village with a border castle and a border church. The castle is one of the Trilateral castles built by Hubert de Burgh in the 13th century to protect the Monnow Valley. It is a simple but striking building, comprising a curtain wall and four rounded towers, within which are the remains of a rare circular keep. The tiny village comprises little more than a row of cottages along the lane beside the castle, which leads to Skenfrith's other gem: the 13th-century church, contemporary with the castle and built by the same man. It is an interesting and sturdy-looking building with thick walls and a massive low tower capped by a wooden belfry that doubled up as a dovecote. The tower gives the church an almost fortress-like appearance and was in fact used as a refuge by villagers during times of trouble. Start by walking back to the main road, TL and follow the road past the Bell and around to the left and over the bridge. Take the first turning on the left, at a notice saying Unsuitable for Heavy Goods Vehicles, and follow this winding lane for a long 1 mile up to Garway, ignoring any road or footpaths on your right as you ascend.

 

2. Garway. Just before reaching the village, TR at a wooden sign for Galway Church and continue along a track to the church. Like the church at Skenfrith this is a typical Norman border church with a fortress feel about it and a solid-looking square tower that could serve as a place of refuge. It is unusual both in its history and appearance. Originally it was one of only six churches in England built by the Knights' Templars, on land given to the Order by Henry II in the 12th century. On the dissolution of that Order in 1408 it passed to their rivals, the Knights' Hospitallers. Its appearance is unusual in that the tower is built at an angle to the main body of the church; originally it was detached and it only became joined to the rest of the church in the 17th century. The interior is dominated by the Norman chancel arch. Pass through the churchyard, keeping to the left of the church, and head for the top left hand corner of the churchyard to go through a metal kissing-gate. Head diagonally across the field, uphill and off to the right towards a house in the far corner of the field where there is a footpath sign and another metal kissing gate which you go through. TR along the road and continue to the top of the hill and through the village. At the end of the village, just passed Garway Inn on the left, you TR along the road signposted to Skenfrith and Abergavenny.

3
 

2
 
3. Garway Common. Cross the relatively small but open expanse of Garway Common, from which there are fine views all around. Follow this road and when it bends sharply left go straight ahead through a metal gate with a sign Beechland, then through a wooden gate and head for the left hand side of two garages attached to a house. Continue on past the garages, ignoring a stile on your left, and carry on past an out building keeping a hedge/tree line on your left. Keep on down hill with a hedge/tree line on your left to reach the end of the field where you go through a gate and onto a road. Go straight across the road to cross over a stile into a field.

 

4
 
4. Downhill. Head downhill along the right-hand edge of a field, keep a wire fence/line of trees on the right. Cross a stile into a larger field and continue downhill keeping the fence/line of trees on your right. Climb a stile at the bottom end of the field and TL along the road, rejoining the outward route. Retrace your steps to Skenfrith and towards the end there are attractive views to the right of both the castle and church across the meadows bordering the Monnow.

 

 

 

1
 
 

 


Walk 31 Worcester Beacon

Last walked in July 2016

 

Description. A strenuous walk of 8 km (4.9 miles) as the crow flies, which should be carried out in clear weather.

Start. Car Park. Explorer Map 190. Grid 770469.

Direction from Whitecross Roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A4110 Canon Pyon (Three Elms road). After 1 mile at traffic lights TR. Continue on the A4103 towards Worcester and at 19.3 miles TR onto the A4219 Malvern/Cowleigh Road. Continue straight on to the end of the road, 21.4 miles, and TR, a few hundred yards on the left, just before a clock tower, is a pay and display car park [21.5m].

 

1. Car Park. At the end of the car park, the opposite end to the main entrance, proceed up a tarmaced track; the road is on your left. After about 100 yards the track splits, continue up hill and ignore the small track that goes downhill and to your left. Next, in front of you and to the right is a cliff face, just before that is a smaller track coming in from the right hand side, turn sharp right here and go up this track in the direction of North Hill, as a stone placard indicates. The track zigzags uphill to reach a junction where you TR and continue along Lady Howard De Walden Drive, which is a wide well kept track. Continue along this path for about half a kilometre as it goes around North Hill to reach the top of a valley on your right.

 

2. Wooden Bench. At this point, by a wooden bench, TL and go up an undefined track between North and Table Hills - detour to either (or both) to admire the landscape unfolding to east and west. Descend, keeping Worcestershire Beacon (almost due south) in your sights. Around here there is a veritable profusion of paths keeping to the ridge choose your own route to reach the trig point at the summit of Worcestershire Beacon, 1,394ft high.

 

3. Worcester Beacon. Here is the usual triangulation column, also an excellent topography to assist you in identifying the features you can see. The name Beacon comes from the use of the hill as a signalling beacon during World War II the Beacon was used as a fire lookout point for air raids on Birmingham and Coventry. In recent years it has been used as a beacon for special occasions such as the millennium night of December 31, 1999 when a large fire was lit as part of a nationwide network of hill top beacons to celebrate the event. A cafe long stood just below the summit, until destroyed by fire - the terrace still remains. When you have drunk your fill of the views head off to the south, starting off down a tarmac/chip path on the eastern side, (left side) of the beacon. Continue down the tarmaced path and just past a concrete litter bin holder and bench you leave the path, which goes around the right hand side of the next hill top, to go straight ahead across a grassy area and onto a small dirt track that goes around the left hand side of the next hill top. Continue down the dirt track for a couple of hundred metres and turn sharp left down a small dirt track which soon meets up with a wire fence that surrounds a quarry. Continue down hill keeping the fence to your right and follow the track as it zigzags down to Earnslaw Quarry, passing an etched stone with Quarry Walk to Goldmine written on it before you enter a clearing then the quarry itself,

1
 
which was once an eyesore, now a beauty spot with a shallow pool. A track goes off to the left, opposite the quarry entrance, towards the main road; at the start of the track and on the left is a stone with St Anns Well etched on it.

 

2
 
4. Quarry. Continue along this track, don't go onto the road but continue along the track ahead, this climbs a little. Near by is a wooden bench and a little further on is an etched concrete sign for St Anns Well. Contour around to St Ann's Well. The track does rise and fall slightly as you venture along to reach the well. At week-ends you can sample some pure Malvern water, in the room next to the cafe. When you reach St Anns well you follow the track that goes up and around to the left, after about a hundred yards you enter a picnic area. Carry on along the track ahead that goes slightly down hill, ignore the track on your left that goes uphill. After a short distance you reach the end of a tarmac road. Cross the road and climb a couple of rocky steps onto a track where you TR. Continue along this track that goes around the right hand side of the hill. Ignore any tracks on your right until you reach the cliff face with the placard for North Hill, here the track forks and you take the right fork downhill, the track will end up at the car park.

 

3
 

4
 
 

 


Walk 32 Pembridge and Eardisland

Last walked in July 2016

 

Description. An 8 km (4.9 miles) walk. Herefordshire is famed for its black and white villages of which Pembridge and Eardisland are among the finest.

Start. Free car park on the R as you enter into Pembridge. Grid reference Explorer Map 201. Grid 392582.

Directions from Whitecross Roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A4110 Canon Pyne/A4113 Knighton (Three Elms road). Continue on, thru Canon Pyon, for 10.1 miles and as the road bends R you TL onto the B4457(A44) to Pembridge/Eardisland. At 11 miles go straight across the cross roads to Rhayader on the A44, also goes to Eardisland, Pembridge and Kington. At 13.6 miles you reach Pembridge, the free car park is on the R (13.9m).

 

1. Pembridge. Out of the car park and TL, walk about 200 yards along the main road to just pass The Old Oak House and TL onto a Public Footpath. Go thru a double wooden gate and walk down the drive on the R to a small haulage yard where you TL and go thru double metal gates and across a small field to the L hand corner where you cross over a hidden stile by a gate (the stile consists of four metal bars) and into a large field{F1}, you then cross over three wooden planks (a footbridge). Keep to the hedge/fence on your L as it turns L after about 150m and continues onto the corner of the field where you cross over a stile/metal gate into {F2}. Keeping the hedge/fence to your L, head towards some houses. TR at the end of the field by a gate near houses, and follow the field boundary, keeping the fence and a small green lane on your L. Carry on to go thru a kissing gate into {F3}then TR.

 

2. River Arrow. The path across these flat riverside meadows does not cling as closely to the river arrow as one may expect and desire, although the river is always on the L. At the end of {F3}, where you keep close to the hedge on your R, you cross over a wooden footbridge with a metal gate at each end into {F4}. Head straight across this field to cross over a stile into {F5}. Head in the same direction across this field, to cross over another stile into {F6}. Keep to the fence and field boundary on your R as you cross {F6} to cross over another stile into {F7}. Go straight across to cross over another stile into {F8} and a tantalising glimpse of the river at a weir. Keep to the L field boundary as you walk around to the narrow end of this large field, ignoring the first and the second concrete bridges that are on your L. At the end of the field you TR and cross over two stiles with wooden steps in the middle, into {F9} where you TL. Follow the hedge/fence on your L to cross over another stile into {F10}. Follow the fence/hedge on your L and after a short distance TL to cross over a wooden gated bridge into {F11}. Bear slightly R as you cross this field and head towards houses and the road, at the end of the field go thru a kissing gate into {F12}. Cross this small field to go thru a kissing gate and onto the main road, where you TL. You are now in Eardisland. Continue on towards the bridge that acts as a magnet for so many visitors.

 

3. The Dovecot. TL just before the main bridge/river and walk along the road, which is Unsuitable for Long Vehicles and runs opposite the Dovecote. Continue along this road for about 2 km (ignoring the road on the R, The Foley) and after about 2 km the road does a sharp R.

Continue straight on the tarmac track on the L leading to the farmstead of Twyford.

 

4. Twyford. After a short distance TR thru a metal gate thats opposite an old petrol pump. Bear half L to cross the field and then a stile/gate into another field. Continue on to the L corner of the field and cross a wooden footbridge into another field. Cross the field and then a stile onto a road. TL and continue along the road to reach a T-junction where you TL and go back to the car.

 

Walk 33 Around Twyn-Y-Gaer

Last walked in August 2016

 

Description. An 9 km (5.5 mile) walk. This is a strenuous walk but has much historical interest. An Iron Age fort caps the summit of Twyn-y-Gaer with panoramic views over three valleys.

Start. Walkers Car Park just north of the Queens Head Inn. Explorer Map OL13. Grid 311222

Directions from Tescos Roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A465 Abergavenny road and at 16.6m TR signposted for Llanthony. A little further on TR again, signposted Llanthony 6. Carry on along the Llanthony road for another 1 mile to The Queens Head Inn, the total distance being 18.2 miles. The Walkers Car Park is on the opposite side of the road. A daily 2 charge is requested and should be paid at the pub.

 

1. The Queens Head. Ascend the steep tarmac road, which leaves the valley road at the entrance to the car park. A steady climb leads thru the woods up the ridge of Twyn-y-Gaer. Eventually the tarmac ends and the ascent continues along a well defined dirt track, a promenade, to reach a metal gate.

 

2. Open Land. Pass thru a metal gate to enter the open land. Immediately TL and climb up a broad grassy track thru the bracken, following a fence is on your L. It veers to the L just below the highest part of the hill and then veers to the R to attack the summit from the east. A cairn marks the top at 427m. The summit plateau is a delightful grassy promenade, studded with gorse bushes. Its easy to see why the ancient Britons chose this site, perched on a hilltop overlooking three valleys. The ditches and ramparts are still discernable. The fort is oval in shape and covers an area of over 4 acres. It consists of three sections, surrounded by a double embankment. From the top you can see the sites of two neighbouring forts. Eastward lies Trewyn at the southern end of the Hatterrall ridge, while Crug Hywel crowns the Table Mountain above Crickhowell. At the top carry straight on past the cairn to the end of the summit plateau. A deep defensive, ditch marks the boundary of the fort. It is easiest to cross this at the L hand end, then picking up a clear grassy path sloping downhill to the R. After a short steep section, there's a graceful descent thru the bracken to the wide saddle of the ridge. From here you can see the ridge ahead is quite narrow and the valleys either side are not far apart. But they drain in completely different directions. To the L, the Grwyne Fawrs water supply the Usk, eventually passing under Newport's transporter bridge to join the Bristol Channel. To the L the Honddu unites with the Monnow a few miles north, and the water then flows to the Wye and on to the Severn at Chepstow. At the bottom, on the R hand side, you come to a wall and fence and meet a track running alongside it. Bear L to join this track and continue along it. In about 500 yards you pass a house set back on the R. About 300 yards further you reach a junction of tracks with a wall now on both sides.

 

3. Sharp L. Turn immediately to the L here and continue along another track, keeping to a wall on your R. Follow this track just above a wall and a wood just below the crest of the ridge. Pass a ruined building on your R as you proceed along an enclosed track. Continue on to reach a metal gate. Pass thru the metal gate and continue along an enclosed walled track, which descends gently with views to the R, across the Grwyne Fawr and over to the Sugar Loaf. Towards the bottom the track is joined by a concrete lane coming in from the L. Continue down the roughly surfaced road as it approaches some farm buildings. Follow the road past the whitewashed cottages.

 

3
 

1
 
4. Sharp L. Not far past the cottages, and just before a tarmac lane on your L, and next to a telegraph pole, TL to follow a muddy track and then go thru a metal gate. Avoid side turnings to a quarry (R) and ascend steadily on the track that bends right though oak, holly and hazel trees, fence is on your L. As the road levels out enjoy south facing views over Cwm Coed-y-Cerrig and the National Nature Reserve, managed by the Countryside Council for Wales. Tbe boggy area in the bottom of the valley includes many alder trees and offers a good habitat for frogs. Higher up the hillside, towards the course of our walk, drier terrain supports mixed woodland including oak, ash, beech and hazel. The secretive Dormouse can be found here, so look out! On the highest section of the route you use the slight diversion that goes around the house. A gate leads to a walled lane, which descends thru the trees and joins the road. TR to walk down the road to the car park.

4
 
 

 


Walk 34 Ledbury to Frith Wood

Last walked in February 2016

 

Description. 8 km (4.9 miles). A delightful all-seasons walk. The outward walk is along tracks and footpaths which - even if the grass dampens your trousers - do not usually get muddy.

Start. The Market House, Ledbury. Explorer Map 190. Grid 711377.

Directions from Whitecross Roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A4110 Canon Pyne (Three Elms road) for 1 mile and TR at the traffic lights onto the A4103 Worcester (Roman road). After 7.7 miles TR, signposted to Stoke Edith. After 9 miles TL at road junction (not sign posted) onto main road to Ledbury. Reach roundabout at 15.9 miles and go straight across heading for the Town Centre. Go thru town centre and at 16.9 miles TR at the clock tower that is on the R (on the L is the Market House), and go a little way down Bye Street to TL into a car park.

 

1. Ledbury Market House. The Market House dominates the centre of Ledbury. The celebrated Kings Carpenter, John Abel, built this brick and timber structure in 1653. Its original use was as a grain store, and it is now used as a council meeting room. Leave the Market House by going up Church Street - care! not Church Lane! Church Street was formerly called Hallend, then Back Lane. This road was probably the beginning of the early route from Ledbury to Worcester. The road climbs a little, and as it turns L, you continue straight ahead on a steeper pedestrian pathway. (A plaque built into the wall at low level tells you this is Green Lane, an ancient packhorse road to Worcester.) After 150 yards or so you reach track junctions, (a green metal bench and a rubbish bin is opposite), take the wide track going broadly straight ahead, keeping the bench to your R as you do so, (ignore the smaller track on your L). Continue along the enclosed wide track, staying just inside the wood and passing the odd bench or two to sit down on.

 

2. Minor Road. When the track meets a road, go straight across to a road opposite which immediately bends R and goes down hill before turning L. There are views on your L down to Ledbury Railway Station, a truly 'Thomas the Tank Engine' type railway station, with a small wooden ticket office and waiting room. A little further on the road bends to the R and a short distance further you go thru a small metal kissing gate on your L, signed as footpaths LR21 and L19. Continue in the same direction as before, keeping to the R of the metal gate, and walk along the top edge of a field, keeping the boundary fence/wood to your immediate R. The path then goes thru a small metal gate, ignore the wooden gate on the L, and go thru a small garden of a house. As you go thru another metal gate into an orchard you turn sharp R. Keep to the edge of the field as it goes up and turns L. Keeping the wood on your R you then continue along the field boundary until you arrive at the end of the orchard field R next to a road on your L. Dont go onto the road just yet but keep in the same direction, following way markers as a track goes slightly into the wood and passes a house on the L and meets up with the road further along.

3. Road. TR and go along the road. Pass a house on the R and then reach a house on the L, the last house along the road/drive (but not the last building). Opposite this house and on your R you go round a wooden gate and follow the track, signposted the Geopark Way. The track will soon have a wire fence on your L, which you follow; this eventually meets up with a wide track where you TL and continue on to meet up with a road. When you get to the road you do a U turn to your R and go over a stile, signed as footpath CW57, and into a field. Walk up and across the field, heading for wooden gates that are at the end of Frith Wood. Go thru the gate(s) and continue along the path ahead of

4
 
you. And on thru the wood.

 

3
 
4. Frith Wood. It is mixed woodland with oak, silver birch, rowan, ash, beech, sycamore and holly (once grown as fodder for sheep, cattle and deer). The wood is rich in bird life and the quiet walker may see a variety of species from the quiet tree creeper to the flamboyant jays and magpies. There is a cross of paths, ensure you go straight ahead, and continue upwards on a narrow, sometimes muddy path signposted Top Walk - DO NOT take the broad track going L or R. Continue in the same direction and ignore any way marked tracks L or R, continue up and along the ridge for about a kilometre until you eventually reach the end of the track at a track junction, by a sign saying Bradlow Knoll, the highest point in the woods. TL, and go down a well-made flight of 54 steps. Follow the track and go thru a small wooden gate and down some wooden steps into a field. Go down the R hand edge of the field and thru a metal gate at the bottom, down a short enclosed green lane and thru a wooden gate and onto the road where you TR.

 

5
 
5. Cut Throat Lane. At the T junction - a nameplate says you are on Cut Throat Lane - go straight across, round a gate and continue along the broad track which takes you straight back to the Town Centre. (When you reach the forked track junction by the green bench take the L fork).

1
 

2
 
 

 

 


Walk 35 Hay-on-Wye, Mouse Castle Wood and Cusop

Last walked in September 2016

 

Description. 8 km (4.9 miles). Starting from Hay-on-Wye, this pleasant and easy paced walk goes across fields, thru woods and by riverside meadows in the gentle rolling countryside of the Wye Valley immediately below the northern slopes of the Black Mountains.

Start. Hay-on-Wye car park. Explorer Map OL13. Grid 231423

Directions from Whitecross Roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A438 towards Brecon, turning L after 12.1 miles. At 19.7 miles TL onto the B4351 to Hay-on-Wye. At the T junction, [21 miles], you TR to Brecon, and at 21.2 miles you TL for the car park which is two hundred yards on your R.

 

1. Hay-on-Wye. TR out of the car park along the road and after 50m TR again, at an Offa's Dyke Path sign, walk down an enclosed path. Go thru metal kissing gate into a field {F1} and continue along its L hand edge. A third of the way along the field you TL over a stile and walk along the L-hand edge of {F2}, to climb another stile to the L of a bungalow. Keep ahead for a few meters, TL in front of a row of cottages to join a road, turn sharp R along it and follow the road for about 1.2 km, (as the road bends to the L you pass a road on your R for Michael Church and Longtown, its about km further on from here, no pavements). Just beyond the drive for the farm building of Wrens Nest, which is on the R, (across the road is a cattle grid drive for The Bricklands Cusop), TR over a stile. Head uphill along the R hand edge of a field, by a ditch, and head towards the woods. Bear slightly L at the top end of the field to climb a stile into a newly planted wood and follow a steep, narrow, uphill path thru it, (initially there is a fence on your R). Continue uphill following way mark signs thru woodland to reach a wooden bridle gate and stile, (on your L is a small metal gate). Cross over the stile, keep ahead for about 80m looking out carefully for a fork in the track and the way marked sign, here you TR uphill, soon bearing L to continue along the top R-hand edge of Hawks Wood, (a wire fence is on your R). Eventually you reach a small wooden gate that you go thru into {F3}, and a few meters ahead you TR thru a metal gate into {F4}.

 

2. Wire Fence. Keep along the R-hand edge of {F4}, by a wire fence and hedge. At the end of the field climb a stile onto a narrow lane. To the R can be seen the tree covered motte of Mouse Castle. TL to follow the twisting lane downhill and after a particularly sharp bend to the R you reach a footpath sign on the R, (before a white house). Turn sharp R onto a narrow track and cross a footbridge and then go thru a small wooden gate. TL and carry on down the track by a wire fence on your L, initially thru woodland. Pass thru another wooden gate into {F5} and continue along the outside edge of the woodland, which is on your R. After 20m, (by a way marked post), you bear L and continue downhill across the field, (there is no visible path here), to pass thru a gap in the hedge in front, into {F6}. Continue in the same direction; bearing slightly R across this field, making for a stile/metal gate at the fence corner in front. Go over the stile/metal gate into {F7} and continue along the L hand edge of this field to reach a wooden footbridge on your L that crosses a brook. Cross over the footbridge and head up hill to cross over a stile onto a road. Go directly across the road to climb a stile opposite, into {F8}. Bear R across the field, and go along the L hand edge, to go up and over a wooden step stile/metal gate into {F9}. Continue in the same direction across this field, bearing away from the hedge on the R and making towards the house seen ahead. Go thru a kissing-gate by a finger post to enter Cusop churchyard, dominated by the huge, ancient yew tree near the south porch of the church and with a pleasantly remote and peaceful atmosphere.

 

3
 

2
 

1
 
3. St Marys Church. Walk Past the church to go though the lych-gate and keep straight ahead along a narrow road. The mound in the field on the L is all that remains of Cusop Castle. Follow the road, which bears R and heads downhill thru trees to join another minor road. Bear R along this though Cusop village and, just after passing a road junction on the R, TL by the side of a house called Rosedale. Soon you bear R, at a footbridge sign, and go along a tarmac track heading downhill. Cross a concrete footbridge, continue between cottages and climb some step to go thru a metal kissing-gate into {F10}. Continue in the same direction for 30m and TR thru another metal kissing gate in the wall and into {F11}, where you walk along the L hand edge. Hay-on-Wye is directly in front. At the field end you go thru a metal kissing gate into {F12}, and turn half-L and head diagonally across this large field, in the corner of which you go thru a kissing gate and into the car park.

 

 

Walk 36 Hereford and Dinedor Hill

Last walked in October 2016

 

Description. 10 km (6.2 miles). Dinedor Hill is the prominent hill (600ft) lying to the south east of Hereford.

Start. Hereford. Grid reference Explorer Map 189 Grid 508397.

Direction. Start in Hereford Leisure Pool car park.

 

1. Hereford Leisure Pool. Hereford is a cathedral city; the cathedral dates from 1079 and contains the Mappa Mundi, a medieval map of the world dating from the 13th century that was restored in the late 20th century. It also contains the world famous Chained Library. Hereford city was the home of the British Special Air Service (SAS) for many years, although the Regiment relocated to nearby Credenhill in the late 1990s. With your back at the leisure pool main entrance, bear R as you walk away from the leisure pool and TR to walk along a tree lined tarmac path going thru Bishops Meadow park towards the river. On reaching the river and the suspension footbridge called Victoria Bridge you TR. Continue along the riverside path, (the river is on your L). At the end of the meadow ignore the path going off to the R and keep on the riverside path to its end, passing the backs of houses, the path will then TR and go up to a road. Keep ahead along the road, pass a miniature roundabout and continue on for a few meters, take the first turning on the L (Putson Avenue) and walk thru suburban housing. When the road bends to the R continue on thru an alleyway (cycle route to Rotherwas) for a short way and at the end of the alleyway TR. Follow a stream (L), going along another short cycle route and cross the stream onto a main road.

 

2. Lower Bullingham Lane. TL and, soon after passing the Wye Inn on the L, TR along Lower Bullingham Lane. Follow this lane for 1.2 km, crossing over Windsor Road and then passing under a railway bridge and climbing gently to a T Junction at Green Crize. Cross over the main road and climb a stile/metal gate, at a footpath sign, to follow a path across a field {F1}, descending to cross a brook into {F2} and climbing the other side to farm buildings, going thru a small metal gate onto a (private) tarmac lane. Continue along the lane for a short distance to reach a minor road where you TL, and continue on, again for short distance, thru the hamlet of Bullinghope.

 

3. St Peter Church. Before you get to the church and just before reaching a black and white house on the L called Church House, TL over a stile, by a footpath sign and continue on for a short distance to cross over another stile into {F3}. Continue along a clear, broad track that heads downhill across fields, slightly to the L is a good view of Dinedor Hill. At the bottom of the field you go thru a small wooden gate and across a footbridge and TL, after a few paces you TR to continue on thru a gap thats next to double metal gates, and crossover a main road. Go thru a small wooden gate into {F4} and continue in the same direction, straight across the field, to cross a stile into {F5}. Continue up hill by a hedge and orchard on the L, to go thu wooden gate onto a road. TL, walk down the road to a T Junction.

2
 

1
 

1

 
 
4. T Junction. Cross over the main road in front and thru a small metal gate by a footpath sign and into {F6). Head downhill keeping roughly parallel to a hedge on the L, to cross over a stile and then to cross a gated footbridge over a brook into {F7}. Continue up hill along the L hand edge of a field, to go thru a small metal gate at the top onto a tarmac lane. Continue up the lane for a few meters and bear R into the woods, going steeply uphill along a well defined track to reach a narrow road where you TL. Follow the road and after about 100m, by a house called The Laurels, the road bends R and goes up hill, (straight on is a no thru tarmac lane) and continues up to the top of Dinedor Hill, reached by a short flight of steps. The views from the summit, which is crowned by superb old beeches on the site of an Iron Age fort that is now a picnic area, are both extensive and magnificent: northwards towards Hereford and southwards over the gentle rolling, wooded country of the Wye Valley. Retrace your steps downhill to The Laurels and TR, to go down the no thru tarmac lane. Follow this for just over 800m descending gently, passing several cottages, (ignore the track thats just past some power lines that forks off down to the L). Later on the lane turns into a mud track and keeps along the edge of woodland thats on the R.

 

5
 

4
 

3
 
5. Houses. You will eventually bear L in front of houses to walk down a tarmac lane/drive to reach a main road. Cross over the road and TR, walk along for a few meters and TL to continue along a tarmac road for over a kilometre, going under a railway bridge and continuing past farms and houses to a T-junction, here rejoining Lower Bullingham Lane. TR for a few meters to the main road and TL to retrace the outward route. [return route: About 100 yds, just passed the Wye Inn, TR, cross the brook into FC Morgan Close. TL at the end of the garages, go along the Cycle Route alleyway to Putson Avenue and TR. End of road TR, down to river TL. Continue on to Victoria Bridge and TL to car park.]

 

 

Walk 37 Hill and Lake Around Boddingham

Last walked in October 2016

 

Description. 5 km (3.1 miles). A moderate walk with some steep slopes thru wooded area, along a lake and across country.

Start. Bodenham. Grid reference Explorer Map 202 Grid 530509.

Directions from Whitecross roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A4110 to Canon Pyne (Three Elms road) and after 1 mile, at traffic lights, you TR onto the A4103 to Worcester (Roman road). At the second roundabout, 3.2 miles, you TL to Bodenham. Go thru Bodenham and at 9.4 miles, just before Englands Gate Inn, you TL to Bodenham Church, (if you reach the main T Junction road you have gone to far). At 10.3 miles you TL by a memorial cross and head towards the church. You can park-up on the R hand side, near to the end of the road and opposite a school, total of 10.4 miles.

 

1. Bodenham church. Continue on to the end of the no thru road, which bends R then L to reach the church lych-gate. The parish church of St Michael and All Angels at Bodenham is set in a beautiful location beside the peaceful River Lugg. The church is primarily 14th century, in the Decorated Gothic style. In the 12th Century, Bodenhams Church was dedicated to St Mary (Our Lady) rather than to St Michael as it is today. Enter the churchyard thru a lych-gate. TL and walk along the edge of the churchyard to go thru a kissing gate in the corner into a field{F1}. Continue in the same direction, keeping to the fence on your L; pass a school sports field to reach the fence corner. Carry on in the same direction and cross the field, going thru the gap in the hedge ahead, into {F2}. Continue across the field and go thru a wooden kissing gate in the far R hand corner. Follow the path for a short distance and go thru another wooden kissing gate. Carry on along the R edge of the field, keeping to the chopped down tree line, and go thru another wooden kissing gate onto the main road.

 

2. (Pigeon House). TL along road for a short distance then TR onto a bridleway by Bank House. As you approach the next house, Bunhill, you TL, to wander up an enclosed green lane thats a Public Bridleway. At the end of the enclosed green lane you pass thru a metal gate into {F3}. Bear R and go uphill, keeping the wide grassy ditch and a few trees on your R side, to reach the field end. Go thru a metal gate and continue on along the wide grassy ditch to go thru another metal gate into {F4}. Continue in the same direction, with the woods on your L, and go thru a metal gate into {F5}. At the end of {F5}, by the corner of the woods, go thru a metal gate and onto a stony tree lined farm track, (or walk over the cattle grid which is off to your R).

3. (Henhouse). Just before the farm buildings, by a circular plantation of trees on youre L, TL and cross over the field. TL and walk alongside the fence on your R, and after about 130m you TR across a stile into the woods. Follow a woodland path downhill, after about 70m you go down six wooden steps to reach a prominent track where you TL, walk about 15m then TR and continue down a smaller track. Continue down the track, pass a stile and more wooden steps to finally emerge onto the road by Bodenham Manor entrance. TL, continue along the road and TR thru the first metal gate into an orchard. Bear R as you walk downhill to the Lady Close Orchard commemorative stone in the middle.

 

4. Boddingham Lake. Continue diagonally across the field to reach the end, and go thru the smaller of two wooden gates. A wooden signpost on your L shows you the direction for the Bird Hide. Continue ahead with the lake on your L to visit the Bird Hide. Bodenham Lake Nature Reserve is 110 acres of varied habitat including riverside meadows, veteran orchard, newly planted orchard, a 'gravel' area and wet woodland and the lake itself is the largest area of open water in the county. It is a very relaxing, tranquil place to visit with breath-taking views across the great expanse of water, a perfect place to come on a lazy afternoon to have a picnic! It is a very important winter-feeding area for wildfowl with approximately half of the site managed as a nature reserve, with no public access, but you can stroll thru the beautiful orchards and meadows and on to the bird hide where you can sit and watch the birds on the lake. When you are ready, retrace your steps back to the signpost.

 

3
 

2
 

1
 

4/5
 
5. Bodenham Sailing Centre. TR and go thru the smaller of two wooden gates, then after a short distance you reach Bodenham Sailing Centre compound. TL, continue along a wide stony track to reach a picnic table and signboard on your L, (there are metal gates in front, which you dont go thru). Bear R and continue along the wide stony track to pass thru the smaller of two metal gates, and head on towards a tall hedgerow of conifer trees. Continue along the track, pass a black and white house on your L, then draw level with the church, now one field away, to go thru the smaller of two metal gates, continue on for a few paces to reach the sign and info board on the bank of the River Lugg. TL, go thru a small wooden gate and follow the path to the church.

 

Walk 38 Ledbury

Last walked in October 2016

 

Description. 7.5 km (4.6 miles). Walking from the centre of the delightful historic market town of Ledbury takes us past the church into Coneygrove Wood and over the hill to the tiny village of Eastnor, with its beautiful early 19th-century castle.

Start. The Market House, Ledbury. Explorer Map 190. Grid 711377.

Directions from Whitecross Roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A4110 Canon Pyne (Three Elms road) for 1 mile and TR at the traffic lights onto the A4103 Worcester (Roman road). After 7.7 miles TR, signposted to Stoke Edith. After 9 miles TL at road junction (not sign posted) onto main road to Ledbury. Reach roundabout at 15.9 miles and go straight across heading for the Town Centre. Go thru town centre and at 16.9 miles TR at the clock tower on the R (Bye Street), and continue on to the car park on your L.

 

1. Ledbury. Ledbury is an ancient borough, dating back to the Domesday Book, where it was recorded as Liedeberge, and returned members to Parliament in the reign of Edward I. Ledbury probably takes its name from the River Leadon, on which it stands. From the 17th century market house, which is across the road from the clock tower, walk up the cobbled road of Church Lane (not Church Street), to pass thru the church gates at the end of the lane. TR and go around the back of the church and along the narrow lane called Cabbage Lane, (on the L hand side is a police station) to reach the main road. TL here and once past the houses cross over the road to the narrow footpath heading up into Coneygree Wood. Climb slightly and when the path divides take the waymarked L fork (the R fork is the route of our return near the end of the walk). Climb steadily and go up steps to reach a broad horizontal track, cross this and keep straight ahead, taking the lower of the two tracks. After climbing some wooden steps you reach a track T‑junction with a wide stony track which you go straight across and continue up a narrow path. Go thru a metal kissing gate into an open field {F1} where you TL. Stay close to the field margin as it bends to the R and then, when it bends again, go straight on to leave this field thru a wooden gate. Go on thru a few trees, descending slightly to go thru {F2} and continue on along the L hand border.

 

2. End of Field. At the end of the field go thru a kissing gate and thru a patch of trees as you climb slightly to be joined by a track coming in from the R. Continue in the same direction to the top of the hill, after which a slight descent and a bend to the L take us thru a metal gate and into {F3}. Continue along the track that crosses the middle of this open field and then go along a short track thru the woods and out into {F4}. Bear slightly L and follow the track down hill. The line of a farm track is our route down the hill, but when the track bends R we follow a way marker and keep straight ahead. Keep to a tree line on your R to reach the bottom R hand corner of the field where you go down some wooden steps and out onto the main road. TR, pass the church on your R, (well worth a visit), and then reach a small green, with its water fountain.

 

3. Eastnor. The road continues to the R past the water fountain on your L. TR up the driveway to Eastnor Pottery. Eastnor Castle was constructed between 1812-20 at a cost of 85,000 or equivalent to approximately between 6 to 28 million in present day (2007). The estate was started in the late 16th century when the Cocks family purchased local land. Pass the pottery and continue along the driveway and up along a stony track. Go past a military parade of tall trees on the R that seem to be in perfect alignment. When the track bends to the L you continue on for about 150m and then go thru a small metal gate on your R, into {F5}. Head diagonally to the L across the field and up to the far corner where you go thru the metal gate thats to the R of buildings. Continue along the track for a short distance to reach the next metal gate, but dont go thru it, TR along a narrow footpath that goes along the edge of the wood, after a short distance you go thru a wooden gate into {F6}. Go diagonally R, cross the field, heading for the bottom far R hand corner where you go thru a small wooden gate, over a plank of wood and thru another small wooden gate into the woods. Follow the indistinct path ahead that soon meets up with a more distinct track that goes up to meet a track junction at the edge of the trees, (a Forestry Commission notice board is on the L that says Conigree Wood).

 

4
 

3
 

1
 
4. Forestry Commission. TR, go up the track. When it levels off slightly at a cross paths, the main track keeps straight ahead, and rising, but we TL here. Follow the path leading thru to an old avenue of beech trees, and soon views over Ledbury begin to open up down to the L. After a slight rise the footpath divides and we take the L fork, keeping nearer the edge of the woods. A large grassy field slopes down to the town, and this is part of the former estate of Ledbury Park. Walk along the edge of the woods until the path broadens out and is floored by stone in places (some of which contains fossils). Continue along the broad track and stay close to a stone wall which appears on your L. You leave the broad track to take a narrow path that goes off to the L by the wall. Quite sunken, this path leads us down to join a path to the R, which was the route of our outward journey. But we keep straight ahead down a few small steps, to reach the road and TL back into Ledbury to the start of the walk.

 

Walk 39 The Central Ridge Beacon

Last walked in October 2016

 

Description. A 9 km (5.6 miles) walk. Views from the ridge are hardly less inspiring than those from greater heights, and the approach from Colwall and the return have sufficient twists and turns to maintain interest.

Start. Brockhill Road, Colwall. Explorer Map 190. Grid 758430.

Directions from Whitecross Roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). From Whitecross roundabout[0m]: Take the A4110 Canon Pyne (Three Elms road) for 1 mile and TR at the traffic lights onto the A4103 Worcester (Roman road). After 7.7 miles TR, signposted to Stoke Edith. After 9 miles TL at T junction (not sign posted) onto main road to Ledbury. Reach roundabout at 15.9 miles and go straight across heading for the Town Centre. Go thru the town centre and near the end, at 16.9 miles, TL at the traffic lights to Malvern on the A449. Stay on the A449 and at 19.8 miles TL onto the B4218 to Colwall. Go straight thru Colwall and just passed the village, at 22 miles you reach a triangle green on the L hand side which has a small shelter in the middle, a few yards further along on the L hand side, by a red post box you TL and park along Brockhill Road.

 

1. Colwall. Colwall is a village and civil parish in Herefordshire, on the border with Worcestershire, nestling into the side of the Malvern Hills. Areas of the village are known as Colwall Stone, Upper Colwall and Colwall Green along over a mile of the B4218 road. From Brockhill Road return to the main drag (Walwyn Road) and TL. Walk up the main road for 200m and TR to walk along Broadwood Drive, which is the first road on the R. Continue to the end of this road. In front and off to the R is a metal gate and stepping-stones that are fixed in the wall, cross over the walled stepping-stones and into field 1 {F1}. Continue along a track on the R side of the field, and after passing a wooden farm shed on your L you go thru a metal gate/stile. TL, go thru a gate gap and TR (Dog-leg L then R), to continue in the same direction, fence is on your R. Follow way markers, initially you keep R of the tree line then you go thru open woods. The track bends sharply to the R just before reaching a kissing gate at the end of the woods. Go thru the gate into {F2} and continue on along a track, keeping woods on your R. Go thru a metal gate into {F3} and continue along the R field edge. Go thru a metal gate and along an enclosed tarmac drive, to reach a T-junction by a minor road.

 

1
 
2. Minor Road. TL. 200m along the road and just before Upper House, you TR and go thru a wooden gate/stile and along and enclosed track. Pass thru another wooden gate/stile and then cross over a stile into {F4}. Cross this field to reach a protruding fenced corner, and continue on to the end of the fence thats on your L. Continue in the same direction, going thru a

4
 
coppice, to reach the board walk by a way marked pole. Continue in the same direction, going into {F5}. Continue in the same direction to cross over a way marked stile into {F6}. Climb up the field and cross over a stile into some woods. Continue up thru the woods to reach the main road at British Camp, opposite the Malvern Hill

1
 
Hotel.

3. British Camp. TL and walk to the end of the path, (about 40m), then TR and cross the road to climb up a track thats on the other side. Take the R track that climbs steeply up, and then walk along the track that has a number of wooden benches along its route. The path bends to the L to join the main ridge, with the Worcester-shire countryside spread out below. Simply follow the ridge, either along its very spine or the paths that contours below the crest.

 

2
 
4. Descent. Eventually the descent to the main road has to be made. TL at the main road and follow the road around then take the R hand fork along the B4218 to Colwall and back to the start point which is about 1 km away.

 

3
 
 

 


Walk 40 Dorstone

Last walked in November 2016

 

Description. A 10 km (6 mile) walk. From the old village of Dorstone set in the beautiful Golden Valley, this walk crosses farmland and rises to the edge of the open hilltop of Merbach Hill.

Start. The Pandy Inn, Dorstone. Park at the Village Hall. Explorer Map OL13. Grid 314416.

Directions from Whitecross Roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A438 Brecon road and after 9.1 miles TL towards Bredwardine. TL at a T-junction by the Red Lion Hotel, signposted for Madley B4352 [10.8m]. Take the first turning R onto Pentre Lane, signed Dorstone 2 [11.2m]. Continue up and over the hill on a narrow road to reach a T-junction and bear R, [12.8m] to continue on the A4348 to Dorstone. Take first L for Dorstone [13m]. At the end of the road, a T-junction, you TR signed for Pandy Inn [13.2m]. A little further on your L, park by Dorstone Village Hall, a total of 13.4 miles.

 

1. Dorstone. The village of Dorstone lies at the head of Herefordshire's beautiful Golden Valley. A little to one side of the Village Hall is the Pandy Inn, which is reputed to be the oldest pub in the county. An old motte and bailey is located behind the Pandy Inn. Dating from around 1185 The Pandy is said to have been built by Sir Richard de Brito during his construction of the neighbouring village church, in penance for the murder of Archbishop Thomas a Beckett. With your back to the Village Hall; TL, walk a short distance and turn sharp R, to walk along Chapel Lane, passing the small village green (R), (with its tall sun dial that was formerly a village cross). At the first road junction TL and go down Church Road, (No Thru Road), heading towards a red telephone box. Continue on across a stream and up an enclosed track thats to the L of the church of St Faith, with its short squat 13th century tower, to reach a main road. The church was built in 1827, in the old church warden style, and dedicated to St. Faith, but being of such a poor structure, was replaced in 1889 with the large edifice, built in the Early English style that we see today, at a cost of 2,162. Three of the church bells are 300 years old; the other is 500 years old. At the road you TR, walk for a few metres then TL and cross the road to go thru a kissing gate. Pass the Bowling Green and fork slightly L across a sports field, heading towards a marker post (public footpath), to cross a footbridge and go thru a small metal gate. Cross a track and go over a footbridge. Continue ahead to the far L corner of the field {F1}, to reach a small metal gate and a track (Spoon Lane). Cross the track, go up a few steps, thru a small metal gate into {F2} and head for the top L hand corner to reach a road. TL and head for Llan Farm. As you start to go thru the farmyard, and just before the farmhouse you TR, then you go thru a metal gate onto a farm track that climbs steadily. Continue on the enclosed farm track to go thru a metal gate into {F3}. Bear diagonally R to cross a stile onto a narrow road.

 

2. Narrow Road. TL and after a few paces TR to cross a stile into {F4} and head up the R hand side of the field. Cross a stile in the corner of the field and walk out onto a track where you TL, after 60 yards TR over another stile. Keeping to the R hand side you go up two fields {F5}{F6} to reach a narrow road by a house where you TL. When the road turns R, go straight ahead thru the gate and continue along the track and when this bends L, keep straight ahead, and keep the remnants of a former hedge on your L. Continue along the former hedge/tree line until you pass thru a small wooden gate thats slightly off to the R, to then continue on and reach the triangular point (318m. 1043ft.) at the top of the red sandstone Merbach Hill. TR here, but first enjoy the wonderful all round views Malverns, River Wye, Clee Hill, Hay Bluff.

 

 

4
 

3
 
3. Merbach Hill Trig Point. Follow the track thats nearest to the shrub/bushes/trees on your L as it starts going downhill then levels off slightly, and continue on to reach a metal gate thats by a Merbach Hill Common notice board. TR and keep to the fence/tree line on your L until you reach two wooden gates, (one large and one small) on your L, TL, go thru the gates and continue along a well define enclosed bridleway to reach a narrow tarmac road on a R angled bend. TR and climb slightly as you continue along the road to reach the second driveway on your L, which is a Public Bridleway to New Farm.

 

5
 

2
 

2
 
4. Farm Drive. TL and cross the cattle grid to walk along the concrete drive to New Farm. Just beyond the farm house, TR and go thru a metal gate and then immediately TL to continue in the same direction as before. With the hedge on your L you pass thru two fields {F7}{F8} and two gates to reach a small clump of fir trees. Here you TR, and with the hedge on your R you head across the field to go thru a metal gate into {F9}. Continue along the L side of this field to go thru a gate onto a narrow road. TL here and walk as far as Arthurs Stone.

 

5. Arthurs Stone. TR and go over the stile/metal gate into {F10} and cross the field to cross another stile/metal gate and onto the line of a farm track, which leads us downhill. Continue downhill, with the hedge on your R, to go thru another stile/metal gate. A pond is now down on your L hand side as you descend to cross another stile/metal gate into the last field, which you continue down to go thru a metal gate in the bottom R corner where you get onto a well defined farm track. Follow the line of this track down thru the fields and the odd house to reach the road to Dorstone. At this four-way road junction you keep straight ahead and carry on along the B4348. Pass the road junction on your L to Dorstone and continuing along the twisting road until you reach a church on your L, just passed the church is the track you started on.

1
 
 

 

 


Walk 41 Bishops Frome

Last walked in November 2016

 

Description. A 7 km (4.3 mile) strenuous walk. Climb a small hill, where spectacular views open up, and continue through farmland with orchards, hop fields, crops and pasture.

Start. The churchyard in Bishops Frome. Park behind the village hall close to the church. Explorer Map 202. Grid 663484.

Directions from Whitecross Roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). From Whitecross roundabout[0m]: Take the A4110 Canon Pyon (Three Elms road). After 1 mile at traffic lights TR. Continue on the A4103 towards Worcester and at 13.1 mile, (the bottom of Fromes Hill), TL onto the B4214 signed Bishops Frome 1. At 14 miles, just passed the church on the R, TR and park in the village centre car park.

 

1. Bishops Frome. Out of the car park onto the main road and TL, after about 40 meters TL and walk thru the churchyard, passing to the R of the church, to go thru a kissing gate and out of the churchyard. St Marys church dates from the 12th century though little remains from that time a notable fragment is the round arc of the south door. The font is Norman, and the tower is 14th century. The parish church contains a font over 700 years old and is approached thru a handsome lychgate. A memorial in the church features the carved figure of a knight in armour, sword in hand and a lion at his feet. Continue in the same direction to cross a bridge over the river Frome. Bear slightly R and cross over a large field {F1} to a kissing gate. Go thru the kissing gate, over a small footbridge and across {F2} to cross a stile onto a tarmac driveway. Cross the driveway and go over a stile ahead into {F3}. Go thru the middle of a field and thru a gateway gap, (which is just by a wooden electric pylon), into {F4}. Carry on, keeping to the tree line on your R, and at the end of the field you cross over a stile into a narrow enclosed grassy path. At the end of the path you cross another stile onto a narrow road.

 

2. Road. Cross the road and go over two stiles into {F4}. Keep the tree line/fence on your R as you gradually begin to climb and at the end of the field you cross a stile and continue along an enclosed path for a short distance and reach a narrow road. Cross the road, go over a stile and straight on up and enclosed track, wood is on your R and initially a fence is on your L. When you get to the end of the garden fence on your L you go into the woods on a steeper climb, following way markers to the top where there is a small wooden gate on your R, (ignore the stile straight ahead). Go thru the small wooden gate into {F5} and TR. Walk alongside the outside edge of the wood, which is on your R. Continue along the edge of the wood/field and just before reaching the bottom R hand corner of the field, (a white house can be seen directly in front of you), look for the gap in the hedge/trees on your R, (immediately past an electric wooden pylon in the hedge), and TR to go over a stile, then down a few steps onto a gravel drive where you TL and go thru a large wooden gate onto a road. TL, climbing slightly at first, follow this road for about a kilometre, passing under high voltage national grid cables, until you reach a tall radio mast on your R. TR at a bridleway sign to pass thru the small wooden gate thats next to a large metal gate, into {F6} and walk on past the R hand side of the radio mast, staying close to the field boundary.

 

3
 

2
 

1
 
3. Three Fields. With fence/hedge on your R, proceed thru this small field and two more {F7}{F8} and then, after a short distance, go thru a small wooden gate which is on your R hand side into {F9}. Keep straight ahead but now with the hedge on your L. At the end of the field you go thru a large metal gate into {F10} and TR. Stay close to the hedge/fence on your R; descend slightly to the end of the field but dont go thru the metal gate, cross over the stile which is in the R hand corner of the field, by the fence. A few paces further on you TR and walk along the top edge of {F11}, (the tree line/fence is on your R), to reach the R hand corner where you then cross a stile (a large stone slab is to the R). Walk along a ditch, (fence is on the L) and continue on, to walk along the edge of {F12} and reach another stile. Cross the stile, TL and descend down a track that keeps to the L hand side of the wood. At the end of the wood cross a stile into {F13} and continue on down hill, keeping to the fence on your L, until you reach Cheyney Court which isnt seen until you are nearly on it. Bear L and cross a very trendy stile with two rungs that lift up to enable small people to cross with ease. Walk on down the drive passing to the L of the recently modernised Cheyney Court and at the road (sign to Cheyney Park and Chapel) TR. Reach a T-junction and TL, walk down the road. Near the bottom you pass a house on your R that was an old mill, also recently modernised. 50m further on you cross over a river bridge (river Frome), and TR at the way marker post to go thru a gap in the hedge into {14}. Follow the R field edge, keeping close to the river. At the end of this large field, over on the L side, is the old Vicarage. TL to walk thru the kissing gate, thru the churchyard and out onto the road where you TR, and back to the car.

 

 

Walk 42 The Cradley Brook

Last walked in November 2016

 

Description. A 7 km (4.3 miles). A pleasant stroll for a summer's evening or a winter's afternoon.

Start. Stifforde Bridge on the A4103. Explorer Map 190. Grid 734481.

Directions from Whitecross Roundabout (turn milometer to zero). From Whitecross roundabout[0m]: Take the A4110 Canon Pyne (Three Elms road) for 1 mile and TR at the traffic lights onto the A4103 Worcester (Roman road). After 18 miles you pass the Red Lion Inn on the R, a little further on you can park up on the R hand side of the road.

 

1. Red Lion Inn. Walk back towards Hereford on the A4103, over the bridge and past the Red Lion Inn (L). 50m past the Red Lion, TL and walk along an enclosed track thats at the end of a tall wooden fence and garden. Cross over a stile into field 1 {F1}; keep the fence on your L and cross another stile in the corner of a field into an orchard. Continue in the same direction, keep to the fence on your L and at the end of the orchard you go thru a small metal gate to cross a track/ driveway and on thru a kissing gate into {F2}. With the hedge on your L, continue downhill, crossing over two stiles separated by a tarmac driveway and into {F3}. Keep hedge on your L as you continue in the same direction (ignore the stile on the L). At the bottom of the hill follow the fence around to the R. Cross a way marked stile/metal gate (L) into {F4}, and continue up hill following a gully thats on your L. At the end of {F4} you continue on thru the gully. Cross a stile, and continue on thru an enclosed path. Cross over a tarmac road and continue along a well-defined track. Cross over another tarmac road and go thru a small wooden gate and along an enclosed track with wall/trees on your R.

 

2. Wooden Footbridge. Cross over a wooden footbridge into {F5}; keep to the hedge on your R and go thru a kissing gate and onto an enclosed farm track. There is a house on your L. Continue in the same direction as you follow the way mark sign and pass thru a metal gate into {F6}, fence/hedge is now on your L. Keep to the hedge as it bends to the L. Cross over a stile and a wooden bridge into {F7} and continue up, keeping hedge then wooden fence to your L. At the end of the wooden fence/field TL thru a kissing gate. After a few metres TR along a driveway and out onto a road. TL, go along the road and over a bridge, pass a gate on the R sign Overley, and about 50m further on TR to cross over a stile into {F8}. Bear slightly R as you cross the field, and after about 100m you TR at a way marker post, heading towards the woods and a church that is beyond the wooded area. At the edge of this field you cross over a well defined stone track (to Overley) and across a stile to continue on, to cross over a stone footbridge into {F9}. Cross the field and head towards the L hand side of a church to a kissing gate. Continue along an enclosed track to the main road.

 

3. School House. TL and walk along main road passing a school house on the L and then just passed a black and white house called Badgers, TL thru a wooden gate to follow an enclosed public footpath signed for Cradley mile. Cross a wooden footbridge and continue onto a tarmac drive where you TR. Continue up the drive for about 250m, and when it bends to the L by a gate, TR and walk up 7 wooden steps and into {F10}. Go straight across the field to cross over a stile and TL, walk along a track, keeping a fence on your L. Some way along the track goes thru two wooden sleepers. Keep fence on your L as you go slightly downhill to reach a drive and metal gate that leads to the red-bricked farmhouse. TR, walk away from the farm house and along the track, the fence is on your L, (you pass a small corrugated shed (L). Go thru a metal gate into {F11}. TL and follow the track towards the woods, after about 80m and just before the track bends R, TL into the woods to go thru a small wooden gate and across a footbridge. Cross over a stile and TL to follow a track, which will bend around to the R, (ignore the way marked track that crosses the river to your L). Keep the stream on your L, further on you cross another stile out of the woods and into {F12}, (ignore the track near to the stile that goes off to the R). Walk along the middle of the field and TL after about

1
 
120m to cross over a stone bridge and head towards a church. Cross a couple of fields and a stile to go thru metal gates and onto a wide enclosed stone track.

 

4
 

2
 
4. Cradley. Continue along the track/road; pass a fifteenth century former school and an old church on your R to reach a war memorial by a main road. Cradley is the largest Parish in Herefordshire. It has St James Church that existed before the Normans came; it is set in beautiful traditional English country surroundings. Cradley Village Hall, is a 16th Century timbered building, recently renovated and restored after a serious fire destroyed a large part of the roof. Bear slightly L and follow the road downhill towards Mathon. After about 100m you TR and cross a stile to continue along and enclosed footpath which is just passed Old School Close. Continue along to the end of the track, crossing another two stiles to reach the road by Brook Cottage which is on the L. TR, the stream is on your R. TL at the first stile on your L thats just before the road bends to the R, and head up {F13}. Continue on with the tree line on your L and cross a stile by a wooden gate and carry on down to the tarmac road. TR and continue along the road to the first turning on the L, which is a drive. TL and walk along the drive to cross a stile/wooden gate and walk along an enclosed track. Carry on thru three large fields, keeping the river on your L, to reach the main road where you TR to walk up to the waiting car.

 

 

 

 

 

3
 
 

 


Walk 43 Ragg Stone and Chase End Hills

Last walked in November 2016

 

Description. 7 km (4.3 miles). The final undulations of the Malvern Hills manifest themselves as Ragged Stone and Chase End Hills. Lower than, and detached from, the main ridge, they tend to be less well trodden, and this adds to their quiet charms. Attractive at any time of year, but especially in autumn, this short walk can form an absorbing introduction to the southern Malverns.

Start. Hollybush (A438) Explorer Map 190. Grid 759369.

Directions from Whitecross Roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A4110 Canon Pyne (Three Elms road) for 1 mile and TR at the traffic lights onto the A4103 Worcester (Roman road). After 7.7 miles TR, signposted to Stoke Edith. After 9 miles TL at road junction (not sign posted) onto main road to Ledbury. Reach roundabout at 15.9 miles and go straight across heading for the Town Centre. Go thru town centre and TL at traffic lights onto the A449 to Malvern and Worcester (total 17 miles). After 1 mile LR onto the A438 to Eastnor and Tewkesbury (total 18 miles). After 2.9 miles just past the Hollybush signpost, on the L is a car parking area with a Countryside Information Board in it (total 21 miles).

 

1. Car Park. Walk down the road from the car park, in the direction of Tewkesbury for about 250m. Shortly before the telephone kiosk take a track to the R, which curves to the L as it goes past the old Post Office and gains height. Immediately after going thru a wooden gate, TR up a small track which heads directly (and hence quite steeply) to one of the twin summits of Ragged Stone Hill.

 

2. Ragged Stone Hill. When you get to the end of the wood on your R, ignore the hill top straight ahead and follow the edge of the wood around to the R, the track descends very slightly then rises and bears L away from the wood and up to Ragged Stone Hill top. I suppose I should have warned you that the hill is cursed. Apparently a monk at nearby Little Malvern Priory lapsed in his vow of chastity, and as a penance had to climb Ragged Stone Hill each day on his hands and knees. He was supposed to pray when he reached the summit, but one day instead he cursed the hill and all upon whom its shadow should fall. Victims are said to include Cardinal Wolsey and William Huskisson MP - the latter killed in an accident whilst Stephensons Rocket was being tested. Still, it's too late to worry about such things now. Admire the views over the Severn Vale, with Bredon Hill prominent and then traverse to the higher summit at 833ft. Views open out to the west with Eastnor Castle especially prominent when clothed in its fiery autumnal mantle of Virginia Creeper. Now descend the ridge for about km along a small rocky path (keep to the path on the L) and thru a wooded area until near the bottom you reach a track junction next to a small part of a rocky wall initialled The Ragged Stone. TR, (heading towards the wooden gate), the track bends around to the R, you pass Elsies Cottage (L) and continue on down thru a wooden gate and onto a tarmac road. This is Whiteleaved Oak - a lovely name for a delectable cluster of original and restored dwellings in one of the most tranquil spots imaginable. The hamlet straddles the boundaries of the Three Counties - Worcestershire, Gloucestershire and Herefordshire. TR along the road and immediately after the road bends L TL along a public footpath (not for horses). A little way along this track you pass Cider Mill Cottage on your L. Continue up hill along a muddy enclosed track that goes thru a small wooden gate and further on you have a stiff little climb to get to the

1
 
triangulation column at the summit of Chase End Hill (once known as Gloucestershire Beacon).

 

2
 
3. Triangulation Point. At a height of 626ft the views are particularly open to the south, to the Cotswolds, May Hill (an upturned pudding bowl with a clump of trees on the top) and on a clear day a glimpse of the Severn Estuary. TR and continue along the ridge, descending to the edge of a wood on your L. TL along a grassy track heading into the woods and keep to the L of a wire fence. Keep the wire fence to your R as you go thru the lightly wooded area for over  km along a dirt track to reach a tarmac road, you pass thru three wooden gates. When you reach the road (a house and bridge is on the R hand side) you TL.

 

4
 

3
 
4. 50m Walk. After about 50m along the road, TR at a small gap in the wood, (opposite a wooden gate). Take the track that goes off to the R and then bends around to the L to meet up with the broken down wall. Follow the wall up hill a short distance to cross a stile and emerge once more at the start of The Ragged Stone hill. Bear R, ignore the track on the L that goes uphill and take the pleasant woodland track along level ground for about a km to return you to the A438 road, ignoring a track off to the L and a wooden gated way marked public footpath on the R. When you reach the road TL and head uphill to the car park on the R.

 

 

 

 

 

 

Walk 44 Hoarwithy and Carey

Last walked in December 2016

 

Description. An excellent 7 km (4.3 miles) easy walk along well defined tracks and along the river Wye.

Start. Lay-by just east of Hoarwithy Bridge. Explorer Map 189 Grid 530509.

Directions from Belmont Roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A49 to Ross-on-Wye, after 500yds TL at traffic lights towards Holme Lacy on the B4399. After another 500 metres you TR at a mini roundabout and head for Hoarwithy. When you get to the outskirts of Hoarwithy, after 7.1 miles, TL to Kings Caple. Cross over Hoarwithy Bridge and park on the R. Total distance 7.4 miles.

 

1. Hoarwithy. Hoarwithy is a small village on the River Wye in Herefordshire, It is known for its church of St Catherine's built in an Italian Romanesque style with detached campanile. The church, on a steep hillside above the village was built to a design by J P Seddon by William Poole, the wealthy Vicar of Hentland in the 1870s. Walk west, back over Hoarwithy Bridge and past the Old Toll House on the L. Continue along to the T junction, ignoring the road on the R to Carey, and reach the Hoarwithy sign on the L, (at this point you can always visit St Catherine's church opposite). TR up hill towards Little Dewchurch and Hereford and climb for about 200m to the end of the speed restriction. TR just passed the pink house on your R and continue along an unsigned enclosed green lane to reach a tarmac road, Cleveland house is on the R. TL and after a short distance uphill, past Stoney-ways house you reach a stony bridle path to your R.

 

2. Bridle Path. TR and follow the enclosed bridle path for about a kilometer, ascending very gradually and pause intermittently for views to the receding river valley below to your R. The path emerges onto a road linking Little Dewchurch to Carey. TR and follow the quiet road down to the bottom where you TL at the T Junction. Pause in front of the Cottage of Content pub and sit by the two public benches over the little bridge and stream.

 

3. Cottage of Content. Originally The Cottage of Content was built in 1485 as three labourers cottages for the Mynor family. This was on the condition that one of the tenants kept an ale & cider parlour in one room, so the 'Cottage' has been a licensed house for quite some time. Resume along the road as it bends R to Ballingham, Holme Lacy and Hereford, the Cottage of Content is on your L, and gently walk uphill, passing The Gaer House on your R. Ignore the road to your L to Bolstone and continue straight on and over the bridge of the dismantled railway line, (look L over the parapet for the railway station, now converted to domestic use). Continue along the road for 150m to the public footpath sign on the R.

 

4. Telegraph Pole. TR at the public footpath sign which is next to a telegraph pole, cross over the stile/metal gate and follow the enclosed green lane gently down hill to reach a wooden gate at the bottom. TR, (dont go thru the gate) and after a few metres you cross over a stile

4
 

3
 
into field 1 {F1}. Cross this field and head for the five pillars of the old railway viaduct that are in the river. On reaching the river you TR, and cross a stile at Harrison Wye Fishing Club into {F2}, and continue along the bank of the river. Cross a stile/gate into {F3}. Cross a stile/gate into {F4}. Cross a wooden bridge that bears a hopefully unnecessary disclaimer, (Walkers use this bridge at their own risk) and then a stile into {F5}. Continue along the riverbank and cross over two more stiles into {F6}{F7}, then go thru a metal kissing gate into {F8}. Continue straight on, keeping to the river on your L. At the end of this field you cross a stile/metal onto the main road.

 

1
 

5
 

2
 
5. Brae Cottage. TL and follow a not unpleasant road for about km, passing Brae Cottage (R), a 30 mph speed restriction sign on your L, and just opposite Wye View House you TL by a public footpath sign and cross over a stile. A few paces further on you TR and go thru a kissing gate into {F9}. Follow the riverbank. Go thru a couple more kissing gates, across a wooden footbridge enclosed by metal gates, and climb some concrete steps to cross over a stile onto the main road where you TL, cross over Hoarwithy Bridge and back to the car.

 

 

Walk 45 Vagar Hill

Last walked in December 2016

 

Description. A 10 km (6.2m) very good scenery. Strenuous hilly walk

Start. Near Snodhill Castle, not far from Dorstone. Explorer Map OL13 Grid 321404.

Directions from Whitecross roundabout (turn milometer to zero). Take the A438 Brecon road and after 9.2 miles TL towards Bredwardine. TL at T-junction by the Red Lion Hotel, signposted for Madley B4352 [10.8m]. Take first turning on the R onto Pentre Lane, signed Dorstone 2 [11.2m]. Continue up and over the hill by a narrow road to reach the T-junction and bear R to continue on the A4348 to Dorstone [12.8m]. Take first L for Dorstone [13 m]. At the T-junction at the end of the road you TL for Snodhill [13.3m]. At the first junction TR for Snodhill [13.4m]. At a cross roads you TL for Peterchurch [14.1m]. You can park just off the road on your L, about 150 metres further on, opposite a house. [14.2m]

 

1. Snodhill Castle. The ruined castle is on top of Snodhill, which is on your R, a little further up from the house. This walk is from the ruined Snodhill Castle, thru woods and over commons to a breezy upland. Snodhill Castle may have been at the back of the queue when evocative names were handed out, but it receives ample compensation in its positioning. The castle was constructed in the late twelfth century, was strengthened in the early thirteenth century, but was ruinous by 1355. The border wars of the early fifteenth century gave it a further lease of life, but a bombardment by the Scots during the Civil War terminated its military career. High on the mound are the remnants of the long, narrow, keep, with thick walls. It seems only to have comprised of a hall above a storage basement. Part of the curtain wall and a flanking tower also remain. From the castle descend to the road where you TL to get back to the crossroads. Go straight across and up the No Thru Road. The road bends to the R, (ignore the public footpaths on the L) and rises steeply into the woods. Carry straight on up the road for just over km. Continue on up the road that bends sharply L, and out of the woods. Go thru the 2nd set of double metal gates on your R, (not way marked) which is about 300 meters before the farm buildings, and into a grassy field {F1}. Keep to the fence on your L and at the end of the field you go thru a metal gate into {F2}. Bear R and cross the field to go thru a metal gate onto an enclosed farm track. TL, go up the track and thru a metal gate into {F3}. Continue uphill, keeping to the hedge/fence on your L, and when you get to the fence corner you break away from the fence, veering slightly R and carry on along a grass track that goes thru the bracken and heads towards the communication tower. Follow the way markers and you eventually meet a stream at a wooden gate. Go thru the gate, cross the stream and climb to a track/road, where you TR.

 

2. Bend in Road. The road bends L and heads ruler-straight to a crossroads where you TL. All roads to this point are drawn with the same geometric precision. Stay on the road as it climbs up, to go thru a metal gate and further on up you reach the communications tower. Continue straight on past the communication tower, keeping to the fence on your L, and pass thru a metal gate onto common land and TL.

 

3. Vagar Hill. Continue on the ridge of Vagar Hill(160) for about 1 km, keeping the fence to your L. When the skylarks are in full song this is definitely the R place to be. At the end of the ridge you reach a mettle gate in front of you. Go thru the gate into {F4} and continue down hill with the fence/wall on your L.

 

1
 
4. Metal Gate. At the end of this field you go thru a small metal gate on your L, then immediately TR to go thru a gate into {F5} the fence is now on your R as you continue down hill.
