Keep to the R edge as you travel thru about 7 fields, heading in the same direction for about 1 km. As you go down the last few fields you should notice an enclosed farm track on your R, which ends at the same place where you TR over a stile and down 6 wooden steps onto a bend in a road.

 

4
 

5
 

3
 

2
 
5. Snodhill. TL, and continue in the same direction for about 1 km, heading along the road to Snodhill. Ignore a road off to the R and then one off to the L where the road then falls steeply down to a stream at Snodhill. Once you cross a stream, follow the road that bends L and goes up hill, (ignore the drive off to the L) and take the first t turning R, back to the castle.

 

Walk 46 Ballingham

Last walked in December 2016

 

Description. An 8km(5 mile) moderate ramble with a steep descent. Sloping fields, view from Carey Bank and along Wye Riverbank. (This is an edited version of a walk in the Hereford Times in July).

Start. Car park at Ballington Village Hall. Explorer map 189 5316 Grid 57,

Directions from Belmont roundabout (turn milometer to zero). Take the A49 to Ross-on-Wye. At the first set of traffic lights, after 1/3 of a mile, you TL and head for Holme Lacy. When you get to Holme Lacy, and at 4.4 miles you TR for Holm Lacy House and continue on to Ballingham. At 5.9 miles you TL, signed Ballingham. At 7.8 miles TL to the village hall and after another 50 metres TL into the car park.

 

1. Ballingham Village Hall. Ballingham is a small village of about 140 people situated in a loop of the River Wye, between Hereford and Ross-on-Wye. It has a parish church dedicated to St. Dubricius, which dates from the Anglo-Saxon times. The church was refurbished in the late Victorian era, but the 14th century roof was kept. The tower dates from this period also although the nave is 13th century. The old primary school is now the village hall and was extensively refurbished in time for the Millennium in the year 2000. From 1908 to 1964 the village was served by Ballingham railway station on the Hereford, Ross and Gloucester Railway. Leave the car park and at the road you TR. When reaching the road junction by the parish council notice board you TR, walk a few yards then TL and continue up a narrow road towards Ballingham Chapel. When you reach Ballingham Chapel you fork L and continue up a stony drive/track for about 200m, (on your R is a footpath signpost and a wooden gate with the name St Athan attached to it). TL and go thru a small gate into a field {F1}. Walk along the R field edge and 50m further on you TR and go thru a gate into {F2}. TL and cross the field to go thru a small metal gate into {F3}. Keep to the R edge and go thru small metal gate into {F4}. Keep to the R edge and go thru a small metal gate into {F5} (a portable small hut is next to the gate). Keep to the R edge and at the end of {F5}, by a t/pole, you continue straight ahead and go thru a line of trees/scrub to go over a stile into {F6}. Follow the R hand edge of the field as it bends around to the L and when you get to the top R hand corner you TR thru wooden gates onto a country lane.

 

2. Carey Court. TL and after 40m, (just past Mews Cottage on your L) TR thru a small wooden gate into a paddock with stables. Cross the paddock and go thru a metal gate thats in the top R hand corner into {F7}. Continue along the field keeping the hedge on your R and go thru a wooden gate in the R hand corner. Keep in the same direction and go along an enclosed shady track to go thru a wooden gate by a stone barn. Walk on a few paces and go thru another wooden gate and descend the enclosed drive. After a short distance the drive forks, take the R fork and continue on to the meet a narrow road where you TR. When the road bends L and goes down towards a farm, go straight ahead and cross over a stile into sloping pastureland.

 

3. Telephone Wires. Bear slightly R, away from the bottom wooded edge, heading towards the far mains power pole, and continue up hill to reach the fence where you TR. Keep to the edge of the field, with the fence on your L, and continue climbing to reach the top L hand corner to go thru a gate into {F8}. Cross the field to go thru a wooden gate by a barn and t/pole into the farmyard.

 

4. Kilforge Farm. Cross the farmyard onto the road and TR. Walk on for 40m and TL to go thru a metal gate. Cross a small farmyard and follow the way markers thru a tall metal gate into {F9}, Solar Panels (L). After a short distance the track veers R and continues across the field. Go thru a tall metal gate, then on thru double gates into {F10}. Walk on a little further, TL and continue along a farm track, with the hedge on your R, to reach its end, where you go thru a metal gate onto a driveway. Walk along the driveway for a few metres to return to St Athan gate, (reached in paragraph 1).

 

5. St Athan. TL at the footpath signpost and go down an enclosed narrow footpath thats between dwellings. Continue on past a marker post on your L to reach a clearing that is more like the end of a lawn; there is a view above the River Wye here. TL, at the wat marker post you TR and continue down a very steep hill, keeping to the fence on your R. Go steeply down hill and over a stile to cross over a road. Go down some wooden steps and an enclosed track to pass thru a small wooden gate, and then continue down a very steep hill to reach the river. TR and go thru a rotting kissing gate, to follow the river on your L.

6. Mansells Ferry. Now follow the river downstream and over a stile by a hut, to continue along the river bank and on thru the lower edge of Ballingham Wood. Cross over a stile into a field and walk along the R edge of the field to where the trees end. TR, after 25 paces TR again and go thru a metal gate into the Woods. Walk up 25 wooden steps and along an enclosed track that runs along the inside upper L hand edge of the wood. Near the end of the wood you go thru a metal gate, and bear R to continue along a tarmac track to reach a hairpin bend in the road. TL, continue up the road to Ballingham Council Notice Board where you TL and go back to the car.


 

Walk 47 Putley and Aylton

Last walked in December 2016

 

Description. A 7 km (4.3m) easy walk with one climb into some woods. Going thru orchards, wood, field paths, country lanes and two churches. (This is an edited version of a walk in the Hereford Times in August 2011).

Start. Car park at Putley Green Post Office. Explorer map 189 652377.

Directions from Whitecross Roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A4110 Canon Pyne (Three Elms road) for 1 mile and TR at the traffic lights onto the A4103 Worcester (Roman road). After 7.7 miles TR, signposted to Stoke Edith. At 9 miles TL at road junction (not sign posted) onto main road to Ledbury. At 12.3 miles TR then immediately L signposted Putley Green. At 13.3 miles TR to park in the car park next to red telephone box at Putley Green.

 

1. Putley Green Hall/Post Office. Putley is a small scattered village, rich in history. The little Putley church was largely rebuilt in 1875 by John Riley. The 14th century churchyard cross with its magnificent carvings is one of the finest in the county. Putley is famed for its beautiful apple orchards and is visited by many each year as part of the Big Apple festivities. With your back to the car park, TR, pass the red phone box and walk along the road for a few hundred meters to reach a lone large house on the R called Abbots Place. Immediately past the house you bare R in front of Mill House and go down an enclosed track (Bad Boys Lane). Continue straight ahead thru three gates at Putley Mill into an orchard. Go thru the orchard and thru an avenue to pass Putley Church and the pond (R) to reach a tarmac drive. Continue in the same direction, passing Putley Court (L) and straight on up to the road at the top. TL, after 25m TR and cross an awkward stile/gate onto a wide farm track that goes up an orchard to a wooden gate at the top L leading into a wood.

 

2. Gateway to Wood. Go thru the gate and bear L and go up an obvious track. TL at the track junction/marker post and walk along a prominent track. TL at the next marker post and go down five steps into the wood. Bend R and follow a narrow path thru the woods to go down 20 more steps and on to reach the edge of the wood and road. TR, after 10m TL and go thru a small wooden gate in the hedge, down three steps and follow the aisle thru an orchard. Keep R of barns and go down towards a telegraph pole to reach a surfaced track and bear R, then L to reach the road at Upper House.

 

3. Upper House. TR and after 30m reach The Old Rectory, and (L of grid), go over stile into an orchard. Bear L thru the middle of the orchard and away from rectory conifer hedge, to reach the fence on the other side, and TR. After about 60m you TL and cross over a stile into the next orchard. TR, walk along the R edge and where the hedge starts to bend L, go R across a stile into the next orchard. Go ahead and where the next edge starts to bend L, go R over a footbridge and a stile into {F1}. Follow the R edge of the pasture for 130m to a marker post, where you TL. Walk across the middle of {F1} and on reaching the other side you TR and go thru a gate to continue along an enclosed farm track to reach the road.

 

4. Road to Aylton Court. TL, and continue along the road for about 1 km, to reach a triangle and road junction. TR for Ledbury five miles, Aylton Court is on the R.

 

5. Aylton Court. On the 10 July 1855, young Emma Foulgar was killed on the staircase in Aylton Court when her bother accidentally discharged a shotgun. Her body was buried in Aylton churchyard only to be stolen by body snatchers. Her ghost is said to haunt the stairway where she died to this day. Keep on along the road beyond the Oast House, old shack and pool and the road will bend L at Birchley. Further on the road veers R, and 200m further on you TL over a stile into {F2} (the stile is just before a drive to some farm buildings on the L, and before dwellings on the R). Walk along the R field edge of this large field, to cross a stile in the R corner and onto a road. TR, and walk for almost a km along the pleasant lane to Aylton. Reach hop kiln at Court Farm and Aylton church just beyond.

6. Aylton Church. The most delightful, simple church which has early 12th century origins. There was some updating in the 13th century. There are 2 bells, the larger of which is circa 1639, and the smaller is possibly 12th century - if this is correct it is one of only two of this date in Herefordshire. Aylton church is a very small church that does not appear to be dedicated to a saint. visit the churchyard. There has been a settlement at Aylton since at least Saxon times, and the name Aylton is derived from name of the Anglo Saxon female leader of the settlement. Return to the road and TL, in your original direction, to reach the road triangle. TL for the Pool End and after a few paces, TL up three steps and thru a small metal gate into {F3}. Go across this field and thru a gate into {F4}. Go across this field and across a gated wooden footbridge into {F5}. Go slightly R ahead over further stile into an orchard and continue along the R field edge (hedge is on your R) to cross over a stile into a small orchard field. At the end you TR and go thru a gate and along a enclosed track, then thru a gate and onto the road. TL, go past The Homestead and TR (as if for Putley Church) and car park.


 

Walk 48 Bredwardine

Last walked in January 2017

 

Description. An 8 km (4.8 mile) strenuous hilly walk along fields, lanes and roads. Beautiful views across the Wye Valley.Wye Valley, lanes, fields and views.

Start. Bredwardine Church. Explorer Map 201 Grid 335445.

Directions from Whitecross Roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A438 Brecon road and after 9.1 miles TL towards Bredwardine. After another 1.6 miles [10.7m], just before the T-junction in Bredwardine, TL to Bredwardine Church. Park at the side of the road just before the church.

 

1. Bredwardine Church. St Andrew's Bredwardine is a fascinating church of considerable antiquity. The south doorway and much of the nave date from the time of the Conquest, and the chancel was rebuilt after being partially destroyed by Owain Glyndwr's soldiers in 1406. Inside, notable features include a massive font, and the tombs of a gigantic knight, Walter Baskerville and a smaller effigy of Sir Roger Vaughan who died defending Henry V at the Battle of Agincourt in 1415. Facing the church, TR onto enclosed public bridleway, after a short distance you go thru a gate, and then TR down an enclosed sunken track. Continue along the track, (ignore any tracks forking off L or R), and go thru a metal gate, then continue on to cross over a boardwalk, which is to the R of a small lake and swampy area. Continue in the same direction. Go thru a gap to the L of the next stile and across a small stream into an open field {F1}. Fork L and follow the L edge of the field to the far L corner where you cross a stile into {F2}. Continue up and along the L edge of this large field and at the top L hand corner you cross a stile/gateway to continue along an enclosed grassy track. Just before the track bends sharp R and joins onto another track, you continue in same direction to cross over a stile/metal gate into {F3}. Continue in the same direction keeping to a hedge on your R, and after about 80m you TR over a stile into {F4}. Head for the top L of this field to go thu a gate onto a road, opposite Moccas Park.

 

2. Minor Road. TR and walk along a not unpleasant minor road for about km. A short distance past Lawn Gate Cottage, the first house on your L, you TL and proceed up a narrow road and thru a gate to reach Bodcott Farm. At the end of the barn and opposite the farmhouse you TR and go thru a metal gate. In front of you are three metal gates, take the R hand gate and follow the finger post into {F5}. Head directly across to the marker post in front of you, then keep to the fence on your R to reach the corner, where you cross over a stream and then a stile into {F6}. TL, after 50 metres you cross over an awkward stile into {F7}. Head diagonally R to go up to cross a stile on the steep grassy bank and into {F8}. Bear slightly L and walk up the field to cross a stile/metal gate onto a road.

 

3. Odhouse Lane. Cross the road and walk along a tree-lined enclosed lane, ignore the drive to The Hollies on the L and continue along the lane to pass over a cattle grid and reach a metal gate that is just to the R of The Old House Farm. Go thru the gate into {F9} and TL, 30m on you TR, (ignore any way mark signs pointing off to the L) and follow the fence on your R. Continue on around the R edge of the field to top where you TR thru a wooden bridle gate into {F10}. Continue along the R field edge and when reaching the corner you go thru a metal gate and down an enclosed farm track to reach a narrow road by Cherry Orchard Cottage. TL and walk along the narrow road and after a short distance, as the road bends to the R, you TL to follow a bridleway that is to the L of Pystil Gwynne Cottage. Continue on thru a gateway and then on thru a small metal gate at the end of the garden/field into {F11}. Continue along the R field edge, keeping the gully on your R, to go thru a metal gate into {F12}. Continue in the same direction and go thru another metal gate into {F13}. Continue in the same direction, to eventually cross over the stream and gully, the gully is now just a ditch and the stream is down to a trickle. Go thru a small wooden gate opposite Holly Bush Cottage, TR along a short drive to reach the road.

 

4
 

3
 

2
 

1
 
4. Road. TR, go along the road, which bends R and further on it bends L as it passes a road on the R called Fine Street. Continue on down to the bottom of the 1 in 4 minor road to reach the cross roads by the Red Lion Hotel. Go straight across, pass the war memorial on your L and a little further on you TR along the lane to Bredwardine Church.


 

Walk 49 Winforton

Last walked in January 2017

 

Description. An 8 km (4.9 mile) steady easy walk across farmland, and along small roads.

Start. Park on The Courtlands Road in Winforton. Explorer Map 201 Grid 292471.

Directions from Whitecross Roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A438 Brecon road and after 12.1 miles TL to continue on the A438 Brecon road. Go thru Winforton and at 13.5 miles, not far passed the Sun Inn which is on your R, TR onto The Courtlands side road.

 

1. Way Marks. Get back onto the A438 and TL, keep on the L hand side of the road and head towards the Sun Inn and Hereford. Before reaching the Sun Inn you TL and walk along a Private Road (wide driveway) to go thru a small wooden gate into a small field. Walk forward and go thru a small metal swing gate into a field {F1}. Carry on across the field keeping the hedge to your L and cross a stile by a metal gate. Walk along an enclosed track for about 80m, going thru bracken, and bear very slightly L when the track forks and then peters out. Cross over a tarmac/chips drive and walk across the field, to cross over a stile into {F2}. Go straight across the field and thru a metal gate into {F3} and continue in the same direction, crossing a wooden footbridge and head towards another metal gate. Go thru the gate, cross over a well defined track into {F4}, a large field. Continue slightly L to go thru a broken tree line/hedge row by a way marker post and a little further on you TL to cross over a stile in the hedge into {F5}. TR and follow the field edge around, keeping the hedge, then a fence, on your R to reach another stile on your R. Cross the stile into {F6} and head towards the far corner of a hedge on your R and go thru a metal gate onto the end of a tarmac road, (there is a cattle grid on your L which covers the entrance to a drive to Wood Farm). Continue in the same direction and walk along an enclosed stone track which runs along the edge of the woods, keep to the fence on your L. After about km the track bends to the R and crosses a bridge over a disused railway line, continue along the track to reach the main road by Red Gates Cattery and Boarding Kennels.

 

2. Wood Eaves. TR and walk along the main road and thru the hamlet of Woods Eaves, (Woods Eaves Cottage is on the L, Sunnyside is on the R). When you get to the last house on the L, (the house is called Orchard Cottage and is red bricked), TL and proceed up an enclosed Public Footpath to go thru a metal gate into {F7}. TR and walk along the edge of the field keeping the hedge on your R, pass thru a metal gate into {F8}. Bear slightly L up thru a small metal gate into {F9}. Head straight across the narrow field to cross over a stile into {F10}. Bear R across this field to cross over another stile into F11. TR and with the hedge on your R continue for a short distance to cross over another stile into {F12}. Bear slightly L and cross this field to cross over another stile into {F13}. Cross the field to cross over another stile by a metal gate onto a tarmac road. TL and walk along the main road.

 

3. Pound Farm. At the first junction by Pound Farm take the road to the R. Continue along the road; ignore the No Thru Road on your L and another road on your L a little further on as you cross over a small bridge. Continue uphill and along to where the road bends to your L and go straight ahead over a stile by a metal gate into an orchard. Head slightly L to cross another stile onto a main road. TR, 30 meters and TL down Park View private drive which is a public footpath. Reach a metal gate at the bottom of the drive, (to the L of a house) and continue on into {F14}. Keep the hedge on your L and at the end of the field cross a wooden footbridge into {F15}. Keep the hedge to your L to go thru a small wooden gate into {F16}. Keep the hedge/trees to your L to go thru a gap and into {F17}. Keep

3
 
the hedge/trees to your L and at the end of the field is a metal gate, about 100m to the R of that is a stile that you cross over onto a road, (Herefordshire Trail).

 

4
 

2
 
4. Herefordshire Trail. Cross the road and go thru a metal gate into a large field {F18}. Bear slightly R and head towards the far R hand corner of this field. Just to the L of the corner you go thru a small wooden gate and onto a disused railway track. Go straight across the track and thru kissing gates into {F19}. Bear slightly R and head for the middle of the wood and go thru a wooden gate and into the woods. Keep the fence on your L and bear slightly R to go thru a metal gate and out into {F20}. Bear R and head for the R hand corner to cross a stile onto the road. Cross the road and stile into {F21}. Bear R across this large field and head for the corner of the wood, and follow the fence on your R to go thru a small metal gate into {F22}. Carry on around the field keeping to the fence on your R to TR thru the next wooden gate. Bear L along a driveway onto a road, then TL. About 100m passed the red bricked house on your R, TR and walk along a concrete drive which immediately forks, take the L fork. Walk along a few hundreds yards and you reach very near the start of the walk, TL and proceed to the main road where you TR and head back to the car.

 

1
 
 

 


Walk 50 Staunton-on-Wye

Last walked in January 2017

 

Description. A 7 Km (4.3 miles). Dont do it when its wet underfoot as it crosses a number of arable fields. Pleasant walk with no hills.

Start. Staunton-on-Wye. Park at side of road near the school. Explorer Map 201 Grid 364450.

Directions from Whitecross Roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A438 Brecon road and after 8.6 miles you TR, signposted to Staunton-on-Wye. Ignore the first and second turnings to Staunton-on-Wye and take the third turning marked to The New Inn. Continue on for a couple of hundred yards and park on the L hand side of the road.

1. Staunton-on-Wye. At the second turning to Staunton-on-Wye is the War Memorial. It commemorates those who died in both world wars and has the names of those from Staunton-on-Wye who died in 1914 1919. Walk up the road, passing on your R the old primary school. Just before the road ends at a T‑junction, and opposite a road on your R, you TL along a footpath that will soon leads onto the main road by a red telephone box. TL, walk a few paces along the road then TR onto a no thru road, signposted for Little London. Walk along the road and when it starts to bend to the L, by Ivy Cottage, you TR and walk along a bridleway. Continue along the enclosed grassy bridleway and just before reaching a black and white house on your L, you TL and cross over a stile. Walk straight across the newly planted orchard and then continue in the same direction, walking thru a more mature orchard along a wide opening between the trees. When you reach the end of the opening, at a T‑junction where the trees are directly in front of you, TR and walk along the row of trees to the end of the field then TL and follow the field edge around.

 

2. Way Marked Stile. On your R hand side at a corner of the field you TR and cross over a conduit (big pipe) thats in the ditch and then follow the track round to your L. At the end of the track, (after about 30 meters and having passed a way marked wooden gate), you cross over another stile into a field {F1}. Cross over the open field and head for a red-bricked house, keeping R of a big oak tree. Continue in the same direction keeping to the hedge on your L and go thru a small wooden gate in the corner of the field and onto an enclosed track. Continue on to cross a footbridge and stile, then TR along a driveway, go over a cattle grid and TL to follow a public footpath over a metal gate into {F2}. Bear R, cross the field and go over another stile and footbridge into {F3}. Cross over an arable field, heading in the same direction towards two tall trees and a way marked sign in a gap in a hedge and into {F4}. Bear R (N) across another arable field to cross a hidden footbridge and stile into {F5}. The route is straight across this field, when you get to the other side cross over a stile onto a farm track. Cross the farm track and new fence into {F6}, (if a stile has not been put up then use the gate gap further up the track) and continue in the same direction, heading straight across this field to a cross a stile and footbridge into {F7}. Head across this field to a metal gate and stile onto a tarmac road where you TR and walk along the road.

3
 
 


4
 

2
 
3. House. Not far past a house on your L is a stile on your R, cross the stile into {F8}, and bearing slightly L go across the arable field, heading for an oak tree, to reach a wide farm track and two metal gates. Cross the farm track and continue in the same direction (south) into {F9}, where you keep to the hedge on your L until you cross a stile and footbridge into {F10}. Bear slightly R and continue straight across this field, heading for a gap in a hedge that is in the far corner of the field. Continue in the same direction, crossing the end of a farm track and into {F11}, where you keep to the hedge on your L. Continue on to the corner of the field and go thru the gap in the hedge into {F12}, where you head to the R of two big oak trees, and to the L hand corner of the wood in front of you where you cross a stile into {F13}. Continue south, keeping to the hedge on your R, and just past the woods you TR over a stile into {F14}. Bear L and cross over this field, cutting off the corner, and head towards the gap in the hedge to cross over a stile and a footbridge onto a partly tarmac track. Cross the track and go thru a metal gate into {F15} to continue in the same direction, keeping hedge to your L.

 

1
 
4. Two Fields. Continue on thru two fields {F16}{F17} keeping to the L edge. The second field bends R as you pass by a wooded area on your L, and when you reach the corner of the field, by a wooden gate and stile, go L over the stile. Go straight across a newly planted orchard, pass a house on your R and continue on towards five very tall trees. Cross a stile on the R of the five very tall trees and continue along the hedge on your R, cross over another stile and then go thru a tall wooden garden gate onto a drive. Go along the drive to reach the main road. TR and continue along the road for about km and thru Staunton-on-Wye where you TL onto the road you have parked your car.

 

 

Book 2

50 Walks Around Hereford

 

 

The start points for all the walks from the given locations in Hereford, (Whitecross roundabout, Fire station, Belmont and Tescos roundabouts) should take about half an hour by car to reach.

*

All of these 50 Walks have been covered many times and they have been constantly edited to ensure most people, (if not everyone) will be able to follow the instructions given. Walks last covered in 2018.

*

The measurements for all walks are a rough measurement of what is stated.

*

 

Index

 

Name

Distance

Description

Walk 1 Frome Valley

8 km (5.3 mile)

Fairly strenuous at times walking up hills and along fields. A couple of interesting churches to see.

Walk 2 Eaton Bishop and Ruckhall

8 km (5 mile)

Fairly strenuous walk through trees, along a brook, the River Wye and along field paths.

Walk 3 Longtown

5 km (3.1 mile)

Moderate walk, with an initial gradual climb over grassy fields and along a road to the end. See a very old castle, a old church and an old pub.

Walk 4 Preston Wynne

8 km (5 mile)

Walk across flat fields and roads. This walk has 17 stiles. This is an edited version of the Hereford Times December 2011 walk.

Walk 5 Brampton Abbotts and Hole-in-the-Wall

8 km (5 mile)

Moderate walk along fields, roads, river and railway. This walk has 12 stiles. This is an edited version of the Hereford Times January 2012 walk

Walk 6 The Golden Valley

8 km (4.9 miles)

The Golden Valley is one of the most tranquil places in the county, a wide vale laced by lanes and tracks, dotted with hamlets and villages and bounded by the first upwellings of the Black Mountains.

Walk 7 Edvin and Edwyn

8 km (5 miles)

Three remote churches secreted amongst the rolling countryside to the north of Bromyard Downs are the target of this walk.

Walk 8 The Skirrid

5 km (3.1 mile)

A moderate walk. Ysgyryd Fawr is the most easterly of the Black Mountains in Wales, part of the Brecon Beacons National Park. The name is often anglicised to The Skirrid or Skirrid Fawr, and the mountain is also known as Holy Mountain or Sacred Hill.

Walk 9 Fromes Hill

8 km (5 mile)

Moderate walk, but it does have a very steep hill at the end that is strenuous to climb. Lovely views as you walk down hill towards Cheyney Court Farm, and a pleasant walk along the bank of the river Frome.

 

Walk 10 Wyevale Nursery

8km (5 miles)

Easy walk along well defined tracks and roads.

Walk 11 Knill and Offas Dyke

8km (4.9 miles)

Moderate walk with a very steep strenuous early climb through woods to reach Offers Dyke. Along open ground and a brook. Well maintained trails with great views. Taken from Hereford Times Feb 2012.

Walk 12 Stoke Prior and the Lugg

5 km (3.1 miles)

Edited version of Hereford Times walk by Garth Lawson. A walk along country lanes and the river Lugg, with easily attained views and wildlife.

Walk 13 In the Wake of Wellington

8 km (5 miles)

Moderate walk. Good paths, but one uneven sunken lane. Eight stiles. Country lanes, field paths, two villages and good views. [Hereford Times walk April 2012].

Walk 14 Ruckhall

5 km (3.1 mile)

An easy walk across fields, along narrow roads and touching the River Wye. Above the river is a very good view.

Walk 15 A Marksmans Mauseoleum

10 km (6.2 miles)

Over 22 stiles, with modest climbs as you walk through woods and low-lying fields. Go past monument and an old Hereford to Gloucester Canal.

Walk 16 Pencombe

8 km (5 mile)

A strenuous walk on minor roads and tracks and across farmers fields.

Walk 17 Black Hill and Olchon Valley

8 km (5 mile)

With spectacular views from an exhilarating ridge and a marvellous valley descent.

Walk 18 Risbury Cross 2

8 km (5 mile)

A moderate ramble investigating country lanes, brooks and field paths. None of the gradients, which also visit the Humber and Holly brooks are too demanding.

Walk 19 North Titley

5 km (3.1 mile)

A moderate walk up and down a hill.

Walk 20 Marcle Ridge

6 km (3.7 mile)

A moderate walk up and down the Ridge. Fine views across south and east Herefordshire. Along a ridge, thru fields and country lanes.

Walk 21 Garway Hill

6.4 km (4 mile)

A strenuous climb, beautiful scenery.

Walk 22 Gladestry and Hergest Ridge

8 km (5 mile)

Strenuous walk. One stiff climb, walking along bridle paths, country lanes, fields and open springy-turfed moorland. Spectacular views. Taken from Hereford Times July 2012.

Walk 23 Golden Valley

9 km (5.5 mile)

Moderate walk in The Golden Valley meadow, pasture and brookside.

Walk 24 Burghill and Tillington

9 km (5.6 mile)

Mostly bridle paths and country lanes. Three stiles. Sites ancient and modern. Can be joined in Tow Tree Lane from Roman Road, Hereford. Hereford Times September 2012

Walk 25 Eardisley and Woods Eaves

7 km (4.3 mile)

A leisurely walk. No stiles. Quiet country lanes and bridle path, mostly surfaced. Hamlet, historic tree and village on the Black and White Trail. Hereford Times walk of October 2012.

Walk 26 Skenfrith Castle Walk

8 km (5 mile)

A pleasant moderate walk, with excellent views of the hilly countryside.

Walk 27 Kings Caple and Fawley

9 km (5.6 mile)

A moderate walk along quite country lanes, fine bridleway, two crop fields and over four stiles. Quite long stretches of road walking. Taken from Hereford Times Nov 2012.

Walk 28 Clehonger

9 km (5.6 mile)

Walk across flat landscape, crossing over a number of cropped fields, so it can be arduous if done when its sodden wet, or when fields have just been ploughed.

Walk 29 Malvern Hills

9 km (5.6 mile)

Walking along good tracks and minor roads through woodland and across part of the Malvern Hills.

Walk 30 Lyonshall

8 km (5 mile)

[Need your speakie as the route may have changed] Walk across farmland, a short stroll through woods and along minor roads. Pleasant and interesting surrounding to look at.

Walk 31 Woolhope

9 km (6 miles)

Moderate ramble over good terrain. Some interesting views. Edited a walk taken from December 2012 Hereford Times.

Walk 32 Kimbolton and Bache Camp

6 km (3.7 miles)

Kimbolton and Bache Camp, Dovecote, hill-fort, pasture and country lane. Mostly avoiding crops.

Walk 33 The Lower Olchon Valley

8 km (4.9 miles)

A strenuous walk up and down a mountain. Beautiful scenic views but there are a number of stiles to cross as you walk across farmland and along patches of road.

Walk 34 Coddington

5 km (3.1 miles)

Coddington, with its thirteenth-century church is a small village nestling in typical Herefordshire countryside just outside the market town of Ledbury and to the west of The Malvern Hills in an area of outstanding natural beauty.

 

Walk 35 Ewyas Harold

6 km (3.7 miles)

A gradual climb up and gentle walk downhill, across farmland and along minor roads.

Walk 36 Ullingswick

9 km (5.6 miles)

A summer or winter walk along narrow roads, thru woodland and along well defined tracks. Good scenery. One stiff road climb. No stiles. (Edited copy from Hereford Times May 2013).

Walk 37 Badnage Wood

6 km (3.7 mile)

This walk goes up a very steep hill thats covered in trees, and down the other side, then back over this very steep hill. A short but strenuous walk

Walk 38 Stoke Prior

8 km (4.9 miles)

Walk along a small amount of narrow roads and across good looking farmland.

Walk 39 Kington and Hergest Ridge

9 km (5.6 miles)

A moderate/energetic ramble thru town, woods and across hilly countryside, with Spectacular views (Hergest Ridge).

Walk 40 Dymock and Ryton

10 km (6.2 miles)

A walk along The Poets Paths, with crop, pasture, woodland edges, nature reserves, and daffodils. (Hereford Times 2015).

Walk 41 Donnington, Brooms Green and the parish of Dymock

8 km (4.9 miles)

A Serene and generally level country lanes and field paths. Taken from Hereford Times July 2013. Long trousers recommended.

Walk 42 Herefordshire Trail

7 km (4.3 miles)

Taking a compass might be useful. A pleasant walk along tracks, minor roads and farmers fields

Walk 43 Joyces Walk

6.4 km (4 mile)

A circular walk in the Forest of Dean. It passes through woods and fields to Hope Mansell, then the walk follows a hilly route to the lane near Horn Hill Farm then skirts Harechurch Wood before returning to the start.

Walk 44 Beside The Wye

8 km (5 mile)

An easy walk starting in Ross-on-Wye. The route is mostly flat, with one gentle climb and one short sharp climb.

Walk 45 Walks around Luston Group Parishes 1

6 km (3.7 mile)

This walk takes us out of Luston Village into the beautiful surrounding country- side. It is mainly through fields, a short stretch along the edge of Oaker Wood and a short section takes us along Croft Lane.

 

Walk 46 Walks around Luston Group Parishes 2

6 km (3.7 miles).

This walk takes us out of the village and into the beautiful surrounding countryside. It is mainly through fields, crossing several streams and the railway line, with a short stretch along Eye Lane.

Walk 47 Walks around Luston Group Parishes 3

8 km (5 miles)

This walk takes us out of Luston village into the beautiful surrounding countryside. It is mainly through fields, but with several stretches along quiet, minor lanes edged with wild flowers. It also takes us to the charming church of All Saints at Eyton (left).

Walk 48 Walk along the Border

7 km (4.3 mile)

A moderate ramble crossing 15 stiles and 4 footbridges.

Walk 49 Old Radnor and Hanter Hill

7 km (4.3 miles)

A fairly strenuous hilly walk along country lanes, across pasture and open hillside

Walk 50 Kyrle-on-Wye

5.3 km (3.3 miles)

An easy walk through suburban streets, woodland and along riverside paths. No stiles

 

 

Starting Points Hereford

 

Whitecross Roundabout.

 

 

Fire Station.

 

 

Asda. Belmont Road.

 

 

Tescos Roundabout

 

 

 

 

 

 

Walk 1 Frome Valley

Last walked in February 2017

 

Description. An 8 km (5.3 mile), fairly strenuous at times walking up hills and along fields. A couple of interesting churches to see.

Start. Park at the roadside just before the grassy lane to Acton Beauchamps church. Explorer Map 202 Grid 680502.

Direction from Whitecross roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A4110 Canon Pyon (Three Elms road) for 1 mile and TR at the traffic lights onto the A4103 Worcester (Roman road). At 13.2 miles, (at the bottom of Fromes Hill) TL onto the B4214 for Bromyard. At 15.2 miles TR for Paunton and travel along a narrow road. At 16.4 miles go straight across the crossroads and head towards Acton Beauchamp. Take the first turning L, after 16.6 miles. After a short distance you park at the roadside near to the grassy lane that goes to Acton Beauchamps church, total distance is 17 miles, tuck tightly into the side. Dont go thru the large metal gates ahead, thats the entrance to Church House Only.

 

1. Acton Beauchamps Church. Set alone on a knoll above a valley, St. Giles is a beautiful country church. The west tower is medieval, the rest of the building being rebuilt in 1819 it is the last Georgian church in Herefordshire. Above the south doorway of the tower is set a section of an Anglo-Saxon cross-shaft, dating from about the 9th century. The font is dated to about the fifteenth century. Walk up the grassy lane and go thru wooden gates into the churchyard. Walk up to the top L hand corner and leave the churchyard by a metal gate and a stile into F1. TR and walk round the field keeping to the fence on your R, on reaching a line of tall trees you cross over a stile into F2. TL, walk up the field edge keeping the trees on youre L, to cross over a stile into F3. Go straight across this field to cross a stile into F4. Go slightly L, and 50m to the R of a small lone tree and 30m R of a gate, you cross over a hidden stile into F5. Immediately TR and go thru a metal gate into F6 and continue up the R edge of this field, to go thru a gate gap into F7. Continue along the R edge of this field until you reach the corner of a wood (Halletshill Coppice) and a small metal gate with a blue waymarker. Ignoring this gate you turn sharp L and drop straight down across the field to go across a wooden footbridge and thru a wooden gate into F8.

 

2. Wooden Footbridge. Go straight up and across 2 fields (F1/F2), keeping the hedge on your R. Go under power lines and thru a small wooden gate; after about 20m TL then R to continue in the same direction along the R field edge of F3 to reach a road. TR, walk along the road. The road bends L, you can TR if you want to go and see the church of St James, a bit further on it bends R at the entrance to The Hawkins, and you go straight on, thru a kissing gate into a F4. Follow along the L field edge to go thru a gate gap, then across a makeshift gate into F5. Keep to the hedge on the L to go thru a gate into F6. Continue down and over stile into F7. Continue in the same direction, down the next field and along a tree line (R), to cross over a wooden footbridge over Linton Brook into F8.

 

3. Linton Brook. TL, walk beside the Linton Brook for 1 km, crossing four fields to reach a road. TL, walk for 150m and TR over a cattle grid and walk along a driveway for 800m, crossing a bridge and another cattle grid to reach Upper Venn Farm.

 

3
 
4. Upper Venn Farm. In 1952 Upper Venns Farmhouse became a grade 2 listed building. Just before the first farm shed you TL over a stile into F1, walk 50m along the R field edge to TR thru a gate into F2. Slightly L across this field to go thru a gate into F3. Straight across and up this field, passing 4 mature oak trees on your L, to cross over a stile (thats beyond an electricity pole) and into a wooded area. Keep to a rough track, (fence is on your L), thru wooded area to cross over another stile into F4. Continue along the track, keeping trees/fence on your L to go thru a gate and onto a drive to The Venn Farm, passing alongside its long black barn. Follow the drive down to reach the minor road, which is just under a kilometre away.

 

4
 

2
 
5. Paunton Court. TL. When the road bends sharp L you pass Paunton Court (home to the Frome Valley Vineyard). Wine has been produced in Herefordshire since Medieval times and Frome Valley Vineyards have planted 4000 vines. The vines are grown on a gentle south facing slope in idyllic English countryside. The vineyards were established in 1992. Continue along the road to reach cross roads where you go straight across, heading for Acton Beauchamp. Climb up this narrow road to take the first turning on your L, and head along this lane to reach your car.

 

5
 

1
 
 

 


Walk 2 Eaton Bishop and Ruckhall

Last walked in February 2017

 

Description. An 8 km (5 mile) fairly strenuous walk that cannot be completed if the river Wye is in flood. You walk thru trees and along field paths. Walk along a brook and along the river Wye, passing an area of a hill fort.

Start. Park the car by the side of the road opposite the cemetery in Eaton Bishop. Explorer Map 189 Grid 444391.

Direction from Tescos roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A465 Abergavenny road. At the second turning on the R, after point eight of a mile, TR towards Madley. After 3.7 miles TR for Eaton Bishop and St Michaels Church. After 4.4 miles, (across the road from the church cemetery), park in the small lay-by on your R.

 

1. St Michael and All Angels Church. The church of St Michael and All Angels dates from the 11th Century with a tower containing six bells added in the 12th Century. The Victorians tiled the floor of the chancel, when the original tombstones were moved into the vestry. The East window has one of the oldest complete examples of a medieval stained glass window in the country installed circa 1320. With youre back to the cemetery TR and go back along the road you came from. Go out of the village and down the road to where the road bends R, you go straight ahead and across a stile/metal gate into a huge crop field F1. Continue in the same directions and cross the field, under electric cables and head to the L of a farm building in front. 100m to the L of the buildings you cross over a stile. Go thru a paddock and then thru a steel gate onto the road. Cross straight ahead into hedge-lined lane (|Unsuitable for Long or Wide Vehicles). Follow the lane for about half a kilometre, passing a house on your R, and just before the lane bends to the R, by a large building and a detached garage, TL and go over a footbridge thats over the Cage Brook and follow a fenced footpath.

 

2. Cage Brook. Keeping to the brook on your R, cross a wooden footbridge and continue on with the brook now on your L and wind thru the woods until you go thru a small metal kissing gate onto a road. TL and walk along the road, and just past the bridge you TR to walk down nine concrete steps into woods, the brook is now on your R. Follow track going along the river, past an old Mill, then cross a sloping footbridge. Move down to the R and follow the brook that is on your R. Just underneath power lines you cross over a stile, TL, cross over another stile into F2 and TR, follow the stream on your R. Go over a stile underneath another set of power lines into F3, continue in the same direction. Go over a small gate into F4, and continue on. Cross over a stile into F5, which is situated below New Barns Farm (L). As the stream goes off R, you go straight across the field and over a stile/metal gate onto a road.

 

3. Eaton Bishop to Ruckhall road. TR, a short distance along the road you TL at the junction for Ruckhall. As you walk up the road you pass a drive on your R to Bank House, a drive on your L to Sunny Bank, and just before the road levels, turn very sharply to the R and head towards Hill Fort House. As the drive bends L towards the house you go straight on along a green lane. A little further on your L, you can climb up the 11 new steps to view the highest part of the 18-acre hill-fort of Eaton Camp at Ruckhall. Go thru metal gate and along and down below the eastern rampart across a stile onto a gravel drive. TL, walk

5
 
along the drive, when the drive bends R into the house, you carry straight on and go thru a wooden kissing gate/metal gate into a field. Continue on for 60m. TL in front of enclosure, then fork R down along the riverbank and cross a stile into trees. After 50m TL and go up 11 steps, TR and after 150m go up 33 more steps, TR to go back down 22 more steps. TL to reach the junction below old Ancient Camp Inn that is on your L and was once a pub/restaurant.

4
 
 


3
 

1
 
4. Below Ancient Camp Inn. TR and go down about steep stepped path (60 to 70 steps) heading towards the river and Bogwell Pool. TL, go over a stile into F6 and follow the riverbank for 250m. Cross a stile thats under trees, then over a concrete footbridge, keep R and continue across three-plank bridge, possibly awkward terrain, and reach Sugwas Island on your R. Emerge into a field (F7) that was at the site of the old ferry.

 

5. Lower Eaton House area. TL in front of a thatched house, pass thru metal barrier and go up byway. After 60m TL and go thru a kissing gate into F8. Turn diagonally R and walk across the corner of the field to cross over a stile into F9. Continue in the same direction to cross over another stile into F10. Continue up hill to pass thru a kissing gate and over a surfaced cross track at the crest and into F11. Continue in the same direction to descend the field and go over a stile and footbridge over a ditch. Go up crop field (F12) and thru a gateway on to a road. TL for Eaton Bishop and after a short distance you arrive at the car.

 

2
 
 

 


Walk 3 Longtown

Last walked in February 2017

 

Description. A 5 km (3.1 mile) moderate walk, with an initial gradual climb over grassy fields and along a road to the end. See a very old castle, n old church and an old pub.

Start. Longtown Parish Hall. Explorer Map OL13 Grid 324287.

Direction from Tescos roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A465 to Abergavenny. At 9.7 miles you TR for Longtown 6. At 10.5 miles TL for Longtown 5. At 15.1 miles you TL for Longtown. At 15.3 miles TR at the The Crown Inn, (Established in 1751), and head for Longtown Village. A little further on, passed the pub on your L and at a T Junction, you TR for Longtown Castle. Two tenths of a mile along the road you park by Longtown Parish Hall, which is on the L. [15.5 miles]

 

1. Longtown Castle. TL from the car park and walk up the road to look at the remains of the Longtown Castle. The English border counties are full of some of the finest motte and bailey castles still in existence in Britain. The castles were the property of Norman lords who built the strongholds in an effort to maintain control over the unruly Welsh. Longtown Castle was built in the 1180's by the Norman lord, Walter de Lacy, inside a rectangular earthen enclosure that may date to the Roman occupation of Britain. Return to the road and TR to go back downhill for 200m, passing the Outdoor Education Centre (L), to TR and go down a narrow No Thru Road. Go down to the bottom of this lane to reach a ford, (where water from Olchon Brook pours over the road), dont cross the ford, TL and cross over a stile/metal gate into F1. With the brook on your R you walk along the R side of the field for 80m and TR, to cross over the brook using a concrete footbridge, and into F2. Turn half L, go across the field and then over a waymarked stile, which is below the oak tree halfway along the distant hedge line, and into F3. Go straight across this field to cross over a waymarked stiled footbridge near the field corner and into F4. Turn half R and cross the field to go thru a waymarked metal gate into F5. Go straight up this field to go thru a small wooden gate into F6. Turn half L, cross this field and go thru a small wooden gate into F7, a barn is about 100m to the L. Walk half R across this field to go thru a small wooden gate onto a concrete drive, (a cattle grid is on your R), TL and walk down the drive to reach a narrow road.

 

2. Waymarked Gate. Cross the road and go thru a metal gate into F8. Turn half R and walk across the field to cross over a stile in a hedgerow and into F9. Turn half L and go down and across the arable field to the bottom corner to cross over a stile thats guarded by a stone slab and into F10. TL, keep to the L hand side of the field and go down thru a metal gate into F11. Go half R across this field, down to the bottom R hand corner, to cross over a wooden styled sloping footbridge and into F12. Keep to the L of the field to cross over another wooden styled footbridge into another F13, then TL. 30m to the R of the bottom corner you cross over a stile, you then cross over a big ditch (dingle) into F14. Turn half R, cross the field and a stile onto a road.

 

1
 
3. Clodock Church. TL, walk along the road to reach Clodock church. This amazing old building has some medieval wall paintings, lovely old pews and a spectacular pulpit, behind which is a memorial stone dating from about AD830. In a dark corner of Clodock church under the gallery are two large stone tablets, mounted on the wall from floor level up to some seven feet, on which a lengthy text sets out the amount of tithes payable to the vicar. The tablets commemorate an episode in the life of the church which has long been forgotten in the local community; a dispute about tithe payments between parishioners and the vicar which led to a court case in 1805.  The text on the tablets shows that the medieval system of tithes in kind were replaced by cash payments in Clodock parish by 1805 and gives the amount of

1
 
money to be paid in lieu of produce. Next to the church is the completely unspoilt Cornewall Arms, well worth a visit. Go across the churchyard and down to the river. TL, and at the north east corner of the churchyard you go across a slab-stile thats been made from an old gravestone and join a wooden fenced enclosed path beyond, the river Monnow is on your R, go thru a gate into F15. Cross this field and over a stile into F16. Cross this field and go thru a gate into F17. Cross this field a across a stile into F18. Straight across this field and over a large stone slab-stile thats in front of you and into F19. TL and walk along the side of this field to cross over stone stab stiles onto the road. TR, walk along the road for 3/4 km to return to the car, keep L at the junction. As you get to the south side of Longtown village, you pass "Old Ebenezer

2
 
Chapel". This chapel has four windows along its side, by each window there is a date stone laid by different people on the 13th June 1889.

 

 

3
 
 

 


Walk 4 Preston Wynne

Last walked in February 2017

 

Description. An 8 km (5 mile) walk across flat fields and roads. This walk has 17 stiles. This is an edited version of the Hereford Times December 2011 walk. This walk is best completed when the ground is dry.

Start. Preston Wynne. Explorer Map 202 Grid 544484.

Direction from Whitecross roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A4110 Canon Pyon (Three Elms road) for 1 mile and TR at the traffic lights onto the A4103 Worcester (Roman road). At the second roundabout, after 3.2 miles, TL towards Bodenham. At 7.5 miles the road bends sharp L, go straight on and park on the No Thru Road to Holbatch. Tuck into the verge as soon as you can.

 

1. Verge. Walk along the narrow No Thru Road for about 1 km to reach Upper Holbatch, (a farm on your R hand side), where the surfaced road ends. The land at Upper Holbatch Farm is the jewel in the crown and comprises a fine block of mostly arable land all with good accessibility. Continue in the same direction, along an enclosed bridle track ahead. After just over km, (passing the gated drive on the L that goes up to Camp Cottage), you get to the end of a line of trees on your R, you TR across a stile and into F1. Walk down the field, keeping to the hedge on your R, and when the hedge ends and the tall trees start, TR, go onto the concrete drive and TL. Walk along the drive that is heading towards the buildings in front of you, which is a spirit distillery called CHASE. On reaching the buildings walk on thru the yard.

 

2. CHASE Office. Just past the Distillery car park and a brick building on your R, (just around the corner of the building are way markers), you bear R and proceed up a narrow road. Continue along the road to go past some houses on your R, when you pass the last house you TR and go thru a metal gate into F2, then keep to the R hand edge. Continue up the field to reach the top R hand corner and cross over two hidden stiles into F3. TL, keep to L edge/hedge and in the corner of the field you cross a stile into F4. Cross over a small field and over another stile and onto an enclosed track. Walk along the track and go over a stile/wooden gate and onto the road in Preston Wynne.

 

3. Preston Wynne. Preston Wynne is a small village and civil parish located 11 km north east of Hereford. It is the site of a medieval chapel and several ancient ring ditches. TR, walk along the road for about 300m to reach farm buildings on your L, (buildings are opposite a white house). TL and go thru a farmyard, (barns on your R and an old black and white farmhouse on the L), to go thru a gate into F5. Cross the field and over a stile into F6. Cross this field and cross over a stile thats to the R of Preston Wynne Church ahead, into F7. Holy Trinity has commemorative plaque just inside. Go diagonally R across this field and thru a kissing gate/metal gate onto a road. TR, continue along the road to pass a lake on your R, the road then bends L and just past an orchard on your L the road bends R, it then bends R for the second time and a little further on you TL and go over a stile into F8. Cross this field and over a stile into a newly planted orchard F9. Bear R across this field to go thru a gap in the hedge into another orchard F10.

 

2
 

1
 
4. Gap in Hedge. Walk along the avenue of trees and at the end of the field you skip a few paces to the R and go thru a gap in the hedge line ahead thats by a large lone tree into F11. Cross over this field and over a styled footbridge into F12. Go straight across this field and cross over another styled footbridge into F13. Cross this field, heading for the far R hand corner and go thru a small wooden gate onto a tarmac drive. Walk along the drive and over a cattle grid, 40m further on you bear R to go over a stiled footbridge thats to the R of Ivy Cottage.

 

5
 

4
 

3
 
5. Tumpy Lakes. Go ahead seven paces and TL over a high stile into F14. Cross the field and over a stile in top L corner into a copse. Follow along the L edge of this copse. Cross two plank bridges and a stile to emerge from the copse. TL, walk a few paces and TR into F15 and continue along the R field edge, up to the far end and out thru gap, onto a surfaced drive. TR and walk towards the buildings of Amberley Court. Just passed the house on the L you TL, to go up a wide footpath. Go thru a small metal gate into a F16 and continue up the R field edge to go thru a metal gate onto Holbach lane and the start point.

 

 

Walk 5 Brampton Abbotts and Hole-in-the-Wall

Last walked in March 2017

 

Description. An 8 km (5 mile) Moderate walk along fields, roads, river and railway. This walk has 12 stiles. This is an edited version of the Hereford Times January 2012 walk.

Start. Brampton Abbotts. Explorer Map 189 Grid 601265.

Direction from Belmont roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Follow the A49 to Ross-on-Wye and at 12.9 miles, at the roundabout you TL towards the M50. At the next roundabout, 14.3 miles, you go straight across towards the M50. At the next roundabout, 14.8 miles you TL towards Ledbury on the A449. At 15.2 miles you TL towards Brampton Abbotts. At a T-junction, after 16 miles, you TL towards Ross-on-Wye. A little further on you TR towards Brampton Church and at 16.2 miles you arrive at the church. Park beside the churchyard stone wall.

 

1. Brampton Abbotts Church. The church closed in 2008, it says it is waiting for a health and safety check. With the wall and lynch gate on your R, walk down the road, passing a sign Wellmead on the house wall on your L. At the next road on your L, just before the village Hall, TL and walk along to the end of this tarmac road, then continue on for a few more paces to reach the dirt track and the last cottage on the R called Townsend. Just passed the last cottage you TR across a stile and into F1. Bear L and cross the field to cross another stile into F2. Go across a large cropped field towards a hedge elbow, (a lone tree is on the L). Continue in the same direction with the hedge on your R, into F3. Carry on up passed trees on your R. From the tree corner you continue in the same direction across a cropped field towards a large corrugated farm building, to go thru a metal gate onto a road. TR, continue along the road, passing the Hill of Eaton Courtyard on your L, and then an old farmhouse on your R, which is just before the road bends to the R, and when it does you TL over a stile into F4.

 

2. Hill of Eaton. Go quite steeply down the pasture to cross a stile and go up a fenced path immediately L of trees of Vicarage Wood. Cross a stile into F5. Keep on upwards, along the R edge (with great views opening out west and north) and over the crest. Go thru wooden gate into F6. Start to descend, bearing very slightly R thru a wooden gate and down a wide tree-lined track. In front of next gate, TR and go upward for about 50 paces, and then bear L to cross over a stile/metal gate into F7. Follow the L edge to the L corner and TL to go thru a small metal gate and go along a narrow enclosed path to reach the road at the Hole-in-the-Wall, (a red post box is on your R).

 

3. Hole-in-the-Wall. TL and go along the quite road, passing the Foy Bridge on your R that goes over the river Wye. 275m beyond the bridge, and opposite Orchard Cottage, you TR and go thru trees along the Wye Valley path. Go thru a gate into F8, (Foy Church is on the opposite bank to the R). Go straight ahead near bottom R edge of the long pasture to cross a stile into F9. Keep ahead near to the R edge, (ignore a metal gates on your R hand side) to reach the far end. Go thru a metal kissing gate, then in and out of the bottom edge of trees and into F10 where you TL. Continue on to the end of the trees on your L, (Monks Grove). Then continue in the same direction across a clear patch of land, to continue along the field edge, with a line of trees on your R. Go ahead to marker post at path junction. TR and continue along the track.

 

4. Marker Post. If you want to you can continue along the riverbank for 150m to see the memorial to H E. Who ever he was? Go on past another marker post (if its still there) and a little further on, (opposite a wooden bench thats on the river bank) you TL and go along the L edge of a flat field F11. In the L corner of the field you go thru a small metal gate and up nine steps to an old railway line where you TL. Go along to a marker post at cross tracks and TL. Go up wide gravel track, passing a green gas hut on your R. Views R to Ross, Chase Wood and Penyard Park. After about a further half a kilometre the track bends slightly L, slightly to the R is a gap in the hedge, which you go thru into F12. Continue in roughly the same direction, heading diagonally up to the top R corner of the huge field. Head towards a sandy coloured house, when seen. Skirt R of a hedge elbow and over 2 stiles ahead. Emerge at drive of Clouds Harrow and follow road R around old school House to lych-gate.

 

 

 


Walk 6 The Golden Valley

Last walked in March 2017

 

Description. An 8 km (4.9 miles) walk along the Golden Valley, which is one of the most tranquil places in the county, a wide vale laced by lanes and tracks, dotted with hamlets and villages and bounded by the first upwellings of the Black Mountains. This walk requires a lot of effort as its up and down a number of steep hills.

Start. Peterchurch. Explorer Map OL13 Grid 345386.

Direction from Tescos roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A465 to Abergavenny. At 0.8 mile you TR onto B4348 to Clehonger 2. At 2.8 miles TL to Peterchurch. At 5.4 miles at a T-junction TR for Peterchurch. In Peterchurch, at 10.3 miles, TL down the lane beside the Boughton Arms pub and by the church. TR into car park.

 

1. Peterchurch. The Golden Valley is one of the most tranquil places in the county, a wide vale laced by lanes and tracks, dotted with hamlets and villages and bounded by the first upwellings of the Black Mountains and low, wooded ridges and commons. This walk starts from the capital of the valley, rising easily to the site of one of the many defensive sites in the area and offering tremendous views across rolling acres of sheep pasture and golden cornfields to distant hills and mountains. Despite its name, the Golden Valley takes its name from the Welsh dwr water, referring to the River Dore that has carved this delightful unspoilt vale east of the Black Mountains. From the car park TR and join the Herefordshire Trail. The church is on your L. Cross the river bridge and bear L then swing R ro walk along a track that traces a course past a farm to reach a minor road. TR and walk along this road, passing Hinton Hall on your R to reach the crossroads. TL, walk for about km, gradually climbing up Long Lane, passing a string of cottages and houses. Youll pass by a house called Temple Bar (L), Nurses Cottage (L), and about 150m after this and opposite a lone white house called Rose Cottage, take the finger posted stile on the L, going up steps and into F1. Walk straight across the pasture, heading towards an overhead power line pole to go over two wooden planks and across a couple of stiles either side of a track here at Hostleys Farm.

 

2. Hostleys Farm. Go ahead between the breeze block buildings and a metal gate, immediately beyond these, cross over a way marked ladder-stile on the L. Walk a few paces and TR to cross a stile into F2. TL, at the end of the field you cross a stile and three planks into F3. TR and walk along the L field edge. At the top L hand corner you cross a stile into F4 and take time to admire the fine views across to Hatterrall Ridge, the edge of the Black Mountains. Go Half R down this field and cross a stile/gate in the bottom R hand corner, (by the corner of the woods, into F5. Go half L and near to the far R corner of this field you cross a wooden footbridge that goes across Trenant Brook into F6. As you climb the L side of this field, look for a small metal gate on your L. Go thru this gate, across a footbridge and into F7. TR, continue to walk up to the top R corner of this field and to Oatley Farm ahead. TR thru a metal gate and walk thru the farmyard to join the rough access loose stone track that continues on to cross over a cattle grid onto a road thats over km away.

 

3. Road. TL, then L again at the nearby junction and continue down this lane for 1.6 km. On the R you pass the gated entrance to Urishay Castle Farm (private, no access). Urishay Castle was one of the countless fortified sites built to defend against the marauding Welsh in Norman times. Just as the road starts to rise beyond a bridge that goes over Trenant Brook, take the way marked path, L, and go thru the L set of gates into F8. Walk up the R field edge and at the top R corner you cross over a slab stile into F9. Go across a stile in the fence ahead into F10. Straight across this field and over a stile into F11. Walk on down the pasture, just R of the centre of two pylons, to a stile beneath trees in an offset corner. Cross this stile into F12. TR, continue down the R side and thru a gate into F13. At the bottom R corner you go over a stile and along a driveway and onto a road. TR, walk along the road and fork L at the No Thru Road to return to the church.

 

 

 


Walk 7 Edvin and Edwyn

Last walked in March 2017

 

Description. A 8 km (5 miles). Three remote churches secreted amongst the rolling countryside to the north of Bromyard Downs are the targets of this walk. Ranging from early Norman to Victorian in age, each has a story to tell, a heady mix of heroism, piety and larceny. The route offers far-reaching views across this corner of Herefordshire, rich farmland at the headwaters of the River Frome, an unsung waterway that flows all the way from this northern corner of the county to the River Wye near Hereford.

Start. Edvin Loach car park. Explorer Map 202 Grid 663585.

Direction from Whitecross roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A4110 Canon Pyon (Three Elms road) for 1 mile and TR at the traffic lights onto the A4103 Worcester (Roman road). Go thru two roundabouts and at 3.7 miles TL onto the A465 to Bromyard. Near Bromyard, at 14.6 miles, TL onto the B4214 to Tenbury. At the T-junction, (15 miles) go straight across and continue onto Tenbury. At 15.5 miles TL to Tenbury. At 19 miles TR and continue along a narrow road to Edvin Loach 1. At 19.8 miles TR to Edvin Loach. At 20.3 miles TR to Edvin Loach church and at 20.4 miles you park at the church.

 

Edvin Loach has two churches; the small Victorian replacement and the ancient original. This latter was built shortly after the Norman Conquest in a style that recalled the church architecture of the Saxons and is thus often known as the Saxon Church. Of particular note is the herringbone pattern of many of the earliest walls still standing. The replacement St Marys Church was built by a local businessman, William Barneby.

1. Edvin Loach. Walk back along the rough approach road and at the T-junction TR - Off to your R, the Malverns draw the eye south beyond the heights of the nearby Bromyard Downs; to the north is Titterstone Clee Hill, capped by a radar dome. Walk down the lane for about km to reach THE STEEPLES, a farm on the L that supplies quality milk. TR and walk up the lane opposite the postbox. After about 400m the lane bends R, ignore the lane to the L, and walk on round for a few paces to TL thru a gateway into F1. Stick to the L edge of the field, passing R of an isolated cottage. Continue in the same direction across a short stretch of open farmland to go thru a small wooden gate into a wood. Drop straight down to go over a wooden footbridge into F2. Go half L to go over a stile/metal gate thats near a house(L), and walk on up the tarred driveway to reach the road.

 

2. T-junction. At the T-junction TR, follow this quiet road for about km thru to the Brickhouse Farm. When the road bends L, look R for a fingerpost thats at the end of a small stone structured barn, TR and go thru a gate into F3. Walk across this field and between ponds, to go thru a gate into F4. Keep to the R field edge (a brook is on your R), and go thru a metal gate in the corner, into F5. TL and walk up the L edge of the field, (heading for the church spire), to go thru a metal kissing gate into F6. Continue along and around the L field edge (this field may be split in two). At the field end you TL thru a small metal gate, then TR to go thru a metal gate onto a narrow road. TL and walk on to reach St Michaels Edvin Ralph church. St Michaels Church dates from the late 12th century. Inside is one of the finest collections of effigy tombs in the county, including knights and rare Pardon Monuments offering a prayer to this was said to grant the supplicant up to 60 days pardon of sins. (Use the R hand light switch by the door.) In the trees to the west of the churchyard is a motte-and-bailey castle, all that remains of a village that succumbed to the Black Death plague in 1349AD.

 

3. St Michaels Church. Continue along the road and turn the corner at Townsend Farm (prominently displayed), and about 100m further on you reach two fingerposts on your R. Choose the first of these, climb the stile and stick to the L edge of four fields (F7, F8, F9, F10) keeping above a brook thats on your L. At the ultimate L corner when you reach a wider brook/stream thats in front of you, TL and go thru a way marked metal gate, across the culvert into F11. Walk beside the brook/stream thats on your R. Just before the next corner TR, then TL before the bridge and go thru a metal gate and along a wide concessionary bridle path. Continue along this bridle path, keeping the brook/stream on your R, for just over km to reach a bridgeway on your R that crosses the brook/stream.

 

4. Bridge. TR here, cross the bridge and thru the waymarked metal gate into F12. Climb the field to pass L of the ruined cottage. Go thru a metal gate into F13 and join a rocky farmers track that goes on thru a hedge gap into F14. Continue on to go thru a metal gate and walk along the R hand edge of F15 to go thru another gate and onto a minor road near New House Farm. TL to walk back to the signposted church access road, passing THE STEEPLES, which is on your R. There were two young noblemen one from each parish who fought a duel for the hand of a certain lady, this lady hearing of the fight rushed between the duist but died when her body was pieced by both swords. The two men, grief maddened fought on until they both died. The three bodies are said to be buried in Edvin Ralph Church.

 

 

 


Walk 8 The Skirrid

Last walked in March 2017

 

Description. A 5 km (3.1 miles) moderate walk. Ysgyryd Fawr is the most easterly of the Black Mountains in Wales, part of the Brecon Beacons National Park. The name is often anglicised to The Skirrid or Skirrid Fawr, and the mountain is also known as Holy Mountain or Sacred Hill.

Start. Explorer Map OL13 Grid 328165.

Direction from Tescos roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A465 towards Abergavenny. After 20 miles and on a short duel carriageway you TL onto the B4521 towards Skenfrith. A little further on, at a T-junction, (20.2 miles) you TL towards Skenfrith. At 21.4 miles you reach the parking area on your L.

 

1. Car Park. Face the road. TR and walk to the end of the car park. TR and walk up the enclosed National Trust Ysgyryd Fawr footpath. Go thru the double wooden gates/stile and follow the well defined, waymarked National Trust track uphill and thru the woods, initially and after a few paces going up some wooden steps and ignoring the track that bends off L. As you venture up the track you pass a wooden seat on your R, and further on the track goes thru a small/large wooden gate where you TR and continue on uphill. As you come out of the wooded area the track bends slightly to the R and continues uphill. You should now have some beautiful scenery around as you continue walking uphill and along the ridge to finally reach the summit.

 

There is a rich mythology attached to the mountain, including a distinctive stone known as the Devil's Table. According to legend, part of the mountain is said to have been broken off at the moment of the crucifixion of Jesus. There was a local tradition that earth from the Skirrid was holy and especially fertile, and it was taken away to be scattered on fields elsewhere, on coffins, and in the foundations of churches. Pilgrimages were made, especially on Michaelmas Eve (September 28th), to the summit. The ruins of an ironage hill fort and a medieval Roman Catholic church, dedicated to St. Michael, lie at the summit. Rudolf Hess used to walk here when he was held prisoner at nearby Maindiff Court during the early 1940s. Pete Snapper Winner, Soldier I, mentions this mountain site in his book, which is the Story of an SAS Hero and the part this hill played during Sickener, (Sickener being part of SAS selection).

 

2. Summit. Return back down to the car the same way as you came up to the summit.

 

Walk 9 Fromes Hill

Last walked in April 2017

 

Description. An 8 km (5 miles) moderate walk, but it does have a very steep hill at the end that is strenuous to climb. Lovely views as you walk down hill towards Cheyney Court Farm, and a pleasant walk along the bank of the river Frome

Start. Explorer Map 202 Grid 682466.

Direction from Whitecross Roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A4110 Canon Pyon (Three Elms road) for 1 mile and TR at the traffic lights onto the A4103 Worcester (Roman road). Continue on towards Worcester for 14.4 miles, and then turn L into Fromes Service Stations car park, (Wheatsheaf Inn on opposite side of road).

 

1. Fromes Hill Service Station. Fromes Hill is a small hamlet in Herefordshire, England. The population is around 350, with most of the residences along the main A road or to the sides of it. The hamlet has a pub, a restaurant, an ex army store and a church. Walk to the main road and TR. Pass the Wheatsheaf Inn on the opposite side of the road and continue on to reach St Matthews church and TR towards Halmonds Frome. (St Matthews Church was founded in 1877 and is Grade II Listed). Continue along this road for about km to TL at a bridleway sign, (look for the mobile phone mast on your L). Pass thru the small wooden gate/large metal gate into F1, and walk on past the R hand side of the mobile phone mast, Staying close to the R field boundary you go thru a gate into F2, and continue on to go thru a metal gate into F3 (an old small orchard), and on thru another gate into F4. After a short distance you go thru a way marked small wooden gate, thats in front of you but on the R hand side, and into F5, a hedge is now on your L. Continue in the same direction along the L field edge and at the end of the field you go thru a large metal gate into F6 and TR. Stay close to the hedge/fence on your R; descend slightly to the end of the field but dont go thru the metal gate in front, cross over the stile that is in the R hand corner of the field, by the fence. Walk a few paces further on and TR, to walk along the top edge of F7, (the tree line/fence is on your R). Reach the R hand field corner and cross a stile into F8 (a large stone slab is to the R). Continue on, but now the fence is on your L, to reach another stile in the L hand corner. Cross the stile, TL and descend down a track that keeps to the L hand side of the wood. At the end of the wood cross a stile into F9 and walk down the L field edge, (ignoring any way makers or gates on your L), follow the L edge all the way round to Cheyney Court, which may not be seen until you are nearly on it.

 

2. Cheyney Court. On reaching the outskirts of Cheyney Court you bear L and cross over a very trendy stile with two rungs that lift up to enable small people to cross with ease. Walk on down the drive thats to the L of the recently modernised Cheyney Court to reach a narrow road, TR. Walk along the narrow road to reach a T-junction and TL onto a wider road. Walk on down this road to pass the old mill on your R, also recently modernised. About 100m past the mill you cross over the river bridge, a few paces further on you TL over a stile into F10. Keeping the river on your L continue to the end of the field and go thru gaps in the hedge onto a road and TL. Walk a short distance and TR by a Public Footpath sign to go thru a metal gate into F11 (ignoring the fist set of metal gates on your R). TL and continue to follow the river on your L, thru two fields (F11/F12) to cross a stile/metal gate onto a road. Cross the road and a stile into a huge field F13, follow the river Frome, which is on your L, for a good 1 km. On reaching the L field corner you continue on along an enclosed grassy track for a short distance to reach a Public Footpath signpost where you TL and cross over a river bridge. The River Frome flows thru Bromyard and Bishops Frome, and at Covender its tributary, the River Lodon, joins it. It then flows west, past Yarkhill, Prior's Frome, before its confluence with the River Lugg at Hampton Bishop. The river also gives its name to several hamlets on the higher ground to the east: Halmond's Frome, Fromes Hill and Castle Frome. Walk along the wide enclosed farm track to a road where you TL.

 

3. Road and track junction. Walk along the road to reach a T-junction. TL and immediately TR up a No Thru Road to St Michael and All Angels Church. The little church of St Michael and All Angels near Castle Frome is to be found at the end of a farm track well away from the village. Originally it would have been in the village centre, but it is probable that this earlier village was evacuated at the time of the Black Death in 1348. Go thru the metal gates into the churchyard and follow the tarmac path as it goes to the R of the church and up to a wooden kissing gate. Go thru the gate and over a stile thats ahead, into open country. Bear slightly L and head on uphill to walk along the gully that runs between the two woods. When you get near the top you head for the R hand side of a house, to cross over a stile. TR and walk a few paces to go thru a small wooden gate onto a road, where you TL. Continue along this road and just past a house on your R, TR thru a metal gate and into F14. Keep to the hedge on you R, and when it turns sharp R, you bear half L, to cross the field, going down the hill towards another way marked post thats near the gully. Go across the gully via some steps, and then go over a stile into F15. Bear slightly L as you continue up hill to reach a garden hedge. Continue along the garden hedge that is on your L to go over a stile onto a road where you TL. Continue along this road to the T-junction and the car park is across the Hereford to Worcester road and off to the R.

 

 

 

Walk 10 Wyevale Nursery

Last walked in April 2017

 

Description. A 8 km (5 miles) easy walk along well defined tracks and roads.

Start. Explorer Map 202 Grid 490413

Direction from Whitecross roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A4110 Canon Pyon (Three Elms road). After mile and just past the pedestrian lights TR to park in the RANGE store car park.

 

1. Homebase. Go back to the pedestrian lights and cross the main road. TL, 40m TR to go thru a kissing gate and onto a public footpath. In front of you and to the L is Whitecross Hereford High School. The form and design of the school is heavily determined by a strong sustainability agenda with natural lighting, green roofs, mechanical ventilation with heat recovery systems and the use of thermal mass to stabilize temperatures. After a short distance you go thru a small wooden gate into a field F1. You go very slightly L as you cross the field to pass a big lone stump of a tree, and then go thru a small metal gate and across a wooden footbridge into F2. Walk around the L hand edge of this field and go thru a metal gate onto a road, (Huntington Lane). TL, after a dozen paces you TR and cross the lane to go thru a small wooden gate into F3. Turn slightly R and head towards an electronic pylon. Half way across the field the track bears off slightly R and you go under more power lines to reach the edge of the field, where you go down five wooden steps and onto an enclosed track. TR and continue along the track to go thru a small wooden gate and onto the Roman Road.

 

2. Roman Road. Cross the Roman Road and go along Tow Tree Lane ahead. When the road bends R, you carry straight on along a gated road and bridleway, and after 100m you TL and go thru a small metal gate into a small field F4. Cross F4 to cross over a wooden bridge into F5. Cross this field to go thru a small wooden gate and onto a main road (Roman Road).
