Go straight across the Roman Road to carry on up the road opposite, to go past the Livestock Market (L). At the end of the road, by tall metal gates and to the R of a No Entry sign thats painted on the road, you continue in the same direction along a tarmac path, and then along an enclosed grassy track. The enclosed track continues on, to go past Wyevale Nursery crops that are on your R, you then go thru a kissing gate/metal gate and continue on for a short distance to reach the main Hereford to Brecon road. Cross the road and TR, walk along the footpath, and not far past the entrance to Wyevale Nursery, and opposite a bus shelter on your R, you TL to go up an enclosed public Bridleway.

 

3. Wyevale Nursery and Wyevale Wood. Continue up to the T-junction at the top of the enclosed bridleway. On your L is Wyevale wood where you can sit down inside a bird watching wooden hut. TL and continue along a bridleway that initially runs just inside Wyevale wood, this bridleway was formerly called Green Lane. Wyevale Wood, formerly called Green Lane Wood, is secondary woodland on an ancient woodland site. Green Lane itself was originally part of a drover's road from the Welsh hills to Hereford and on to London. The drovers had an overnight stopping place at the "King's Acre", an area just east of the wood where there was a drinking pond for the animals. The bridleway widens out to become a stone track/road. Further on, just past a pond on your R, the road bends R, you go straight ahead and thru a hedge gap into F6 and continue in the same direction, keeping to the hedge on your R, (ignore any way mark signs to your L, that go into Drovers Wood). Continue on to the end of this field, thru a gap in the hedge and onto the end of the next field F7 where you TL down a bridleway.

 

4. Bridleway. Proceed down hill, keeping to the hedge on your R. At the bottom you continue in the same direction along a tarmac drive to reach the main Brecon/Hereford road. Go straight across the road and along Huntington Lane. After a kilometre the road bends R, L and R again, and a little further on we get to the pathway to St Marys church on your R. The church isn't easy to see from the road, this is the very pleasant path leading down to it. Just passed the churchyard and opposite Newcourt Farm drive, you TR thru a metal gate and into F2. Follow the R hand field edge around to cross over a wooden footbridge, thru a small metal gate and into F1. Go straight across this field, and thru the kissing gate thats near to Whitecross Hereford High School. Continue on thru another kissing gate and on to the road where you TL and then TR to cross over by the pedestrian lights. TL and carry on to the car park.

 

Walk 11 Knill and Offas Dyke

Last walked in April 2017

 

Description. An 8 km (4.9 miles) Moderate walk with a very steep strenuous early climb through woods to reach Offers Dyke. Along open ground and a brook. Well maintained trails with great views. Taken from Hereford Times Feb 2012.

Start. Explorer Map 201 Grid 291604. Knill church.

Direction from Whitecross roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A438 towards Brecon. At 12.1 miles go straight on, heading towards Rhayader on the A44. At 12.6 miles carry straight on through Eardisley, heading towards Rhayader. At 18.2 miles go straight across roundabout, head towards Rhayader. Go straight across the next roundabout, (18.5 miles), head for Rhayader. At 22.3 miles TR and take the B4362 towards Presteigne. At 24.7 miles TR to Knill. After a short distance you go through the hamlet of Knill and the road bends L (24.9 miles), you continue straight on and up an unmarked tarmac drive to the church (25 miles).

 

1. Knill Church of St Michael. Knill is one of those rarest of British locations, a thankful village. The term thankful village was coined in the 1930s to describe the handful of communities that suffered no military fatalities in the First World War. Between 1914 and 1918, there were no settlements in Scotland or Ireland that did not lose a member of the community, and only 52 parishes in England and Wales. Walk back down the church approach drive, on reaching the road you TR and walk along the road to cross over Hindwell brook ahead, via a concrete footbridge. Bend to the R and walk along the river bank for a short distance to TL and walk up a wide forest path thats between the two houses. 80m beyond a green corrugated iron shed that is on your L, TL, and go up a public footpath quite steeply through the trees of KnillGarraway. Continue up a well marked track and along a line of trees to bend R when you get near to the top, to reach a marker post, Mortimer Trail path junction. TR for 35m to reach another marker post, and TL to continue up to cross over a stile/metal gate into a large field {F1}.

 

2. Stile on upper, south edge of wood. Keep to the L field edge to continue up hill to cross over another stile/metal gate into F2. Keep in the same direction and bearing away from the woods on your L, follow way marker posts to reach the Offers Dyke path on the brow of the hill and TR and follow Offas Dyke path. Go thru a metal gate into F3 and continue on to reach the corner of a wood (R). The path bends to the L and continues on, it starts to descend slightly to go thru a metal kissing gate into F4.

 

3. Stile. Continue to follow Offas Dyke path as it gradually descends, going to the L of woods. Go thru a small metal gate into open countryside. Continue in the same direction and after about twenty metres you bear L and follow the path down for 100m to reach the information board at the cross track junction. Welcome to Herrock Hill Common gives you information on Grazing, Offas Dyke, Butterflies and birds, Common land and Common care. TR, walk up, along and down Offas Dyke path, following way marker signs to contour the east side of Herrock Hill. Descend through a small/large metal gate and continue on down. The path reaches a junction, you continue in the same direction, along an enclosed track. You pass a sheep pen and small buildings on your L and go through a small/large metal gate. Continue on down to go through another small/large metal gate and 50m further on you go onto a driveway (house is L). Continue on down the driveway and at 150m you TR through a small wooden gate into F5. Cross over the field towards the far L hand corner to go through a small wooden gate and onto a wide farm track. Bear L and continue along the farm track to reach the main road.

 

4. Riddings Brook. Just before the main road you TR across a stile/metal gate into F6. Keep to the L field edge of this very large field, following the small brook that eventually joins a bigger brook called the Hindwell Brook. Cross a stile into the F7 and keep to the L edge. Further on you TL and cross over a wooden footbridge across Hindwell Brook. Bear R and keep to the hedge on your R to go through a gap in the metal fence ahead and into F8. Bear slightly R and cross the field, keeping R of pond to go through a metal gate ahead, into F9. Bear slightly L to cross this field, to go through gate onto the road. TR, along road to where it bends L, go straight on and up to the church/car.

 

 

 

 

Walk 12 Stoke Prior and the Lugg

Last walked in May 2017

 

Description. A 5 km (3.1 miles) edited version of Hereford Times walk by Garth Lawson. A walk along country lanes and the river Lugg, with easily attained views and wildlife.

Start. Explorer Map 202. Grid. 523565.

Direction from Whitecross roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A4110 Canon Pyon (Three Elms road) for 1 mile and TR at the traffic lights onto the A4103 to Worcester (Roman road). Turn L at the first roundabout (2 mile), onto the A49 to Leominster. At 9.5 miles you go straight across the 2nd roundabout towards Shrewbury on the A49. At 10.5 miles TR on a minor road to Stoke Prior/Golf Course. At 11.8 miles, near to Stoke Prior church, park on the side of the road. Or a bit further on at the road junction.

 

1. Stoke Prior. Taking the start point to be the road junction island in the centre of the village, head up the road as if for Leominster. You go past an old Post Office on the R that has a number of old signs for food: Lloyds Tea, Colmans Mustard etc., and further on you go past the Lamb Inn (closed) on your L, with its large car park. After about km, on your R you go past a gated drive going up to a white house called The Slough, and 80m further on, by a hidden sign post and whats L of a barn, you TR to go thru a gate and along an enclosed track. After 75m you go thru a stile/gate and along the L edge of an orchard, to cross a stile into a field F1. Go along the L edge which bends L after about 20m.

 

2. Copse. A little further on the field edge bends R but you go straight on along a narrow path and into the copse. Keep ahead at the path junction, going under telegraph lines and on thru a gate into F2. Keep ahead and go thru a small field that has ant-hills. Go thru waymarked gap in a line of trees ahead (with great views of the Black Mountains and Radnor Forest). Keep ahead to cross a stile into F3, then you pass a way marker post on your L and veer L, to join a hedge on your L hand side. Continue down the path to the bottom of the field, cross over a farm track and go down the bank into a ditch called Hollow Way. TL to go over a stile and walk down an enclosed gully to pass to the L of Eaton House, over a stile and on to a country lane.

 

3. Eaton. TR, walk along the country lane for 195m to TL at a tarmac drive. Continue along the drive and thru the gates to reach the end of the farmyard, where you continue in the same direction, going in-between buildings (Stables are on the L), to reach the river Lugg beneath the Scots Pines. Going a little to your L you cross the River Lugg and weir via Eaton Hall Bridge and the Millennium Gate.

 

4. Eaton Halls 17th Century Stone Bridge. The next mile (1.2km) along the Lugg are a favoured place to spot a kingfisher. TL along the river bank, soon using two stiles to keep to the edge. Skirt past an extravagant loop in the Lugg, cross a stile that by the waters edge and cross a stile in L corner next to the bridge. Favoured area for otters and hares.

 

5. Volca Bridge. TL thru the gate and across Volca Bridge to then TR and cross over a three-plank foot bridge into a field. TL and follow the L edge. Go thru a gate in the L corner and across a loose stone driveway that goes to horse stables on the R, go thru another gate and into a field. Continue along the L field edge to cross over a stile in the corner to go down three steps onto the road. TR and return along road to Stoke Prior village.

 

 

Walk 13 In the Wake of Wellington

Last walked in June 2017

 

Description. An 8 km (5 mile), moderate walk. Good paths, but one uneven sunken overgrown lane (may need long trousers). Eight stiles. Country lanes, field paths, two villages and good views. [An edited Hereford Times walk April 2012].

Start. Park in church car park. Explorer Map 189 Grid 530212, continue on Explorer Map OL14.

Direction from Belmont roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A49 to Ross-on-Wye. At 9.4 miles TR onto the A4137 to Monmouth. At 11.4 miles TR onto a single lane road to Llangarron, (unsuitable for long vehicles). At 13 miles you reach Llangarron church car park.

 

1. St Deinst Church. St Deinst was a Celtic saint who died in c584 and tradition suggests he founded a church in Llangarron under his name, one that does not appear elsewhere in England. Records of a church being in Llangarron go back as far as Edward the Confessor, when a wooden church was consecrated, it was re-consecrated under William 1 as "lan garan" church. With your back to the car park/church, go straight up the road, as if for St Weonards. Near the top of Herberts Hill, turn sharp L up three steps and cross a stile into F1. TR and keep to the hedge on your R. After 100m you cross thru a small metal gate on your R hand side into F2 and continue in the same direction, the hedge is now on your L. At the end of the field continue along a channel to go thru a metal gate onto a road. (Ignore the main road on your L) TR and follow the road thats going to Broad Oak, walk up to the top of the hill, reaching a farm on the L called Tredunnock.

 

2. Tredunnock. TL in front of barn conversion and walk along an enclosed concrete lane (Private Road) for about km to reach Trecorras Farm. En route to Trecorras farm, (ignore the Private road going off to the R) the concrete changes into stony chippings. The lane/farm track has hedges on your L and fences on your R. Very near to the farm and just past the gated, cattle gridded drive that goes off to the R to Trecorras Cottage, bear off to the R, go thru double wooden gates and continue along the enclosed farmers dirt track. A little further on past a cream/stone house on your R, the track continues into F3 (ignore the track going down to the R) and continue in the same direction, keeping to the hedge on your R. The track continues along F4 going underneath power lines to reach a marker post at the end of the field.

 

3. Path Junction. TL, walk along the field edge, keeping to the hedge on your R. Cross a stile into F5, (there is a pond in another field to your R) and continue in the same direction with the hedge on your R. Cross a stile/metal gate into F6 and continue in the same direction, a fence is on your R. Go thru metal gate onto the road at Treduchan Farm. Keep straight ahead along the road into Llangrove, passing the Royal Arms pub (R) and on down to reach the church, (ignore roads off to the R).

 

4. Llangrove, Christ Church. Christ Church, completed in 1856, was the first church designed by George Frederick Bodley (1827-1907) who went on to become one of our major Gothic Revival architects. Continue on past the church and War Memorial, and at the end of the village, just past Llangrove Nurseries (R), take the next road L for Bryn Elm (small sign is on wall). At the cross roads, (just past The Elms), go straight across and down the road for about km. When you reach the last house on the R (new buildings) the road/drive bends R, but you carry straight on, with a hedge on your L, to go thru a metal gate/stile into F7.

 

2
 

1
 
5. The Grove. Go straight across this field to cross a stile into F8. You now have to cross a stile into F9, the stile is situated in the far L hand corner of this field, (to get to the stile you can bear L and walk across the field to reach a hedge corner, then turn half R and walk across a narrow strip of field and along the L field edge, following the hedge on your L). TR and go down the R field edge, with a hedge on your R, and at the field end you cross over a stile into F10. Continue on down and around to the R, parallel with overhead line. Cross a stile and go straight on down an enclosed, uneven sunken and overgrown track, to reach a surfaced country lane.

 

6
 

3
 
6. Trereece. TL and ross the pretty bridge over the Garron Brook and up the lane past Trereece Mill. At Treceece House you stay on the lane, which winds around the the R. Now follow the lane to the junction. TL, continue on over the stone bridge re-crossing the Garron to reach the church up to your R.

 

 

4
 


 


Walk 14 Ruckhall

Last walked in July 2017

 

Description. A 5 km (3.1 mile) walk across fields, along narrow roads and touching the Wye River where a small climb is involved. Very good views.

Start. Clehonger. Explorer Map 189 Grid 452377.

Direction from Tescos roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A465 to Abergavenny and at the second turning on the R you TR for Clehonger 2. In Clehonger, after 2.7 miles you TL, signed Village Hall, and park along Birch Hill Road. Entrance to the village hall is a few hundred yards on the L.

1. Clehonger Primary School. Walk down the tarmac drive to reach the village hall/school and TL, the hall is now on your R as you walk on across the grass to go thru a small wooden gate onto the main road to Hereford. Cross the main road and TL, after about 30m you TR and walk down a public footpath and thru a kissing gate into F1. Walk down the middle of the field, bearing off to the R, and go thru a small metal gate in the far R corner, into F2. With the hedge and woods on your L you walk along the edge of this field, when you get near to the end of the field, about 80m away, you TL and go thru a small metal gate in the hedge. Go down a muddy track and thru 2 metal gates and some wooden steps to reach the bottom and cross over a wooden footbridge. About 20m further on you TL(ignore gates on your R), and walk across F3 that maybe quite marshy, to go thru some brambles and cross over another wooden footbridge in the far L corner into F4. Walk up the field a few paces then TR, and keeping the brook on your R you walk across a large field (field might be split in two) to cross over a stile, (there are farm buildings on your L, at the top of the hill) into F5. Keep the brook on your R as you cross another large field, when the brook bends to the R you continue on across the field to cross a stile/metal gate onto a road.

 

2. Ruckhall Mill. TR, walk along the road and TL at the first junction, heading for Ruckhall. The road goes up hill then levels off, and when it bends to the L you TR and go along a road thats opposite a red telephone and red postbox (ignore the first turning R). After about 40m you bear off to the R and go along an enclosed narrow hedged lane. The lane bends to the R, further on it reaches a set of wooden gates into the Ancient Camp. TL just before the gates and go along a bridleway for about 10m to a track junction where you TR. Walk along a narrow ledged track, looking at the view across the River Wye as you cross a flight of steps and keep on ahead into the woods, (ignore the steps going down to the river, and the few stone steps going up to an old inn). Further on you TR and climb a flight of wooden steps, shortly after you go down a flight of steps. Carry on along the track and further on you go down another flight of steps to the riverbank. TR, continue along the riverbank and cross over a stile, just ahead is an old pumping station. Pass R of the old pumping station and along the gated boardwalk then TR, go along for 80m to pass thru a swinging gate/metal gate onto a driveway. TL and go along the driveway, crossing a bridge, and then going passed Tuck Mill cottage and house that is on your R, to reach a metal gate. Go thru the gate and up a woodland path to go thru another metal gate into F6. TR and skirt around the woods to go thru another metal gate into F7. Bear slightly L and go across the field and down towards the road. Pass thru a metal gate onto the road and TL.

 

2
 
3. Vallets Farm. Continue along the road. 100m passed Vallets Farm, (which is on your L), TR and go thru a metal gate into F8. With the hedge on your R, climb up the field edge to TR thru a kissing gate in the top R hand corner into F9. Walk along the field edge for 40m and TL thru another kissing gate that is directly under power lines, into F10. Head across a vast field, and in the far corner you go thru a kissing gate into a sloping field F11. The Black Mountains can be seen in the distance, and closer to hand you can see the three big satellite dishes at Madley Earth Station. Continue on in the same direction, keeping to the field edge, and walk down to the field corner. There are two gaps in front of you going into two different fields, you take the way marked gap

3
 
on the R and continue in the same direction keeping to the L field edge, the hedge is on your L. At the bottom of the field is an old wooden barn. Go to the R past a wooden barn and on thru a metal gate. Head up the field to pass thru another metal gate in the top L hand corner, into an orchard. Continue on in the same direction, with the hedge on your L, to pass thru a kissing gate into a field. Walk on to the far corner where you TL and go thru a kissing gate, then onto the road. Cross the road and TL, walk a short distance and TR thru a small wooden gate. The village hall and your transport is just ahead.

 

 

 

1
 
 

 


Walk 15 A Marksmans Mauseoleum

Last walked in July 2017

 

Description. A 10 km (61/4 miles) over 22 stiles, with modest climbs as you walk thru woods and low-lying fields. Go past monument and an old Hereford to Gloucester Canal. This walk is taken from the Hereford Times newspaper in May 2012.

Start. Ashperton Village Green. Explorer Map 202 Grid 644418.

Direction from Whitecross roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A4110 Canon Pyon (Three Elms road) for 1 mile and TR at the traffic lights onto the A4103 Worcester (Roman road). After 9.7 miles you TR at the traffic lights onto the A417 to Gloucester. At 12.3 miles you park on Ashpertons Village Green, which is on the L by the Village Hall and contains a big concrete cross in the middle.

 

1. Ashperton Village Green. Standing by the cross and with your back to the A417, head to the R hand corner of the green and go thru a wooden gate and into F1, (there is a small pond on your R). Bear L and walk down the field, going to the R of three imposing trees, to go thru a small wooden gate to the L of the bottom R corner, into F2. Walk to the far R corner, going underneath power lines and heading towards the wooden buildings of Canon Frome cricket ground. Pass thru a gate, then TL and walk in front of the pavilion. Leave the cricket grounds via a wooden gate and go into F3. Cross the field and go over the stile ahead (and three wooded planks), into F4. Go along the L hand edge of the field (ignore any metal gates or breaks in the hedge row(L)) to reach the top L hand corner and cross over a stile near by, into a newly grown orchard. TR and walk up the R hand edge of the orchard. At the top of the orchard you continue in the same direction and climb three wooden steps into F5. Bear L and cross the field to go thru a metal gate into F6, follow the L edge fence up the bank (Hansnett Wood is on your R). Near to the field end, TL across a stile into F7. Go straight across 2 fields (F7/F8), going over 2 stiles. Bear diagonally R and head to the R of a telegraph pole, to cross a farm drive and a planked footbridge and stile into F9. Go straight across the field to cross over a stile into F10. keep to the L of a stone building and go thru a gate to continue on L along a drive to reach the road.

 

2. Meephill House. Go straight across the road and thru a metal gate into F11. Bear R and head up to the top R hand corner of the field, to go thru a rusty way marked gate. Continue in the same direction along a woodland track for a couple hundred meters to go over a stile/rusty gate into a F12. TR, walk along the field edge (Childer Wood is on your R) to reach the bottom R hand corner of the field.

 

3. Path Junction. TL 40m, TR over a plank bridge and stile into F13. Go straight across the field and newly planted orchard to reach a hedge on the other side where you TR. Walk to the hedge corner and TL to go over a stile into F14. Follow the L field edge up the bank to reach the far L corner. TR, walk 40m to a gate and TL onto a road. TL and walk along road for about 1/2 km. Just past Clissett Wood (L) you TR at a Public Footpath sign to go thru a metal gate into F15. Walk down a farm track for about 20m and then bear L and cut straight across the field heading towards a power line pole and a small clump of trees. Continue on, to reach the corner of a wooden fence where you TR. Cross a stile (L) thats near the bottom L hand corner of the field, and cross over a small field and another stile by a corrugated iron barn on your R.

 

4
 

3
 
4. Gold Hill Farm barn. Just past the corrugated barn you TR across a stile into F16. Go straight across, heading to the bottom R hand corner where you cross a stile/metal gate into F17 and TR to cross a brook and go thru double metal gates into F18. Go diagonally L across the large field to reach the far R hand corner. Go thru metal gates into F19 and continue along the R field edge to reach the far R hand corner. Cross a stile into F20 and continue around the R field edge. As the field edge bends L, 50m further on you TR to cross a stile, then a drive going to Upleadon Farm, then another stile and into F21. Bear slightly L across the field to cross a footbridge into F22. Bear L and cross the field to cross over a stile into F23. Bear R over crest of crop field and cross stile into F24. Bear L across this field to go over stile onto a road.

2
 
 


5
 

1
 
5. Haywood Lane. TR and follow the road for just over 2 km. In so doing, cross the Hereford and Gloucester canal, bend R with its still waters below, past the old Munsley Tunnel House, beyond cricket ground and Haywood Thatches up to a Public footpath sign on the L and a house and an enclosed path on the R. TR and walk along an enclosed path, which is at the end of back gardens, to cross over a stile into a field. Walk along the R field edge to reach the R hand corner and cross over another stile. TL and go straight across the field, back to the car at Ashperton Green.


 

Walk 16 Pencombe

Last walked in July 2017

 

Description. An 8 km (5 mile) strenuous walk on minor roads and tracks and across farmers fields.

Start. Explorer Map 202 Grid 600528. Pencombe church.

Direction from Whitecross roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A4110 Canon Pyon (Three Elms road) for 1 mile and TR at the traffic lights onto the A4103 Worcester (Roman road). At the second roundabout, after 3.2 miles, TL towards Bodenham. At 9.5 miles at the T-junction TR onto the A417 to Gloucester. At 10.5 miles TL and go along a minor road to Pencombe. At 13.7 miles park in Pencombe Parish Hall car park on the L, just passed Pencombe church.

 

1. Pencombe Church. St Johns church is a very ancient and remarkable building in the Norman style. The tower (of stone) was rebuilt in 1840, and contains 3 bells. It has nave, a chancel, apse, porch, an ancient font, and three modern tablets. The church was rebuilt in 1865. With your back to the Parish Hall. TR and walk back along the road and past the church, which is on your R. Just past the church you bear R onto the road to Risbury, and go passed the village green on your L hand side that contains a monument. The road bends to the R and continues up a gradual hill. When the road bends to the R again, (on the L is a house called Hillside and on the R is a white house called Old Crosses) you TL and go through a rusty metal gate into F1. Bear diagonally R and cross the field, aiming to the R of a water tank on top of a tower that can be seen on the distant horizon. Cross over an stile (that may no longer exist), into F2, the stile should be near to a large pond and a corrugated iron roofed building. TR, walk a short distance and then bear off to the L, to pass to the R of the corrugated iron roofed building, and to cross over a stile into F3. Go straight across this field and over another stile into F4. Turn diagonally R and head up hill to reach the field corner and go through a gated gap in the hedge onto a road.

 

2. Road. TR and walk along the road. At the fork in the road you bear L towards Risbury. You pass by Great Hegdon Farm on your R and continue along the road to TR at a communication pylon, and continue along the enclosed bridleway to Little Hegdon. When you reach Little Hegdon you continue in the same direction along an enclosed grassy track thats to the L of the farm, and at the end of the track you TL through a gate into F5. Keep to the hedge on your R, and after a short distance your route continues along an enclosed farm track. Just as the track starts to bend to the R, TL and go through a small wooden gate into F6, then bear slightly R to cross the narrow field to go through a waymarked metal gate in the field corner and into F7.

 

3
 
3. Metal Gate. Walk up the middle of the field and aim for the top R hand corner to go through a metal gate onto a farm track. Continue in the same direction along an enclosed farm track and onto Grendon Court Farm. Go through the farms courtyard, keeping in the same direction, to meet up with a tarmac drive/road. The tarmac drive continues down to the bottom of the hill, when you get to the T-junction (end of the tarmac) you TR and cross over a cattle grid to continue along a wide farm track. As you walk along the track you go passed Grendon Lair cottages on your R and then continue up hill to Durstone Farm.

 

4
 
4. Durstone Farm. Go through the farmyard and follow the track as it bears to the L. Cross over a cattle grid to leave the farm and continue down a wide farm track. Keep to the track for about 11/2 km to reach the road at Pencombe. TR and walk to the car.

2
 

1
 
 

 


Walk 17 Black Hill and Olchon Valley

Last walked in August 2017

 

Description. An 8 km (5 mile) with spectacular views from an exhilarating ridge and a marvelous valley descent. An energetic ramble. No stiles. Challenging stepped, terrain ion places. Hereford Times Feb 2016.

Start. Picnic Area that is 3 miles from Longtown heading towards Llanveynoe. Explorer Map OL13. Grid 288327.

Direction from Tescos roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A465 to Abergavenny. At 9.7 miles you TR for Longtown 6. At 10.5 miles TL for Longtown 5. At 15.1 miles you TL for Longtown. At 15.3 miles TR at the The Crown Inn, (Established in 1751), and head for Longtown Village, a little further on, at the T-Junction you TR for Longtown Castle. Go past the castle heading towards Llanveynoe, and follow Picnic Area signs. At 16.4 miles TL and head for the Picnic area 3m. Go past Llanveynoe church and at 18.3 miles keep R and follow Picnic Area signs m. At 19.1 miles TR and at 19.3 miles you reach the Picnic Area car park.

 

1. Black Hill Picnic Area and car park. You are already at 410m above sea level. Leave the park area away from the approach road via the stile or gate. Go L straight up the obvious ridge along the grassy path between gorse bushes. Its quite a baptism: the steepest and toughest part of the walk is R here at the start. Take your time and youll reach a prow (the pointed front part of a ship) at the bottom/southern end of the very narrow spine. Now keep ahead, with the route becoming more level along a series of craggy stepping stones and recesses. (Spectacular views open out R across Herefordshire and L to Hatterall Ridge). After reaching the king of rocks, the obvious way ahead, along a well worn track, broadens out gently to the summit amid the heather and bilberry.

 

2. Black Hill Trig Point. Trig point is 640m high. From the Trig Point you bear L, north-west, and go past a small pond on your R and along a wide path that goes across typically boggy Black Mountains moorland terrain. Its a level walk across the plateau and you need to keep going in this direction for 1.2 km. You will reach a junction with a bridle path and be careful not to miss your turn here!

 

3. Cairn. The junction marker really is just a small pile of stones. Turn very sharp L here for the return leg down thru the Olchon Valley. Follow the faint, narrow grassy path downwards. It soon drops into an obvious depression. The valley opens out spectacularly in front of you. Keep L of the brook. The terrain becomes a rocky track. Eventually it levels out to become more of a grassy track thru Bilberry. Cross a couple of fords and go thru a gate in the corner. Now follow a sunken green lane, which can be muddy to join the narrow country lane.

 

4. Olchon Lane. Follow the lane for 2 km ahead until a L turn takes you quite steeply up to the car park.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 


Walk 18 Risbury Cross 2

Last walked in August 2017

 

Description. An 8 km (5 mile). A moderate ramble investigating country lanes, brooks and field paths, some quite testing. None of the gradients, which also visit the Humber and Holly brooks are too demanding.

Start. Explorer Map 202 Grid 571553.

Direction from Whitecross roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A4110 Canon Pyon (Three Elms road) for 1 mile and TR at the traffic lights onto the A4103 Worcester (Roman road). At the second roundabout, after 3.2 miles, TL towards Bodenham. At 9.5 miles at the T-junction TL towards Leominster. At 9.7 miles TR down Bowley Lane for Risbury. At 11.4 miles TR for Risbury. At the cross roads, [12 miles] TR towards Pencombe and after about 100m you can park on the L hand side, opposite The Old Post Office, and a red Post Box.

 

1. Risbury Cross. Walk back down the road and over the crossroads, westwards towards Stoke Prior and Leominster. Continue on past the derestricted speed limit sign and drop down the tree-canopied road. Continue along the road that bends to the R and goes up the hill to reach a T-junction. TR and descend to a pond thats on your R, just beyond an old mill house.

 

2. Risbury Bridge. About 30m past the road bridge you TR and go thru a wooden gate into an orchard and walk along the brook that is on your R. TR and cross over a wooden bridge over the brook and into a small field. TL (the brook is on your L) and walk along the narrow field, thru some trees, along the narrow field to cross over a stile. Continue on thru (possibly nettled) copse, and out via a metal footbridge on your L, into F1. Bear R and walk across to the L field edge. Continue on up the L field edge to pass between the fence/wood and the ruined building called Gobs Castle.

 

3. Gobs Castle. 100m beyond the building you TL thru a waymarked metal gate into F2. Now go half R and over the crest of large field and down to cross a wooden stiled footbridge (in trees) and into F3. TL, go down to the field corner and continue on for about 20m to TR thru a metal gate and into a wooded area. Follow narrow path thru trees and bear L to exit trees via a gated concrete footbridge. TR, the track follows the stream for a couple of hundred metres then goes off to the L and up the bank to reach F4. Continue on around the cropped field, keeping to the R edge. Ignore the stile on you R and about 100m further on you TR thru a small wooden gate into F5. Go half L and across the field to cross a stile onto a road. Keep on the same line across the junction and go along the road towards Stoke Prior. At the cross roads by the Stoke Prior and the 30mph signs you TR and continue on towards the Stoke Prior School.

 

4. Blackwardine Crossroads. The road bears to the R and reaches a cross roads that you cross over and go straight ahead and down all the way to Humber Church. Opposite the church lych-gate you TL and go along a Public Bridleway to Humber Court Farm. The lane bends R and further on it bends L (metal gates and a stile are on the L), at this point you TR, and walk along a short (30m) farm track that bends L to reach a metal gate just beyond a barn on the L. Go thru the gate into F6 and bear R, to walk up the long pasture to reach the far L corner and go thru a waymarked metal gate into F7. Follow the L edge/hedge to cross over a wooden gated footbridge in the bottom L hand corner of this field into F8, (ignore any gates on your L).

 

5. Bridle Path. TL and walk along the L edge of a large field, Go thru a small wooden gate in the L hand corner into F9. Continue along the L edge of this field and go thru metal gate at the end, which is 30m in from the L corner into F10. Go straight ahead and across this field, and thru a metal gate into F11. Continue along the L edge of the next two fields (F11 & F12) and thru a metal gate onto a farmer track. Go up a bank and on thru another metal gate and along an enclosed farm lane, into Buckland farm buildings forecourt.

 

7
 

6
 

5
 

4
 

3
 
6. Buckland. 40 metres beyond a weather vane thats on a roof to your R, TR (unsigned) and go down a farm track between barns and trees to go thru metal gate into F13. Bear R and pass just to the R of a hedge corner sticking out at you. Continue down the L field edge/hedge, and on thru a gate in the L corner and into F14. Descend quite sharply and head for the bottom R field corner, going just to the R of a lone tree. Cross Holly brook via a low bridge, and go thru two metal gates into F15. Climb the L edge of huge crop field and after about 350 metres cross a stile on your L, (the stile is opposite a lone tree).

 

2
 

1
 
7. High Stile. TR and continue on your original line up along old drovers lane. Just beyond a stile on your R (ignore) go thru farm gate, bear R by a grid (L) down a track past Gilhorn Cottage, up beyond Rail Meadow and Poplands to join surfaced track to Risbury Cross and start.

Walk 19 North Titley

Last walked in September 2017

 

Description. A 5 km (3.1 mile) moderate walk up and down a hill.

Start. Explorer Map 201 Grid 335604.

Direction from Whitecross roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A4111 to Kington. At 18.2 miles go straight across first roundabout, heading towards Rhayader on the A44. At the second roundabout (18.6 miles) TR onto the B4355 to Presteigne. At 21.6 miles, park in the layby thats across the road and just before reaching the church in Titley.

1. St Peters Church. The Parish church of St Peter dates from 1865 and is built on the site of a former priory for a branch of the Benedictine Order. Titley lies at the junction of two drover's roads and was used for the weighing of wool. Walk along the road and just past the church on your L, TL up a public footpath signed Circular Walk, (the Circular Walk route is what we are following). Go thru a metal gate in front of you and continue on up an enclosed track, keeping to the hedge/tree line on your R hand side. Ignore the first kissing gate on your L and continue up hill to the next kissing gate in front of you, which you go thru into F2, (ignore the enclosed track that goes R then L). Keep to the R field edge and near to the top of the hill, when the hedge on your R turns R, you go straight on ahead, to cross the field and go thru double kissing gates into F3. Cross this field, bearing slightly R of the L hand edge, to go thru another gate into F4. Start to descend as you cross this field to go thru another gate into F5, (Green Lane Wood is over on your R hand side). Continue in the same direction, under electric cable, and cross over a stile thats to the R of a gate and into F6. Keep to the L edge of the field and pass the farm buildings that are on your L, to cross over a stile.

 

2. Green Lane Farm. TL and after a few paces you TR and walk along a tarmac/dirt lane, (green Lane). Go thru metal gates and continue on towards Wychmoor Farm. Further on you pass a farm cottage on your R and go thru a gate onto an enclosed overgrown grassy lane, then on thru another gate and continue along an enclosed dirt track lane for almost a kilometre, going thru another two gates on your way along the lane. Just past an old stone, corrugated iron roofed farm building thats on your L, and at a wooden signpost, you turn sharp L and head towards Titley 1 miles, along an enclosed track.

 

3. Burnt House. Follow the Circular Walk way markers downhill and along an indistinct track. Go thru a small metal gate and into F7 on your R, then continue along the L field edge. Beautiful scenic views as you walk along. Go thru a gate into F8 and keep to the L edge for 80m, and at the hedge corner by a way marker post you turn diagonally R and continue on down to go thru a kissing gate into F9, (the gate isnt far from the bottom of the field). Go straight across this field, keeping parallel with Stocking Wood on your R

2
 
to go thru another kissing gate into F10. At the end of F10, in the bottom R hand corner, you TR into F11, and then TL to walk along a farm track, a hedge is on

3
 
your L. Continue along farm track and go thru a metal gate and along an enclosed track to reach a road by a farm house at Turning Ways. Cross over the road, and then cross over a stile into the field ahead. Dont loose or gain height while you cross this field and go thru a gate into another field. Head to the L of the church and surrounding buildings and

1
 
cross over a stile, then go thru a metal gate and TR, to head down to the main road where you TR for the car.

 

 

Walk 20 Marcle Ridge

Last walked in October 2017

 

Description. A 6km (3.7mile) moderate walk up and down the Ridge. Fine views across south and east Herefordshire. Along a ridge, thru fields and country lanes.

Start. Explorer Map 189 Grid 630346.

Directions from the Fire Station. (Turn milometer to zero). 200 yards passed the Fire Station TR signed 'Fownhope B4224'. After 3.9 miles, (in Mordiford) TL signed Woolhope. After 6.8 miles, (in Woolhope) TL at a T-junction and continue on main road signed for Ledbury. Keep R thru the next village and at a road junction, after 7.7 miles, TR signed Much Marcle. Go up the hill and along the ridge and at 8.8 miles TR at the next junction on the R and park on the L. (2 blue sign posts at this site: Unsuitable for HGVs and Unsuitable for LGVs).

 

1. Marcle Ridge Car Park. From the car park you go back up to the Much Marcle road and go up the public footpath steps on your R, over a stile and into F1, (you will now be following the R hand field edge and along the inside edge of the woods on your R for the whole length of the ridge, heading towards the TV and Radio Mast). Go thru a gate gap into F2. Just over half way up this field you will TR and go thru a small way marked metal gate and into the woods. TL and walk along the inside edge of the woods (fields are on your L). A little further along you pass a Trig Point. Walk in the same direction as you leave the inside edge of the wood and continue along an enclosed grassy track (fields L, shrub R). Go past the major TV and Radio transmitter ,which is in the field on your L, and continue along to the end of the enclosed grassy path to reach a metal gate. Dont go thru the gate but TL and go thru a small broken metal gate into F3, then TR and continue along the R hand edge of the field and down to some wooden steps to go thru a wooden kissing gate and onto an enclosed track. TL and walk up the wide aggregated track. Keep ahead at the crossroads, now surfaced, and go past the Primitive 1858 Methodist Chapel on your R. Continue on past Upper Nuttal on your R, then underneath power lines to reach Nuttal Cottage that is also on your R.

 

2. Nuttal Cottage. Directly opposite, TL across a double stile and into F4. Go across the field, following the power lines, and go thru three gates to the R of Nuttal Farm and into a small orchard. Continue in the same direction and go thru two more gates and into F5. Keep to the R edge (the TV/Radio mast is up the hill off to your L) and go thru a gate into F6. Continue in the same direction going thu more fields and gates and then you cross over a stile. At the end of this field you cross over a low fence where there once was a stile thats in a dip and into F7. Bear L and go across the field, thru a swathe of crops, heading for a lone oak tree. Go past the oak tree and thru a gate in the field corner and onto a road. Walk in the same direction along the road, passing the farm house called Noggin (R). Just beyond a corrugated iron roofed barn at the far end of farm, TR across a stile onto a track. After 40m you TL across a stile and into a field, then you turn immediately R over another stile and into another field (F8). Keep in the same direction as you walk along the top R edge of the bank in the sloping field for about a km, following the power lines all the way. Go thru a makeshift gate into F9. The bank descends and when you get near to the path/brook on the L side, follow the power lines and TR to cross over a stile thats above and to the R, into F10. TL, follow power lines down to the L hand corner of the field where you TL and go down a set of wooden steps with hand rail. TL along farm track to the road just beyond Pear Tree Cottage.

 

3
 
3. Rushall. TL and walk up to the crossroads (a walled red post box is in front). TL and walk uphill towards Woolhope. When you get to the T-junction you TR, heading towards Woolhope. The car park is further on the L, near the bend in the road.

1
 

2
 
 

 

 


Walk 21 Garway Hill

Last walked in October 2017

 

Description. A 6.4 km (4 mile) strenuous climb up and down hilly country. The 4 mile feels more like 5.

Start. Explorer Map 189 Grid 445269.

Directions from Tescos roundabout. (Turn milometer to zero). Follow the A465 to Abergavenny for a 7.1 miles and TL onto a minor road signed Garway Hill. At 8.1 miles TR at the T-Junction. At 9.2 miles TL at the next T-junction. At 10.3 miles at the hamlet of Bagwyllydiart, ignore the turning to the L and continue for 40 meters to TR signed Garway Hill. Continue along main road to park on the grass verge just before the red telephone box, total distance of 11.7 miles.

 

1. Telephone Box. Continue along the road and TL towards St Weonards. After 100m TL, at a Public Footpath sign, to go across a stile and down an enclosed track thats on the R side of F1. Cross over a wooden fence thats in the R hand corner and go into F2. Continue down this very rough fallow field; keep to the R of a stone building thats in ruins and on into F3, (field fencing is not that prominent). Carry on down, as far as possible to the R side of this field to TR when you reach the concrete driveway, and then TL when you reach the road. Proceed along the road, passing Stoggle Oak thats on your R, to TR at the first road junction. Go down to the bottom of this steep road to reach the drive at Lower Moors and TL to go thru the gate, then 10m on you TR and cross over a double stile into a field where you turn immediately L and continue up the L edge of F4.

 

2. Lower Moors. Cross a stile in the top L hand corner and along an enclosed track for 15m, then cross another stile into the next field F5. Keep to the L edge as you cross another stile in the top L hand corner and go into F6. Cross a stile at the end of F6 and continue up a track just inside a wooded area, to cross another stile onto a road and TL. Walk along this road to take the first road on your L, (at Bagwyllydiart), sign posted to Garway Hill. Continue up this road for almost a kilometre. You pass a chapel on your L by a fork in the road, as you continue onto Garway/Monmouth, and not far past Ashfield which is on your L, you TR and go up an enclosed dirt track.

 

3. Dirt Track. 80m up this track you TL and continue up hill along an enclosed track. The track gets narrower and more enclosed as you proceed up hill, (ignore the metal gate on your R). At the end of the enclosed track you go thru a metal gate out onto the open hillside, a radio mast is just off to your L. Continue in the same direction, going up hill to reach the brick enclosure by the trig point at the top of Garway Hill. Garway Hill is a prominent local landmark rising to over 1200 feet. From the top of the Hill there is a view of seven counties in a 360-degree panorama. White mountain horses graze there most of the year and raise their foals amongst the bracken. Sheep roam freely. A pond near the summit provides a water supply for the animals which lasts all the year round, despite there being no visible source to keep it topped up. The pond is also home to a protected species of newt.

 

4. Garway Hill Trig Point. TL and go down a wide grassy path, along a ridge, keeping to the R of a pond to reach a fence. Follow the fence around to the R and reach a metal gate by Garway Hill notice board. TL and go thru the gate and down an enclosed stony track/drive to reach a road and TL to the car.

 

 

4
 

3
 

1
 

2
 
 

 


Walk 22 Gladestry and Hergest Ridge

Last walked in October 2017

 

Description. (Take compass) An 8 km (5 mile) strenuous walk. One stiff climb, walking along bridle paths, country lanes, fields and open springy-turfed moorland. Spectacular views. Taken from Hereford Times July 2012.

Start. Explorer Map 201 Grid 230551.

Direction from Whitecross roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the (A4111) road to Kington. After 18.2 miles you cross over the first roundabout at Kington, (the town centre is off to the L), and head for Rhayader on the A44. A little further on, at 18.5 miles, you cross over the second roundabout and head for Rhayader on the A44. At 21.2 miles turn L onto the B4594 to Gladestry. Arrive in Gladestry and at 24.6 turn R and R again to go thru gates into the Community Centre, which is opposite the church.

 

1. Gladestry Church. This church, (of St Mary the Virgin at Gladestry), and parish almost certainly owes its foundation to Harold, King of England after his conquests of this part of Wales in the 11th century. Walk back the way you came, going around the outside of the churchyard, to reach the main B4594 road, (by a park bench thats on an island), and TR. Walk across Gladestry Brook and turn immediately L, (opposite the red telephone box) to walk along a surfaced lane/road, (Offas Dyke Trail). Walk for km to the point where the lane starts to turn R beyond an imposing Stone House (on the R), Once owned by James Watt, the inventor of the Steam Train in 1769. Just beyond the Stone House you TL and follow the public footpath sign thru the first metal gate into F1, the gate is under a telegraph pole. Bear L and follow the rutted farm track ahead, going thru a gate into F2. Continue along this field, keeping to the hedge on your L, to reach the far L corner of the field and TL thru a rusty metal gate. Go thru a Beech Tree plantation, thru another rusty metal gate and further on you TR across a wooden foot bridge at Mill Cottage. Go ahead across paved forecourt and bear L up a grassy track to cross a stile onto a country lane. TR, walk on for 150m to farm.

 

2. Llan-y-felin Farm. TL between the first farm buildings and go thru a metal gate. Continue on thru two more metal gates and into F3. Continue in the same direction, going up an obvious track. At the end of the field the track veers L and you continue on in the same direction, following a wye marker and passing two metal gates on your R, to go thru a gate gap beneath trees. Continue up an enclosed track and 50m further on you go thru a metal gate into F4, (This track gets overgrown and it might be easier to walk further into the field, keeping the R hand field edge in view). Continue in the same direction and stay by the R edge, to go thru a small metal gate thats in the R corner into F5. Keep to the R field edge to go thru a metal gate in the far R corner and along an enclosed grassy avenue. There are wonderful views opening up on your R side. Continue along the avenue going thru 3 or 4 more metal gates to reach a surfaced drive.

 

3. Upper Rabber. TL and go up thru a metal gate thats to the L of a cottage, into F6. Continue steeply up and thru the next gate and out into common pasture. TR and walk near the fence thats along the R edge. At the fence corner you leave the fence and continue in the same direction, taking the lowest track down Rabber Dingle and back up to meet trees and fence again. Continue in the same direction and where the fence on the R ends (goes sharply R), go straight ahead to walk along the lower flank of Hergest Ridge. Go past a way marker post and continue on for about 1/3 km where you reach a bridle way direction post. TL. Climb steeply up ahead to the trig point of Hergest Ridge. Might need a compass bearing at this point.

Hergest Ridge is a large elongated hill which traverses the border between England and Wales between the town of Kington in Herefordshire and the village of Gladestry in Powys. Its highest point, which is in England, is 1397 feet high.

4
 
4. Hergest Ridge Trig Point. At the trig point TL, head south west along Hergest Ridge for two km. The ridge dips and at a marker post you take the L fork, continuing along Offers Dyke path. Pass to the L of a small pool/puddle and descend, south-west, to pass four more concrete Offas Dyke posts to reach a dip. A little further on, at a point where the track is rutted and by a fifth

3
 

2
 

1
 
Offas Dyke post, bear L and go down the stony path which turns into an enclosed track. Pass thru wooden gates to reach the road, TR and continue down to reach the main road. TL along the road to pass the Royal Oak on your L, and on to TR to the church. Opposite the Royal Oak is the old Post Office and the Zion Baptist Chapel, which was built in 1842, it was here that the famous Welsh preacher known as "Jones the Rock" (Rev James Jones, 1820-1907) began his ministry.


 

Walk 23 Golden Valley

Last walked in October 2017

 

Description. An 9 km (5 mile) moderate walk in The Golden Valley meadow, pasture and brookside.

Start. Explorer Map OL13 Grid 363365.

Direction from Tescos Roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A465 Abergavenny road. At 0–8 of a mile you TR and take the B4348/9 to Hay on Wye. At 2–8 miles, in Clehonger, TL onto the B4349 to Hay on Wye. At 5–2 miles, at the T Junction, you TR onto the B4348 to Vowchurch. At 8–6 miles, and in a hidden dip, you TL for St Bartholomews Church and Vowchurch. 200 yards further on park opposite the church.

 

1. St Bartholomews Church. Face the church. TR, cross the bridge and continue along the road to Turnastone. Pass the first building on your R, Turnastone Court (renovated), then the church, then the old shop on your L, (I vow I will build my church before you turn a stone of yours declared two pious women who each decided to build a church in their parishes and the churches of Vowchurch and Turnastone stand on either side of the River Dore. The road bends R and 50m further on you cross a stile/metal gate on your L, into F1.

 

2. Long Meadow. Keep to the L of this long field to reach the far L corner. Do not cross the stile thats in the corner but TR, walk 10m up the field and TL to cross over a different stile into F2. Continue along the L edge, (by Slough Brook) for about 90m then bear R, to cross the field and head for the far R hand corner. Go thru a rusty gate onto a road, (directly in front is a drive going up to Cothill). TL and walk along the road for about km. Just after passing a wooden footbridge on your L, you TR and go thru a wooden gate and go up the L hand side of a plantation. Cross over a stile in the top L corner and TR under trees, to go past a marker post and on up thru ferns into pasture. Bear L and continue on up, heading for a stone building (Cothill Farm). Go under power lines, then cross over a tarmac drive, and continue further up to reach the drive to Cothill Farm where you TL.

 

3. Cothill Farm. Walk along the drive towards the house and cross the cattle grid, then continue on, heading between a barn conversation on your L (called The Stable), and the farm house on your R, to leave the farmyard via a couple of metal gates into F3. Follow the R field edge and go thru the gate in the far R corner into F4. TR and walk along the R field edge and go thru a metal gate into F5. TL, the fence is now on your L. Continue across the field to cross a stile/metal gate into F6. Bear slightly L as you cross this field, to go thru a metal gate thats L of trees, into F7. Turn half R to go across this pasture to the far corner, and continue along a little enclosed track and thru a metal gate. TL and walk along the L edge (L of the barns) and on thru a metal gate into F8, and just 10m on you go thru another gate on your R and into F9.

5
 
4. Shegear Farm. Bear L and go diagonally down sloping pasture, underneath power lines and towards the bottom R edge of the wood thats on your L. Go thru a metal gate at the tree edge and into F10. Walk down the pasture, (Peterchurch church spire can be seen on L), and across a stile thats to the L of a metal gate into F11. Keep descending along the L edge to cross over a stile into F12. Turn half R and head for the corner of the trees, after 50m you turn half L and continue on down the L field edge, to reach a wooden gate in the bottom L corner.

4
 
 


3
 

2
 

1
 
5. Trenant Brook. When you reach the footbridge and ford, do not cross but TR on yourself to follow the bank of the brook, which is on your L, downstream. Continue along the brook, going thru three gates and past Poston Court Farm that is on the other side of the stream. Go thru the fourth gate, and 25m beyond the footbridge that is on your L, TL across a stile and immediately go thru a gate ahead, (ignore the gate on your R). Go along aqn avenue, a fence is on your R and Trenant Brook is on your L. Reach the footbridge into Poston Mill. Do not cross, TR thru gate into meadow. Follow Dore, towards Turnastone church. Go thru gate by river elbow, orchard and gate to road. TL back to Vowchurch Bridge and car.

 

 

Walk 24 Burghill and Tillington

Last walked in October 2017

 

Description. A 9 km (5.6 mile) walk, mostly bridle paths and country lanes. Three stiles. Sites ancient and modern. Hereford Times September 2012.

Start. Explorer Map 202 Grid 479445.

Direction from Whitecross (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A4110 Canon Pyon (Three Elms road) for 1 mile and TL at the lights. Point 2 of a mile further on you TR and go along Tillington Road for Burghill 1. At 2.2 miles you branch R for Burghill. At 2.8 miles TL for the church car park.

 

1. St Marys Church, Burghill. (Among the antiquities in the church are a curious font of metal, placed on a stone figuratively carved of the Twelve Apostles; and a very richly carved oak screen, one of the finest in England). With the church behind you and to the R, TL and proceed up the enclosed wide bridle path/drive heading towards the mast thats in front, at the top of the hill. Go past a house on your L and continue on up the enclosed grass/dirt track. When you get near the top you will pass the radio mast thats in a field on your R hand side, then you pass a bungalow on your L and start to descend. At the slight R bend (the road can be seen below), TL thru a gate gap and by a signed bridle path into F1.

 

2. Go thru bridle gate. Continue up the L edge of the field to go thru a small wooden gate into F2. Ignore the way marker and go diagonally R, across and down the field to the bottom far corner, to go thru a way marked small wooden gate into F3, (if the field is heavily cropped then TR and follow R edge of the field down and around). Cut straight across this field, (if field is heavily cropped you go up and around the L edge), to go thru a small wooden gate thats about 80m down from the top of the field, into an enclosure. Continue across the top edge of the enclosure and pass some Mountain board Slopes that are on your L. Go out thru a gateway onto a wide enclosed drive and TL, towards Farm Shop and PYO. Ignore the Farm Shop as you go ahead thru Tillington Court buildings to follow a more surfaced drive at CourtCottage. Continue along the surfaced drive to reach a narrow country road T-junction and TL. Continue along this road to reach cross-roads that are by a pond on your L, and opposite Tillington Business Park.

 

3. Tillington pool. Go (carefully) straight across the cross-road and continue along the narrow country road opposite. Continue along the road for almost a km, going past Tillington Fruit Farm, to reach a T-junction, a gap into a golf course is ahead. TL, and continue to the end of the narrow country road (Crowmoor Lane), to reach a cross roads. Go straight across and up the lane/drive ahead that goes to Stretton Nursing Home. At the gated driveway, (gate no longer there) keep to the L hand side and go up the grassy ride between trees and hedge, keeping to the L hand side of the home. When you reach the upper end of the Home you go straight on ahead, thru a metal gate and into F4, ignore the small wooden kissing gate on the L. Continue on down the L edge, down a wide, grassy path. Go thru a metal gate and along an enclosed grassy path to reach the end, (about 130m), to go thru a small wooden gate on your L, into F5 and continue in the same direction. After a

2
 
short distance (20 paces), the field edge turns R and you continue straight ahead, walking along a wide grassy track, initially you go between a crop

3
 
(on the L) and tree plantation (on the R), to reach a metal gate. Go thru the gate and along an enclosed farm track. The track turns into a tarmac lane, to go thru a metal gate and onto a T-junction at a bend in a minor country road

 

1
 
4. Tow Tree Lane. TL. The country road goes slightly upwards for about of a km. Pass Tow Tree House (R) and reach the Hereford to Burghill road. (Cross to the pavement thats by 27 Willow House and TR, walk on for 115m. TL into St Marys Lane 175m to Chestnut Lane. TR to memorial tablet unveiled on August 18, 2011, the 67th anniversary of the crash in which 10 United States servicemen and flying crew lost their lives. Return to crossroads at 27 Willow House and TR.) Cross over the main road and continue on down the road opposite, to reach a pool (L). TL, and walk along a pebble path at Little Burlton, to cross a stile into a field. Go straight ahead and at the end of this field, in the far R corner, you cross over a stile into another field. Keep to the R edge of the cropped field as it bends R, then bends L. Continue on to go thru a kissing gate thats in the R corner. Go ahead along surfaced lane to Lower Orchards T junction. TL and walk up to the next T-junction. TL and 100m along this road you TR and go up to the car park. (Twelve Apostles. Go up churchyard between Yew trees. Plaque to airmen is by Memorial Cross. TR to exit just above Wordsworths ancient yew. Plaque to St Marys dead is in northern churchyard.)

 

4
 
 

 


Walk 25 Eardisley and Woods Eaves

Last walked in November 2017

 

Description. A 7 km (4.3 mile) leisurely walk. No stiles. Quiet country lanes and bridle path, mostly surfaced. Hamlet, historic tree and village on the Black and White Trail. Hereford Times walk of October 2012.

Start. Explorer Map 201 Grid 313492.

Direction from Whitecross roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the (A4111) road towards Kington and at 13.1 miles, at the church in Eardisley, TL. Follow the road and the public bridleway as it bends L around the church, to park in the small car park by Eardisley Millennium Castle Green.

 

1. Eardisley Parish Church. The church of St Mary Magdalene is famed for its extraordinary carved Norman font, which must be accounted one of the finest fonts in England, if not one of the finest bits of Norman Romanesque architecture of any kind. The font is built like a truncated hour-glass, or a goblet, with a short circular base supporting a wide circular bowl. The carvings are designed to tell a cautionary tale; a sinner saved from the clutches of evil. In the carvings the figure of a man is pursued by a lion (evil), and is saved by Christ from the lion. Christ is accompanied the Holy Spirit in the form of a dove above his shoulder. This scene is also interpreted as a depiction of the Harrowing of Hell. In another part of the design two knights engage in combat. The two figures are thought to represent Lord Drogo of Clifford and his son-in-law, Ralph de Baskerville of Eardisley, who engaged in a real-life combat in a dispute over ownership of land sometime before 1127. The elder knight was killed, but Ralph repented of his actions and became a monk at Gloucester Abbey. It may be Ralph who was responsible for hiring the Herefordshire School of carvers to create the font for Eardisley church. Out of Eardisley Millennium Castle Green car park and TL, walk along the surfaced bridleway, an enclosed lane. You are going to follow this wide and straight bridleway, that continues in the same direction for the next three kilometres, starting by crossing a small bridge before going into open countryside. As you continue on you will see buildings back to your L which are on the site of the old Eardisley wharf and the Hereford, Hay and Brecon Railway ran parallel with our route, 300 metres over to the L. After about 1 km you go past a mansion on the L, between farm buildings and then a couple of cottages before the path changes into an enclosed aggregated wide grassy track. Continue on to the end of the enclosed track, to go thru a metal gate and into a field. Continue in the same direction, along the L field edge. Go thru a metal gate and along an enclosed farm track to go thru another metal gate onto the road. You are now by the Red Gate Cattery and Boarding Kennels.

 

2. Red Gate. TR and walk along the country lane for about 1 km, passing thru the hamlet of Woods Eaves, to reach a road junction at Woods Eaves Farm. Follow the road around to the R, ignore the road on the L as you walk on ahead, with views opening up to the R (south) to Bredwardine and Merbach Hills. Walk on for about km to go past the next road junction on your L, by an old chapel and a cottage called Great Oak Cottage. (Just up to the L of the chapel is The Great Oak. Find the hollow in the trunk, which once accommodated 28 schoolchildren having a tea party to celebrate its rescue from a fire that they started).

 

3. Great Oak. Continue along the road to go past the next road junction on your L thats by a place called Hurstway, and a little further on a cottage called The Laurels. The road continues on to cross a small bridge over a stream and then reaches a T-junction by The Tram Inn in Eardisley. TR and walk along either pavement and go past Eardisley Village Hall to reach the church.

 

 

 

2
 

3
 

1
 
 

 


Walk 26 Skenfrith Castle Walk

Last walked in November 2017

 

Description. An 8 km (5 mile) pleasant moderate walk, with excellent views of the hilly countryside.

Start. Parking area in front of Skenfrith Castle. Explorer Map 189. Grid 458202.

Direction from Belmont roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A49 towards Ross-on-Wye. At 4.5 miles TR and take the 466 to Monmouth. Carry on the 466 thru Wormelow, then thru St Weonards, and at 11.2 miles TR towards Abergavenny. Go thru the hamlet of Broad Oak and at 14.1 miles TR and park at Skenfrith Castle.

 

1. Skinfrith Castle. Skenfrith Castle is the only low-lying fortress of the three castles of Skenfrith, Grosmont and White Castle, now known as the castles of the Trilateral. We have no early reference as to the foundation of the fortress, though a castle certainly existed here by 1160 when it came into the kings hands. In 1187 the engineer Ralph Grosmont was instructed by King Henry II to rebuild the castle in stone. However this work proved abortive and Henry II cancelled the building work in 1188 as unnecessary. In 1193, Sheriff William Braose pushed the unfinished castle into rapid service and a prison was later built within the stockade. With your back to the castle TR and walk along the minor road that bends L then R, going past St Bridgets church, a National School AD1843, The Old Vicarage and the Malthouse before the road crossing over a stream where you TR for Grosmont Castle and walk up a No Thru Road. Continue along this road for a good kilometre as it changes into a stony enclosed track when you go over a cattle grid. At the bottom of the hill near the river at Birch Hill, just before another cattle grid, cross over a stile on your R side and continue in the same direction along an enclosed footpath.

 

2. Wooden Stile. Continue along the footpath passing a farmhouse on your L to cross a stile and continue along a dirt track going down towards the river. Cross a stile thats on the R side of a metal gate and go into a field. TL, walk along the L field edge and after 30 paces bare R, a little further on you go along a way marked wooden walkway. Cross a stile, down some steps and along another wooden walkway. At the end of the walkway TR and go across a small concrete bridge over a brook and into F1, continue along the R field edge. Cross a stile/metal gate into F2 and along the R edge. Go over stile/metal gate into F3 and bear slightly away from the field edge to go over stile/metal gate and continue along the R edge of F4, passing Trevonny farm on your R. Cross a stile and two wooden planks into F5, the hedge is on your L. After short distance you hit a farm track, TL, go thru metal gate and continue up the enclosed stony track towards Box Farm.

 

3. Box Farm. Go thru the farmyard and at the end TR, pass the farm house that is on your L and cross over a cattle grid, continue along the farm track/drive to eventually cross another cattle grid and onto the main road. In front of you are two metal gates, go thru the L gate/stile into F6. Bear slightly L and follow the hedge on your R, near the far end of the field and just before

3
 
reaching two big trees you TR thru a metal gate into F7. Bear L to the far corner and go over a stile. TR, cross a gated wooden footbridge and up some wooden steps. Continue on for a short distance and hit a tarmac drive where you TR. Continue up

2
 
the drive to cross over a cattle grid, TL and go thru a wooden gate into F8. Go straight across this field, thru a small wooden gate/metal gate, across a brook and up the track that bends to the R. Go straight across this field (F9), heading to the L of the buildings in front of you to go thru the gate in the corner and onto a farm track/drive. TL and proceed down the drive. The drive bends to the R and goes over a cattle grid, it then continues on and goes over

1
 
another cattle grid before reaching the main road.

4
 
 


4. Main Road. TL, walk along the main road and after about 140m you pass Norton Baptist Church(L), after another 200m you TL over a stile by a footpath sign and into a small field. Keep to the brook thats on your R to cross a gated wooden footbridge over a stream and into F10. Cross the field then a stile/metal gate onto a main road. TR, 30m on you TL and proceed along a narrow single lane road for 1 km to Skinfrith Castle and the car.

 

 

Walk 27 Kings Caple and Fawley

Last walked in November 2017

 

Description. A 9 km (5 mile) moderate walk along quite country lanes, fine bridleway, two crop fields and over four stiles. Quite long stretches of road walking. Hereford Times Nov 2012, edited version.

Start. Map 189 Grid 55828. King Caple church.

Direction from Belmont roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A49 to Ross-on-Wye and after .3 of a mile, at traffic lights, you TL and head towards Holme Lacy on the B4399. At the first mini roundabout (.5 of a mile) TR to Hoarwithy. At 7.2 miles, just before entering Hoarwithy, TL to Kings Caple. About mile further on, at 7.6 miles you TR, signed to Ruxton, and drive along a single lane road to the church. Total distance is 8.5 miles.

 

1. Kings Caple Church. The churchyard stands on the bailey of a Norman castle, whose motte, known as Caple Tump, stands across the road. With youre back to the church gate, cross the road and TL, walk a short distance and TR to walk along a drive. Walk a short distance and TL to cross over a stile/gate and into F1. Follow the R edge and at the end you go thru a kissing gate and onto the road, (the field may be separated by an electrified fence). TR, walk down the road, (Sellack Church can be seen in the distance), after just over km you pass by Shieldbrook, a cottage on your L that was once an inn called The Old Boar, serving barge workers.

 

2. L turn at bottom of lane. At the bottom of the hill the road bends sharply to the L. At this point you can take a quick detour and go straight on along the enclosed public footpath to look at Sellack Boat suspension bridge. The bridge was built in 1895 and brought to an end the centuries old ferry between the parishes. Stay on the road and after almost a kilometer you reach an islanded T-junction, TR, the cattle grid entrance to Poulstone Court is on your R. Continue along this road until it bends sharply to the L.

 

3. Bridlepath to Fawley. Go straight ahead and along a wide grassy bridleway at (what is) Ingsbury Cottage, where you go thru a metal gate into F2. Follow the fine L edge of the field (with Strangfords old Wye bridge coming into view over to the R). At the end of the field you drop under the old railway line and go thru a metal gate into F3. Bear R and go across the field, (there is a pond on the L hand side), and go thru a bridle gate thats near to two large oak trees and into F4. Bear L up a bank and go along the L edge of the field. Further along this field you walk along a dirt track and then thru a metal gate into F5. Go straight ahead across a cropped field, head to the R hand side of a small wood in front, to go thru a metal gate and into F6. Follow the L edge to the end of the field and go thru a metal gate, then along a drive and thru more gates that are L of barns, to reach a road.

 

4. Fawley Chapel Area. TL, (TR for Fawley Chapel), walk along the road for km to reach as T-junction at Fawley Cross. TL and walk along the road for km to reach Fawley Court. The road bends to the R and after a short distance you TL for Kings Caple and Hoarwithy. Cross over a cattle grid and along an unfenced road. Continue along this road for about 1 km, crossing over another cattle grid and over an old railway line, (Fawley Halt was down to the L, and Fawley Tunnel is a couple of hundred yards on the R, shrouded by trees,) to reach a boulder island T-junction at Penalt.

 

5
 

4
 

3
 

2
 

1
 
5. T-Junction. Go very slightly L and over stile/metal gate to cross an enclosure and over another stile into F7. Go slightly R as you cross this field and thru a gap in the hedgerow into F8. Continue in the same direction across this next field, to go thru a very narrow gap in the hedge thats just R of a wooden power cable pole, and into F9. Follow the overhead power cables and on reaching the way marked second pole, about 100m on, you bear L, (the lines go off to the R) to go straight across this field to reach a road, (directly opposite is Caple Avenue). TR, continue along the road to pass King Caple Primary School thats on your R. Continue along the road, going straight across the crossroads and on back to the church at Caple Tump.

 

 

Walk 28 Clehonger

Last walked in November 2017

 

Description. A 9 km (5 mile) walk across flat landscape, crossing over a number of cropped fields, so it can be arduous if done when its sodden wet, or when fields have just been ploughed.

Start. Clehonger. Explorer Map 189 Grid 452377.

Direction from Tescos roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A465 to Abergavenny and at the second turning on the R, (after point eight of a mile) you TR for Clehonger 2. In Clehonger, after 2.7 miles you TL, signed Village Hall, and park along Birch Hill Road, very near to the Village Hall.

 

1. Clehonger Village Hall. Walk a little further along the road and when it bends R onto Gosmore road you go straight on and continue along Birch Hill Road. The road bends R, and a short distance further on you TR and go along Pleasant Row. When you get to the first T‑junction you TL, at the next T-junction you TR and walk along Poplar Road for a couple hundred meters, passing The Hollies road thats on the R, you then TL at a Public Footpath that is across the road from house number 15 (Berllan). Walk along an enclosed track to cross a stile into F1. Continue along the L field edge for about 120m, then TL thru a kissing gate and immediately TR and walk along an enclosed track. Cross a stile and go straight across F2. Go over a stile, over three planks of wood and across a minor road.

 

2. Minor Road. Cross a stile/metal gates into F3 and go half L across this field. Cross a stile and three planks of wood into F4. Go straight across this field, heading for a gap in the far R corner. Go thru the gap in the corner into F5; ignore the bigger gap in the hedge thats on your L side. TL and walk around the field edge, (hedges on your L), and 30m around from the L field corner you TL to cross over a styled wooden footbridge. Keep to the fence on your L, (there is a pond on your R) and after 25m you bend L and then TL to cross a stile and to walk along a wooded area, keeping to a fence thats on your R. Just past a cottage thats on you R you cross over a stile, then immediately TL and cross another stile into F6. TR and carry on up the R field edge. Go past the metal gates in the field corner and continue around the field edge, to TR over a stile and onto a road. TL and continue along the road. Go straight forwards across the first cross roads and head towards Allensmore, then TL at the next crossroad and head towards Holly House, along a No Entry road.

 

3. Crossroads. 100m passed the house on your L (Court Plocks), TR and go thru a wooden gate into F7, and go along the R field edge. Go thru two small wooden gates, into F8 and continue in same direction. Cross a stile/metal gate and along a short narrow enclosure to go thru a small wooden gate into F9. Continue along the R field edge, to go thru a kissing gate and over three wood planks into F10, TR and follow R field edge. Ignore the first gate that leads to a wooden footbridge and TR thru the second metal gate, to walk along a grassy enclosure, heading towards buildings. Go thru a gap in the hedge/fence into F11, TL and follow L field edge to cross a stile/metal gate and onto a driveway. TL, walk along a bridleway/driveway and pass Goospool house thats on your L. Go thru metal gate into F12 and carry on along the R hand field edge, the wood is over on your L side. Go thru a metal gate thats in the field corner and into F13. Go across a large field and thru another gate into F14. Walk across this field to go thru a small wooden gate and onto a road. TL, 30m TR and walk along Church Road toward Ruckhall.

 

4
 

3
 

2
 

1
 
4. Church Road. Walk along Church Road until you get to the church and TL up a Public Footpath. The path starts along a grassy enclosed track thats at the back of houses, you then go thru a metal gate into an open field (F15), and follow the R field edge. Go thru a double metal into F16 and keep to the L edge, heading for farm buildings. Continue in the same direction along an aggregated farmers drive to reach a track junction, TL and walk along the farmers drive and thru a metal gate onto a road thats by the entrance to Bowling Green Farm. TR, walk along the road and take the first turning L, to walk along Gosmore Road. After about kilometre TR at a Public Footpath sign (ignore the first one on the R), then, keeping to the R you cross a childrens playing field to go thru a small gap and onto the village hall car park, TL to get to the road and your car.

 

 

 

Walk 29 Malvern Hills

Last walked in December 2017

 

Description. A 9 km (5.6 mile) walking along good tracks and minor roads through woodland and across part of the Malvern Hills.

Start. Hollybush (A438) Explorer Map 190. Grid 759369.

Directions from Whitecross Roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A4110 Canon Pyne (Three Elms road) for 1 mile and TR at the traffic lights onto the A4103 Worcester (Roman road). After 7.7 miles TR, signposted to Stoke Edith. After 9 miles TL at road junction (not sign posted) onto main road to Ledbury. Reach roundabout at 15.9 miles and go straight across heading for the Town Centre. Go through town centre and TL at traffic lights onto the A449 to Malvern and Worcester (total 17 miles). After 1 mile LR onto the A438 to Eastnor and Tewkesbury (total 18 miles). After 2.9 miles just past the Hollybush signpost, on the left is a car parking area with a Countryside Information Board in it (total 21 miles).

 

1. Car Park. With your back to the main road, cross over a cattle grid and walk up a tarmac road/drive to Peacock Villa, which is about 1 km away.
