(As you walk up the road, (that soon loses its tarmac), away over on the left hand side can be seen Eastnor Obelisk, a 90 foot high memorial to various distinguished members of the Somers Cocks family, the greatest of whom was John Somers, Lord Chancellor in 1700 and adviser to William of Orange who arrived from the Netherlands with the Glorious Revolution in 1688. Another is Philip James Cocks, an intelligence officer on Wellingtons staff, who died at the siege of Burgos in the Peninsular War on 8th October 1812). Before reaching Peacock Villa the road/drive goes through a metal gate and starts to descend, and at the bottom is a cattle grid. Just before the cattle grid, (dont go over it) you TR, through a metal gate, (or gap), and into the woods, and walk along a prominent dirt track. After about km you reach a cattle grid, and there is a small wooden gate at the top of the bank on your right, go through that gate and veer off slightly to the right (east) as you follow an indistinct track up and out of the woods, onto the open hillside and up to the ridge top, where there is a low level, stone concreted direction indicator post that points to: Obelisk - Midsummer Hill, British Camp, and so on. When you get to the top of the ridge you TL.

 

2. Direction Post. Walk along the ridge of the Malvern hills, keeping in the same direction for about 2 kms, to reach a car park on the A449. Firstly you reach a T‑junction in the track at Hangmans Hill, and TL to continue along the ridge. You then pass a small cave on your right called Clutters Cave, (used to be called Giants Cave, but the name of Clutter was taken from a hermit who lived there some centuries ago). You then get to cross tracks by a stone concreted direction indicator post, and go straight across, keeping to a track that goes down and around the right hand side of the British Camp. (The British Camp is an Iron Age hill fort located at the top of Herefordshire Beacon in the Malvern Hills. The fort is thought to have been first constructed in the 2nd century BC. A Norman castle was built on the site. The extensive earthworks remain clearly visible today and determine the shape of the hill. The height of the summit of British Camp is 1,110 feet). Keep on this track thats goes down to the car park, passing a reservoir thats over on your right hand side.

3
 
3. Herefordshire Beacon Car Park. Once you have gone through the wooden gate into the car park, you turn hard right, (almost back on yourself) to walk down to the bottom corner and cross a cattle grid, then continue down a tarmac lane, heading for the reservoir. Go past the reservoir thats on your right and on down a very steep concrete drive, and then onto a dirt track into the woods. The track bends to the right across a brook and continues up a slight incline, heading south. You come out into the open, and keeping in the same direction follow the track that heads for the farm buildings/houses in front and slightly to the left. On reaching the houses you continue on south, along wide track/drive and pass the houses on your left. Continue along the track/drive and when it bends left you carry straight on, and go along a Public Bridleway, (ignore the track thats veers off to the right). For about km you go across rough swampy ground, keeping in the same direction and very slightly to the right, to reach a minor road at Swinyard Car Park.

 

2
 
4. Swinyard Car Park. TR and go along the minor road, (ignore the tarmac lane on your right). After about 1 km and not far past a house on your left (roughly 300m), you veer off up a well defined dirt track on your right that initially goes in the same direction, then bends right to meet a main road. TR and walk up along the road to the brow of the hill and to the car.

 

1
 

4
 
 

 


Walk 30 Lyonshall

Last walked in December 2017

 

Description. [Need your speakie as the route may have changed] An 8 km (5 mile) walk across farmland, a short stroll thru woods and along minor roads. Pleasant and interesting surrounding to look at.

Start. Lyonshall Church. Explorer Map 201. Grid 331563.

Directions from Whitecross Roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A438 to Brecon and after 1.4 miles TR onto the A480 to Stretton Sugwas/Creden Hill. At 2.1 miles you go straight across the roundabout and head towards Kington. At 10.9 miles TL onto the A438, and immediately TR for Kington. At 14.8 miles the road bends R then bends L, and continues on towards Kington. At 15.4 miles TL at a T-junctions and head towards Kington, a little further on (15.5 miles) TR up a narrow drive for Lyonshall church car park.

 

1. Lyonshall Church and Castle. Face the church and take the path that goes along the R hand side of the church, with the main road being off to your R. Go thru the small wooden gate. (at this point you could bear L and go thru a small metal gate to look around the remains of the Norman castle. Walk round the moat and the back of the keep. The building of the castle started in about 1090, when the Devereux family held it as lords of the manor from Roger de Lacy. In 1406 Owain Glyndur and Welsh raiders damaged both the castle and the church. Bear slightly R to go thru a small metal gate and into a field, bear L and continue along the top of the field to go thru a metal gate onto a tarmac lane. TL, and continue along the tarmac lane that turns into a wide dirt/stony track. Just past the apple tree plantation on your R the dirt/stony track bends around to the R, but you carry straight on along a dirt track thats to the R edge of a field. The track enters a wood and you go thru a wooden gate and continue on in the same direction for a good distance, ( km or more) to reach a T junction. TL and walk along a stony track to go thru wooden gates and onto a minor road where you TL. Continue along the road to just before reaching the T junction, you turn L and walk along an aggregated drive/public footpath.

 

2. The Heath. At the end of the dirt track/drive you go thru a metal gate into a field F1. After 100m down the R side of the field you TR to cross a stile and walk along a fenced enclosure and thru a metal gate into a field. In the top R hand corner you TR thru a small metal gate, you then TL and go thru a kissing gate into a field. T sharp R, cross the field to cross over a stile into F2. Go just past a wooden hut (L) to TL and pass thru a metal gate and up an enclosed track to reach the main road. Cross the road and thru a k/gate and walk along the L edge of F3. Walk about 100m (almost to the electricity pole) to TL thru a k/gate into F4 and continue along the L field edge/hedge. Follow L field edge/hedge to the bottom L hand corner, TL thru a metal gate into F5. TR, and walk along the R field edge, you are now walking along Offas Dyke. Continue along the R edge of this large field to cross over a stile and thru a metal kissing gate onto a tarmac lane that goes to Lynhales Nursing home.

 

3. Tarmac Lane. TR, walk 30 paces and TL, go thru another kissing gate into F6. TR, follow the R field edge and go thru another kissing gate thats in the field corner and into an apple orchard. TL, go down L edge and thru the metal gate. Turn sharp R, walk a few paces to reach a track and TL, walk along the track thats between trees, to reach Bollingham Lane. An archaeological dig by Cardiff University in 2003 found fragments of 1st and 2nd century pottery in this vicinity. Cross the road to the path to the R of the house (Lower Lodge), thru a small metal gate and along a short enclosed track. Cross over a wider track and continue in the same direction along another enclosed track, the fields on your L and wooded area on your R. Cross a double gated wooden footbridge into F7. Continue up the L hand field edge and near the top, when the field edge bends to the R, walk on around for a few paces and then you TL, to follow a track that soon goes thru a kissing gate and along an enclosed track that heads towards some buildings. At the end of the track you TL thru a kissing gate and along a drive to reach the road and TL.

 

2
 

1
 
4. Road. On reaching a T-junction, turn L thru a kissing gate and into F8. Go straight across this field and thru a kissing gate into F9, and follow the fence on your R. Go thru a k/gate and along a farmers drive and towards buildings and the church in the distance. Continue to walk along the trach as it bends to the R in front of an orchard. You cross a stream, if its too deep you can cross it by using the double gated footbridge thats on your R hand side. Continue on along the farm track and cross another double gated wooden footbridge, thru a kissing gate and onto a road. Opposite is a place called, The Barns.

 

5
 

3
 
5. Kissing Gate. TR, 20m on, opposite a chapel, TL along an enclosed drive. At the end of the drive you continue for a short distance along an enclosed track to cross a stile/metal gate into F12. Go straight across this field to cross a double stile by a metal gate and into the orchard ahead. Straight thru the orchard and at the end you TL and walk along the R edge for a short distance to TR and cross a double stile into F13. Cross this field to go thru a kissing gate and onto a tarmac lane. TR, walk along this lane to cross the main road ahead and on up to the church car park.

 

 

4
 
 

 


Walk 31 Woolhope

Last walked in January 2018

 

Description. A 9 km (6 mile) moderate ramble over good terrain. Some interesting views. Edited a walk taken from December 2012 Hereford Times.

Start. Woolhope. Explorer Map 189 Grid 612358.

Directions from the Fire Station. (Turn milometer to zero). 200 yards passed the Fire Station TR signed 'Fownhope B4224'. After 3.9 miles, (in Mordiford, by the Moon Inn) TL signed Woolhope 3. At 6.6 miles, (in Woolhope) TL into the village hall car park.

 

1. Woolhope Village Hall. Woolhope lies in the Woolhope Dome, a designated area of outstanding natural beauty, with some of the most beautiful landscape, intriguing geology and abundant flora and fauna in the county. Walk away from the hall and along the R edge of the playing field, (the main road is on your R hand side). Go thru the small wooden gate thats in the far R corner and TL to go along the track that goes to Woolhope Church. Go thru a wooden gate and pass the church, which is on your L, and out thru a small gate thats to the R of the lych-gate and onto the road. TL and go down the road for Ledbury, Putley and the Butchers Arms; the Butchers Arms being about  km away. Just before reaching the Butchers Arms pub garden, (which is on the R hand side), TR and go along a surfaced lane that heads towards the woods. In about km you reach a junction where the lane bends L along a Public Footpath to The Poplars, dont TL at this point, carry straight on up towards the woods. Continue up an aggregated farm track that bends R, (ignore the track going off to the L), the track continues on behind residence(R), to go out thru a wooden gate into F1.

 

2. Wooden Gate. Bear slightly R and walk up the field valley to reach the R hand corner of the field, to bear R and cross a stile/metal gate into the wood. Go straight thru the wood, (ignore the track thats goes off to the R), and back out via a stile/metal gate into F2. Keep to the outside edge of the wood thats on your R, and when the field/wood bends R, by a metal gate, you cut straight across this large field to go across a stile on the other side, and into Hyde Wood. Continue in the same direction and go down a wide stony path into Hyde Farm.

 

3. Hyde Farm. At the track junction by barn you turn sharply L and head towards another barn. TR in front of the second barn and continue on thru a metal gate and along a farm track that bends R, further on it bends to the L. The track goes thru a metal gate and bears R as you go along a straight tree lined avenue. Go thru double wooden gates/stile/cattle grid and onto a tarmac lane and TL. The lane rises as you pass the drive to Sapness House on your R, it then goes down a little before you turn sharp R and continue along a wide enclosed farm track. The track goes down and bends away from Sapness House, to continue along the L hand side of two large fields. At the end of the second field the farm track bears off L by a row of trees that are directly in front of you. Go straight on along a muddy track and along the row of trees (L) towards a house (Greyhill Barn) (R) to reach a stony lane.

2
 

1
 
4. Greyhill Barn. TR and continue along the stony lane. The lane becomes tarmacked, you continue on for some distance to reach a road T junction. Go straight across and over a stile into F3. Cross the field to go over a stile/metal gates into F4. Cross over a stile, then a drive and another stile thats underneath a tree, into F5. Make for the L corner of the field to reach a stile near the road, but dont cross it. Instead TR and walk along the old Houet Brook(L). Cross stile/metal gate into F6 and continue along the brook thats on your L, to cross a double gated wooden footbridge into the churchyard.

 

5
 

4
 

3
 
5. Sollers Hope Church. Between 1300 and 1546 the church here is thought to be the work of Robert Whittington, the elder brother of Dick Whittington, the three-time Lord Mayor of London whose much simplified life story is familiar to every schoolchild. Within the church the most interesting monument is a slab tomb and effigy to a medieval knight which may date to as early as the 13th century. Immediately behind the church is a tump which marks the site of a Roman camp. TL, a short distance around churchyard you TL again, and go thru a small wood gate. 30m on, (dont cross brook), you TR thru a metal gate into a paddock, on the other side of the paddock you cross over a stile. Walk on a short distance to go thru a metal gate and into another paddock. Continue thru the paddock to cross a stile thats just to the R of a small brick shed and go into F7. Continue in the same direction along the R field edge, and go thru the gap at the end of the field. Go slightly L across the small enclosure to go over a stile and brook into F8. Keep to the hedge on your L and when it bends L you continue straight on over the crest of hill and a stile into F9. Cross this field and then go across three wood planks into F10, then TR. 120m further on, when the brook bends to the R, you continue straight on across the field passing a telegraph pole to cross a stile onto a road. TL and continue along road, to TL again by a road island as you continue on to reach Woolhope, ignoring the road on the L thats going to Alford Mill. At T junction TL and a little further on you TR to go thru the churchyard and so back to the village hall.


 

Walk 32 Kimbolton, Bache Camp Hillfort and Dovecote

Last walked in April 2018

 

Description. A 6 km (3 mile) walk thru pasture and country lane and passing thru Kimbolton, the Dovecote and Bache Camp Hillfort. Edited walk taken from September 2014 Hereford Times.

Start. Kimbolton St James church. Explorer Map 203 Grid 526616.

Directions from Whitecross Roundabout (Turn milometer to zero. Take the A4110 Canon Pyon (Three Elms road) for 1 mile and TR at the traffic lights onto the A4103 Worcester (Roman road). TL at the first roundabout (2 miles), onto the A49 to Leominster. Go straight across the next two roundabouts (9. 6 miles then 12. 5 miles) and TR at the third roundabout (13. 4 Miles), heading towards Shrewsbury. At 14. 5 miles, when the road bends L, you TR onto A4112 to Kimbolton. At 15. 4 miles, TL up a narrow road, signposted Lower Kimbolton church. Take first L and head to church at 15. 7 miles.

 

1. Kimbolton. St James Church. With the church spire up to your L, go thru the kissing-gate and down the churchyard path. Exit via a wooden gate and bear L across F1 and towards a lone house. Go thru a kissing gate onto the narrow road/lane and TR. Go down the lane to reach the main road, (a school is on the L). Cross the main road and walk along the No Thru Road, for Minnalls Farm. The narrow road/lane converts into a grassy path as you pass by the farmhouse (R) and go thru a gate. Continue ahead and down, to cross Yolk Brook via a footbridge and metal gate.

 

2. Yolk Brook Cottage. Go a dozen paces up the path thats just to the R of the cottage, and then TR and go up the bank and thru a wooden bridle gate into F2. TL, walk up the L edge by the fence, and go thru the next bridle gate into F3 and walk straight on up thru trees to go thru another bridle gate and onto a lane. TL, walk along the lane, and just past the drive to Bachefield Farm (homeward route) you TR up a No Thru Road to Gorsty Hill. Climb up the lane and go past Bache Hill Farm (L), The Field House Farm (L) and Gorsty Hill Farm drive (R). A little further on, near the brow of the hill, you pass a footpath going R and L, you keep ahead, going along the more aggregate permissive path aiming R of three barns. Swing around L past the barns.

 

3. Upper Bache Dovecote and Farmhouse. Continue on down the aggregated path, winding past brick cottage(s) on your L, and get the first glimpse of an Iron Age camp called Bache Camp ahead at two oclock. Carry on down the wide corridor between fence and hedge, to reach a cropped field. Keep to the hedge on your R, that TR after a short distance, to continue down an enclosed track (wide corridor) to reach the brook. Pass an information board and cross the Whyle Brook via the gated footbridge into F4. Continue straight on up the field thats to the L of the camp mounds. Pass to the L of a way marked lone tree, and continue on up, to reach a bridle gate in a fence.

 

4. Bache Camp. Permissive footpath. Go thru the gate into F5 and TL, walk along L tree-lined edge. Go thru the bridal gate ahead and into F6. Bear L and walk down hill,

 

5
 

2
 

1
 
cutting off the L corner the field, to cross a brook via a gate/a footbridge and gate into F7. Climb very stiffly up next pasture on exactly the same line, keeping near to the L field edge, to go thru gate/stile into F8. Continue straight on up this field to cross a stile into F9. TR, and keep to R field edge to reach the field corner. Ignore the stile in front of you and TR thru a metal gate and along an enclosed grassy track, to go thru another metal gate and onto a narrow road/lane.

 

4
 

3
 
5. Stile on Road. TL and walk down a country lane for about 1km, taking in the countryside views as you travel. When you get to the road junctions at Bachefield Farm, (point 2), go R and walk a couple of yards along the Bachefield Farm drive, to TL thru a metal gate and into F10. Walk up the R field edge/hedge, then down over a stile and into F11. Bear slightly R and go across the field, keeping to the L side of the oak tree, to go thru a metal gate onto a lane/drive. TR to go along the drive to Yolk Brook Cottage (point 2 again). Retrace steps over f/bridge, back up to Kimbolton Church.


 

Walk 33 The Lower Olchon Valley

Last walked in April 2018

 

Description. An 8 km (4.9 miles) strenuous walk up and down a mountain, crossing field after field after field, luckily they are not ploughed. Beautiful scenic views as you make your way up. There is a bucket load of stiles to cross.

Start. Longtown Parish Hall. Explorer Map OL13 Grid 324287.

Direction from Tescos roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A465 to Abergavenny. At 9.7 miles you TR for Longtown 6. At 10.5 miles TL for Longtown 5. At 15.1 miles you TL for Longtown. At 15.3 miles TR at the The Crown Inn, (Established in 1751), and head for Longtown Village. A little further on, passed the pub on your L and at a T Junction, you TR for Longtown Castle. Two tenths of a mile along the road you park by Longtown Parish Hall, which is on the L. [15.5 miles]

 

1. Parish Hall. Out of the car park onto the road and TR. Walk for 120m and TL to cross over a slate slab (by a telephone box), and walk along an enclosed Public Footpath, then cross over a stile into a field F1. Go half R and cross over a stile into F2. Bear slightly L across this field to go over a stile in the L hand corner onto a road and TL. Cross a road bridge and TR and walk along the road to Ewyas Harold. Further on, (about 100m) you cross Escley Brook and TL over a stile into a field F3. Head off half R to cross the field corner and to go up some wooden steps and thru a small wooden gate onto a farm track/drive where you TL. After about 80m the drive turns into a muddy track that you continue along, (farm buildings are on your L), to reach 2 metal gates. Go thru the gate on the R side and into a field F4. Continue in the same direction, keeping to the hedge/tree line, and Escley Brook, on your L. In the field corner you cross over 3 planks of wood and a stile into F5. Continue along the field edge to cross over a slate stile into a wooded area. Cross 3 planks of wood and a little further on you walk up wooden steps and over a stile into F6. Go straight across this field and thru a wooden gate into F7. Follow the L field edge to the corner where you cross a stile/wooden gate into F8. Bear R down this narrow field to TR thru a wooden gate into a wooded area (Permissive Access Natural England). Continue along the L inside edge of the wood. Cross a stile/wooden gate into F9, and follow the fence on your L, (look behind you. The scenery is of the Black Mountains in the distance, with Hay Bluff on the R hand side). Go thru wooden gate gap into F10. Go thru a wooden gate and across F11, bearing slightly L. Go thu a small wooden gate and a few paces further on you go thru another small wooden gate and into F12 and head for the L hand corner. Go thru a small wooden gate, across a wooden footbridge and along the R edge of a small wooded area, to cross a stile/wooden gate into F13 and TL. A short distance further on you go across another stile/wooden gate and onto a road and TR.

 

2. Road. Walk along a narrow road and at the T-junction you TL. 20m along the road you TR to cross stile/metal gate into a field F1, and head up to the top, keeping to the R field edges as you go. Cross a wooden footbridge into F2. Cross over two stiles into F3. Cross two stiles into F4. Go thu 2 metal gates into F5. Cut straight across F5, heading for the far corner. There are 2 gates, go thru the gate on the L and straight on across this field F6, to reach the far corner. Go straight forward, thru 2 metal gates and along an enclosed farm track, after a short distance the track ends and you cross a stile/metal gate into F7 where you TR. Keep to the R field edge and when you reach the corner you cross a stile. Go thru a narrow strip of wood to cross two

2
 
more stiles into F8, keep to the fence on your R. Just past Upper Brooks Farm that is on your R, you TR across a stile onto a tarmac drive and TR.

 

3
 

1
 
3. Upper Brooks Farm. Walk along the drive as it goes past the farms on either side. Follow drive/enclosed track thru metal gate, farm buildings on your R. The enclosed track bends R and goes down hill. The track descends steeply, and when the track bends L, by a cattle grid, you go straight on thru a metal gate into F9, keep to the R field edge. At the bottom of the field you bear R, go thru a metal gate and continue down an enclosed farm track. Go thru a double metal gate onto track junction and TL. Bear R to go thru a gate into F10 (ignore the gate on the L side). Head diagonally R down this field to follow the gully/brook thats on your R hand side. Go thru a metal gate and down an enclosed track (the gully/stream is on your R). Go thru another metal gate; bear R across a small field to follow the gully/stream down to the river, going thru a metal gate and a short distance along a farm track. At a T-junction you TR, a little further up you TL to cross the river via a concrete footbridge and go into F11. Go straight across this field to cross a stile/gate onto a road junction. Cross over two roads and TR, head for Longtown Castle. Walk up this road back to the car park.

 

Walk 34 Coddington

Last walked in May 2018

 

Description. A 5 km (3.1 miles). Coddington, with its thirteenth-century church, is a small village nestling in typical Herefordshire countryside just outside the market town of Ledbury and to the west of The Malvern Hills in an area of outstanding natural beauty.

Start. Coddington Church. Explorer Map 190 Grid 718426.

Directions from Whitecross Roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A4110 Canon Pyne (Three Elms road) for 1 mile and TR at the traffic lights onto the A4103 Worcester (Roman road). After 7.7 miles TR, signposted to Stoke Edith. After 9 miles TL at T-junction (not sign posted) onto main road to Ledbury. Reach roundabout at 15.9 miles and go straight across heading for the Town Centre. At 16.3 miles you TL onto the B4214 to Bromyard. At 16.6 miles TR for Wellington Heath. At a T-junction, (17.8 miles) TR for Coddington. TL for Coddington at 18 miles. At a T-junction, (19.4 miles) TL for Coddington. A little further on, (19.8 miles) park in the church car park.

 

1. Coddington Church. The early English All Saints Church replaces an earlier Saxon church. Out of the car park and TR, walk down the lane and join the minor road as it goes around the church, which is on your R. Continue on down the road, ignore the No Thru Road on the R that goes to Woofields, and 40m further on you TR to go thru a gap in the hedge and into a field F1. Go straight up, across this field and to the R of the bricked house in front, to go over a stile into F2. Keep to the L edge as you go up this field to cross a stile/metal gates that are in the top corner (a small cottage is on your L). A little further you go down to reach the road. TR and walk uphill, (passing Jobeys Cottage on your L) and continue up to reach the top, where the road veers off to the R.

 

2. Concrete Water Tank. Bear L off the road, (a small concrete water tank is on the L), and continue straight on up a track and into woods, (ignore the track on your L thats going down hill). Cross a stile/metal gate and a little further on you cross another stile/metal gate. Bear half R; get off the track and onto open ground and head uphill, to reach the trig point on Oyster Hill. Turn half R and walk on past a wooden bench thats on your L, to continue along the brow of the hill for a short distance to go thru a wooden gate and along an enclosed track, (the woods are on your R). Keep in the same direction and at the end of the enclosed track you go thru a small metal gate and out onto open ground. Hope End House is off to the L. A house of the 1750s was replaced after 1809 by a new one designed by J.C. Loudon, who laid out a picturesque garden around it. The house was demolished in 1873 and replaced by the present one. After about 120m you bear slightly L and head to the L of two lone trees on the brow of the hill. Continue on, to cross a stile/wooden gate, (Upper Lodge is on your L) and TR when you get onto the road.

 

3. Upper Lodge. Walk along this road to TR at the first turning to Coddington (Raycombe Lane). After about km, and going past a couple of houses, you reach a black and white house thats on your R, opposite this house you TL and go thru a small metal gate and into a field F3. Turn half R and aim for the L hand corner of the house in front of you, (the house is near to a wooden power line post). On reaching the house corner you continue on across the field to the field corner and cross a stile/metal gate into F4, keep to the L edge of this field. Go thru a small/large metal gate, bear slightly L across F5 to cross a stile into F6.

 

4. Stile. In the bottom L hand corner you cross a stile into another field F7 and TR, you then cross a metal stile/metal gate onto a road. TR, 10m along the road you TL and go thru a small metal gate and into a park area. Cross over a wooden footbridge and continue along the edge of the orchard thats on your R, (pass by a pond on your R). Half way along the orchard edge you TR and walk up a wide grassy corridor in the orchard, to go thru a kissing gate. After 10m you TR and go over two stiles and into a field. TL, walk along the L edge to cross a stile in the corner, then TR and walk along an enclosed track, to reach a tarmac drive (a cattle grid is on the R) where you TL to reach the car park by the church.


 

Walk 35 Ewyas Harold

Last walked in May 2018

 

Description. A 6 km (3 7 miles) gradual climb up and gentle walk downhill, across farmland and along minor roads.

Start. Ewyas Harold Explorer Map OL13 Grid 388286

Directions from Tescos roundabout. (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A465 to Abergavenny. At 9 7 miles you TR onto the B4348(B4347) for Ewyas Harold 1. At 10 5 miles TL for the Village Centre and park on side of road.

 

1. Ewyas Harold. The village is named after Harold, son of Ralph the Timid earl of Hereford, and great-grandson of King thelred the Unready, who was king of England in 978 ad. It lies on the site of Ewyas Harold Castle, of which only the motte remains. Continue along the road, passing by Temple Bar Inn, a Fish & Chip shop, the Dog Inn and the Village Store, you then cross over the Dulas Brook. 130m further on up the road you TL onto a footpath that goes up concrete steps and thru a small wooden gate towards Ewyas Harold Castle. Continue on wooden steps to go thru a kissing gate, and in front of you is the castle mound. The first castle on the site is believed to be one of the very few which were built before the Norman conquest under the Saxons, probably in 1048. Continue on up and around the L hand side of the castle mound, and onto concrete that leads you thru metal gates to a ruined farm building where you bear L. Just past a corrugated iron building on your R you go thru a metal gate and into F1. Continue along the L hand field edge, and at the field corner you TL to go thru a small metal gate into F2. Continue up the R field edge, to go thru a metal gate into F3 and continue up the R field edge to reach the field corner, where you go thru a metal gate into F4, (next to a mains electricity pole). Continue on in the same direction, the hedge is now on your L. Ignore any gates on your L as you walk up the L field edge and go thru a small metal gate in the field corner and into F5. Keep to the R field edge, and continue along the edge of the woods, to cross over a stile in the field corner into a copse. Continue in the same direction thru a small copse, keeping to the L of a wire fence. At the end of the small copse you reach the open field on your L F6. Bear half L and continue up the field to cut off the R hand corner of this field, and meet up with a metal gate at the hedge corner, (dont go thru this gate).

 

2. Hedge corner. At the hedge corner you TR, keeping to the hedge on your R, to pass thru a metal gate into F7. Keep to the R field edge, and at the end of this field, you go thru a gate gap into F8, and go straight on across and thru a metal gate into a farmers yard. Go straight on across the farmers yard, keeping to the R hand side, (farm house is on the R). A short distance ahead you go thru a metal gate, and 20m further on you go thru another gate and into F9. TL, go straight across this field to cross over a stile into F10. Go half R across this field, heading towards a wooden mains electricity pole, to cross a stile onto a road. TR and walk along the road. TL at the first road junction going to Rowlestone and Walterstone. 120m further on you TL thru a small wooden gate and onto a public footpath.

 

3. Small wooden gate. Walk a short distance thru a lightly wooded area and into F11. Cut straight across F11 to reach the far R corner where you cross over a stile into F12. TL, keep to the L field edge. In the top L hand corner of this field you TL into F13, then immediately TR, and continue along the R field edge to reach the field corner and a gap in the hedges, (Wigga Farm is on your R hand side). Go thru a gate, thru a farm yard and thru another gate into F14 and TL. Walk along the L field edge, (following the hedge on your L) Cross over a double stile into F15. Bear half R and just past a small pond thats in a ditch on your L hand side, you cross over three wooden planks and a stile, into F16. Go straight across this field, heading to the R of a wooden farm house (Cwm Barn) to go thru a metal gate into F17. Continue along the L field edge, and just past Cwm Barn you bear half R to cut off the field corner. In front of you are two metal gates going into separate fields, go thru the L gate and into F18, and walk along the R field edge. Go thru a metal gate into F19 and follow the L field edge for a short distance before heading of R towards a red roofed house in the corner of the field where you go thru a gate and onto a road. TR, Pass Old King Street farm on your R and ignore the No Thru road on your R as you walk on into Ewyas Harold

3
 

2
 

1
 


 

Walk 36 Ullingswick

Last walked in May 2018

 

Description. A 9 km (5.6 mile). A summer or winter walk along narrow roads, thru woodland and along well defined tracks. Good scenery. One stiff road climb. No stiles. (Edited copy from Hereford Times May 2013).

Start. St Lukes Church, Ullingswick. Explorer Map 202 Grid 596499.

Direction from Whitecross roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A4110 Canon Pyon (Three Elms road) for 1 mile and TR at the traffic lights onto the A4103 to Worcester (Roman road). Go thru two roundabouts and at 3.7 miles TL onto the A465 to Bromyard. At the next roundabout, (9 miles) TL onto the A417 to Leominster. At 10.1 miles TR for Ullingswick. At a T-junction by a red telephone box (10.5 miles) TR. At 11.2 miles TL for Ullingswick church. At 11.4 miles the road bends right and at 11.6 mile you reach the church car park.

 

1. St Lukes church, Ullingswick. The church is on your R. Go out of the car park onto the road and TL. After km, (by a drive for Sheepcotts Court), the road bends L, continue along the road to reach a T-junction where you TR. After 35m you TL onto a wide bridle path. Go thru a small wooden/ metal gate by Tidmour Cottage (R), and continue along an enclosed path to go thru a metal gate into F1, (ignore the gate on the L hand side). Continue in the same direction along the L field edge to reach the far L corner, next to trees. TL into F2 then TR and continue alone the R field edge and along the outside edge of trees that are on your R. Reach the field corner and go on thru a strip of the wood, to reach F3. Continue in the same direction, along the R field edge, the trees are on your R. Go thru a hedge gap into F4 and continue along the R field edge. Go thru a gap into F5. A little further on, just before reaching the hedge corner, you TR and go thru a hedge gap to go quite steeply up a track into the trees.

 

2. Derndale Coppice. Continue up and along the track, to pass a canopied building on your L. TR at the track T junction and go on thru a wooden gate and along an enclosed track, (wooden fence on either side, a cottage on L called Dovedale). The track turns into a tarmac drive. Go thru a metal gate, the tarmac breaks up into aggregated drive and continues onto a road. At the main road you TL and continue on for almost a kilometre, first passing The Old School House (L), and later on a black and white house called Townsend House (L), then a red telephone and post box (L). Ignore the road going L and continue on, in the same direction for about 100m, to a point just past The Wilden (L), where you TR and walk along a No Entry road towards The Criftage. (About 200m further along the road, opposite Stone House, is the spot where William Hope molested then murdered Mary Corbett, a willing maidservant to the Skerretts of Ullingswick, in October 1862. William Hope was the last person to be hanged in public in Hereford. His execution took place above the gate of Hereford jail on April 15, 1863, in front of a boisterous mass of spectators. Mary Corbett was laid to rest in Ireland just a week after her murder.) After about km the road bends R and you go straight on along an enclosed grassy track. Carry on to reach a road at Lower Hope Lodge. TR and walk along the road for 1km, going steeply up hill to reach the turn off for Shortwood Family Farm at the top.

 

3
 
3. Shortwood Family Farm. TR and walk along wide footpath for Shortwood. Where drive goes L for Shortwood, you go straight on thru a metal gate into a field enclosure, then thru another metal gate into a bigger field. Keep to the R field edge, (Red Hill Coppice is on your R), and go thru another gate into a bigger narrow field. Continue along the R hand field edge to go thru a gate in the right hand corner and bear R along an enclosed dirt track, woods are on your R. A little further on the dirt track bends L and then R and continues on, along a wide enclosed dirt track. (Good views on your R side) When the main track goes L you carry straight on, going thru a medal gate, (Broxash Wood is on your R) and along a track thats along the R field edge. At the fence ahead, thats R of dwellings, TR for 25m down into trees, then TL and go thru a metal gate onto an aggregated track.

 

2
 

1
 

4
 
4. Hundred Bank path junction. Take sharp R and turn down an enclosed aggregate bridle path. After 65m the track bend L but you go straight on thru a metal gate and into F1 (Broxash Wood is on your R). Continue down the R field edge, and go thru a small metal gate in the R corner, into F2. Keep on top of the bank along the R field edge, to go thru a metal gate and along an enclosed track thats along the inside edge of the woods. Go thru a metal gate and out into {F6}. Walk along the L field edge, thru a metal gate and along an enclosed track. When you reach a corrugated iron barn shelter (R), TL and walk along a hedged bridal path and drive, to car park.

 

Walk 37 Badnage Wood

Last walked in June 2018

 

Description. A 6 km (3.7 mile). This walk goes up a very steep hill thats covered in trees, and down the other side, then back over this very steep hill. A short but strenuous walk.

Start. Tillington Common. Explorer Map 202 Grid 453461.

Direction from Whitecross roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A4110 Canon Pyon (Three Elms road) for 1 mile and TL at the lights. At 1.2 miles you TR for Tillington. Go straight thru Tillington and at 4.6 miles you reach Tillington Common, where you park along the roadside, by a red Post Box and opposite a minor road that goes to Woodfield Farm.

 

1. Red Post Box. In 1853 the first pillar box on the British mainland was erected at Botchergate, Carlise. Opposite the red post box, and the houses called The Orchard and Heath Farm, is the minor road you start walking along. After about 120m you TL up an enclosed public footpath. Go thru a metal gate and continue on up. Go thru another metal gate, (ignore the gate on your L). Go thru a kissing gate/metal gate into Badnage Wood and TR. 40m along you TL and continue up a smaller track. Climb 21 wooden steps and further up you climb another 8. Reach a track junction at the top of the hill and TR. After a few hundred meters you TL at the first way-marker post thats on the L, and go down a steep track. At the next X-tracks you go straight across and continue on down, 40m further on you go thru a small wooden gate and continue on down, a fence is on your R. Go thru another small wooden gate into F1 and continue on down, with a hedge/fence on your L. Continue along an enclosed track (L field edge) to reach Waterloo Farm.

 

2. Waterloo Farm. Bear R to go thru the farmyard and onto the aggregated driveway. Walk along the long driveway, and just before reaching the gated main road you TL and walk to the L of a small cottage to reach the hedge where you cross over a wooden footbridge and go thru a small wooden gate into F2. TR, and with the hedge on your R you continue on to go thru a kissing gate onto the main road, where you TL. After about  km, as the road bends R, you TL and proceed up a small road towards Nupton Hill Farm. The road bends slightly L and you pass Great Nupton building (L), as you make your way up this steep Private Road for about a kilometre, and when it bends sharply to the R, you continue straight on up, thru a double metal gate into F3.

 

2
 

3
 
3. Double Metal Gate. Continue straight on up the field, passing the copse thats on your L and the lone tree, to reach the top R hand corner. TR thru a small metal gate and into another field, (ignore the gate directly in front of you), and continue along the L field edge for 30m to TL thru a small metal gate and into Badnage Wood. Bear L and continue on down a well defined track. On reaching a track T-junction by a way-marker post you TL and follow the blue markers. A little further on you TR at a way-marked track junction and go steeply down hill. You come out of Badnage Wood, passing Wood Cottage on your L, and onto the road, where you TL. Walk past Tillington sign and onto the car.

 

1
 
 

 


Walk 38 Stoke Prior

Last walked in June 2018

 

Description. A 8 km (4.9 mile) walk along narrow roads, across cropped fields and good looking farmland.

Start. Explorer Map 202 Grid 520565, by the side of the road.

Direction from Whitecross roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A4110 Canon Pyon (Three Elms road) for 1 mile and TR at the traffic lights onto the A4103 to Worcester (Roman road). Turn L at the first roundabout (2 mile), onto the A49 to Leominster. At 9.5 miles you go straight across the next roundabout towards Shrewbury on the A49. At 10.5 miles TR on a minor road to Stoke Prior. At 11.8 miles, TR into Stoke Prior church, (might need to open church gates).

 

1. Stoke Prior Church. (St Luke's, Stoke Prior, is a Victorian church, Grade 2* listed, which replaced an earlier Norman edifice demolished in the early 1860s). Walk down to the road and TR. Continue along the road. Ignore the first road off to the L thats going to Leominster and continue on towards Humber. Continue up the road for about a kilometre, ignoring the next road off to the L, Unsuitable For Heavy Goods Vehicles, to TL by the national speed limit signs and head for Stoke Prior School. Go straight across the crossroads and on to Humber, along a no thru road. On your way you cross a river bridge, (HCC 483) and pass St Mary the Virgin, Humber church that is on your R. Ignore the turning L for Humber Court Farm (directly opposite the church lynch gate), and just before you get to Cider Mill, TR by a public footpath that goes thru a metal gate and along an enclosed track. At the end of the enclosed track (ignoring any gates L or R), go thru a metal gate into F1 and continue along the R field edge. About 100m along the field edge you go thru a new metal gate and into F2, and continue in the same direction but with the hedge now on your L. In the field corner you go thru a metal gate/stile into F3 and continue in the same direction, this time with the hedge on your R. You pass a disused brick cottage (L) as you proceed to the end of the field and cross over a gated metal footbridge into a wooded area. TR, and follow a track a short distance thru woods (stream is on your R), to cross a stile out of the woods and continue in the same direction across F4. Go thru a wooden gate into a grassy area, and continue past Risbury Mill (L) to cross over a stile onto a road, where you TR.

 

2. Risbury Bridge. (HCC 58 1936) Walk along the road for a few hundred metres to TL onto an enclosed bridleway to Hollywell Farm. Just before the farm you TR and go thru a small wooden/metal gate into F5 and walk along the L hand edge. At the end of the field you go thru a small metal gate into F6 and continue in the same direction, with the hedge on your L. At the end of this field you go thru a gap and continue in the same direction along a wide farm track, the hedge is now on your R. Just past a wooden electricity pylon, and when the farm track bends R, you continue in the same direction, straight across a cropped field and towards the L side of a copse. On reaching the L side of the copse you continue on along a grassy enclosed track, to reach a road, where you TR. Walk along the road and after about 100m, (at the end of the copse on your R), you TL and go thru the first metal gate (waymarked) and into F7. Continue along a public footpath along the R field edge (hedge is on your R), heading towards a white cottage with Solar panels on its roof (Little Wickton). At the end of the field continue straight on, passing to the R of Little Wickton cottages

 

3
 

2
 

1
 
3. Little Wickton. Continue in the same direction thru F8, keep to the hedge on your L, to go thru a metal gate in the field corner and into F9, the fence/hedge is now on your R. Cross a stile/metal gate into F10, and continue on in the same direction, the hedge is on your R. Cross a stile and go straight across F11, ignoring any waymarker indicating to go off to the R. Go thru a metal gate into F12 and bear slightly R as you cross this field to go over a stile into F13. Bear slightly R as you cross this field and cross another stile into F14. Initially you will go steeply down hill to go thru a kissing gate and down an enclosed track to reach tarmac driveway. Continue on to the road and TL, continue along road toward the church and the car.

 

 

Walk 39 Kington and Hergest Ridge

Last walked in June 2018

 

Description. A 9km (5.6 mile) moderate/energetic ramble thru town, woods and across hilly countryside, with Spectacular views (Hergest Ridge). (Edited Hereford Times April 2015)

Start. Kington car park (off Mill Street). Explorer Map 201 Grid 296566.

Directions from Whitecross roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A4111 to Kington. At 18.2 miles you TL at a roundabout heading for Kington Town Centre. Follow the road as it bends L and goes thru the town centre, and at 18.8 miles you TL at the clock tower and go along Mill Street into the car park (total 18.9 miles).

 

1. Mill Street East car park, Kington. Facing the school, TR and walk a short distance along Mill Street to TR at the T-junction by the clock tower. Walk along the High Street and when the road bends R you go straight on, along Duke Street. Go past the Oxford Arms Hotel (L) and continue along the road and just past 32A Duke Street (L), which is opposite Love Lane (R), you TL and go up an enclosed lane (Gravel Hill Drive). Keep walking up the enclosed Board School Lane (Mortimer Trail) until you reach a T-junction, where you TR and proceed up to the top L hand corner of The Square and TL into Doctors Lane. At the main road you TR and walk up the pavement. Bear slightly R to go into Kington churchyard and continue on up the footpath thats on the L side of the church.

 

2. St. Marys Church. When the path ends you TL, walk a few paces then TR and continue on passed Wych House (R), onto the main road. Go straight across the main road and up the road opposite thats going to Ridgebourne. Walk on past Hergest Croft Gardens Car Park (R) then go a little more steeply up and thru the bridle gate onto Hergest Ridge Common. Strike straight up the obvious path ahead for about 2km to reach Whetstone Marker Post, the post is just before a group of 9 Monkey Puzzle Trees.

 

3. Whetstone Marker Post. Go a little further R, about 40m, to the stone itself and the views, then return to the marker post. A glacier dropped the Wandering Whetstone here during the last ice age. From the original direction of approach up the ridge, turn very sharp L on yourself. Head down SE along the four feet wide path thru the bracken. Cross the disused race track after about 250m and head for the buildings and the small coppice below. Go passed the farm and buildings and onto the surfaced lane ahead. Keep on the lane for about 1km, passing an information board, a cattle grid and Upper House before reaching the tree island at the road junction.

 

4. Castle Twt. Dont go onto the road but TL and go a few paces up the track, then TR and go up and thru a k-gate (climb up for view?). TL, keep along L edge fence, down handrail, over three-plank bridge and thru k-gate into F1. Up wooden steps and continue along the L field edge to go thru another k-gate and along an enclosed track. Go thru another k-gate into F2 and carry on up the L field edge. Go thru a k-gate into F3, and go half R across the field to go thru another k-gate into wooded area.

 

5. Park Wood. Keep to the widest path, go past the Rhodendron Pool. Keep to the L of Park Wood Cottage, go over a cattle grid/thru gate and sweep up to the R on aggregate drive, go over next grid/gate. Just before Cutterbach Cottage, TR and go thru a gap by a stile and down the L edge of field. Cross a stile onto a road and TR. After about 100m and opposite a sign that says Hergest Mill you turn sharp L and go down a footpath, thru k-gate.

 

6
 

5
 

4
 

3
 

2
 

1
 
6. Tattymoor. Pass above pool, thru two more k-gates and go straight across a playing field. Near the field end you kink R thru a k-gate into Thomas Skarratt Halls Recreation Ground. Keep along the surfaced drive ahead and go thru a gate into Mill Street and the car park.

 

Walk 40 Dymock and Ryton

Last walked in July 2018

 

Description. 10 km (6.2 mile) walk along The Poets Paths, with crop, pasture, woodland edges, nature reserves, and daffodils. (Hereford Times 2015).

Start. Explorer Map 190 Grid 702313.

Directions from Whitecross Roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A4110 Canon Pyne (Three Elms road) for 1 mile and TR at the traffic lights onto the A4103 Worcester (Roman road). After 7.7 miles TR, signposted to Stoke Edith. After 9 miles TL at the T‑junction (not sign posted) onto main road to Ledbury. Reach roundabout at 15.9 miles and turn R for All Other Traffic. At the next roundabout at 16.4 miles continue on the Thru Traffic. 16.9 miles is the next roundabout keep to All thru Traffic. Next roundabout at 17.1 miles you via R and head along the B4216 for Dymock. At 20.9 miles you reach a T-junction, The Beauchamp Arms is on your R. Park in the field across the road from The Beauchamp Arms, (you might want to check with the pub that its OK to park there).

 

1. Dymock. Walk back along the road you have just arrived on, the B4216 to Ledbury. Cross a road bridge over the River Leadon (Long Bridge). After 100m you TR (Poets Path No. 1) and go thru a small metal gate into F1. Go straight across and over a stile into F2. Go straight across to reach the end of a hedge (L), and go into F3, where you angle slightly L to go thru a kissing gate, down 5 steps and onto a road.

 

2. Elmbridge Villas. Bear L and continue along the road for a few hundred meters, passing the sign posted Vellmill Meadow Nature Reserve (R). 50m past the meadow you TR, walk a few paces and TL to cross a stile into a small field F4. TR, walk thru the field to go thru a gate thats to the L of the house, and into F5. After 25m you TL over a footbridge into F6. Bear R, cross this field to cross over another footbridge into F7. Cross F7 to go thru a k/gate, and into F8. The River Leadon is on your R and the fence on your L as you walk straight ahead, to cross a stile into F9. Continue in the same direction and in the bottom R corner you cross over a footbridge and under the motorway. Go over another footbridge into F10. Bear L, cross this field to cross over a footbridge into F11. Bear L and head towards the R edge of the farm in front, to reach a marker post near a gate.

 

3. Callow Farm. Do not go thru the gate but TL and walk along R field edge/near side of fence, and thru gate gap into F12. Continue along R field edge to cross stiles ahead either side of a drive and into F13. Keep ahead on upper R edge of a vast field, heading towards the next motorway bridge. At end of field you TR and walk along a stretch of enclosed hedged grassy field to go thru a k/gate/gate onto a road. TR, carry on up the road to reach a T-junction. TL for Rytron. When you reach a cream coloured house call The Smithy (L), TR and walk up an enclosed public footpath, (PP1). Follow bridle path on edge of Ryton Firs for a kilometer. At bottom of dip you go thru gate and onto track junction.

 

4. Track Junction. TR, go thru gap into F14, follow track to go sharply back up bank to the R. After 100m, and before the track bends sharply L, you bear R off the drive and cross a stile into trees. Follow woodland edge for a kilometer, going over a stile and thru a wooden gate, trees now up to the L and fence is R. The track bends R and the path now heads for the L side of Farm buildings, to go thru the buildings of Ketford Farm. At far end you TL thru a small metal gate into F15. Walk above a ditch and follow L edge of field, down to reach a bridle crosspatch at the field end. TR, walk along path to go thru a gate/cattle grid and onto a road. TL, walk along the road, crossing over the River Leadon at Ketford. As soon as you cross the river TR and continue along PP1 bridleway. Before reaching the gate in front, labeled Barn Farm, you TR and go thru a metal gate and along an enclosed grassy bridleway that bends L, and goes to the R of a white house. Go up bank, and continue along enclosed bridleway.

 

5. Ketford Bank Nature Reserve. Go thru small metal gate and continue along an enclosed track. Go thru small metal gate and pass nature reserve board (R) and thru small wooden gate into F16. Follow L f/edge, go thru small gate into F17 and continue along L f/edge and enclosed straight path back over M50. Further along the path turns into tarmac and you continue on, for a kilometer to reach a T-junction. Go straight across, up steps and thru a k/gate into F18. Bear slightly L to cross the field and reach a fence corner, TL thru a k/gate into F19. TR, walk along R field edge and on thru Dymock Cricket Ground. At the far end you go thru metal k/gate into F20. Straight on across, and bend round to the L, to go thru k/gate onto a road. Cross the road and TR and walk up pavement to the start.

1
 

2
 

3
 

5
 

4
 

 

 


Walk 41 Donnington, Brooms Green and the parish of Dymock

Last walked in July 2018

 

Description. 8 km (4.9 miles). A Serene and generally level country lanes and field paths. Taken from Hereford Times July 2013. Long trousers recommended.

Start. Donnington Church. Explorer Map 190 Grid 708344.

Directions from Whitecross Roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A4110 Canon Pyne (Three Elms road) for 1 mile and TR at the traffic lights onto the A4103 Worcester (Roman road). After 7.7 miles TR, signposted to Stoke Edith. After 9 miles TL at the T‑junction (not sign posted) onto main road to Ledbury. Reach roundabout at 15.9 miles and turn R for All Other Traffic. At the next roundabout at 16.4 miles continue on the Thru Traffic. 16.9 miles is the next roundabout keep to All thru Traffic. Next roundabout at 17.1 miles you via R and head along the B4216 for Dymock. At 18.9 miles you TL, signposted for Donnington. A little further on at 19.1 miles by St Marys Church you can park in a small lay-by on the R side of the road.

 

1. St Marys Church, Donnington. The Doomsday survey (1085/6) records Donnington to have 6 villagers and 6 smallholders with 7 ploughs and 1 female slave. Value of 25s. An earlier translation, quoted by a former vicar of Donnington, J. E. Gethyn-Jones, in his own History of the Church published in September 1958, describes the female slave as a bondswoman. He further adds that Donnington was then, what it is today, a small agricultural community with about 1,000 acres under cultivation. With your back to the church, TR and continue along the country road for about 1 km. After about km the road bends R, (ignore the No Thru Road going off to the L), continue on to reach a cottage on the L called Nethertways. Nethertways has a red post box in its wall. TR, cross the road and go over a hidden stile and along an overgrown enclosed track for about 30m, then TL to cross over a footbridge and out into F1 via a stile. If this section is to overgrown, go thru the gate into the field and walk a short way along the R field edge to reach the stile. After crossing the stile you go straight across F1, keeping to the R of a line of three mature trees to cross a stile into F2. Keep ahead on the same line, to cross another stile into F3. Walk along the L edge of this large field, (ignore any stiles off to the L) and keep to the R of the farm house, to cross over a stile in the far corner ahead. Walk in and out of a small wooded area via a stile onto a road.

 

2. Brooms Green. TR, go passed a red telephone box as you walk along the road for about 100m, and before you get to the 30mph sign posts you TL, and walk along an enclosed public footpath, (Poets Path No 2). Cross over a new wooden footbridge and TR along the R edge of F4. Go thru a k-gates into F5 and continue along the R field edge. Go thru a k-gate into an enclosed wooded area and a few paces further on you go thru another k-gate and into F6. TR and Sweep around the R field edge and at the end of this field you go thru a gate gap into F7, ignoring the wide gap in the hedge thats on your R hand side. Continue along the R edge of this field, near the end it bends R and descends to go straight on across a wooden footbridge over a brook and into an adjoining field F8. Veer slightly L as you cross over this cropped field to cross over a stile. Veer slightly R and walk on a dozen paces to reach the country road, (dont TL and go over the cattle grid). TL and continue along

1
 
the country road for about km, the road then bends R and you come to a T-junction. TR for Dymock and Newent and walk along the road for about km to pass Vell Mill cottage, then a few hundred meters further on, (and ignoring any public footpaths going off to the L), reach a small off road car park on your L that opens out onto Vell Mill Meadow Nature Reserve, (has an information board on display).

 

3. Vell Mill Meadow. Continue along the road for about 30m and TR thru a metal gate into F9 to follow Poets Path footpath. Bear half L to cut across the field heading for lone trees. Cross over a wooden footbridge into F10, TR and continue along the R field edge to cross a stile/metal gate onto a road. TR, walk about 20m to a road junction and TL for Brooms Green. Walk along the road for about a kilometre, passing Burton Farm and Ockington Farm to reach a T-junction at Memorial Hall, an information Board is outside.

 

2
 

4
 
4. Road Junction. Cross the road very slightly L and head up the path thats to the R of Upper Lodge. Go thru two metal gates and then thru a wooden gate/stile into F11. Walk on ahead; keeping to the fence on your L, to reach a stile thats in the far L hand corner of the field, the stile is next to a metal gate (L) thats got a card saying Private Land No Access Without Permission. (It might be easier to continue along the prominent farm track and TR when you reach the metal gate). Cross over the stile into F12 and continue straight on across the field, heading to the R hand side of buildings ahead. You pass a direction sign post as you make your way to the end of the field, where you continue on thru a gate gap/stile. Keep to the R edge for about 30m then on thru a short enclosed path and over a stony stream bridge and into F13. Ignoring the track that veers off to the L, you continue along the L field edge for 150m to TL across a stile into F14. TR, continue along the R field edge and thru a kissing gate into the church yard. Walk on thru a couple of gates and onto the road and the car,

 

Walk 42 Herefordshire Trail

Last walked in July 2018

 

Description. 7 km (4.3 miles) Taking a compass might be useful. A pleasant walk along tracks, minor roads and farmers fields.

Start. Wacton Court. Explorer Map 202 Grid 615574.

Directions from Whitecross Roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A4110 Canon Pyne (Three Elms road) for 1 mile and TR at the traffic lights onto the A4103 Worcester (Roman road). Straight across the first roundabout (2m), and the second roundabout, then at 3.8 miles you TL on the A465 to Bromyard. Go straight across the next roundabout (9m), and continue on to Bromyard. At a T-junction (15.1m) you TL onto the A44 for Leominster. At 18.5 miles, next to a small garage, you TR for Wacton and go along a narrow one way No Through Road. Park up along the grass verge by Wacton Court (19.2m), which is on your left.

 

1. Wacton Court. Continue along the road, (passing Wacton Grange on your R), the tarmac deteriorates into a farm track and at the end you go thru a gate into a field F1. Turn half L and cross the field to go thru a gate and under disused railway lines unto F2. Go straight across this cropped field and thru a small wooden gate and continue along an enclosed track. Go thru a small metal gate, (down to the L is a small bricked footbridge) and continue on, to go thru wooden gates and bearing slightly R to reach a road by Butterley Brook cottage.

 

2. Butterley Brook Cottage. Cross the road and walk up and along an enclosed well defined farm track for just over a km. The track then bends R and goes on past High Acres farm (R), and further on the track becomes a tarmac road. You go past Clarks Croft Cottage (L), and further on you reach a prominently displayed public footpath sign post, (the drive on your L goes to Velvet Stone Cottage).

 

3. Velvet Stone Cottage. TR, go thru a gate and continue along the L field edge of F3. You are now going along part of the 153 mile long Herefordshire Trail. Go over a stile and walk along L edge of F4. Thru a gate/stile and continue along F5. Thru gate (a farm building is on the R) and continue along F6. Thru double wooden gates and onto a road. TR, continue along the road and pass Little Street Field farmhouse (L) to reach a fork in the road. Take the L fork and continue on, to pass Street Field Farm (R) where the road turns into a farm track. Go thru a gate onto a road and TR.

 

4. Cattle Grid. Pass over a cattle grid. Continue down the road and cross over another cattle grid and TL, (you are now going back the way you came, along Butterley Brook, which is on your R). Continue along the dirt track, go thru a small wooden gate and into an open field F2. Cut straight across the field and under the old railway bridge, thru a metal gate into F1. Go up this field to reach the top R hand corner to go thru a small gate onto an enclosed dirt track. Walk up and along to reach the car.

 

 

3
 

1
 

2
 

4
 
 

 


Walk 43 Joyces Walk

Last walked in August 2018

 

Description. Joyces Walk is a four-mile (6.4 km) circular walk in the Forest of Dean. It passes thru woods and fields to Hope Mansell, then the walk follows a hilly route to the lane near Horn Hill Farm then skirts Harechurch Wood before returning to the start.

Start. Bailey Lane End. Explorer Map OL14 Grid 643195.

Direction from Belmont roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Follow the A49 to Ross-on-Wye and at 12.9 miles, at the roundabout you TL towards the M50. TR at the next roundabout (14.3 miles) and onto the A40 for Gloucester. Go straight across the next two roundabouts and continue on the A40 to Gloucester (15.3). At 17.9 miles TR for Drybrook. At 19.6 miles you park off the road, on the R hand side, opposite the road junction to Mitcheldean.

 

1. Barrier. Climb over the stile, or cross over the forestry barrier and walk straight into the wood for about 50m. At this point five tracks meet, including the one you are on. Take the second track on the L. A little further on this track splits and you take the L hand fork, which goes down hill, (it is the only one that goes downhill). Follow the track downhill thru the conifer woodland. At the foot of the slope the track bears R and runs parallel to a small brook (Bailey Brook) on your L. Further on you join a wide track/drive coming up from the L, you continue around to the R. Pass a holiday cottage on the L called Oak Tree, and when you reach a T‑junction you TL. A little further on you reach the post for Bailey Brook and Lilley Cottages (L) where you TL and go down hill, (you will be following the Red way markers for Hope Mansell). Pass a white cottage on the R, and continue on down to go to the R hand side of another cottage called Bailey Brook Cottage. Continue to descend the path to a stile and a small bridge over the stream. After crossing the bridge go straight ahead, with the stream to your R, for about 50m and cross another small stream by an earth bridge. You are now at the foot of a short, but steep, hill with a fence and stile on the skyline. Climb the short hill and cross a stile into another field.

 

2. Style. Go straight across this field and cross a stile in the hedge to descend the steps onto a lane. You have now reached the village of Hope Mansell and are standing outside the Old School House and the small village hall, both on the L. Continue down the lane to meet a T‑junction, immediately opposite is a prominent display cabinet containing information about the walks in and around Hope Mansell, TL. Walk up the lane for about 150m to St Michaels Church on the L. St Michaels is a very attractive stone church, probably built in the 12th or 13th century. According to the information in the church, existing Registers of Births, Marriages and Deaths date from 1556 and it is interesting to note that English replaced Latin from about 1590. Other fascinating facts reveal that the font is about 700 years old and, the sturdy rafters have survived six centuries. Continue up the lane for about 400m to where a finger post points to the R up a short lane where two five-bar metal gates can be seen. Go up the lane and thru the gate to the R. Continue up the steep-sided lane, emerging into a field, with good views over Hope Mansell to your R.

 

3. L Hedge. TL and follow the hedge on your L as it curves up the field. Head towards a prominent five-bar gate with a new pedestrian gate alongside it. Go thru the pedestrian gate and continue up the field close to the fence with woodland on your R. Keep close to the woodland and pass under low hanging tree branches. When you are nearing the top of the slope you TR thru a small metal gate and go across a small field to pass thru another small metal gate into a field. Head slightly L to cross a stile onto a lane at a T-junction. There is a cottage called High Stones on the junction. At the junction you TL and go down the lane towards Hope Mansell, (going past the cottage on your R). The lane goes down quite steeply. Walk for about 200m down the hill until you reach a bench seat (donated by M F Freeman) on the L. From this seat you can see virtually the whole of the route so far.

4
 

3
 

2
 

1
 
4. Seat Donated by M F Freeman. Continue downhill and along the lane for about 700m, passing the entrance to Horn Hill Farm to reach the road junction where you TR for Drybrook. The lane goes slightly uphill and after a short distance you pass the drive entrance to Twizling Farm on the L, and 30m further on you TL onto an enclosed byway, (the byway sign is tight against the fence on the L and easy to miss). Continue along the byway and as you emerge from woodland you will arrive onto an open lane at Hom Grove Farm. TR and walk almost a km along the track and, just before reaching the road, pause to admire one of the bridges over one of the many disused railway lines in the Forest of Dean. Where the track meets the road, turn L and walk, with care as the traffic travels very quickly, back to the start.

 

 

Walk 44 Beside The Wye

Last walked in August 2018

 

Description. An 8 km (5 mile) easy walk starting in Ross-on-Wye. The route is mostly flat, with one gentle climb and one short sharp climb. It follows the river Wye through pleasant riverside meadows, using a section of the Wye Valley Walk, and returns through Brampton Abbotts. There are fine views over Ross and towards May Hill. (A Ross Ramblers walk).

Start. Park in the car park by the river. Explorer Map 189 Grid 594239.

Direction from Belmont roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Follow the A49 to Ross-on-Wye and at 12.8 miles you go straight across the roundabout for Ross-on-Wye, and a little further on, at 13.2 miles you TR into the car park.

 

1. Car Park. From the car park entrance you cross the road and TR, about 100m along the road you TL and walk along Wye Street to reach the Bandstand on the R. TL, opposite the Bandstand, and walk along the tarmac path towards the river. Originally Wye Street was the main route into Ross from Hereford before the current road that passes below the Gazebo Tower was built in the 1820s; it used to be called Dock Street, reflecting the navigable state of the river in years gone by. On reaching the river bank TR and follow it upstream along the tarmac path, passing the Hope and Anchor Riverside Inn. On reaching a large grassy area known as The Ropewalk you will see a superb metal sculpture. This was made by the internationally renowned local sculptor, Walenty Pytel, and is entitled Swans in Flight. The path eventually bares R and meets the road leading into the grounds of Ross-on-Wye Rowing Club. Cross the road and continue over the bridge and into a playing field, (the bridge crosses the Rudhall Brook). TL and walk round the L edge for a short distance, then TL over another footbridge (ignore the first bridge that goes into the rowing club), and shortly after re-crossing the Rudhall Brook, the path bares half-R and rejoins the river bank. Pass beneath the bridge and continue alongside the river. About a km beyond the bridge you TR at a marker post to follow the Permissive Route for Wye Valley Walk, going away from the river, and 40m further on you TL onto the path of the dismantled Hereford to Ross railway line.

 

2. Dismantled Railway Line. Continue along the old railway line for about a km, cross a farm track and about 200m further on you TR by a marker post and go down some wooden steps and on thru a small metal gate into F1. Walk along the R edge of a field until you reach the river bank once again, at a point where the path meets a farm track. TR. Walk along the farm track, 100m further on you ignore the Wye Valley Walk that goes off to the L and go straight on along the track towards a farm building known as The Cotts (R), (on the L is the Old Brompton Barn). After passes The Cotts the track rises gently until it reaches Townsend Farm.

 

3. Townsend Farm. TL and walk between the farm buildings until you reach a lane. TR and follow the lane past several cottages and a very old, sparse, derelict orchard (L). At the end of the orchard the lane turns sharply to the L, but you continue straight on, along an enclosed track and to the R of St Michaels Church. St Michaels was closed in September 2008 as the roof is unsafe. After the final service the Bishop of Hereford led a procession taking the precious items to Bridstow Church for safe keeping. The event ended 800 years of worship on this site. Keep to the churches brick wall until 40m further the wall bends L and you carry straight on, down across the next two

3
 
fields (F2/F3) towards Netherton. At the end of the fields go through a gate down onto a narrow lane, bare R and continue along the lane. The lane drops down into a small valley, known locally as The Dingle. In the bottom of the valley a small lake on the R is a haven for wildlife and swans can be seen. Continue along the lane and up the short, steep climb to reach a slightly wider lane, Brampton Road. Take the high level pavement on the R and walk in front of the houses to reach the bridge over the main A40 dual carriageway.

 

1
 

2
 

4
 
4. Bridge over A40. Do not cross the bridge but TR to walk downhill, parallel to the dual carriageway. This area of the town is known as Greytree. Pass a succession of roads to your R, named First Avenue to Sixth Avenue, and pass beneath the dual carriageway. Carry on until you reach the entrance to a car park, on your R. Go into the car park and cross slightly towards the L to a bridge over the brook. TR, after a few paces the path splits and you take the L hand path, 30m along you pass a house perched high on the bank to your L, marked with a circular blue plaque. As you continue along the path, remains of the old town wall can be seen on your L. At the end of the path you reach another blue plaque thats directly in front of you, this RIVERSIDE plaque tells you that Ropes Baskets and Boats where made here in the 19th century. TR, walk around two metal pedestrian barriers and continue on towards the river. On reaching the river you TL and walk along the tarmac path, that turns L and meets Wye Street road. TR and continue along to the main road, opposite is the car park.

 

 

Walk 45 Walks around Luston Group Parishes 1

Last walked in September 2018

 

Description. This 6 km (3.74 mile) walk takes us out of Luston Village into the beautiful surrounding country- side. It is mainly thru fields, a short stretch along the edge of Oaker Wood and a short section takes us along Croft Lane.

Start. Townsend Park Road Luston. Explorer Map 203 Grid 486635.

Directions from Whitecross Roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A4110 Canon Pyon (Three Elms road) for 1 mile and TR at the traffic lights onto the A4103 to Worcester (Roman road). TL at the first roundabout (2 miles), onto the A49 to Leominster. Go straight across the next two roundabouts (9.5 miles then 12.5 miles) on the A49 heading towards Shrewsbury. TL at the next roundabout (13.3 miles) onto the A44 to Leominster. At 13.8 miles TR onto the B4361 towards Richards Castle. At 15.8 miles you enter Luston, and at 16.4 miles you TL and park somewhere along Townsend Park road.

 

1. Townsend Park road. Walk straight to the end of Townsend Park road and TL, walk along a short enclosed track and into F1. Follow the hedge on the R and continue on to cross over a stile in the top R hand corner of the field and into F2 (Ignore a stile on your R). Continue in the same direction with a hedge on your R, and on reaching the hedge corner you dont turn R, you go straight across the field, heading towards the gap in the hedge ahead, just L of a lone oak tree. Go thru the hedge gap into F3 and continue across this field to reach hedge gaps in the far R hand corner. TR, walk a few paces and TR again, to cross over a stile into a small field F4 (electric wires are overhead). Go under the electric wires and bear slightly L to cross the field, and over another stile into F5 (Croase Farm is on your R side). Go straight up and across, heading for a lone tree in the hedgerow ahead. Walk thru a small metal gate, into an orchard and continue on to the far R hand corner where you cross a stile onto a tarmac drive.

 

2. Hill Top. Cross the unfenced drive into F6 and TL, then walk along the L field edge, passing to the R of Hill Top farm to go thru a small metal gate into F7. Bear slightly R as you cross this field and go thru a small metal gate into F8 . Bear slightly R and head for the bottom R hand corner, to go thru a small metal gate by a public footpath sign, and onto a road. Go straight across the road and thru a gap in the hedgerow into F9, (there is a Public Footpath signpost here, but this may be hidden), keep to the L field edge. After about 150m you TL and cross a stile, you then continue along the inside perimeter of a wood, keeping a wire fence on your L. Further on you TL over a stile and across two planks into F10. TR and follow the outside edge of the wood, now on your R. Keep straight on across the field as the wood indents to the R, to reach the R hand corner of the field, where you cross over two stiles and three planks into F11, (use the gate on the L if the stiles are over grown).

 

4
 

3
 

2
 

1
 
3. Two Stiles. Bear half L across this field to reach a stile that is just to the L of a power line pole (gate is to the R). Cross the stile into F12, walk thru some holy and continue along the L hand side of the field. Go thru a gate gap into F13. Bearing slightly L you cross this field to go over a stile and down wooden steps onto a road. TR, walk along the road for about 200m to reach a Public Footpath sign post (L), (this post is just before a minor road that goes off R), TL and continue down an enclosed dirt track. Go thru a kgate into F14 and bear slightly R to cross a gated wooden footbridge into F15.

 

4. Footbridge. TL, and walk along the L field edge to go thru a small metal gate into F16. Go along the L edge of this large field and keep to the field edge as it bends up and around to the R, (dont go straight on thru the hedge gap in the field corner into another field). Walk on up to reach to the field corner and continue in the same direction along an enclosed green track, (ignore the stile on your L). You continue along the track to pass the school on your L and then the backs of houses. Go over a footbridge and on to end of the path and thru the gate onto the main road (opposite is The Balance Inn). TL and go down the road to TL at Townsend Park road.

 

 

Walk 46 Walks around Luston Group Parishes 2

Last walked in September 2018

 

Description. 6 km (3.7 miles). This walk takes us out of the village and into the beautiful surrounding countryside. It is mainly to go thru fields, crossing several streams and the railway line, with a short stretch along Eye Lane.

Start. Balance Inn, Luston. Explorer Map 203 Grid 486633.

Directions from Whitecross Roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A4110 Canon Pyon (Three Elms road) for 1 mile and TR at the traffic lights onto the A4103 to Worcester (Roman road). TL at the first roundabout (2 miles), onto the A49 to Leominster. Go straight across the next two roundabouts (9.5 miles then 12.5 miles) on the A49 heading towards Shrewsbury. TL at the next roundabout (13.3 miles) onto the A44 to Leominster. At 13.8 miles TR onto the B4361 towards Richards Castle. At 15.8 miles you enter Luston, and at 16.4 miles you TL and park somewhere along Townsend Park road.

 

1. Townsend Park. Walk back to the main road and TR. Walk on the L side of the road. 50m past the Balance Inn, and opposite the Methodist Chapel you TL at a footpath sign. Go thru a gate and along an enclosed track and into a small field, keeping to the hedge on your L, to reach the bottom corner. Go thru a gap in the hedge into F1 and walk straight across, heading towards a large hedgerow tree by a gap in the hedge. Go thru the gap and continue across F2 to cross a footbridge over a stream into F3. Follow the hedge on the L to cross a stile, then a railway line and over another stile into F4. Continue straight ahead to go thru a gate then across a farm track to go thru another gate into a small field F5. Walk straight across; two thirds of the way across you TL to walk to the hedgerow where you go thru a small metal k/gate into a small field. Go across the field and thru another k/gate into the the churchyard, (tall brick wall on the L). Continue on thru churchyard to reach the Lychgate.

 

2. Eye, St Peter & St Paul Church. Though not necessarily remarkable, Eye church is designated as a grade I listed building and is lovely example of a typical English country church. Thru the Lychgate and TL, follow drive to Eye Lane. TL and follow the lane, past the old railway station (now a private house) and over the railway bridge. When the lane starts bending L, and just before Cowley Village Hall thats a little further on (R), you TR (footpath and way marker signs), to go thru a gap in the hedge and on thru a small shrub field into F6.
