3. Hedge Gap. Keep to the hedge on your L, and when it turns sharp L you continue straight on across the field, heading towards some buildings and a gap in the tall hedge in front of you. Cross over a stile, then a tarmac drive to cross over another stile and walk along an enclosed grassy track, to cross over a stile into F7. Continue along the L field edge to go thru a k/gate into F8. Continue along the L field edge to cross over a wooden footbridge and onto a road.

 

4. Footbridge. Go thru k/gate on the opposite side of road and into F9. Turn half R and go diagonally across this field, heading towards the last lone tree on the R, to cross a stile and footbridge into F10. Turn half L and continue across this field to go thru a gate into F11. TL (ignore waymark pointing R) and follow fence to the bottom of the field. Cross over an earthy bridge over a stream, and go thru a k/gate into F12. Continue directly up the middle of the field to go thru a k/gate in the hedge at the top of the hill. Follow an enclosed narrow hedged path going thru a small metal gate and onto Yarpole Lane.

 

5. Yarpole Lane. Cross the road, follow farm road opposite. As the road bends R and just after a traffic bump, (and by chicken sheds) turn sharp L into F13. Follow R field edge and after 100m you TR to go thru the hedge and into F14. Walk straight across this field towards large oak tree, and past it to cross a stile into F15. TL and walk along L field edge, across the concrete and along a farmers track ahead to reach Townsend Park Road. Follow road thru houses to car.

 

 

 

Walk 47 Walks around Luston Group Parishes 3

Last walked in September 2018

 

Description. 8 km (5 miles). This walk takes us out of Luston village into the beautiful surrounding countryside. It is mainly thru fields, but with several stretches along quiet, minor lanes edged with wild flowers. It also takes us to the charming church of All Saints at Eyton (left).

Start. Balance Inn, Luston. Explorer Map 203 Grid 486633.

Directions from Whitecross Roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A4110 Canon Pyon (Three Elms road) for 1 mile and TR at the traffic lights onto the A4103 to Worcester (Roman road). TL at the first roundabout (2 miles), onto the A49 to Leominster. Go straight across the next two roundabouts (9.5 miles then 12.5 miles) on the A49 heading towards Shrewsbury. TL at the next roundabout (13.3 miles) onto the A44 to Leominster. At 13.8 miles TR onto the B4361 towards Richards Castle. At 15.8 miles you enter Luston, and at 16.4 miles you TL and park somewhere along Townsend Park road.

 

1. Townsend Park. Go back to the main road and TR. Walk up towards the Balance Inn (L), and just before the bus stop thats across the road from the inn you TR and go thru a gate and along an enclosed track. Cross over three wood planks, a little further on the track bends R and continues on, there are fields on the L and buildings on the R. At the end of the enclosed track you continue on in the same direction (ignore the stile on your R), and go around the edge of a large field (F1) with a hedge on the R. At the end of F1 you go thru a small metal gate into a narrow field (F2), and continue for a short distance along the R field edge to get to the end, where you TR and cross over a gated footbridge into F3. Bear half L, and about 60m across the field, at a hedge corner, you bear L and thru a k/gate and walk along an enclosed track until you reach a road, (Croft Lane) at the Riddle Common.

 

2. The Riddle. TL, walk a few paces then TR into Seggin Lane (Unsuitable for Heavy Goods Vehicles). Follow the lane for about 1 km, (the lane bends L a couple of times), to reach a T junction by Eyton Church. (Pause to enjoy this pretty church and its churchyard with lovely views. It is worth taking a short diversion by turning R and following the lane for 80m or so, to see Eyton Court, and a noted timber framed house on the R, and beyond it, Eyton Common. Return to the junction).

 

3. Eyton Church. Cross the road in front and TR, walk a few paces then TL and go up the bank, thru a gate and along a short enclosed track and over a stile. Bear slightly L and cross a stile/gate in a wall and go into F4. Bear half L across the field to cross a footbridge into F5. Bear slightly R across F5 to reach a gate between two oak trees. Go thru the gate into F6 and follow the L field edge, keep the wood area on the L. Go over a stile/gate gap into F7 and continue along L field edge, with the wood on your L. Go over a stile into F8 and continue along L field edge to reach the wood end, (a small farm barn is on your left). Go thru a gate into F9 and bear half R to pass an old willow tree and cross over stiles on both sides of a tarmac drive into F10. Cross over this field and climb over another stile and wooden planks into F11. To the left is Scatterbrain Farm, its name recalls carnage in this vicinity during the Wars of the Roses. Cross this field, pass a power line pole thats in the middle of the field to go thru a hedge gap thats just to the L of twin power line poles into F12.

Keep to the hedge thats on your L, and when it turns sharp L, by a Byway marker, you continue straight on across the field, to go thru a k/gate in the hedge ahead into Croft Lane and TL.

 

4. Croft Lane. Walk on up the road for about km, passing a Children Playing signpost thats by a small static caravan site. Just before you reach the brow of the hill you TR thru a kissing gate and into F13. Walk on a few paces keeping to the hedge on your left. Pause then to enjoy panoramic views over Luston, Eye Church, Eye Manor and Berrington Hall, and beyond to Titterstone Clee and Brown Clee. At the hedge corner you TL and follow the hedge to the end of the field, bearing slightly R to go thru a small metal gate by a willow tree into F14. Continue down the L field edge to cross a stile and two wood planks into F15. Continue up the L field edge and over the next stile into F16. Continue along hedge and when it ends, head straight across the field to get to the top corner.

 

5. Tarmac Lane. Cross a stile/metal gate onto a tarmac lane and TL. Walk about 80m and just before the house you TR and go thru a gate gap into F17]. Go straight across the field to reach a copse, a nature reserve, and continue on to reach a stile in the field corner. TR, cross the stile and continue along a short enclosed fenced path (copse on the R). At the end you TL over a stile into F18 and continue along the R field edge. Go thru a gate gap in the corner into F19, continue along R field edge. Go thru small metal gate into F20 and continue down the R field edge. TR thru small metal gate into F21, continue along L field edge for a short distance to reach a farm track/drive that by a cattle grid. TR and follow the drive back to the village, passing a chapel on the R. At the road junction you TL and return to Townsend Park Road on the L and to the car.


 

Walk 48 Walk along the Border

Last walked in October 2018

 

Description. 8 km (5 miles). A strenuous ramble up and down a steep hill.

Start. Hay-on-Wye car park. Explorer Map 201. Grid 231423

Directions from Whitecross Roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A438 towards Brecon, turning L after 12.1 miles. At 19.7 miles TL onto the B4351 to Hay-on-Wye. At the T junction, [21 miles], you TR to Brecon, and at 21.2 miles you TL for the car park which is two hundred yards on your R.

 

1. Hay Castle. Begin by turning R out of the car park along the road and after 50m TR, at an Offa's Dyke Path (ODP) sign, and walk down a short enclosed track. Go thru a metal gate into a F1 and walk along L edge. Thru k-gate into F2 and walk along R edge. Go thru a k-gate into F3 and straight across the field and along the L edge. Go thru a k-gate into F4 and along L field edge with Dulas Brook below (L). Cross brook via a gated wooden f/bridge and go up an enclosed track. Thru a small metal gate into F5 and up the L edge. Thru small metal gate, and continue in the same direction along ODP, to go out into F6. Cross the field and over a stile/metal gate into F7 to cross a track, bear slightly L and head for a t/pole.

 

2. T/pole. On reaching the L field corner by a gate and the ODP signpost, you TR, (do not go thru the gate). Continue up the L field edge to reach a road via a stile. TL along road for 100m. TR to cross a stile into F8 and carry straight on up the R field edge, (a brook is on the R). After 300m you TR to cross over the brook via a wooden f/bridge, thru a k-gate and into F9. TL immediately and walk up L field edge. Cross a stile and wooden f/bridge and up an enclosed aggregate track to go thru a small metal gate onto a road.

 

3. Danyforest Farm. TR, walk along the road between buildings and then quite steeply up. Just before a cattle grid you TR and cross over a stile. Go down the L side of the tree clearing to go thru metal gate into F10. Keep to L edge of steeply sloping field, and after 75m, TL over a stile. Cross a stream in a minor ravine and go up and over another stile into F11. Bear slightly R as you go down this field. Cross a ditch and stile into F12. Cross this field, heading for the L of a farmhouse, and go thru a gate and across a stream, (a few paces further on you can reach a low marker post). TR and go thru gate, thru a farmyard and a gate and onto a lane.

 

5
 

1
 
4. Pant-y-fithel. TL, walk along the lane to reach the first bend. TR over a ditch and stile into F13. Cross the field and head for the gate on the skyline. Go thru gate and TR, walk along the R field edge/fence and cross the stile ahead. Go thru three strips of woodland, passing a marker post (R) at the start of the third strip. Leave the woods thru a gap and head to the R of a farm house (The Werns) to cross a stile/metal gate into F14. Go slightly L thru this field to cross a stile, a minor road, and another stile into F15. Go slightly R as you keep ahead down thru a scrubby field, which tapers thru trees. Beyond a gap, follow the hedge (L) down track thru copse. Now TR along R edge/hedge. A little further on (R) is a small white post with Mainline Pipelines Ltd., written on it.

2
 
 


5. White post. Mainline Pipelines Ltd. With railings over to the R, keep ahead to reach Login Brook. Go thru the lower gate (L), which is a small metal gate, and over a f/bridge. Now follow the brook, crossing it twice, below Hay cemetery to reach a road beyond lych-gate. TR, go past Recreation Ground to Hay Castle.

4
 

3
 

4
 

3
 


 

Walk 49 Old Radnor and Hanter Hill

Last walked in October 2018

 

Description. 7 km (4.3 miles). A fairly strenuous hilly walk along country lanes, across pasture and open hillside.

Start. Church in Old Radnor. Explorer Map 201 Grid 250591.

Direction from Whitecross roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Take the A438 towards Brecon. At 12.1 miles go straight on, heading towards Rhayader on the A44. At 12.6 miles carry straight on thru Eardisley, heading towards Rhayader. At 18.2 miles go straight across roundabout, head towards Rhayader. Go straight across the next roundabout, (18.5 miles), head for Rhayader. At 22.4 miles you TL for Old Radnor. At 23 miles TL and park-up opposite the church.

 

1. St Stephens Church, Old Radnor. The place-name Radnor refers to a red bank or hill side and its earliest authentic occurrence is in the Domesday Book. The parish church of Old Radnor is dedicated to St Stephen to whom there is no other authentic Welsh dedication. Outside the Lych-gate and with youre back to the church, TR and go down to the main road, (the Old School House is on the L). TL and walk down the main road for about km, to reach a road junction with a minor road going off to the L. Keep to the R and after 40m, TL over a stile/public footpath thats in a hedge. Go straight down an indistinguishable track that goes steeply down thru bracken, (a stream/small gully is on your R side), to cross a stile/gate into a F1. Continue down F1 to cross another stile/metal gate into F2. A cottage is on your R and you bear L to cross a brook via a wooden footbridge onto a road. TR and a little further on you reach the B4594 main road, (the Crossing Bungalow cottage is on your R). Cross the main road.

 

2. No Thru Road. Immediately cross over the stile on your R and into F3. TL and walk along the L edge, to cross a stile and footbridge into F4. Bear R across this field to reach the field corner and go thru the R hand gate into F5. Veer very slightly R as you cross this field, you will cross over an aggregate farm track, and then under telegraph wires to go thru a metal gate into F6. Straight across F6 to reach a metal gate, but dont cross it, TL to cross over a stile thats up on the L and go into F7. Go under telegraph lines as you go straight up the pasture/field, and go across the stile ahead. Scramble up bank under trees. Go very slightly R to reach a distinct stony farm track. TL then follow the track as it contours right, around Hanter Hill.

 

3. Track. Carry on up the track to reach a metal gate thats in front of Touchstone Cottage. Dont go thru the gate but TL. A little way up you go thru a gate and onto a track, TR (You are now going to do a 2 km, anticlockwise circle around most of Hanter Hill). Continue gently going up thru bracken and starting to go L with a telegraph line. Go past the markers that are on a telegraph pole(R), thats just before a farm house (Upper Hanter Farm). Keeping the farm on your R you continue around, with (now) a more clearly defined path. Continue up the path to reach a marker post on the brow of the hill where you TL.

1
 
4. Border Post. You are on county and country border here. Go straight ahead along a level path, going past a small marker post (ignore the path going up hill). The path starts going down hill then descends more steeply to meet fence on the R. Continue to drop down past unexpected small group of living huts, thru avenue of trees, and continue on down to reach a T junction below. TR, about 90m to reach a gate that goes into Lower Hunter Farm.

 

2
 
5. Lower Hanter Farm. Go thru the gate and TL, go thru another gate and along an enclosed hedged drive, called Hanter Lane. Continue along the lane to to reach the main B4594 road again, go straight across and along a minor road that bend to the R, (Crossing Bungalow cottage is on your L). When the road crosses over a brook you turn immediately L at the road junction. Go up the road to a junction and take the first L, (dont go up the no thru road thats in front of you). Continue on up the road and back to the island junction where you TR, continue on up back up to the church.

 

3
 

5
 

4
 
 

 


Walk 50 Kyrle-on-Wye

Last walked in October 2018

 

Description. 5.3 km (3.3 miles). An easy walk through suburban streets, woodland and along riverside paths. No stiles.

Start. Park in the car park by the river. Explorer Map 189 Grid 594239.

Direction from Belmont roundabout (Turn milometer to zero). Follow the A49 to Ross-on-Wye and at 12.8 miles you go straight across the roundabout for Ross-on-Wye, and a little further on, at 13.2 miles you TR into the car park.

 

1. Car Park. At the back of the car park, behind the skate-boarding area. Cross the footbridge, bear slightly L as you go up to the top of the steep hill, (path may be blocked by large fallen tree). Further up the path gets more distinct. Go up a number of steps to reach a T-junction, TR, you are now walking along a level path called The John Kyrle Walk, an iron railing fence is on your R. Go thru a k-gate into a field and continue along the R edge. Continue along the R edge of field 2. Near the field end the path bears off slightly R. Go thru a k-gate and down to descend some steps to reach a sign posted track junction in a hollow. TL. Continue on, to go thru a large k-gate and along an enclosed track that becomes a tarmac path, emerging by a house called The Cleeve. TL, walk along this lane to reach a road. Go straight across and continue along an enclosed path beside houses. Keep on this alleyway for about km as it crosses several residential streets, to reach a disused railway line thats more a dirt track, (just before reaching the path junction and on the R side is a field; houses are in front of you; a sign post saying: Please take your litter home, to deposit it here is an offence, penalty 100). TL, walk along the disused railway line, thats decorated with trees and occasional picnic tables, to reach the main B4234 road. Straight across a lighted road crossing and along an enclosed track, to reach Fernbank Road, (a car park is directly in front of you). TR and walk up Fernbank Road. Keep straight ahead, ignoring Woodmeadow Road (R). The road becomes a track, and rises steadily, entering Chase Wood.

 

2. Hill Farm. Bear L just before reaching the buildings of Hill farm, and go thru a metal gate and on a descending path, (Hill farm buildings are in front of you, very near to the top of the hill). After about 30m you take the left fork, to soon descend on a steep stepped path. Continue down and at the bottom you reach a T-junction. TR, and when you reach a k-gate you TL into a field and follow the R field edge down. Cross the disused railway again, and continue down an alleyway and a cul-de-sac to reach Merrivale Lane. TR, and immediately cross the road to walk up a very narrow alleyway thats beside an electricity sub station to reach another road, where you TR. Walk to the end of this road (The Avenue) that further up bends L. At the end of The Avenue TR, then immediately TL into Ashfield Crescent. Walk down to the cross roads and TR. At the next cross roads you go straight across, along along Redhill Road. Go past Ashfield Park Avenue (R) and the primary school entrance (R) to continue in the same direction along an enclosed path. On reaching iron railing by a way marker sign post, you TR along Buggy Route and John Kyrle Walk, (here you are not many paces from a point on the outward walk). Take the fenced path beside the school's playing fields, and continue on to reach the large churchyard. Continue in the same direction. Directly in front of you is a

1
 
tall brick wall and an iron gateway that you have to go thru. Getting to the gateway and

3
 
into the enclosure means going around, or straight thru a few graves. Have a good look around the enclosure, called The Prospect.

 

2
 
3. Gateway. Leave The Prospect by the gateway close to St Mary's Church. John Kyrle was buried in the chancel here. Leave the church grounds by the main entrance, (over in the bottom R hand corner) passing the fine, sandstone Rudhall's Almshouses (1575). TL into Church Street, then L at a T-junction and walk to the end of High Street. Cross the road and pass in front of the Man of Ross public house (R) (the plaque in front of it describes the 18th-century problems of muddy streets). Descend steps to reach the river beside the Hope and Anchor pub. TL. (Here the wheel for pumping water up to the town once stood.) Follow the riverbank, passing a number of benches and bearing L across the grass to go past a metal statue of two birds. Continue on to cross over the main road ahead, and into the car park.
